Ikea Index Indicates the Euro Is Not a Price Equalizer Yet

Author: Sylvers, Eric

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]23 Oct 2003: W.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/432549165?accountid=11752

Abstract: Following the lead of the Big Mac index, a comparison of the price of the McDonald's sandwich around the world that is published by The Economist, Mr. [Gabriel Thulin] constructed the IKEA index, which compares a basket of 26 Ikea products, including the Moppe storage chest, across 15 countries: 8 in the euro zone, 3 non-euro European Union countries, 2 European countries not in the union, the United States and Canada. While the United States is the cheapest Ikea country over all, some products in the survey are cheaper in Europe. For instance, though Finland is the most expensive country for the full basket of Ikea goods in Mr. Thulin's index, one item, the Sultan Skymning mattress, is 42 percent less expensive there than in the United States. This indicates that high local costs -- like taxes, wages or advertising -- are not the only reason for the price differentials, because if that were the case, the cost of all products would be higher in a higher-cost market. The Ikea index, created by Gabriel Thulin, a Swedish statician, tracks the cost of a basket of 26 Ikea products across 15 countries. According to the index, the United States is the cheapest Ikea country over all, but some products in the index are cheaper elsewhere.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Ikea+Index+Indicates+the+Euro+Is+Not+a+Price+Equalizer+Yet&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=2003-10-23&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=W.1&amp;au=Sylvers%2C+Eric&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: That a storage chest sold by the Swedish home furnishing giant Ikea costs 59 percent more in Austria than in the United States is perhaps not surprising, considering the countries are on different continents and have different currencies, taxes, inflation, labor laws and interest rates.
But that the same Moppe storage chest is 39 percent more expensive in Austria than in Germany, countries that share a border and a currency, is an indication that the introduction of the euro has yet to succeed in one of its basic missions: to create a single, transparent market where identical goods cost the same everywhere.
Just how elusive this goal has been was highlighted by some recently published research by Gabriel Thulin, a Swedish statistician.
Mr. Thulin, whose fellow Swedes voted overwhelmingly last month against membership in the European single currency, works for the financial communications consulting firm of Hallvarsson & Halvarsson. He conducted his research on his own time.
Following the lead of the Big Mac index, a comparison of the price of the McDonald's sandwich around the world that is published by The Economist, Mr. Thulin constructed the IKEA index, which compares a basket of 26 Ikea products, including the Moppe storage chest, across 15 countries: 8 in the euro zone, 3 non-euro European Union countries, 2 European countries not in the union, the United States and Canada.
According to the report, consumers in the United States pay the least for Ikea products, and those in Finland, a euro country, pay the most. Among euro countries in the survey, people in the Netherlands pay the least for the full hypothetical basket -- 17 percent less than in Finland.
The cost and time involved in buying a bookcase in Germany and transporting it to Belgium will more than cancel out any potential savings for most consumers. So Ikea can still charge Belgians 33 percent more than Germans for the Billy bookcase, even though both are euro countries and there is a German Ikea store near the Belgian border.
Ikea, like many multinational companies, is also able to charge different prices in different countries because the company is adept at exploiting local market conditions, experts say. For example, here in Italy, the fourth-most-expensive Ikea country in the index, the local competition tends to be from smaller high-end furniture stores rather than large retailers as in the United States.
''At the end of the day it is a question of supply and demand, and prices will be higher where there is more demand,'' said Lorenzo Codogno, co-head of European economic research at the Bank of America in London. ''There has been some convergence thanks to the euro, but not as much as initially expected.''
Price convergence is not the only aspect of monetary integration that did not develop as quickly as expected, Mr. Codogno said. Trade between countries in the euro zone has grown since the introduction of the common currency, he said, but not by as much as policy makers had expected.
Ikea also capitalizes on its brand name by charging more where the brand is strongest, Mr. Thulin said.
According to Marianne Barner, Ikea's communications manager, ''Each country sets its own prices, which depend on competition, wages and taxes.''
''Our philosophy is to have the lowest price on comparable products in every country, compared with our competitors,'' she added.
While the United States is the cheapest Ikea country over all, some products in the survey are cheaper in Europe. For instance, though Finland is the most expensive country for the full basket of Ikea goods in Mr. Thulin's index, one item, the Sultan Skymning mattress, is 42 percent less expensive there than in the United States. This indicates that high local costs -- like taxes, wages or advertising -- are not the only reason for the price differentials, because if that were the case, the cost of all products would be higher in a higher-cost market.
''In due time something will have to give and there will be a trend toward having similar prices in all euro countries, but many factors that make price discrimination possible are destined to remain,'' said Fabrizio Onida, an economics professor at Bocconi University in Milan. ''As long as there are differences between national markets, then price discrimination is possible.''
If the differences in pricing eventually disappear, it will be as much because of the Internet as from the introduction of the euro, because just as a Californian can go online to compare the price of a golf club sold in Nevada and New York, an Italian can see if a new stereo would cost less in Germany or France.
In fact, while the privately owned Ikea printed 131 million copies of the current catalog in 23 languages, it was the company's decision to put an increasing number of prices online that allowed Mr. Thulin to develop his index.
''The idea for the index was born five years ago, but when I tried to develop it back then it was impossible to get all the catalogs,'' Mr. Thulin said in a phone conversation from his office in Stockholm. ''Prices weren't on the Internet and I couldn't get the catalogs sent to me from some countries.''
He added that ''eventually it became inevitable to have prices online. '' Ikea has 186 stores in 31 countries, but the company will send online purchases to only 9 countries. And customers cannot buy from one nation's Ikea Web site and have the product sent to a different country, or receive a catalog for one country at an address in another.
When calculating his index, Mr. Thulin used Oct. 14 exchange rates. But the catalog's prices, guaranteed until July 2004, were set when the dollar was stronger relative to the euro, and the dollar's recent fall in value played a role in making the United States the cheapest Ikea country in the survey.
Mr. Thulin said he chose Ikea for his study because, among other things, the store has many products that are exactly the same in every market; the goods are not perishable so they can, in theory, be easily transported from one country to another; and the goods for all countries are all made in the same factories so production costs are the same.
He also said he was planning to repeat the index next year, so it may be possible to see whether, at least according to some home furnishings, the single currency is leading to an alignment of prices in euro land.
Chart ''How Much for that Skymning?''
The Ikea index, created by Gabriel Thulin, a Swedish statician, tracks the cost of a basket of 26 Ikea products across 15 countries. According to the index, the United States is the cheapest Ikea country over all, but some products in the index are cheaper elsewhere.
Difference in cost of Ikea index's products, compared with their cost in the U.S.
Finland: +33%
Denmark: +26
Norway: +23

Swelling Trade Gap Worries Some Experts and Policy Makers

Author: Stevenson, Richard W

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]10 June 2000: C.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/431468974?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''With the current account deficit at a record high, it's silly to say it can't possibly be of any importance,'' said John Lipsky, chief economist at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. ''But the current account deficit is only a sign of other developments of more direct importance, in this case the significant and sustained growth differential between the U.S. and its trading partners.'' The current account deficit, which amounted to 3.7 percent of total economic output for all of last year and 4.2 percent in the fourth quarter, is projected by most economists to rise again this year. It is already by far the largest among the big industrialized countries. The last time trade was a big issue for the American economy, during the mid-and late-1980's, the current account deficit peaked at 3.4 percent of gross domestic product. It could recede quickly if Japan bounces back and Europe's recovery continues, especially if the Federal Reserve also succeeds in slowing the growth of economic demand in the United States. And in any case, foreign companies and investors have been happy so far to finance the deficit by recycling the dollars they earn through trade back into the United States, where the technology-fueled boom has offered high rates of return. Indeed, some economists see the current account deficit more as an indicator of a healthy surge of foreign investment into the United States than as a sign of a sickening trade imbalance.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Swelling+Trade+Gap+Worries+Some+Experts+and+Policy+Makers&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=2000-06-10&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.1&amp;au=Stevenson%2C+Richard+W&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: If this bionic economy has a soft underbelly, it may be trade.
As Americans gorge on imported cars, electronics, clothing and a long list of other goods from abroad, the nation's trade deficit has swollen to record proportions, leaving economists and policy makers increasingly troubled.
The trade deficit for March, the most recent month for which data is available, was $30.2 billion, 56 percent higher than in March 1999. Imports for March totaled $117.4 billion, up 21.9 percent from the corresponding month a year earlier.
Broader measures of the nation's international transactions have also deteriorated. The current account deficit -- which includes foreigners' profits on investments in the United States and Americans' investments in other countries as well as trade in goods and services -- reached $338.9 billion in 1999, up 53.6 percent from 1998.
The current account deficit, which amounted to 3.7 percent of total economic output for all of last year and 4.2 percent in the fourth quarter, is projected by most economists to rise again this year. It is already by far the largest among the big industrialized countries. The last time trade was a big issue for the American economy, during the mid-and late-1980's, the current account deficit peaked at 3.4 percent of gross domestic product.
The main reason for the surge is clear. For the last few years, the American economy has been booming, while those of its major trading partners have been weak. As a result, the thirst for imported goods has grown even as the market for American exports has stagnated.
What is less clear is whether the trade imbalance will prove to be a substantial problem.
It could recede quickly if Japan bounces back and Europe's recovery continues, especially if the Federal Reserve also succeeds in slowing the growth of economic demand in the United States. And in any case, foreign companies and investors have been happy so far to finance the deficit by recycling the dollars they earn through trade back into the United States, where the technology-fueled boom has offered high rates of return. Indeed, some economists see the current account deficit more as an indicator of a healthy surge of foreign investment into the United States than as a sign of a sickening trade imbalance.
But there is a worst-case set of possibilities out there that haunts many economists: foreign investors lose faith in the American economy's relative advantages, investment from abroad dries up, the dollar plunges, inflation jumps and the Fed is forced to respond by driving interest rates sharply higher, endangering the long expansion.
With the American economy strong and unemployment low, the growing trade deficit so far has not produced the same protectionist pressures that previous surges in the trade gap have provoked. Yes, anxiety about competition from low- wage workers abroad was at the heart of labor's failed campaign against normalizing trade relations with China. But the trade gap itself has merited hardly a mention so far in the presidential campaign.
And in contrast to the 1980's, when the United States was plagued by a simultaneous rise in its trade and budget deficits, the federal government is currently running a large budget surplus, providing a substantial cushion for the economy.
Still, the situation has policy makers in Washington concerned. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has repeatedly warned that the rapid growth in imports compared with a much more modest increase in exports cannot go on forever. And it has been on the mind of Lawrence H. Summers, the Treasury secretary.
''When a large external imbalance reflects a period of strong growth relative to the rest of the world, and relatively high investment in our productive potential, as it does in the United States today,'' Mr. Summers said in a speech last month, ''that imbalance is unlikely to pose an immediate threat to our economic well-being.''
But, Mr. Summers added, ''a large and growing current account deficit is not something that can be sustained indefinitely.''
''It can also give rise to protectionist pressures,'' he said, ''and it distorts the pattern of domestic economic activity.''
The Clinton administration has shown no inclination to push down the dollar to promote exports by making American goods cheaper when purchased in foreign currencies. Indeed, calls for a weaker dollar from exporters and industries that compete with imports have been relatively muted compared with the 1980's, when auto companies, steel makers, farmers and other howled about their inability to compete with their foreign counterparts.
Instead, the administration has stressed the importance of increasing national savings by paying down the federal debt -- a step that could help reduce reliance on foreign capital -- and has pressed Japan and Europe to overhaul their economies to create more demand for goods from the United States.
''We'd see a more balanced situation if Europe and Japan were growing faster,'' said Ralph C. Bryant, an economist at the Brookings Institution, the research organization. ''But you wouldn't want to put the brakes hard on the U.S. economy just to get the trade and current account deficits smaller, and you don't want to put up new fences at the border. That would be far more costly than would make sense.''
But as the current account deficit has grown, there has been an increasing debate inside and outside of government about the degree of the threat posed by the trade gap.
One camp views the deficit as essentially benign.
In this view, the trade gap will narrow as the American economy slows. In any case, imports so far in this economic cycle have served as a safety valve for the supercharged American economy, helping to keep inflation under control at a time when domestic producers cannot keep up with demand.
Moreover, by purchasing so much from abroad, the United States has helped many other countries rebound from the financial crisis that swept around the world in 1998. And by investing the dollars they earn back into the United States, foreign companies, governments and investors are adding to the pool of capital that American companies have used to become more productive and competitive.
''With the current account deficit at a record high, it's silly to say it can't possibly be of any importance,'' said John Lipsky, chief economist at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. ''But the current account deficit is only a sign of other developments of more direct importance, in this case the significant and sustained growth differential between the U.S. and its trading partners.''
At the same time, Mr. Lipsky added, ''The emergence of what is sometimes called the new economy has attracted foreign investors.''
In the sense that the current account deficit is just the reverse side of a flood of foreign direct investment in the United States, ''it represents something good about the U.S., not something bad,'' Mr. Lipsky said.
But there is a more dire view of the trade imbalance.
In this view, further expansion in the current account deficit cannot be sustained. The deficit is at a level that leaves the economy vulnerable to a sharp fall in the value of the dollar, a jump in inflation and interest rates, and a slowdown in growth or even a recession.
''You cannot continually run a growing current account deficit without ultimately facing a very sharp fall in your exchange rate, which in the current circumstances of the U.S. economy could be a killer,'' said C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
The chain of events that Mr. Bergsten worries about would involve a steep drop in the dollar, a resulting surge in inflation and a determined response by the Federal Reserve to restore stability by pushing interest rates up sharply.
The current account gap, Mr. Bergsten said, is ''the single biggest threat to the current expansion of the economy.''
Among policy makers in Washington, there is less a sense of crisis than a gnawing concern about the long-term trends in trade. Officials at the Fed cite a theory first developed in the 1960's by Hendrik S. Houthakker, an economist at Harvard University. He found that growth in imports to the United States relative to income growth runs at roughly twice the rate it does in the rest of the world. That finding has been confirmed repeatedly over the years.
In other words, if the American economy is expanding at anything close to the rest of the world's growth rate, the American trade deficit will increase.
That was not a big problem during a lot of the post-World War II period, when much of the rest of the world experienced higher growth rates than the United States. But should growth in the United States remain as strong as it has been the last few years, and should the rest of the world not rebound, it could push the trade deficit to previously unimagined levels.
In political terms, there is also the possibility of the trade deficit with a particular country or set of countries creating protectionist pressures in Washington. Organized labor is likely to keep a close eye on trade with China, which is about to join the World Trade Organization. And any renewed effort by Japan to export its way out of its doldrums could bring a return of the trade tensions that characterized its relationship with the United States for years.
But among consumers, who have enjoyed lower prices and improved quality in many products as a result of global competition, there are few signs of worry.
''If Americans are going to want me to buy their car, then they need to offer me a good product,'' said Diane Spivey of Clermont, Ga., who recently bought a Volkswagen Passat. ''I don't look on it as your economy and my economy. The world is a pretty small place these days.''
Photograph Toyota cars and sport utility vehicles await transfer from a lot at the port of Long Beach, Calif. (Associated Press)(pg. C4); (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times); (Justin Lane for The New York Times)(pg. C1)
Graph ''Trade Threat?''
Even as the American economy has advanced strongly, the growing gap in the current account balance -- which measures trade in goods and services and net earnings from overseas assets -- has sparked a debate among economists.

Greenspan Cranes His Neck Over Stock and Home Prices

Author: Uchitelle, Louis

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]07 Nov 1999: 3, 4:5.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/431294264?accountid=11752

Abstract: THE Federal Reserve, as everyone knows, is always trying to keep inflation down without sacrificing too much economic growth. The public debate that accompanies this process focuses on the behavior of the real economy. The booming stock market has stretched that focus, of course. But even so, the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, is expressing greater concern lately about the dangers of a high stock market and rising home prices. Far more than in the 1970's or 1980's, the wealth embedded in stocks and home ownership generates spending, and thus raises the odds that consumer demand will exceed the nation's supply of labor, materials and services. Inflation would then accelerate. Mr. Greenspan and his fellow policymakers have argued that case in the past. And now the chairman has underscored his concern in three speeches since mid-October. Mr. Greenspan himself has probably not decided yet. The Fed tries to control inflation, or the threat of it, by raising interest rates. But the target is inflation itself, Fed officials insist, not any one of the contributors to it, like stock prices. In his recent speeches, Mr. Greenspan has not changed that message. But his remarks have heightened the profile of stock prices and home prices as potential contributors to inflation.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Greenspan+Cranes+His+Neck+Over+Stock+and+Home+Prices&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1999-11-07&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=3.4&amp;au=Uchitelle%2C+Louis&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: THE Federal Reserve, as everyone knows, is always trying to keep inflation down without sacrificing too much economic growth. The public debate that accompanies this process focuses on the behavior of the real economy. The booming stock market has stretched that focus, of course. But even so, the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, is expressing greater concern lately about the dangers of a high stock market and rising home prices.
Far more than in the 1970's or 1980's, the wealth embedded in stocks and home ownership generates spending, and thus raises the odds that consumer demand will exceed the nation's supply of labor, materials and services. Inflation would then accelerate. Mr. Greenspan and his fellow policymakers have argued that case in the past. And now the chairman has underscored his concern in three speeches since mid-October.
''The frequency with which he makes this point means that his not-terribly-successful campaign to talk down the stock market continues,'' said Alan Blinder, a Princeton economist and a former Fed vice chairman. ''He has not given up.''
And if his jawboning doesn't work? If stock prices fail to decline from present levels, or even resume their climb? Would he want to raise rates at the next Fed policy meeting, on Nov. 16, fulfilling an expectation that unsettles the stock market?
Mr. Greenspan himself has probably not decided yet. The Fed tries to control inflation, or the threat of it, by raising interest rates. But the target is inflation itself, Fed officials insist, not any one of the contributors to it, like stock prices. In his recent speeches, Mr. Greenspan has not changed that message. But his remarks have heightened the profile of stock prices and home prices as potential contributors to inflation.
The economy once drove the stock market; now the opposite is true. Raising rates is one way to discourage stock buying and nullify the market's inflationary potential.
''There is no question that the stock market has become an important component'' of our discussions, said Edward M. Kelley Jr., a Fed governor.
Mr. Greenspan's recent speeches outline these discussions, or at least his decisive contribution to them. New technologies, he argues, have made corporate management more efficient, and have raised the level of labor productivity, or the amount of goods, services and revenue that an average worker produces in an hour. All this adds to Corporate America's capacity to increase supply and thus satisfy rising demand.
Rising stock prices reflect this improvement, Mr. Greenspan says. They also reflect a view that stocks are less risky an investment than in the past and therefore worth more. Both factors, however, may be unsustainable. Stock prices, in short, may be unjustifiably high, in bubble territory.
A financial crisis could restore the old risk factor. A stock that now seems worth $10 may, a few months from now, be fairly valued at only $8 to a more nervous investor. The ''equity premium'' will have risen, or, as Mr. Greenspan puts it, ''The key question is whether the recent decline in equity premiums is permanent or temporary.'' If the improvement is temporary, then stocks will eventually plunge in some crisis, damaging the economy and also creditors who have loaned tens of millions of dollars for the purchase of stocks.
THE productivity-growth trend presents another danger. While it certainly is at a higher level than in the recent past, that level cannot keep on rising. When the inevitable plateau comes, Mr. Greenspan warned in one of his speeches, then consumer demand, still driven by market wealth, ''can accelerate so much that total demand could rise above even the productivity-augmented'' greater supply of goods and services. As demand exceeds supply, shortages develop and prices rise.
A speech on Tuesday added home prices to the mix, but in a subordinate role to stocks. For every dollar of stock market gain, consumer outlays are lifted by 3 to 4 cents, Mr. Greenspan said, while higher home prices yield 5 cents for each dollar of gain. But only ''about a sixth of the so-called wealth effect -- that is, the impact of capital gains on consumer spending -- stems from equity extracted from the sale of existing homes,'' he said, or the refinancing of mortgages. The rest comes from the huge, booming stock market.
The distinction adds to the stock market's importance in the Fed's deliberations. ''Greenspan is not targeting the stock market,'' said William C. Dudley, a chief economist at Goldman, Sachs, ''but he is saying the market is an increasingly important factor in setting interest rates.''
Illustration Graph tracks the total value of United States stocks, plotted weekly, from 1996 through last Thursday. (Source: Datastream)

Why Brazil Did What It Did and What Options Are Left

Author: Nasar, Sylvia

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]16 Jan 1999: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/431118253?accountid=11752

Abstract: After yesterday's surprise move, the real tumbled another 8 percent, but stock markets from Toronto to Santiago surged in apparent relief that Brazil would no longer waste billions of dollars propping up the currency. For a day, at least, Brazil did not threaten to spin out of control, taking the rest of Latin America down with it. Whatever Brazil's decision, it will reverberate throughout the world. The impact will be felt most heavily in Argentina, Brazil's biggest trading partner and, like Brazil, a country that has only recently recovered from years of hyperinflation. Should the Brazilian currency be allowed to trade freely, it is unclear how the Argentine peso could keep its dollar peg when most of its exports and imports will be priced in a currency that can fluctuate wildly in value. Currency volatility is the last thing Latin American economies need, as they enter a period of slowing growth and rising unemployment. A. Brazil is the biggest economy in Latin America, about twice as big as Mexico's. While it buys just 3 percent of United States exports, its economic health is vital to a region that accounts for one-fifth of United States exports. But Brazil looms even larger in the minds of international investors for the simple reason that it was one of the last large countries to go down the road of free trade, privatization and hard money. If that approach fails in Brazil, the ideal of a unified global economy knit together by trade and investment is threatened. That is one reason that the I.M.F. cobbled together one of the biggest rescue packages in history, and one factor in the Federal Reserve's decision to lower interest rates in the United States three times last fall.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Why+Brazil+Did+What+It+Did+and+What+Options+Are+Left&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1999-01-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.1&amp;au=Nasar%2C+Sylvia&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/00702097&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: On Wednesday, Brazil drew a line in the sand in front of its embattled currency, the real. Yesterday, it erased that line, sending the sand scattering, as it allowed the real to trade freely against other currencies.
That abrupt reversal came after investors doubted the Brazilian Government's ability to defend the currency following the resignation of Brazil's hard-money central bank chief, Gustavo Franco, and the 9 percent devaluation in the real's value on Wednesday.
After yesterday's surprise move, the real tumbled another 8 percent, but stock markets from Toronto to Santiago surged in apparent relief that Brazil would no longer waste billions of dollars propping up the currency. For a day, at least, Brazil did not threaten to spin out of control, taking the rest of Latin America down with it.
But throwing in the towel on its old policy of pegging the real to the dollar is only a stopgap. Now the Brazilian Government and international finance policy makers must wrestle with what comes next.
Brazil has the same choices that other countries with tottering currencies have had. It can continue allowing the currency to trade freely, or it can try to set a new trading range and maintain that range by buying reais in the foreign exchange market.
Or it can follow the more radical example of its neighbor Argentina, and set up a currency board, which would peg the real to the dollar at a fixed rate of exchange.
Such options are likely to be discussed this weekend, when Brazil's Finance Minister and central bank chief meet in Washington with officials from the International Monetary Fund and the United States Treasury Department.
Whatever Brazil's decision, it will reverberate throughout the world. The impact will be felt most heavily in Argentina, Brazil's biggest trading partner and, like Brazil, a country that has only recently recovered from years of hyperinflation. Should the Brazilian currency be allowed to trade freely, it is unclear how the Argentine peso could keep its dollar peg when most of its exports and imports will be priced in a currency that can fluctuate wildly in value. Currency volatility is the last thing Latin American economies need, as they enter a period of slowing growth and rising unemployment.
For American investors and businesses, the Brazilian eruption is the latest chapter in a contagious currency crisis that started in Thailand in July 1997 and spread as far as Russia last summer. If the turmoil leads to a prolonged downturn on Wall Street or cuts heavily into American exports, the robust economy in the United States could turn anemic. Here is a brief guide to what is at stake and what might happen next:
Q. Why is Brazil so important?
A. Brazil is the biggest economy in Latin America, about twice as big as Mexico's. While it buys just 3 percent of United States exports, its economic health is vital to a region that accounts for one-fifth of United States exports. But Brazil looms even larger in the minds of international investors for the simple reason that it was one of the last large countries to go down the road of free trade, privatization and hard money. If that approach fails in Brazil, the ideal of a unified global economy knit together by trade and investment is threatened. That is one reason that the I.M.F. cobbled together one of the biggest rescue packages in history, and one factor in the Federal Reserve's decision to lower interest rates in the United States three times last fall.
Q. What's a devaluation?
A. Both devaluation and depreciation refer to a decline in the value of a currency. The distinction is this: when a government has declared that it is pegging its currency to another and will defend it by any means necessary but lets it fall anyway, that is a devaluation; when the falling currency is that of a country that allows the market to set its value and its value falls, that is a depreciation. One involves a broken promise; the other doesn't.
When Brazil announced its devaluation, overseas investors saw it as a sign that the Government was caving in to political pressure from unions and big business to put its anti-inflation strategy on the back burner and to fight unemployment instead.
Q. Why did Brazilians make the choices they made?
A. Brazil pegged its currency to the dollar in the first place as a way of convincing investors at home and abroad that it would no longer tolerate the chronic inflation that has plagued it for decades. When the so-called Real Plan was enacted in 1994 inflation was running at more than 3,000 percent. Like Russia and scores of other developing countries, Brazil had long financed huge Government commitments mainly by printing money rather than collecting taxes.
But fixing the exchange rate and getting inflation down initially proved easier than scaling back Government commitments. Brazil has a social security system that allows workers to retire after 20 years, often with pensions higher than the pay workers were earning on the job. What is more, it takes the equivalent of a constitutional amendment to lay off public workers.
At the same time, Brazil's economy has been stagnating, unemployment is at near-record levels, exports are falling and the trade deficit is way up. Tight money was not only hurting exporters by keeping the currency strong but was keeping interest rates high (around 30 percent). Remember the early 1980's, when the United States had a big budget deficit and the Federal Reserve's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, declared war on inflation? Interest rates were sky high, the dollar was extremely strong and American manufacturers were screaming murder.
Now, Brazil's industrialists and unions are the ones who are screaming. They want a weaker currency to stimulate exports by making their goods more competitive on the world market -- even at the cost of more inflation, lately running less than 3 percent a year. Newspapers in Sao Paulo, the industrial center of Brazil, had been calling for Mr. Franco's head for months.
Q. What did Brazil hope to accomplish?
A. The devaluation was supposed to buy time. If investors had gone along, bond prices might have stabilized or gone up, interest rates might have leveled off or fallen, and exports might have received a lift. But the strategy fell apart almost as soon as it was introduced for the same reason it failed in Thailand, Russia and elsewhere. Investors at home and abroad simply were not convinced that the first devaluation would be the last. They saw it as a sign of more to come. Any investor holding a currency she thought was going to be worth less tomorrow would sell immediately.
With foreigners and, increasingly, domestic investors taking large positions against the real, Brazil faced a nasty choice. It could try to stem the tide by using its hard-currency reserves. Unlike Mexico in 1994 or Russia in 1998, Brazil had roughly $40 billion in reserves as well as a $30 billion credit line from the I.M.F. Or it could let the currency fall to whatever value the market placed on it, making no promises to exchange it for dollars at a particular rate or to defend it if it fell below a certain level. It chose the latter.
Q. What are Brazil's options now?
A. A jet flying at 40,000 feet can fall 10,000 feet and still avoid disaster if the pilot manages to regain control of the aircraft. Everything depends on Brazil's regaining control of its economic policy. For the moment, at least, it has. But to resolve its currency crisis, Brazilian policy makers must choose among several long-term strategies.
Brazil could simply announce a new fixed rate -- or more accurately a new range of rates -- tied to the dollar to replace the old range of rates. As with the old regime, the new currency system could be devalued by a specified, tiny amount every few days, but no more than that. The central bank would promise to use monetary policy and foreign exchange reserves to support the value of the currency in the foreign exchange market. But this would work only if Brazil could keep investors convinced that it was going to keep its promises more faithfully in the future.
With good reason, the Finance Minister of Mexico noted at the height of his country's currency crisis that only the most extreme exchange rate regimes -- in other words, those that essentially remove any discretion -- truly rule out the threat of speculative attacks. A permanent floating rate, the system that the United States and most other rich countries have embraced, is one such extreme. The other, chosen by Argentina and a number of former Soviet republics, is to adopt a system that virtually rules out devaluation by putting foreign exchange policy in the hands of a currency board.
Letting your currency fluctuate with supply and demand has the definite advantage of allowing the currency to adjust to shocks like, say, a collapse in commodity prices. Further, a country does not risk speculative attack because it has not promised to exchange r its currency for a specified amount of dollars. Alas, Brazil is not a good candidate for a permanent floating exchange rate scheme.
For starters, where Brazil goes, Argentina must follow. Argentina, Brazil's biggest trading partner and a fellow recovering inflation addict, would be forced to abandon its fixed rate currency strategy -- a strategy that seems to be working well and one that lots of investors are counting on.
The Brazilian Government's huge domestic debt, around $270 billion, also poses an obstacle. Because the Government could not persuade investors to lend it money except by providing very short maturities and promising to index much of the debt to dollars, every time the exchange rate fell, the Government's obligations would jump. A big drop in the currency would mean instant default, just as it did in Russia last summer or in Mexico in 1995.
Another option for Brazil, a currency board, is the most radical, but has some strong supporters both within Brazil's central bank and in the I.M.F. It is a desperate measure that involves giving up all pretense of controlling one's own currency and in effect replacing the central bank with a board that includes some foreigners. On the other hand, Argentina, which has such a board, has been able to borrow on world markets at the modest rate of 8 percent this week.
Under a currency board, the supply of reais in circulation would have to be fully backed by dollars and convertible, on demand, at a fixed rate of exchange. In effect, Brazil would be handing over control of its money supply -- which would fluctuate with the amount of dollars available -- to Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Currency boards have long been considered an appropriate strategy for small economies that rely heavily on international trade. They do not eliminate the need to solve the fiscal imbalance, but simply take away the option of printing more money to finance shortfalls -- yet another hard choice for Brazil.
Photograph A floating currency made traders frantic and stock prices jump yesterday at the stock exchange in Sao Paulo, Brazil. (Associated Press)
Graph ''Much Resting on Broad Shoulders''
The health of Brail's economy, the largest in Latin America, is vital to the health of its neighbors. Recent developments have raised fears of a return to the volatility of the ealy 90's. Graphs shows Brazil's inflation, gross domestic product and unemployment, from 1993 through 1998. (Source: Santander Investment; Havel Analytics)

Right Time for an Inflation Hedge?

Author: Schultz, Abby

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]05 Apr 1998: 42.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/430964600?accountid=11752

Abstract: Since the securities were first offered, a little more than a year ago, only three retail funds specializing in them have been introduced. Together, the funds have just $26.6 million in assets, some of which is in inflation-indexed securities issued by other countries. According to Daniel S. Bernstein, director of research at Bridgewater Associates in Wilton, Conn., when the inflation-indexed securities were issued last year, inflation would have had to be 3.3 percent or more a year for the notes to earn a higher total return than traditional Treasury notes. Today, he said, inflation would have to be just 2 percent or more a year for them to do so. If inflation does strike harder, these securities will offer better protection than traditional inflation hedges like commodities, precious metals, collectibles or real estate, said John B. Brynjolfsson, manager of the $7.7 million Pimco Real Return Bond fund, another of the funds specializing in inflation-indexed securities. That is because inflation-indexed notes not only guarantee that the principal of the securities will maintain today's purchasing power, by rising with inflation, but they also offer interest income, now about 3.7 percent for 10-year issues.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Right+Time+for+an+Inflation+Hedge%3F&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1998-04-05&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=3.2%3A42&amp;au=Schultz%2C+Abby&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/00665621&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   YAWN.
That is how investors have greeted the small crop of new mutual funds investing in inflation-indexed Government securities.
Since the securities were first offered, a little more than a year ago, only three retail funds specializing in them have been introduced. Together, the funds have just $26.6 million in assets, some of which is in inflation-indexed securities issued by other countries.
But now, precisely because inflation is so low, the cost of buying protection against its rise is about the cheapest it has been since the Government began issuing the securities in 1997. And that could make this the right choice at the right time for people seeking a conservative fixed-income investment.
''I can't say what inflation will be in 10 years, but inflation protection costs less now than it did,'' said David W. Schroeder, manager of one of the funds, the $5.2 million American Century-Benham Inflation-Adjusted Treasury fund.
According to Daniel S. Bernstein, director of research at Bridgewater Associates in Wilton, Conn., when the inflation-indexed securities were issued last year, inflation would have had to be 3.3 percent or more a year for the notes to earn a higher total return than traditional Treasury notes. Today, he said, inflation would have to be just 2 percent or more a year for them to do so.
''From a year ago to today, it just makes inflation-indexed bonds more attractive,'' he said.
If inflation does strike harder, these securities will offer better protection than traditional inflation hedges like commodities, precious metals, collectibles or real estate, said John B. Brynjolfsson, manager of the $7.7 million Pimco Real Return Bond fund, another of the funds specializing in inflation-indexed securities. That is because inflation-indexed notes not only guarantee that the principal of the securities will maintain today's purchasing power, by rising with inflation, but they also offer interest income, now about 3.7 percent for 10-year issues.
''That essentially means until the year 2008 you can lock in a 3.7 percent real return above inflation,'' Mr. Brynjolfsson said.
INSTITUTIONAL investors worldwide have bought most of the $39 billion in these securities that the United States Treasury has issued so far. Retail investors have been more reticent, and for several reasons.
The first, of course, is low inflation -- it is about 1.4 percent a year now, down from 3 percent at the time of the first, $7 billion offering of 10-year notes last year, and it shows no signs of picking up. Selling inflation-indexed bonds now is like ''selling ice in the winter,'' said Michael Shamosh, chief fixed-income strategist at Gabriele Hueglin & Cashman, a New York brokerage firm.
Investors have also avoided the securities because of a tax on the so-called phantom income that accrues in the notes but is not passed on to investors until the security matures. Unlike regular Treasury notes and bonds, which have a fixed principal and a fixed coupon, the principal in an inflation-indexed bond is adjusted continually for inflation, as determined by monthly changes in the Consumer Price Index. If inflation were to rise 10 percent in a year, the principal of a $1,000 bond would adjust to $1,100 and holders would be taxed on the $100 gain as ordinary income, even though they had not pocketed the increase.
But it is most likely that individual investors have shied from inflation-linked funds because their returns have paled in comparison with those of other fixed-income funds, let alone the soaring returns of stock funds.
The average total return of the three retail funds -- the third is Brown Brothers Harriman's 59 Wall Street Inflation-Indexed Securities -- was 3.7 percent for the 12 months ended March 31, according to Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher in Chicago. That is less than the 3.9 percent return of a Lehman Brothers index of the Treasury's inflation-indexed securities for the same period, and well below the 10.5 percent return of intermediate-term Government bond funds or the 7.4 percent return of short-term Government bond funds, Morningstar said.
The meager results reflect the fact that ''real yields,'' or interest rates minus inflation, have risen and prices have fallen in the last 12 months. At the same time, yields on traditional bonds have fallen and prices have risen because inflation has continued to drop. The first 10-year inflation-indexed Treasury note, for instance, was priced at 101.05 percent of par value when American Century opened its fund on Feb. 10 last year; on April 1 this year, the note's price had fallen to 97 percent of par value -- although the loss was not quite as great as it seems because the par value had grown in line with inflation. The fund, meanwhile, returned 3.4 percent for the year ended March 31.
While this short-term record is lackluster, long-term investors should not be discouraged, said Mr. Schroeder, the fund's manager. ''Folks should know that, over the short term, performance will be impacted by changes in real yields, while long-term performance will be impacted more by changes in inflation,'' he said.
That is a strong reason to take a look at these securities now, when the inflation protection is relatively cheap. The traditional 10-year Treasury note yields about 5.5 percent, while 10-year inflation-linked notes yield about 3.7 percent -- a difference of just under two percentage points. If inflation were 2 percent a year or higher for the next 10 years, the return on the inflation-indexed security would be higher than the return on the traditional 10-year note, Mr. Schroeder said.
Mr. Brynjolfsson's fund, Pimco Real Return Bond, is the best-performing of the three retail offerings. It had a total return of just over 4 percent for the 12 months ended March 31, according to Morningstar.
The manager uses several strategies to outperform the Lehman Brothers index of inflation-linked securities, including the buying of foreign inflation-indexed bonds -- other big issuers include Canada, New Zealand and Australia -- and securities issued by corporations and agencies in the United States.
The $13.7 million 59 Wall Street Inflation-Indexed Securities fund also invests overseas and in corporate issues. Only American Century sticks solely with United States Government issues.
All these funds will have the opportunity to lock in inflation protection over a longer period on Wednesday, when the Treasury Department auctions $8 billion in 30-year inflation-indexed securities.
Chart ''Low Inflation, Low Returns''
The three funds investing in inflation-indexed securities have fared poorly, reflecting the fact that inflation has plunged. The Consumer Price Index is up only 1.4 percent for the 12 months ended February. Chart shows year-to-date and 12-month returns. (Source: Morningstar Inc.)

Strong Economy, No Inflation in Fed Survey

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]19 Mar 1998: 4.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/430945229?accountid=11752

Abstract: Despite a decline in export sales, the economy in all regions of the United States remains strong -- yet inflation seems ''eerily calm,'' the Federal Reserve said today. ''Industrial activity is on the rise in most parts of the country, with orders and production up,'' it said in its ''beige book'' survey of regional economic conditions. ''Most districts, though, are experiencing a decline in exports to Asia.'' Before the Asian crisis emerged in full force this fall, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and his colleagues had been warning that labor shortages in the United States could eventually lead to increased inflation.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Strong+Economy%2C+No+Inflation+in+Fed+Survey&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1998-03-19&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.4&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/00662669&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Despite a decline in export sales, the economy in all regions of the United States remains strong -- yet inflation seems ''eerily calm,'' the Federal Reserve said today.
''Industrial activity is on the rise in most parts of the country, with orders and production up,'' it said in its ''beige book'' survey of regional economic conditions. ''Most districts, though, are experiencing a decline in exports to Asia.''
American consumers continue to spend strongly on most items except cars, the report said. It was based on information collected through March 9.
''Retail sales are generally up in most districts, exceeding retailers' expectations in many of them,'' it said. ''Auto sales, however, are generally down, although demand for pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles remains high.''
Before the Asian crisis emerged in full force this fall, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and his colleagues had been warning that labor shortages in the United States could eventually lead to increased inflation.
Since then, they have been counting on the impact of the Asian turmoil to dampen growth and ease labor shortages in the United States. So far, though, that does not seem to be happening, the beige book said.
''The demand for labor remains strong, with nearly all districts reporting shortages of workers at the entry level and in certain skilled categories,'' it said. ''Widespread labor market tightness appears to have increased the degree of wage pressures.''
Despite that, ''pressures on product prices remain eerily calm,'' it said, adding, ''Domestic competition, productivity gains and the Asian situation help to constrain production costs.''
The beige book, named after the color of its cover, was prepared for the March 31 meeting of the Fed's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee. The panel sets short-term interest rates through changes in the overnight rate on loans between banks.
A year ago, it nudged the rate up by a quarter percentage point, to 5.5 percent, citing excess demand in the economy. Since then, it has left the rate untouched, watching nervously to see if strong growth and scarce labor would produce increased inflation.
In other developments, the beige book said that mild weather in many parts of the country, the product of the El Nino current in the Pacific Ocean, had created ''unseasonably hardy'' housing markets and healthy commercial real estate markets.
But conditions on the nation's farms are mixed, it said.
''An abundance of precipitation has harmed crop prospects and delayed field preparation activities,'' it said.
Illustration Chart/Map: ''Economy Tempers in Places, but Remains Vigorous''
A roundup of regional economic conditions in recent months for the Federal Reserve's 12 districts, according to the beige book report issued by the Fed yesterday.
Minneapolis -- Growth continued at a steady pace led by the construction, manufacturing and retail industries.
Chicago -- Growth increased modestly, led by gains in consumer spending and housing. Manufacturing operated near capacity and new orders showed no signs of slowing.
Cleveland -- The economy continued to grow at a moderate pace. Labor markets were strong and price pressures light. Real estate flourished.
Boston -- Retail sales picked up while manufacturing had mixed results. Many companies reported hiring difficulties.
New York -- The economy grew briskly in the first two months of 1998 with better-than-expected retail sales. The housing market retained momentum.
Philadelphia Manufacturers saw continued strength in shipments and orders, while retail sales were rising. Car sales eased.
Richmond Retail sales rose above last year's level. Manufacturers said shipments and orders rebounded sharply and real estate picked up.
Atlanta -- The Southeastern economy continued to grow at a moderate pace. Retail sales met expectations; home sales rose as mortgage rates declined.
St. Louis -- The economy continued to generate business growth with few signs of rising prices. Retail sales met expectations while manufacturers experienced strong sales and orders.
Kansas City Labor markets remained tight, with intensifying wage increases. Retail prices held steady, sales dipped slightly and construction slowed.
Dallas -- Economic activity expanded at about the same pace or a little slower as before. Manufacturing prices were flat to down while the service and construction industries saw higher prices.
San Francisco -- The economy continued its vigorous growth although with signs of moderation in certain areas, including retail sales. The effects of Asian economic turmoil were evident in several sectors.
Map shows area of regions.
(Source: Bloomberg News)
