Second-Guessing The Economic Doctor

Author: DAVID E. SANGER and RICHARD W. STEVENSON

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]01 Feb 1998: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/430931803?accountid=11752

Abstract: Seven thousand miles away, on Capitol Hill, the I.M.F. is also a target of growing criticism -- but for exactly the opposite reasons. Here, the call is for far more American intrusiveness in I.M.F. programs, and a far smaller American contribution to solving Asia-style crises. At the extreme ends of both parties, there are calls to kill off the I.M.F. altogether. While that is hardly likely, Congress has the opportunity in the next few months to send a message that will be heard in markets around the globe. It will be debating the question of whether the United States should fulfill its commitment to provide $18 billion in additional contributions to the fund so that it can handle new outbreaks of the kind of the economic contagion that is still whipping through Asia. If Congress balks, few doubt that the rest of the world will, too. Rarely in its 52-year history has the fund been under such concerted attack from so many quarters. Liberals complain that its actions in Asia chiefly benefit the likes of Citicorp and J. P. Morgan, to say nothing of Japan's biggest banks, often at the expense of workers -- both abroad and in the United States -- whose jobs are threatened by its policies. Conservatives say that the emergency help for South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand interferes with free markets, and that they undercut American jobs by encouraging the afflicted countries to export their way out of trouble. Many economists say the I.M.F.'s prescriptions are only making things worse, though because they are economists, they disagree forcefully on what prescriptions would make things better. CAUGHT in the uncomfortable middle is Mr. Rubin. For three years, since the United States stepped in to rescue Mexico, he has been struggling to get nations around the world to prepare for future crises by bolstering their contributions to the I.M.F. and agreeing that international consortiums, not the United States, serve as the lender of last resort. In Asia, the I.M.F. has taken the lead -- with plenty of behind-the-scenes coaching from Mr. Rubin and his deputy, Lawrence H. Summers -- although the United States has committed several billion dollars in backup financing, called a ''second line of defense,'' to South Korea and Indonesia. (None has been disbursed.)

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Second-Guessing+The+Economic+Doctor&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1998-02-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=3.1&amp;au=DAVID+E.+SANGER+and+RICHARD+W.+STEVENSON&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/04902777&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: ALL over Southeast Asia, people are complaining that a cabal of heartless bureaucrats at an institution many have come to loathe -- the International Monetary Fund -- is worsening their economic misery. Here in Washington, the I.M.F. isn't a lot more popular, but for very different reasons.
Almost every night in Thailand, a stream of television commentators chafe at the humiliation of witnessing their country's leaders negotiate every element of national economic policy -- from interest rates to budget deficits -- with economists who work largely in secrecy out of the I.M.F.'s offices off Pennsylvania Avenue here.
Outside a McDonald's in Jakarta, Indonesia, last month, a clutch of young professionals argued that the fund, which had just forced President Suharto to terminate government subsidies that kept the price of fuel and food low, is simply a tool of an American, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin.
''There's a rumor that this is all a game started by America,'' said a 27-year-old advertising executive named Doli, repeating a version of an oft-heard conspiracy theory in which Washington secretly plotted to destroy Asian competitors. ''America should not have let the rupiah keep dropping,'' he said, dismissing suggestions that Indonesia might bear some responsibility for the 80 percent plunge in its currency.
Indeed, throughout Asia these days, people talk about the I.M.F. as if it were a branch of the Clinton Administration, and as if it -- with Washington's connivance -- aspires to run the region today the way Gen. Douglas MacArthur ran it a half-century ago. Around Asia, one hears variants of the same lament: The fund is imposing too many conditions, often the wrong ones, and providing too little real financial support in Asia's moment of need.
Seven thousand miles away, on Capitol Hill, the I.M.F. is also a target of growing criticism -- but for exactly the opposite reasons. Here, the call is for far more American intrusiveness in I.M.F. programs, and a far smaller American contribution to solving Asia-style crises. At the extreme ends of both parties, there are calls to kill off the I.M.F. altogether. While that is hardly likely, Congress has the opportunity in the next few months to send a message that will be heard in markets around the globe. It will be debating the question of whether the United States should fulfill its commitment to provide $18 billion in additional contributions to the fund so that it can handle new outbreaks of the kind of the economic contagion that is still whipping through Asia. If Congress balks, few doubt that the rest of the world will, too.
Rarely in its 52-year history has the fund been under such concerted attack from so many quarters. Liberals complain that its actions in Asia chiefly benefit the likes of Citicorp and J. P. Morgan, to say nothing of Japan's biggest banks, often at the expense of workers -- both abroad and in the United States -- whose jobs are threatened by its policies. Conservatives say that the emergency help for South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand interferes with free markets, and that they undercut American jobs by encouraging the afflicted countries to export their way out of trouble. Many economists say the I.M.F.'s prescriptions are only making things worse, though because they are economists, they disagree forcefully on what prescriptions would make things better.
CAUGHT in the uncomfortable middle is Mr. Rubin. For three years, since the United States stepped in to rescue Mexico, he has been struggling to get nations around the world to prepare for future crises by bolstering their contributions to the I.M.F. and agreeing that international consortiums, not the United States, serve as the lender of last resort. In Asia, the I.M.F. has taken the lead -- with plenty of behind-the-scenes coaching from Mr. Rubin and his deputy, Lawrence H. Summers -- although the United States has committed several billion dollars in backup financing, called a ''second line of defense,'' to South Korea and Indonesia. (None has been disbursed.)
The backup financing is chiefly an exercise in market psychology, intended to reassure investors that the United States is willing to play a big role in stabilizing markets. But that same act of symbolism only incenses many American lawmakers, who ask why taxpayers should bail out faraway nations. The Administration fears that the more it supplements the I.M.F., the greater the risk that Congress will pull the plug on contributions altogether.
The public case for deeper American participation was made by President Clinton in his State of the Union address on Tuesday, when he argued that a prosperous Asia would help American exporters. ''These countries are our customers,'' he said, ''and if Asia sinks into recession, they won't be able to buy the goods we'd like to sell them.''
The private case, one of Mr. Clinton's top aides noted recently, will have to be made by Mr. Rubin. ''Basically, it comes down to this,'' the aide said. ''Bob is going to have to say: 'If the Asian meltdown comes to Wall Street, do you want the blame?' ''
On the streets of Bangkok, Jakarta and Seoul, the I.M.F. era looks pretty grim -- and the popular sentiment, right or wrong, is that the I.M.F. is making it grimmer.
The search for a scapegoat is understandable: Economic activity has ground to a halt. The cranes towering over half-completed buildings don't move, and tens of thousands of workers who headed back to their hometowns last week for the end of Ramadan and the Chinese New Year have been told not to return. The Thai stock market, which had a market capitalization of $133 billion in 1993, the height of the Southeast Asian boom, is now worth about $22 billion. When it comes to buying overseas goods, Indonesia's currency buys 20 percent of what it did a few months ago. The crisis, in short, has hit the streets.
''Things are a lot worse than people expected, and they could get worse yet,'' said Teera Phutrakul, who runs an investment firm along one of Bangkok's busiest commercial streets. ''That's because of a lot of bad decisions made here in Thailand. But now, along comes the I.M.F. to impose some discipline, and it's very, very politically convenient. The Government can say, 'We have no choice -- Michel Camdessus made us do this,' '' he said, referring to the I.M.F.'s managing director.
In Thailand, though, Mr. Camdessus comes off a lot better than President Clinton and Mr. Rubin, whom many in the country's leadership contend were indifferent to Thailand's call for help last summer and only got serious about the Asian crisis when it began to sweep through the continent and around the world. ''The Thais felt quite hurt that they saw no signs of support from the U.S.,'' Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said after returning from a recent tour through Asia. ''It left some wounds'' -- including some suggestions from Thai officials that they may not be so accommodating the next time the United States needs to move its military forces through Thai air bases.
The I.M.F. program in Thailand is typical of the institution's approach in Asia. Weak financial institutions are being closed down. Interest rates have been pushed up sharply, so that investors have an incentive to buy the local currency. To comply with the I.M.F.'s mandate against budget deficits, the Thais have cut their spending by roughly 30 percent, killing many social programs and public-works projects.
Financial firms are being required to use internationally accepted accounting procedures and to disclose far more data than they ever have before. The new rules are intended to expose the kind of under-the-table deals that have long fueled Asian economies while enriching the politically connected. Real regulation is being imposed, including bank supervisors who are supposed to make sure that money is being lent to sound projects, rather than to cronies.
But this new regime of openness in business, and a war on crony capitalism, requires a huge cultural change in the way Asia has always operated -- a change that is hard to impose from half a world away. And it carries with it a lecturing tone that is already stirring up a popular and political backlash.
The United States, of course, is celebrating any changes that move the Asian economies closer to the American model of capitalism and further from the Japanese model. But for ordinary people, the benefits of such a shift are difficult to see through the swirl of fleeing foreign money and plummeting currencies.
So it is hardly surprising that many Asians are seizing on criticisms of the I.M.F. Jeffrey D. Sachs, the Harvard economist who is a longtime critic of the fund, attracts more Asian reporters than a Hong Kong pop star when he shows up at conferences to make his case that the policies are only making matters worse. High interest rates and rampant bank closures, he says, have simply frozen economic activity. ''Even healthy companies cannot get letters of credit to make the exports they need to generate revenue,'' he says. ''Does this make sense?''
OTHER critics, however, say the problem is the I.M.F.'s inability to handle the huge overhang of private, dollar-denominated debt that local companies cannot pay back. In South Korea, this problem is being addressed through an accord with foreign banks that resulted in a tentative deal last week, but there has been no equivalent process in Thailand and Indonesia.
Still other I.M.F. critics, including George Soros, the international financier, say the real problem is the absence of global regulation of global markets. In their view, the international economic and financial order created in the aftermath of World War II, at the Bretton Woods Conference in New Hampshire, needs to be overhauled. That system, of which the I.M.F. and its sister institution, the World Bank, are central elements, worked well for most of the last half-century. But today, these people argue, it has been overwhelmed by 24-hour trading and needs to be updated so it can keep up with the terrifying speed at which money flows in and out of countries.
All of this has left the I.M.F. reeling. It has adjusted its programs slightly to quiet some of the criticism. But its defenders, including Mr. Rubin, say that while Asia is burning, no one should be reorganizing the fire department.
I.M.F. officials, meanwhile, are starting to answer their critics. ''None of this will be easy,'' Stanley Fischer, the No. 2 official in the I.M.F., said in a speech last week. The currency depreciations, Mr. Fischer said, have not ''occurred by I.M.F. design'' and clearly have gone too far. But ''without I.M.F. support as a part of an international effort to stabilize these economies, it is likely that these currencies would have lost still more of their value,'' he added.
Turning to Congressional critics -- whom he was careful not to name -- he said, ''Simply letting the chips fall where they may would surely cause more bankruptcies, larger layoffs, deeper recession and even deeper depreciations than would otherwise be necessary to put these economies back on a sound footing.''
THE I.M.F.'s troubles in Washington start with the conservative right in Congress, which has long mixed a suspicion of Wall Street and big banks with a streak of isolationism. To some on the right, the problem with the I.M.F. is not just the way it has dealt with the Asian crisis, but the institution's very existence.
Republican critics, like Senator Lauch Faircloth of North Carolina and Representative Ron Paul of Texas. say I.M.F. bailouts have proved ineffective and, worse, have distorted the workings of the free market.
They are a form of welfare for the rich, these skeptics contend, insulating banks and investors from losses they deserve to suffer for misjudging risks in overseas markets. Furthermore, the critics say, the rescue efforts sow the seeds of future disasters by reassuring lenders and investors that even if they repeat their mistakes, the fund will always be there to cushion the blow.
By this line of reasoning, the much-hailed Mexican bailout was actually a failure, encouraging investors to roll the dice again in Asia.
''The I.M.F. is welfare for the very rich investors, and serves only to keep afloat reckless political institutions which have policies that destroy their own economies,'' said Mr. Paul, once the Libertarian Party's candidate for President and perhaps the most vocal Congressional critic of the fund.
''The big bankers and investors quite correctly support the notion of less government and economic liberty when we talk about their profits, but when losses occur they are quick to call for the Government to socialize the burden,'' he said on Wednesday, introducing a bill calling for the United States to leave the fund.
While the Clinton Administration views Mr. Paul as the enemy, in private, some officials concede half his point. It is virtually impossible to salvage an ailing economy without also benefiting the banks and investors that poured cash into it. Before the Asian storm clouds turned into a typhoon, Mr. Rubin often raised alarms about the ''moral hazard'' of encouraging reckless investments.
EVEN now, Mr. Rubin takes pains to distance himself from saving big banks and burned investors. ''I would not give one nickel to help any creditor or investor,'' he said recently, noting that the Asian crisis had hurt profits at J. P. Morgan, Chase and Citibank. But in the next breath, Mr. Rubin noted that the issue is ''complex'' because ''any action to force investors and creditors involuntarily to take losses'' would cause all investors to pull their money out of a country -- just at the moment that it needed fresh capital.
Conservatives, however, are hardly the I.M.F.'s only critics in Washington. Some liberals argue that the agency does not demand enough in the way of political and social changes in return for its aid. They want to make the assistance contingent on improvements in human rights, working conditions and environmental standards.
''The American people are going to be very skeptical of any plan to bail out international speculators and repressive regimes that simply encourages them to repeat the same pattern of abuse and excess all over again,'' said Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the Democratic whip. ''We cannot support a bailout that imposes an economic stranglehold on working people, tramples democratic rights, ignores the underlying causes of instability and then asks the American taxpayer to foot the bill.''
The I.M.F. is increasingly sensitive to the criticism that it is props up dictators. In Indonesia, it has forced the breakup of monopolies and an end to Government aid to business ventures run by President Suharto's family and friends. But it has steered clear of making political demands -- that Mr. Suharto, for example, lift the repression in East Timor, which was seized two decades ago. And it has not uttered a word about the delicate question of political succession, even though that is the central issue affecting Indonesia's economic future.
''We can attack crony capitalism,'' a senior I.M.F. official said. ''But it's a stretch to make an economic case for an end to human-rights abuses, beyond urging 'good governance.' ''
The Administration hopes to steer clear of these arguments in its effort to persuade Congress to approve $18 billion in new American contributions to the I.M.F. But members of both parties say the price it might have to pay is a severe restriction on its freedom to use the Exchange Stabilization Fund, a $40 billion American kitty for dealing with international currency crises. Now, the Administration can lend the money at its discretion -- just as it did to Mexico in 1995. That prompted Congress to impose a restriction on the use of the exchange stabilization fund that expired just as the Asian crisis broke. Legislation introduced last week would reimpose such a restriction, requiring Congressional approval for dipping into the fund for more than $250 million.
IF Congress worries that I.M.F. bailouts are out of control, Asia worries that Washington secretly runs the I.M.F. And despite Washington's denials, the Asian concerns are not exactly baseless.
The United States has the strongest voice within the fund, an 18 percent voting share, three times that of any other country and enough to wield a veto over major decisions by the fund's board. Moreover, it is often able to persuade other big industrial countries to vote with it, giving Washington a 40 percent voting bloc. Early in the Asian crisis, a senior Administration official boasted this fall, one phone call from Mr. Summers changed key conditions on the Thai bailout.
Still, American power is not absolute. The United States pushed the I.M.F. to provide additional financial aid to Russia two years ago to help prop up the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin, but the agency's management refused, saying it had lent Russia all that its rules allowed.
Other countries have carved out their own spheres of influence. France considers development of French-speaking nations its prerogative, and Britain has championed an initiative to reduce the debt loads of poor nations.
But when a big crisis arises, the United States usually takes charge, as the fund's handling of the most recent crisis in Indonesia illustrated.
Last month, the United States and the fund worked together to send Mr. Camdessus, Mr. Summers, Defense Secretary Cohen and Mr. Fischer, the I.M.F. official, to Jakarta to pound home a crucial message to President Suharto. In a series of meetings over two days, they pressed upon the Indonesian leader the need to agree to tough terms for emergency loans -- and to implement them promptly.
I.M.F. officials said it was no accident that they all carried the same message to Jakarta -- a message that had also been backed up by phone calls from President Clinton to the Indonesian leader.
''We agreed there had to be a major effort,'' said a senior Fund official. ''We had to get to Suharto, and we had to get him to realize the seriousness of the situation.''
That message was put together in the White House at a meeting presided over by President Clinton, with Mr. Rubin, Mr. Summers and a range of State Department and National Security officials in attendance. Soon Mr. Suharto received calls from leaders around the world, politely telling him he had no choice.
''A remarkable coincidence of timing,'' a senior American official deadpanned during Mr. Summers' trip to Jakarta.
Photograph President Suharto of Indonesia assented to I.M.F. demands under the gaze of Michel Camdessus, the fund's director general. A bank worker in Seoul, South Korea, protested austerity measures imposed as a condition of an I.M.F. loan. (Photograph by Naum Kazhdan/The New York Times)(pg. 1);Treasury Secretary Rubin finds himself caught in the middle of a debate on the International Monetary Fund. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. 9)
Chart ''Many Ailments, One Prescription''
The International Monetary Fund, typically working in concert with Washington and other Western capitals, has prescribed the tough medicine of austerity as the cure for one sick economy after another. Now the Fund is under attack on many fronts: in Congress, by economists, and on the streets of Asia.
CASE
Mexico, 1994-95
SYMPTOMS
Collapse of the peso amid rampant imports, dwindling foreign reserves and high inflation in an overheated economy.
PRESCRIPTION
Austerity, including a clampdown on credit and wages, in exchange for loans and guarantees led by the United States and backed up by the I.M.F. and other institutions.
CONSEQUENCES
Widespread bankruptcies. Massive job losses. Increased income inequality, poverty and social strife. But the peso stabilized relatively quickly, and within months Mexico regained the trust of foreign lenders.
CASE
Indonesia, 1997-98
SYMPTOMS
Collapse of the rupiah amid an explosion of foreign debt and a sharp stock market slide.
PRESCRIPTION
Austerity and economic restructuring -- including an end to special deals for businesses linked to President Suharto's family, the forced break-up of monopolies, the closure of failing banks and tight limits on government spending -- in exchange for billions in aid from the I.M.F., the United States and other industrial nations.
CONSEQUENCES
Remain to be seen. Analysts expect inflation, unemployment and bankruptcies to skyrocket. The military stands ready to put down social unrest as political opposition to Mr. Suharto begins to emerge. The I.M.F. projects a stagnant economy this year, but renewed growth in 1999. Meanwhile, the rupiah continues to fall.
CASE
South Korea, 1997-98
SYMPTOMS
Collapse of the won and the stock market under staggering foreign debt in a sheltered economy built on crony capitalism.
PRESCRIPTION
Austerity and economic restructuring -- including deep cuts in public spending, tight credit, markets thrown open to imports and foreign investment and the removal of government props for bloated conglomerates -- in return for the biggest I.M.F.-led bailout ever.
CONSEQUENCES
Remain to be seen. Growth is screeching to a halt, and analysts expect a boom in unemployment and bankruptcies. Social unrest remains possible, but the stock market has rebounded and the won has steadied. (pg. 1)
''A World of Troubles''
International Monetary Fund programs take a variety of forms, depending on the depths of a country's economic woes and its ability to repay loans. But hardly a corner of the world has gone without I.M.F. assistance in the last five years. World Map shows countries where the International Monetary Fund has intervened in the last five years.
Program A
Stand-by Arrangements
Cover periods of one to two years and focus on macro-economic policies, like monetary and exchange rates, though they can promote restructuring.
Program B
Extended Fund Facilities
Programs of three to four years intended to overcome balance-of-payments difficulties and restructure economies.
Programs C or D
Structural and Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facilities
Low-cost loan programs to support economic restructuring of low-income countries.

Calmer Trading Overseas Helps Bolster U.S. Stocks

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]14 Nov 1997: 3.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/430874843?accountid=11752

Abstract: Stocks ended higher yesterday, bolstered in part by calmer markets overseas and by expectations that economic slowdowns in Asia and Latin America would keep United States interest rates low. Such expectations overcame, at least for a day, concerns on how the overseas turmoil will hurt profits of American companies. Investors confidence was heightened in part by comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. He told the House Banking Committee that the problems in Asia and other regions would not threaten prosperity in the United States and could even help hold down inflation. United States stocks were also helped by gains in Hong Kong and Brazilian stocks. The Hang Seng index of 33 stocks, the Hong Kong market's main stock index, rose 112.87 points, or 1.17 percent, at 9,720.78. Brazil's 51-share Bovespa index, which fell 10.2 percent on Wednesday, closed up 250.02 points, or 3.20 percent, at 8,07203 yesterday.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Calmer+Trading+Overseas+Helps+Bolster+U.S.+Stocks&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1997-11-14&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.3&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/04797342&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Stocks ended higher yesterday, bolstered in part by calmer markets overseas and by expectations that economic slowdowns in Asia and Latin America would keep United States interest rates low.
Such expectations overcame, at least for a day, concerns on how the overseas turmoil will hurt profits of American companies. Investors confidence was heightened in part by comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. He told the House Banking Committee that the problems in Asia and other regions would not threaten prosperity in the United States and could even help hold down inflation.
The turmoil in Asia and Latin America ''ultimately will be beneficial to the U.S. economy, our stock market and also our bond market,'' said Robert Bloom, chief investment officer at the Friends Vilas-Fischer Trust Company in New York, which manages $2.4 billion.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 86.44, or 1.2 percent, to 7,487.76. The Dow began the day with an 87-point gain, tumbled to a 51-point loss and bounced back up again in a furious rally late in the session.
Other market indexes were higher. The Nasdaq composite index rose 16.02 points, or 1 percent, to 1,557.74, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 10.70, or 1.2 percent, to 916.66.
United States stocks were also helped by gains in Hong Kong and Brazilian stocks. The Hang Seng index of 33 stocks, the Hong Kong market's main stock index, rose 112.87 points, or 1.17 percent, at 9,720.78. Brazil's 51-share Bovespa index, which fell 10.2 percent on Wednesday, closed up 250.02 points, or 3.20 percent, at 8,07203 yesterday.
''There's a seesaw going on here,'' said Andrew M. Brooks, vice president in charge of equity trading at T. Rowe Price Associates. ''The Asian situation continues to be troublesome and of concern, and we're struggling to find some direction.''
In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 leading issues recovered from sharp losses to end down just 6.9 points yesterday.
Early today, however, Japanese stocks were lower. At the midday recess in trading, the Nikkei was down 206.29 points, or 1.34 percent, at 15,220.98.
Among individual issues, AT&T rose 2, to 48 3/4, for the biggest percentage rise in the Dow industrials, The Sprint Corporation rose 3 1/4, to 57 1/2, and the BellSouth Corporation gained 11/16, to 49 5/8. Worldcom Inc.'s acquisition of the MCI Communications Corporation puts pressure on big telephone companies to merge or form alliances, analysts say.
Computer-related shares, which plunged on Wednesday on concern that Southeast Asia's financial woes would hurt their profits, rebounded yesterday. Texas Instruments Inc. rose 3 3/4, to 97 1/2, after losing 12 1/2 points yesterday. The Dell Computer Corporation rose 5 1/16, to 77 1/16.
Auto and chemical shares sank. General Motors fell 9/16, to 62 1/4, and The DuPont Company lost 2, to 57.
Oil service stocks fell on concerns that sales cannot increase because drilling rigs are booked solid and that price increases could delay some drilling by oil companies in the future, analysts said. ''That's worrisome in the environment of very robust valuations,'' said Byron Dunn, an analyst with SBC Warburg Dillon Read Inc.
The Cooper Cameron Corporation lost 3 5/8, to 70; Tidewater Inc. fell 3 3/8, to 62, and the Halliburton Company fell 2 13/16, to 53 1/2.
ON THE WEB
The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

America Has a Labor Shortage. Europe Has the Answer.

Author: Walter, Norbert

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]04 Oct 1997: 15.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/430848498?accountid=11752

Abstract: One month, the financial markets are bent over backward because the United States economy is supposedly growing too fast. Interest rates are pushed higher. The next month, fresh statistics cool the inflation fever, and the markets calm down. Leaving aside the debate about exactly how low the American unemployment rate can fall without fueling inflation, the reality remains that finding talented workers in the American labor market is becoming more difficult. These buffers, though, may not suffice to keep inflation at bay over the long haul. Assuming the American economy keeps growing above 2.75 percent a year, labor will get very scarce -- unless the United States makes more creative use of international labor mobility.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=America+Has+a+Labor+Shortage.+Europe+Has+the+Answer.%3A+%5BOp-Ed%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1997-10-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.15&amp;au=Walter%2C+Norbert&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/00639441&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: AuthorAffiliation Norbert Walter is chief economist of the Deutsche Bank Group.
One month, the financial markets are bent over backward because the United States economy is supposedly growing too fast. Interest rates are pushed higher. The next month, fresh statistics cool the inflation fever, and the markets calm down.
But what would really turn America's ''inflation tango'' into something more dangerous would be a broad rise in labor costs. This possibility, which would increase inflationary pressures, seems the main concern of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Leaving aside the debate about exactly how low the American unemployment rate can fall without fueling inflation, the reality remains that finding talented workers in the American labor market is becoming more difficult.
For a while longer, employers will still be able to draw workers from the ranks of those who until recently were not actively seeking work. Productivity increases have also eased some pressure.
These buffers, though, may not suffice to keep inflation at bay over the long haul. Assuming the American economy keeps growing above 2.75 percent a year, labor will get very scarce -- unless the United States makes more creative use of international labor mobility.
If it can take advantage of this safety valve, I am convinced the United States could have an unemployment rate below 4 percent and still avoid inflation. If the United States doesn't have enough workers, and if low-wage countries like India and China can't provide enough of the highly skilled labor that America needs, then Europe may have the cure.
Though growth forecasts are turning cautiously positive, few analysts predict any meaningful reduction in European unemployment. Europe's pressing need (finding jobs for its people) happily coincides with America's pressing need (finding people for its jobs).
The skills of Europe's work force are particularly well suited to fill this need. Increasingly, the labor shortages threatening the American economy are in the ''new collar'' occupations -- technically skilled jobs in the manufacturing and service industries that require specialized training, but usually not a college degree.
Europe's labor resources are quite rich in these areas, a result of the huge investment in job training made by the continent's corporate and public sectors. This expertise -- in computer-assisted design and manufacturing, for example -- is an ideal fit for the current needs of American business.
Suppose a grand bargain could be arranged whereby many of Europe's unemployed packed up and moved to greener pastures in the United States?
American immigration laws already have provisions that allow the recruitment of skilled labor abroad, but the administration of the law has been uneven at best. Perhaps all that is needed is for the rules to be interpreted more broadly -- or for American employers to make more creative use of them.
If this strategy works, then American corporations would gain a vast pool of qualified workers, many of whom already speak excellent English. The American people would win as inflation fears caused by low unemployment gradually disappeared, pushing down interest rates for consumer loans and home mortgages. The Europeans would finally find solid jobs, and the European governments could slash unproductive social spending.
Is this a pipe dream? If French or German workers won't move just a few miles to find a job in Europe, how can migration across the Atlantic be a credible option? And can the Europeans live without the long vacations and other fringe benefits they have long felt entitled to?
Yes, many Europeans who were raised in an era of generous benefits tend to be immobile. But there is anecdotal evidence that the situation is changing, particularly among the young and better educated.
A German newspaper, the Neue Presse, has reported a sharp rise in the number of Germans inquiring at the American Consulate in Frankfurt about the possibility of immigrating to the United States.
Is it even conceivable that American officials would accept a major increase in immigration? With jobs plentiful and American voters increasingly optimistic about their personal financial prospects, perhaps the needs of the American economy will prevail over politics.
And at this moment, Europe's and America's labor needs are a perfect match.
Illustration Drawing (Scott Stowell)

INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Chile Fears a Delay in Trade-Bloc Entry

Author: Sims, Calvin

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]05 May 1995: D.4.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/430183384?accountid=11752

Abstract: Eduardo Aninat, Chile's Finance Minister, said in an interview that he saw no obstacles in Mexico, Canada, or Chile that would deter the quick approval of Chile as a trade-bloc member that the United States promised at a meeting of Western Hemisphere leaders in Miami last December. "We believe that the United States and Nafta partners are on track with respect to Chile's accession to Nafta," said Charlene Barshefsky, a United States deputy trade representative, in a telephone interview from Washington. "We have met not only as Nafta partners, but working relations are very good and the commitment on the part of all the countries involved is very firm." Claudio S. Garcia, president of Chile's American Chamber of Commerce, which represents United States companies with business interests here, said that the Mexican crisis had "splashed a bucket of cold water on the issue of Chile and Nafta" but that his organization was continuing to lobby in Congress, seeking to shift the tide.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=INTERNATIONAL+BUSINESS%3B+Chile+Fears+a+Delay+in+Trade-Bloc+Entry&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1995-05-05&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.4&amp;au=Sims%2C+Calvin&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: With negotiations over Chile's admission to the North American free-trade bloc scheduled to begin next month, trade officials and business leaders here are worried that the United States, engulfed in domestic concerns, could delay its promise to bring Chile into the pact.
Eduardo Aninat, Chile's Finance Minister, said in an interview that he saw no obstacles in Mexico, Canada, or Chile that would deter the quick approval of Chile as a trade-bloc member that the United States promised at a meeting of Western Hemisphere leaders in Miami last December.
But Mr. Aninat said that despite bipartisan support in the United States Congress for expanding the North American Free Trade Agreement -- or Nafta, as it is widely known -- Chile's entry may be slowed by fallout from the Mexican devaluation crisis and by gridlock over an ever more complex domestic policy agenda.
"It is a bit dangerous for me to give this opinion, but there is a possibility that they will say, because we are so occupied with upcoming elections and a new Congressional political agenda, 'Chile, come back another time,' " Mr. Aninat remarked.
He said that while such a delay would not be a disaster for Chile, "it will be very disappointing and a very sad point in U.S.-Chilean relations."
Chilean membership in the North American trade group has been anticipated ever since the Bush Administration said in 1992 that Chile, with the most advanced economy in Latin America, would be the next country admitted to the trade group. The Clinton Administration has reiterated that commitment.
The Administration has cited Chile as a test case for economic integration of the Western Hemisphere, in which almost all the countries in the region would reach a trading accord over the next decade.
In the last decade, Chile has become the model for economic change in Latin America as it privatized most state enterprises, slashed tariffs, liberalized investment markets, and opened its doors to foreign capital. The result has been 11 years of uninterrupted growth, with an average annual rate of 7 percent for the last eight years. Inflation slowed to 8.9 percent last year from 15 percent in 1992; unemployment is currently 5 percent, and Chile has one of the highest savings and investment rates in the region.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said recently that bipartisan support for a free-trade pact with Chile remained strong, and that the Administration was committed to obtaining so-called fast-track authority from Congress this year.
Under such an arrangement, used in gaining approval of both the North American trade accord and the more recent world trade pact, the Administration negotiates the details of an agreement and the House and Senate vote only to approve or block the pact without amendments.
"We believe that the United States and Nafta partners are on track with respect to Chile's accession to Nafta," said Charlene Barshefsky, a United States deputy trade representative, in a telephone interview from Washington. "We have met not only as Nafta partners, but working relations are very good and the commitment on the part of all the countries involved is very firm."
American trade officials said that trade and finance ministers from the United States, Canada, Mexico and Chile are to begin formal negotiations on June 7 and that if all goes well, Congress is expected to vote on an agreement providing for Chilean membership near the end of the year. But expectations that Chile would gain rapid approval have been fading since late December, when Mexico devalued the peso, causing chaos in financial and credit markets in Latin America and sending investors running for cover.
Critics of the North American trade pact in the United States, like Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, have called on the Administration to abandon plans to expand the North American agreement to all of Latin America unless regional labor and environmental rules are included. Republicans dismiss any such rules as unacceptable, under pressure from American businesses that fear the same rules may be applied to them in the United States. The controversy has cast uncertainty on the expansion of free trade through the Western Hemisphere.
And the Republican-controlled House has been occupied of late with legislation promised in the Contract With America, and is next expected to emphasize conservatives' agenda items that were not addressed earlier in the year.
Clinton Administration officials say they are uncertain where the Senate stands on expanding the North American trade alliance.
Claudio S. Garcia, president of Chile's American Chamber of Commerce, which represents United States companies with business interests here, said that the Mexican crisis had "splashed a bucket of cold water on the issue of Chile and Nafta" but that his organization was continuing to lobby in Congress, seeking to shift the tide.
"It appears today that there will be difficulty getting fast-track Nafta through the United States Congress," said Gert Rosenthal, executive secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean, which is based here. "If Nafta is delayed for Chile, the biggest casualty will be the spirit of the Miami conference, this concept of Western hemispheric integration that the United States has been promoting."
Mr. Rosenthal said that delaying Chile's entry into the North American trade group would send the wrong message to other Latin Americans and to Asian countries, which the United States is trying to persuade to open markets and broadly liberalize their economies.
Chile, a relatively small nation of 13.5 million people in an area of less than 300,000 square miles, is rich in natural resources like copper, timber, fish, iron ore, nitrates and precious metals. Last year, it had exports of $11.64 billion, of which $2.01 billion went to the United States -- mainly fruit, vegetables and forestry products. Chile imported $11.36 billion last year, of which $2.64 billion came from the United States, including vehicles, electronic equipment and other consumer goods.
Mr. Aninat said he was still optimistic that fast-track authority was possible, and he foresees an approval process in which Congress passes a fast-track measure by September, formal negotiations begin in October, and a draft of a new agreement is sent to Congress in January or February.
Yet some Congressional trade experts consider such a timetable very optimistic, and think that fast-track authority may not be completed until shortly before Christmas.
Mr. Aninat said that if fast-track authority was delayed, the United States would be missing a prime opportunity to establish an early trading agreement with a country where imports are growing 26 percent a year, one seen by many Asian nations as a platform for trade with the rest of Latin America.

U.S. Businesses Flocking to Brazilian Ventures

Author: Brooke, James

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]09 May 1994: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/429753330?accountid=11752

Abstract: "Russia should only hope to have Brazil's problems," said Paula Stern, an international economist based in Washington. "I'm sensing a new excitement about Brazil." "It's a plan of electoral opportunism," said Paulo Rabello de Castro, chairman of SR Rating, a new credit rating company in Rio de Janeiro. "Inflation could go down to 5 or 10 percentage points. But that is nothing new; Brazilian governments have already done that several times. But it won't be permanent." "Brazil's balance of Trade" shows Brazil's imports and exports from 1990 to 1994. (Source: U.S. Trade Center; Brazilian Exporters Association)(pg. D4)

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=U.S.+Businesses+Flocking+to+Brazilian+Ventures&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1994-05-09&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=Brooke%2C+James&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Special to The New York Times
Business people from the United States are flocking to Brazil in a new display of confidence that economic ties between the two giants of the Americas will now revolve around trade and investment.
Even before Brazil's $49 billion commercial debt was rescheduled on April 15, Brazilian and foreign businessmen detected the thundering hoofs of United States investors and exporters.
Sao Paulo, a state with an economy larger than Argentina's, has seen a string of business announcements in recent weeks: Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment bank, is to open an office here; J. C. Penney, the retailer, is to start a catalogue mail order business, and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, is opening an advertising agency. Later this year, Wal-Mart Stores is expected to open a discount store in Sao Paulo, its first in Brazil.
"It started last year -- then, all of a sudden, these guys are all over us," said Barry J. Gluck, a United States partner of the Brazilian office of Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, referring to the estimated 300 business people from the United States who now visit Sao Paulo each day. Symbol of New Interest
Indeed, as bankers lined up in New York to sign Brazil's foreign-debt deal, United States exporters and investors in Sao Paulo were already exploring the new United States Trade Center, a freshly minted aluminum-and- glass building that symbolizes the new business relationship.
International business interest in Brazil is rising as investors increasingly look beyond the nation's two prominent drawbacks -- a 45 percent monthly inflation rate and a chronically weak central Government -- and see a Latin American economy the size of Russia's.
But while Russia is struggling to recover from the collapse of Communism, Brazil's economy is growing this year on the shoulders of a record grain harvest of 74 million tons, a forecast of an unprecedented output of 1.5 million automobiles, record foreign currency reserves of $37 billion, a healthy trade surplus and a growing appetite for United States imports.
"Russia should only hope to have Brazil's problems," said Paula Stern, an international economist based in Washington. "I'm sensing a new excitement about Brazil."
By relaxing rules and slashing taxes in the early 1990's on profits sent overseas, Brazil stimulated new investor interest, especially in franchising.
"Australia and metropolitan Sao Paulo have about the same population -- 18 million people," Michael K. Lorelli, president of Pizza Hut International, calculated during a visit here in early April. "In Australia, we have 434 Pizza Huts. In Sao Paulo, we have 38. I don't see any reason why we can't double here every two years."
In the last two years, franchising grew in Brazil by 30 percent a year. Economists predict that in 1994 and in 1995, United States franchises alone will expand by 20 percent a year in Brazil.
With United States companies swarming into a once-restricted market, Sao Paulo's fast-food consumers can now choose among Domino's Pizza, Arby's and Kentucky Fried Chicken. Within a year, Taco Bell and Pizza Inn are to enter the market and McDonald's is to open its Latin American training center here, Hamburger University South.
Brazilians, who drink 1.4 billion gallons of soft drinks a year, constitute the world's third-largest soft-drink market, after the United States and Mexico. Opening an aggressive new front in the cola wars, Pepsi-Cola plans to open a new $25 million bottling plant in Rio de Janeiro this year, part of $90 million in investments planned by Pepsi through the end of the decade.
Brazil was long a closed market but abolished its list of banned imports in 1990. Over the last decade, it has slashed average tariffs from 78 percent to 14 percent, near the regional average. In response, foreign imports jumped 25 percent last year, hitting $25 billion. This year, they are expected to jump 20 percent more. Narrower Trade Gap
For the United States, which is Brazil's largest trading partner, this means that the United States' trade deficit with Brazil is expected to drop by half this year, to less than $1 billion.
"It's a new ball game here," said Richard R. Ades, a Commerce Department official who heads the new United States Trade Center here. "The trade gap is narrowing. A lot of American companies are coming down here to appoint distributors."
The number of United States business executives using the services of his office is running at four times last year's level, Mr. Ades said. Last year, 12 official United States trade missions visited Brazil, four times the number in 1992.
United States exports to Brazil increased by 10 percent last year and are expected to rise another 15 percent this year. Underlining Brazil's new importance to United States exporters, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown will visit Sao Paulo late this month to dedicate the new trade center.
Analysts predict that United States-Brazilian trade will grow steadily in two areas -- computers and tourism. Brazil's imports of United States-made computers and peripherals appear likely to grow by 30 percent a year through 1995. And with more than 700,000 Brazilians expected to visit the United States this year, Brazil could become the fifth-largest source of foreign tourists, after Japan, Germany, Britain and France.
"Brazil has the most dynamic private sector in Latin America," said William R. Rhodes, the Citibank vice chairman who led the creditor banks in the renegotiation of Brazil's foreign debt. A Government's Troubles
The healthy Brazilian business sector contrasts with its sick public sector. Brazilian executives look to the Government with low expectations.
To beat inflation, which reached a record 2,500 percent last year, economists say that Brazil needs to close its budget deficit by cutting Government spending and by collecting more taxes.
Tax collection is up by one-third over last year's levels. But Congress has been reluctant to cut spending with elections looming on Oct. 3. Brazil's President, Itamar Franco, whose term winds up at the end of this year, recently signed a measure allowing for the return to work of 108,000 federal employees dismissed during the previous Government.
A privatization program cycles along at a modest pace. One state company has been sold so far this year. In May, auctions are to be held for a state shipping line and for the state aircraft manufacturer. In June, seven state petrochemical companies are to be auctioned to private bidders.
A new economic plan to reduce inflation before the presidential election was disclosed in March by Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who subsequently resigned as Economy Minister to run for president as Mr. Franco's successor.
"It's a plan of electoral opportunism," said Paulo Rabello de Castro, chairman of SR Rating, a new credit rating company in Rio de Janeiro. "Inflation could go down to 5 or 10 percentage points. But that is nothing new; Brazilian governments have already done that several times. But it won't be permanent."
If the plan is successful in the short term, it will probably set off a consumer spending boom, sending Brazil's growth rate back up to the 5 percent registered last year. But if Mr. Cardoso's plan fails, the election will probably be won by his foremost rival, Luis Inacio Lula da Silva, a socialist who has led opinion polls by a 2-to-1 margin over any challenger, including Mr. Cardoso.
When Mr. da Silva visits New York and Washington this week, he is expected to reassure United States investors that he supports foreign investment, free trade and the recent reworking of Brazil's foreign debt. Beyond Politics
Yet the flow of investment suggests that many Brazilian and foreign business people are gambling that there is limited damage a new president can do, whatever his ideological stripe. While few Brazilian business executives back Mr. da Silva, Brazilian and foreign companies here are going ahead with investment plans totaling $45 billion for this year, the highest level in five years.
"Even with its mind-boggling inflation last year, the economy grew by 5 percent in real terms and the manufacturing was up 9 percent," said Jeffrey E. Garten, the United States Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, who visited Sao Paulo last month.
"The business community is optimistic that Brazil is about to turn the corner," said Mr. Garten, a former New York investment banker. "Business is booming. Foreign investors are clamoring to get in."

Ades, a Commerce Department official who heads the center. (John Maier Jr. for The New York Times)(pg. D1)

Rates Soar On Selloff In Treasuries

Author: Hurtado, Robert

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]11 Mar 1994: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/429475630?accountid=11752

Abstract: It appears that fear of inflation and uncertainty about when the Federal Reserve may raise short-term interest rates again are still the main reasons for the collapse in the bond market, which began when the Fed raised its short-term interest rate target a quarter-point on Feb. 4. Although many market analysts argue that the rise in interest rates has already been more than enough to offset another increase by the Fed, traders and analysts are still uncertain whether the rise has reached its peak. Many economists also argue that fears of inflation are overblown, given the current economic data and the apparent determination of the Fed to resist price increases. "If the Fed moves quickly, I think the bonds can improve from where they are now. But if the Fed continues to drag its feet, any improvement will be limited because investors are waiting for further tightening by the Fed." The faster the Fed moves, he said, the more the market will become convinced that the central bank is doing the right thing to stave off inflation in 1995, 1996 and beyond. "If it moves slowly, the Fed will have justified the market's concern that inflation is a problem," he said. The Fed moved at the right time in February, he said, but the increase was not big enough to calm the inflation fears of the bond market.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Rates+Soar+On+Selloff+In+Treasuries&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1994-03-11&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=Hurtado%2C+Robert&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Prices of Treasury securities plunged yesterday, pushing up the yield on the 30-year bond to 6.95 percent, its highest level in more than nine months.
Long-term interest rates, which move in the opposite direction of bond prices, are now more than a percentage point above the 25-year low reached on Oct. 15 and nearly three-quarters of a point higher than in early February. For the Clinton Administration, which has based its hope for steady economic growth on the lift from low long-term interest rates, the selloff in the bond market must be raising concerns.
Some traders sought to explain yesterday's selling by pointing to the uncertainty generated by the investigation into the Whitewater land deal and the political unrest in South Africa, the world's largest gold producer, which pushed up gold prices sharply. Fears of Inflation
But it appears that fear of inflation and uncertainty about when the Federal Reserve may raise short-term interest rates again are still the main reasons for the collapse in the bond market, which began when the Fed raised its short-term interest rate target a quarter-point on Feb. 4. Although many market analysts argue that the rise in interest rates has already been more than enough to offset another increase by the Fed, traders and analysts are still uncertain whether the rise has reached its peak. Many economists also argue that fears of inflation are overblown, given the current economic data and the apparent determination of the Fed to resist price increases.
With no fresh data to support the bond market yesterday, investors looked for an excuse to change their investment strategy or sell. Traders said investors who were selling long-term securities turned around and bought short-term Treasury bills, which are less volatile and risky when the market outlook is unclear. A Shift to Shorter Maturities
In late trading, the price of the 30-year bond fell 1 1/2 points, to 917/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.95 percent, up from 6.83 percent on Wednesday and the highest since May 1993, when it was 6.98 percent. The rush by some investors to seek the shelter of the shorter maturities lifted the bill market. The three-month bill rate fell 3 basis points, to 3.48 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc., said, "The fact remains that there is simply no demand for Treasuries with investors knowing that the Fed is going to hike interest rates soon."
He said traders and investors, by selling relentlessly last month, had pushed interest rates much higher than what could be justified by the economic outlook. He added that investors might be realizing that the inflation they were concerned about was not a problem for 1994, although it could be an issue in 1995 or beyond.
"We don't know yet if the economy will even be strong enough to produce inflation in those years," Mr. Fine said.
Joseph V. Battipaglia, managing director of Sterling Advisers, said investors were in a selling mood yesterday and were looking for any excuse to sell. But he argued that "everything in market said you should have been a buyer, not a seller."
Mr. Battipaglia said a reference to gold as a gauge of inflation expectations by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, in Congressional testimony last month had made gold a fashionable measure for investors. "And a spike in the price of gold like we had today might spook bond investors," Mr. Battipaglia said.
The gold contract for April delivery jumped $8.10, to $388.20 an ounce, in trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday. "The market is sending a clear message that the Fed has not done enough," Mr. Fine said.
"If the Fed moves quickly, I think the bonds can improve from where they are now. But if the Fed continues to drag its feet, any improvement will be limited because investors are waiting for further tightening by the Fed."
The faster the Fed moves, he said, the more the market will become convinced that the central bank is doing the right thing to stave off inflation in 1995, 1996 and beyond. "If it moves slowly, the Fed will have justified the market's concern that inflation is a problem," he said. The Fed moved at the right time in February, he said, but the increase was not big enough to calm the inflation fears of the bond market.
Some reports that should have helped the market yesterday included the weekly report on initial claims for unemployment benefits for the week that ended on Saturday. The number of Americans filing claims increased by 32,000, to 346,000. Today's report on retail sales for February may draw some attention, traders said, but it is next week's inflation numbers that are more important. The producer price and consumer price indexes for February will be released on Tuesday and Wednesday. China Bonds
Elsewhere in the debt markets, the Bank of China, a bank owned by the Government of China, received an enthusiastic reception yesterday for an issue of five-year bonds, but an issue of 20-year bonds, the longest yet issued by a Chinese agency, did not do as well.
The $400 million issue of five-year bonds was priced to yield 6.819 percent, or 98 basis points above comparable Treasury securities. The initial sale was completed, and the lead underwriters, Morgan Stanley & Company, allowed the bonds to be traded freely.
The $100 million issue of 20-year bonds, which was priced to yield 8.281 percent, or 135 basis points above comparable Treasury securities, was bid by Morgan Stanley at a 140 basis point spread, a lower price.
Jim Pelgrift, a bond syndicate manager for Morgan Stanley, said some of the 20-year bonds remained to be sold.
Although not formally guaranteed by the Government of China, the bonds were priced as if they were, reflecting the Government's support of the bank.
Graph "Tax-Exempt Yields" shows the average weekly yields for 20 general obligation bonds and 25 revenue bonds, in percent from Nov. '93-Mar. '94. (Source: The Bond Buyer) (pg. D5)

O.E.C.D. Says Fed May Raise Rates

Author: Greenhouse, Steven

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]19 Nov 1993: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/429358568?accountid=11752

Abstract: The Paris-based organization, which promotes economic cooperation among its 24 member nations, said in a new study that "there is good reason to expect inflation to remain below 3 percent," but added that with short-term rates so low, unemployment edging down and factory utilization rising, monetary tightening could be justified to head off a resurgence of inflation. In its annual grading of America's economic performance, the organization -- which normally takes a tough stance on inflation -- added that "tightening could also be justified if" inflationary "expectations need a jolt and the Federal Reserve's credibility is endangered." 'Real' Rates: Zero Percent The O.E.C.D. expressed concern that "real" short-term rates -- nominal rates minus the inflation rate -- were zero percent. Mr. [Peter Jarrett] said rates at that level were highly stimulative and could reignite inflation.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=O.E.C.D.+Says+Fed+May+Raise+Rates&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1993-11-19&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Greenhouse%2C+Steven&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Special to The New York Times
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development predicted today that the Federal Reserve would soon push up short-term interest rates because of concerns that the inflation rate had stopped falling.
The Paris-based organization, which promotes economic cooperation among its 24 member nations, said in a new study that "there is good reason to expect inflation to remain below 3 percent," but added that with short-term rates so low, unemployment edging down and factory utilization rising, monetary tightening could be justified to head off a resurgence of inflation.
In its annual grading of America's economic performance, the organization -- which normally takes a tough stance on inflation -- added that "tightening could also be justified if" inflationary "expectations need a jolt and the Federal Reserve's credibility is endangered." 'Real' Rates: Zero Percent
Peter Jarrett, the economist who wrote the study, said in an interview that if the Fed decided to raise short-term rates, that should not in turn push up long-term interest rates, because the Fed would be showing its determination to keep inflation low.
The O.E.C.D. expressed concern that "real" short-term rates -- nominal rates minus the inflation rate -- were zero percent. Mr. Jarrett said rates at that level were highly stimulative and could reignite inflation.
Fed officials declined today to respond to the report.
In what was probably the most pointed section of its report, the organization criticized the Clinton Administration's efforts to pressure Japan to open its markets and agree to specific targets for reducing its trade surplus and increasing imports. The report said this approach ran the risk of creating managed trade, and might result in the "cartelization" of Japanese markets.
It also questioned the usefulness of Washington's pressure campaign, saying that even if the Clinton Administration succeeded in persuading Japan to reduce trade barriers, this was unlikely to do much to reduce the American trade deficit with Japan.
Mr. Jarrett said the Clinton Administration challenged this part of the report more than any other. The Administration has repeatedly argued that efforts to press Japan to import more promotes freer trade, rather than managed trade. Sees More Growth
Each year the O.E.C.D.'s secretariat issues a report that assesses the economic policies and problems of each member nation.
The study forecast a slight rise in American economic growth to a moderate 3 percent next year, with an increase in the trade deficit and another moderate drop in the unemployment rate, currently 6.8 percent.
"While this may appear to some as a disappointing picture, it is actually rather satisfactory," the report said. The organization was less sanguine about long-term growth prospects, saying the nation's potential growth rate was a lackluster 2.3 percent.
In another piece of bad news, the report said that because of slow productivity growth, the United States would lose its worldwide lead in productivity per worker within a decade. Probably the biggest long-term problem for the American economy, the O.E.C.D. said, is inadequate savings. This holds back the nation's ability to increase educational skills and expand plants and equipment, in turn inhibiting productivity growth.
After years of criticizing the United States for not tackling its budget deficit, the organization praised President Clinton's deficit-reduction efforts, but suggested that a new round of cuts might be required by 1998.

Vague Mexico Wage Pledge Clouds Free Trade Accord

Author: DePALMA, ANTHONY

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]29 Sep 1993: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/429240095?accountid=11752

Abstract: Mr. [Carlos Salinas de Gortari]'s pledge was not enough to quell all complaint. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, said Mr. Salinas's promise fell short because so few Mexican workers receive just the minimum wage. Last week he said he would vote against the agreement. 10 Percent Get Minimum According to the Bank of Mexico, the minimum wage now applies to only about 10 percent of Mexican workers, and the Mexican Social Security system reports that only 16 percent of its 8.8 million enrollees receive the minimum wage. But the practice has developed in Mexico of using increases in the minimum wage as the basis for negotiation involving salaries higher than the minimum. Some higher-paid workers, mostly Government employees, would be directly affected because their salaries are calculated as multiples of the minimum wage. According to the Bank of Mexico, the minimum wage now applies to only about 10 percent of Mexican workers, and the Mexican Social Security system reports that only 16 percent of its 8.8 million enrollees receive the minimum wage. But the practice has developed in Mexico of using increases in the minimum wage as the basis for negotiation involving salaries higher than the minimum. Some higher-paid workers, mostly Government employees, would be directly affected because their salaries are calculated as multiples of the minimum wage.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Vague+Mexico+Wage+Pledge+Clouds+Free+Trade+Accord&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1993-09-29&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=DePALMA%2C+ANTHONY&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Special to The New York Times
As they try to make the case for Congressional approval of a free trade agreement with Mexico and Canada, President Clinton and other supporters repeatedly say the pact will raise minimum wages in Mexico and reduce the country's ability to undercut businesses north of the border with cheap labor.
But by focusing on how minimum wages might rise, the Clinton Administration has put itself in a somewhat awkward position because that particular pledge is not found anywhere in the 2,000-page North American Free Trade Agreement it is meant to support. Nor is it in the special side agreements to the pact, or in Mexican labor law. A Promise by Salinas
Rather it is a personal promise made by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico that this country's minimum wage -- which can go as low as $4 a day, depending on the type of work -- will be increased in tandem with increases in worker productivity.
Mr. Salinas's pledge, announced publicly in August on the same day the side accords were announced, was seen as crucial to getting the pact past a worried United States Congress.
But the pledge was so vague, and the issue of measuring productivity so potentially troublesome, that Mr. Salinas is now under pressure to come forward with a concrete plan for lifting the incomes of Mexico's poorest workers.
Mexican officials have said only that their Departments of Labor and Economic Development are working with their National Commission of Minimum Salaries to devise a formula for the increases.
Labor unions say they have reached an agreement with the Government to give bonuses to productive workers in specific industries, but that does not seem to meet the letter of Mr. Salinas's pledge. Beyond that, little is known on either side of the border about what Mexico will actually do.
"Nobody really has a good understanding of what they're going to do," said Mauricio Gonzalez, a partner at a Mexico City consulting company.
If an accurate and reliable format could be worked out, linking productivity to wage increases could go far toward returning the Mexican work force to the standard of living it had before the debt crisis of 1982 brought soaring inflation and a deep national recession. But the average American factory worker is 4.6 times more productive than the average Mexican factory worker, although in some new Mexican plants the rates can be roughly comparable. Still, few believe that Mexico can close the gap quickly.
It is also not clear how Mexico would manage productivity-based increases, or when they would become effective. Mexican officials say it is doubtful that anything could be in place by the beginning of January, when they hope the trade agreement will be signed and in force.
The Mexican negotiators of the pact were careful not to commit themselves to wage parity with the United States. Mexico is going to try only to make up for some of the losses suffered by workers over the last decade, when the buying power of the minimum wage dropped 60 percent.
There is even uncertainty about what Mr. Salinas's pledge actually means. "We will be assured of an effective and permanent improvement of minimum wages now and for the future," Mr. Salinas said in a speech in which he outlined the plan.
Harley Shaiken, a labor economist at the University of California at Berkeley, said, "As a statement of intent it is a preamble, but the devil is in the details, and this has no details."
A United States Labor Department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Clinton Administration was using Mr. Salinas's pledge because of the "symbolic value" it represented. The official said a new system would have a practical, though limited, effect on shrinking the gap between wages in the United States and Mexico. Clinton Stresses Pledge
Despite that, the pledge has become a key part of Mr. Clinton's efforts to sell the pact. In a speech in New Orleans this month, the President praised the trade agreement and the side accords -- one on the environment, the other on labor -- that are intended to toughen parts of the original pact, which lowers or eliminates tariffs on most goods traded between the United States, Mexico and Canada.
The side agreement on labor, Mr. Clinton said, "commits the Mexican Government to enforce its own labor laws, and you should know what that really means."
"It means that for the first time in history a government has committed itself to raise the minimum wage as its economy grows, thereby raising the wage structure throughout the country," he said.
But Mr. Salinas's pledge was not enough to quell all complaint. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, said Mr. Salinas's promise fell short because so few Mexican workers receive just the minimum wage. Last week he said he would vote against the agreement. 10 Percent Get Minimum
According to the Bank of Mexico, the minimum wage now applies to only about 10 percent of Mexican workers, and the Mexican Social Security system reports that only 16 percent of its 8.8 million enrollees receive the minimum wage. But the practice has developed in Mexico of using increases in the minimum wage as the basis for negotiation involving salaries higher than the minimum. Some higher-paid workers, mostly Government employees, would be directly affected because their salaries are calculated as multiples of the minimum wage.
But as in the United States, increases in the minimum wage do not necessarily result in across-the-board increases. In the United States, the minimum wage has been increasing while average wages have fallen.
In Mexico, there are actually 264 minimum wages; each of 88 different occupations has three minimums that vary according to where the jobs are performed. In general, wages are highest in Mexico City and other urban areas, and lowest in rural states.
Minimum wages are set by the National Commission of Minimum Salaries, which is made up of representatives from business, labor unions and the Government. From 1986 to last January, the commission changed the levels 16 times. Government Deeply Involved
The Government's involvement is an essential part of Mr. Salinas's efforts to tame inflation and keep investors interested in Mexico. Under a set of wage and price controls in effect since 1987, just before Mr. Salinas took office, businesses and unions have kept negotiated wage increases below the level of inflation, while the Government agreed to keep down gasoline and electricity prices while also pumping money into a public works programs called Solidarity.
The program has worked. Inflation is below 10 percent for the first time in 25 years. Despite a slowing of Mexico's economic growth, investment has continued strong. There has even been some recovery in real wages over the last few years. But it has not been enough to compensate for staggering losses of the 1980's. Real wages today are 68 percent of what they were in 1980.
All that has worsened the gap between wages in the United States and Mexico, even though Mexican productivity has been increasing by 4 percent or more each year since 1989. Mexican compensation was 22 percent of United States wages in 1980. It dropped to 7 percent in 1987 and since has risen to 15 percent, according to a report by the Democratic Study Center, a nonprofit academic foundation in Washington.
"We don't expect that in three, four or five years we will have the same minimum salaries as the United States," said Juan S. Millan Lizarraga, secretary of education for the Confederation of Mexican Workers, the largest labor syndicate in Mexico. "But we expect to cut the gap."
Mr. Salinas's pledge, announced publicly in August on the same day the side accords were announced, was seen as crucial to getting the pact past a worried United States Congress. But the pledge was so vague, and the issue of measuring productivity so potentially troublesome, that Mr. Salinas is now under pressure to come forward with a concrete plan for lifting the incomes of Mexico's poorest workers.
