CREDIT MARKETS; Taming Inflation, and Its Impact

Author: FUERBRINGER, JONATHAN

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]16 Nov 1992: D.5.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/428761655?accountid=11752

Abstract: "I still don't believe that most bond investors believe we are looking at a major structural break in inflation," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence. "I think the bond market is still very concerned about a rebound in inflation." "I don't think that the bond market is misinterpreting the inflation facts," said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at the Dreyfus Corporation. What worries the market, he said, is not an expected rise in inflation in the near term but the "uncertainty about the economic policy of the Clinton Administration." "The difference between the bulls and the bears," he said, "is not about what inflation will be in 1993, but about what economic policy will be in 1993, 1994 and 1995. There is a fear we won't deal with the deficit." 'Crowding Out' Feared More

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=CREDIT+MARKETS%3B+Taming+Inflation%2C+and+Its+Impact&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1992-11-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.5&amp;au=FUERBRINGER%2C+JONATHAN&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: When inflation in the United States is out of control, as it was in the 1970's and early 80's, it is the talk of the land and topples Presidents. When it is under control people just don't seem to notice it.
Well, for the record, inflation in the United States should dip this year to its lowest sustained level since the beginning of the 1970's.
This is not a flash in the pan. The data would cover the 10-year period through the end of 1992. If the Consumer Price Index for the United States rises only 3 percent this year -- and it is moving at that pace right now -- prices will have risen just 3.8 percent a year on average in the last decade. That would be the slowest 10 years' worth of inflation since the same 3.8 percent in the period that ended in 1973.
There has not been a 10-year period in which consumer prices rose at an average annual rate of less than 3 percent since 1961 to 1970, when the average was 2.77 percent. Trend Among Industrial Nations
America's industrial allies have seen similarly tame inflation, from Britain and Germany to Australia and New Zealand. Inflation in the 23 most industrialized countries could average 3.9 percent a year for the last decade, according to International Monetary Fund data. That would be the lowest level for the group since the 3.82 percent figure for the 10 years that ended in 1972.
This should be good news for the consumer and the bond market although there has been quite a cost for this success. In the United States it was the steep recessions of 1980 and 1981 and, later, the four years of either minimal growth or recession since 1988 that undermined President Bush's chances for re-election.
But low inflation has its benefits, one of the most important being the opportunity for a longer period of sustained growth in the economy.
There are numerous signs of continued moderate inflation in the United States. Despite the somewhat surprising rise of four-tenths of one percent in the Consumer Price Index for October, reported Friday, several analysts said they were not worried, in part because one-time factors, like increases in airline fares, contributed to the overall jump. Inflation Scenario Discounted
Closely watched inflation monitors, like the Commodity Research Bureau's index, are declining. What ismore, both the recent rise of the dollar, which makes imports less expensive, and slow growth in Europe, which cuts demand for American products, should both help restrain inflationary pressures.
"There is just no inflation scenario," said Rudiger Dornbusch, professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "You need 3.5 percent growth for three or four years to get a crunch."
Still, it seems that traders and investors in the bond market, which is ultrasensitive to price movements, have yet to believe the inflation story.
Some analysts contend that long-term rates, given the recent inflation performance, should be lower than the 7.57 percent yield on Friday on the new 30-year bond. This belief was the basis for many of the projections, now generally abandoned, that long-term rates would soon fall below 7 percent.
"I still don't believe that most bond investors believe we are looking at a major structural break in inflation," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence. "I think the bond market is still very concerned about a rebound in inflation."
Others believe that in the next year the story on low inflation will finally sink in and bring down bond yields. Mr. Yardeni said the inflation downdraft could pull rates on the long bond close to 6 percent. Others are more conservative, projecting a fall to around 7.25 or 7 percent.
But there are others who think that much of the inflation story is reflected in the market already, which means that other factors -- like the performance of the Clinton Administration -- will have more impact on the future course of bond yields.
"I don't think that the bond market is misinterpreting the inflation facts," said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at the Dreyfus Corporation. What worries the market, he said, is not an expected rise in inflation in the near term but the "uncertainty about the economic policy of the Clinton Administration."
"The difference between the bulls and the bears," he said, "is not about what inflation will be in 1993, but about what economic policy will be in 1993, 1994 and 1995. There is a fear we won't deal with the deficit." 'Crowding Out' Feared More
John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said the concern in the market now is not inflation but of "crowding out," a term that became popular early in the Reagan Administration. It is the worry that with a rising Federal budget deficit the borrowing demands of the Treasury will "crowd out" the private-sector demand for borrowing. And this, the theory goes, will lead to higher interest rates.
Nancy J. Kimelman, chief economist at Technical Data in Boston, takes a different view. She says investors and traders are already correctly interpreting a Clinton Presidency. The current interest rate on the 30-year bond, she said, assumes that inflation will rise under Mr. Clinton.
"I am not sure that the market is wrong in assessing that Clinton will mean higher bond yields than Bush," she said. Mr. Clinton, she said, wants to get the economy growing to create more jobs. And this, she acknowledged, will probably mean higher inflation.
"The bond market knows that sluggish growth, no real improvement in incomes, and austerity are not the American way," she said. "And everyone knew that the deficit was at a record level, and they still elected Bill Clinton."

TURMOIL IN EUROPE; I.M.F. Chief Defends Central Bankers

Author: Greenhouse, Steven

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]18 Sep 1992: D.4.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/428671512?accountid=11752

Abstract: In an interview with a French newspaper, he urged the United States to play a more active role in calming Europe's market turbulence. Recognizing the powerful role the United States plays in the world economy, he said, "You cannot stabilize international markets without the cooperation of the United States." 'Not Enough on the Budget Side' He said he was optimistic that Germany's central bank would cut rates again. "As you look forward, I think you can say that in due course in Germany, we will look forward to lower interest rates," he said. 'That's clearly the signal that they've sent." He added that the timing of that was "a complex matter." Mr. [David C. Mulford] said the United States had been "relatively unaffected" by Europe's currency crisis, although he expressed concern that turmoil in currency markets could spill over into other financial markets. But he said Europe again was stabilizing, so there was "a minimum of risk" for such financial market turmoil.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=TURMOIL+IN+EUROPE%3B+I.M.F.+Chief+Defends+Central+Bankers&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1992-09-18&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.4&amp;au=Greenhouse%2C+Steven&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Special to The New York Times
The head of the International Monetary Fund went to bat today for central bankers humiliated by this week's crisis in European currency markets, asserting that the underlying reason for the chaos was less-than-stellar policy making by elected officials.
In a news conference, Michel Camdessus, the fund's managing director, singled out Germany's Government, saying its failure to rein in its huge budget deficit had virtually forced its central bank to raise interest rates.
And in an interview with a French newspaper, he urged the United States to play a more active role in calming Europe's market turbulence. Recognizing the powerful role the United States plays in the world economy, he said, "You cannot stabilize international markets without the cooperation of the United States." 'Not Enough on the Budget Side'
The high German rates had forced other European countries, many of them in or near recession, to raise their rates to keep their currencies from falling against the mark. This week, despite large-scale central-bank intervention, the British pound, Italian lira and Spanish peseta, under the attack of currency speculators, had to be devalued.
"If we went through these tensions, it's probably because not enough was done on the budgetary side," Mr. Camdessus said.
He spoke two days before the world's central bankers and finance ministers gather here for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank. He also spoke two days before a meeting of Group of Seven finance ministers in Washington.
Asked whether Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, has been too tough in raising its key rates above 9 percent to cut inflation, Mr. Camdessus responded: "I wouldn't say that. I would say that too much burden has been put on them."
Mr. Camdessus insisted that the European currency crisis could end up strengthening Europe's system of fixed exchange rates rather than weakening it.
"In spite of the formidable turmoil of the last few days, the system has once again demonstrated its remarkable resilience," he said.
In the interview with the French newspaper Les Echos, Mr. Camdessus asserted that the crisis in Europe stemmed in large part from the huge gap between America's low interest rates and Germany's stratospheric rates.
This gap pushed the mark so high that it became difficult for other European countries to keep their rates linked to the German currency. He criticized America's huge budget deficit, saying that because the deficit made it difficult for Washington to use fiscal policy to stimulate the economy, the burden fell on the Federal Reserve to keep cutting rates. U.S. Emphasizes Growth
With the United States economy anemic for the last three years, the Bush Administration has been pressing other industrial nations to put more emphasis on growth. In a news briefing today, David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury, said he welcomed this week's currency devaluations as well as Monday's interest rate cut by the German central bank, saying they would help spur economic expansion worldwide.
Mr. Mulford said this week's actions showed the Europeans were finally backing the American approach.
The week's decisions in Europe "were very, very important," he said.
"They reflect a recognition of the consensus that has been building -- the United States has been promoting these views for about a year and a half now -- of the importance of strengthening world growth."
He said he was optimistic that Germany's central bank would cut rates again. "As you look forward, I think you can say that in due course in Germany, we will look forward to lower interest rates," he said. 'That's clearly the signal that they've sent." He added that the timing of that was "a complex matter."
Mr. Mulford said the United States had been "relatively unaffected" by Europe's currency crisis, although he expressed concern that turmoil in currency markets could spill over into other financial markets. But he said Europe again was stabilizing, so there was "a minimum of risk" for such financial market turmoil.
He said that at Saturday's Group of Seven meeting, the finance ministers would discuss developments in currency markets, as well as ways to spur world growth, help the developing world, and aid the former Soviet bloc as it adopted a market economy.
The seven ministers will meet with Russia's Deputy Prime Minister, Alexandr Shokhin, to discuss that nation's economic reforms, and they will also debate a plan to grant large-scale debt relief to Russia.
As Mr. Camdessus described it, the agenda for next week's I.M.F.-World Bank meeting will largely overlap that of the Group of Seven meeting. At the I.M.F. session, ministers will discuss how to end the economic doldrums in the industrialized world, how to help the former Communist world stabilize and grow, and, in his words, how to "consolidate and generalize the progress we observe in many developing countries."
Mr. Camdessus complained that many industrial countries had not pursued their commitments to get their economic houses in order. The I.M.F.'s World Economic Outlook, a semiannual report that was issued Wednesday, criticized the United States, Germany, Britain and Italy for not doing nearly enough to reduce their deficits. He said the large deficits were placing too much weight on central banks to run economic policy.
I.M.F. officials say the large deficits are slowing growth worldwide by pushing up long-term interest rates and by diverting money for consumption that could be used for private investment to build for the future.
Photograph Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, blamed bad politics yesterday for Europe's economic ills. (Associated Press)

U.S. Trade Pact a Spur To Canada

Author: Farnsworth, Clyde H

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]22 July 1992: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/428584561?accountid=11752

Abstract: Even Mr. [Brian Mulroney], who usually strikes a friendly pose toward the United States, has been hotly critical, using terms like "unacceptable" and "counterproductive" and accusing Americans of "sideswiping Canada." And, illustrating the degree of resentment are the widely quoted remarks of Simon Reisman, the man Mr. Mulroney appointed to lead the Canadian free-trade negotiating team in the late 1980's. "The Americans are bastards," he told an interviewer earlier this year. "They're behaving like real thugs these days in protecting their interests." Maude Barlow, an adviser on women's issues during the early 1980's Liberal leadership of Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau, heads the Ottawa-based Council of Canadians, the chief lobby against free trade. She said her group would begin a campaign this fall to abrogate the 1989 pact "with brochures, buttons, cross-country tours, town hall meetings, the works" and is "forming alliances with like-minded organizations in the United States and Mexico, to bring our experiences to bear." "It's time to blow the whistle on the free- trade blame game," said Michael Wilson, Canada's International Trade Minister. "Despite the problems generated by a tough global recession, a spate of difficult disputes with the United States and a deep slide in public support for the free trade agreement in Canada, there is now clear evidence that the free trade agreement is working."

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=U.S.+Trade+Pact+a+Spur+To+Canada%3A+%5BA+New+North+America+--+Second+of+three+articles.+%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1992-07-22&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=Farnsworth%2C+Clyde+H&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Special to The New York Times
New economic studies indicate that Canada has become more competitive as a result of its trade agreement with the United States and, some analysts believe, is about to outpace all major industrial nations in economic growth. Yet Prime Minister Brian Mulroney faces a herculean task over the next six months in getting the House of Commons to ratify an expansion of the treaty to include Mexico.
The Prime Minister's Government is expected reach agreement on the treaty with Mexico and the United States in coming weeks.
Despite the signs of increased strength -- manufacturing output rose four tenths of 1 percent in 1991, for example -- Canada is still suffering, along with much of the rest of the world, from the persistent effects of recession. And the current trade agreement between the United States and Canada, which came into force Jan. 1, 1989, is getting much of the blame; Canadians are upset about recent plant closings, continued joblessness and the flight of some businesses to the United States.
From a three-way arrangement, Canada is looking not only to preserve trade gains with the United States but to increase its access to Mexico's thriving market.
Canada's trade with Mexico is still modest -- $3 billion a year of two-way business, or only 1.5 percent of exchanges with the United States. Mexico enjoys a huge surplus -- $2 billion last year, chiefly reflecting shipment to Canada of Mexican-assembled cars of the Big Three. Canada last year, for example, imported 41,000 Cavaliers. Canadians also bought nearly $100 million of Mexico's fruits and vegetables.
"People are really very angry," Joan Fawcett, a Liberal Party member of the Ontario Provincial Parliament, said. "They feel these closings are a direct result of free trade -- and that the Canadian Government sold them a bill of goods."
Polls show ardent criticism of the 1989 agreement. The latest survey of the Angus Reid Group has found that 64 percent of Canadians oppose the proposed North American treaty -- and 66 percent are still against the initial agreement with the United States.
Only 6 percent believe that Canada has won any benefits at all in the accord with Washington, which by 1999 virtually eliminates all trade barriers between the two nations.
The provincial governments of Ontario and British Columbia have gone so far as to demand that Canada walk away from the negotiating table.
Many Canadians think that President Bush wants a new free trade deal to boost himself politically. Ontario's Trade Minister, Ed Philip, sounded a popular note here when he commented the other day: "Helping to get George Bush elected by signing on to a dubious free trade deal is not part of Canada's economic agenda."
Still, no one expects Mr. Mulroney to pull out of the talks, and in the end most analysts think the Canadian Parliament will go along with the agreement -- that its great economic dependence on the United States leaves it no other choice.
In fact, neither the United States nor Mexico was initially keen on Canada's participation, fearing Ottawa would only complicate already fiendishly difficult negotiations. But Canada insisted on joining because of its "vital interests," a term Ottawa used repeatedly.
Canada, Mexico and the United States are now trying to create what eventually would become a single market for North America's 370 million people. The agreement is expected to be initialed within a few weeks and come up for ratification later in the legislative bodies of all three countries.
Despite the naysayers, many Canadian economists insist that treaty has had strongly positive effects. New studies are showing that free trade has quietly helped manufacturers reverse a long-term decline in productivity, made Canadian enterprises more global and given Canada a supranational judicial process providing a measure of protection against arbitrary American trade decisions.
A University of Toronto analysis has found that freer trade has stimulated growth, lowered the rate of inflation and lessened the severity of the recession. The researchers found that Canada's output of goods and services last year was four-tenths of a percent higher than it would have been without the free trade agreement; unemployment was down one-tenth of a percent and inflation was seven-tenths of a percent lower. The International Monetary Fund and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development have both recently predicted that Canada, energized by free trade, is about to become the fastest growing of the major industrial countries.
"Things are looking up," said Allan R. Taylor, chairman of the Royal Bank of Canada, the nation's biggest bank, adding, "It is ludicrous to argue, as many are doing, that Canada would somehow have been more protected in the current recession without the free trade agreement."
Trade liberalization, combined with anti-inflation policies, deficit control and industrial deregulation have put Canada in the position, according to Mr. Taylor, where "our costs and prices are finally under control," adding that "they are now running below those of the United States." The Results U.S. Companies Expand in Canada
In contrast to the highly publicized plant closings, many large companies are quietly expanding in Canada to serve the North American market. American multinationals in Canada, it is estimated, have created at least as many jobs as they have terminated.
Figures from the Government's Statistics Canada agency show a net loss of 403,000 manufacturing jobs and a net gain of 185,000 service jobs since Jan. 1, 1989. But Doug Drew, manager of the statistical agency's Labor Force Survey, said it was not clear how much of the changes reflect freer trade and how much Canada's recession.
The stakes for Canada in an expanded trade zone are unusually high because trade with the United States is so closely linked to its own prosperity. More than 75 percent of its exports went to the United States last year, while almost 70 percent of its imports came from the United States. Exports to the United States, a market 10 times larger than Canada's, account for 20 percent of Canada's gross domestic product. No other country -- not even Germany's trading partners in Europe -- are so economically dependent on a neighbor.
Together the United States and Canada do $200 billion of trade with each other, representing the largest commercial relationship in the world. The opening up of new markets in Mexico should help diversify Canada's trade and reduce dependence on the United States.
Procter & Gamble, with 94,000 employees worldwide, says it has capitalized on freer trade to create 200 additional jobs in Canada in the production of specialty soaps and hygienic products for North American distribution. At Pointe Claire, outside Montreal, it has a new pump-soap production line. At Belleville, in southern Ontario, it has just started another operation for the Always panty liner.
"We've been able to take the opportunities created by the free trade agreement for moving product and raw materials across the border more cheaply," said Margaret Bawden, manager of public affairs for Procter & Gamble's Canadian subsidiary. "We find some operations in Canada now more cost effective."
Others taking advantage of lower tariffs to expand are Dow Chemical, Cargill Foods, Du Pont, Rubbermaid, GTE Sylvania, Hughes Aircraft and Kodak.
Freer trade has also accelerated industrial reorganization, as companies seek to operate more efficiently and cut their production costs. The readjustment has been painful in some instances. Jobs indeed have been lost, though in some cases the cause may be an isolated downturn in business, not the lower trade barriers.
Cooper Industries, for example, recently closed a plant near Coburg in southern Ontario that employed 200 people who made hand-held steel files for removing and smoothing metal or wood. Brock McCloskey, a vice president of employee relations, said the operation was consolidated in Cullman, Ala., where the company already had a larger file-making plant.
He said the move had "nothing to do with free trade," adding, "We had excess capacity in both plants and consolidated into one to best utilize manufacturing capacity." The Rivalry Canadians Remain Suspicious of U.S.
If free trade has become the agreement the Canadian people love to hate, part of that feeling stems from the belief among not only the people but also Government officials that the United States continues to use its economic power to keep Canada down in a number of critical sectors, including autos, lumber, steel, beer and apparel. Or, at least, to exact as many advantages as it can before 1999.
Even Mr. Mulroney, who usually strikes a friendly pose toward the United States, has been hotly critical, using terms like "unacceptable" and "counterproductive" and accusing Americans of "sideswiping Canada." And, illustrating the degree of resentment are the widely quoted remarks of Simon Reisman, the man Mr. Mulroney appointed to lead the Canadian free-trade negotiating team in the late 1980's. "The Americans are bastards," he told an interviewer earlier this year. "They're behaving like real thugs these days in protecting their interests."
In recent weeks the United States has threatened to hit Canadian exports of steel and beer.
American steelmakers have accused the Canadians of "dumping" steel, or selling it in the United States at below cost, a violation of United States law. If the American industry can prove its case, higher tariffs would be forced on Canadian steel.
But the Canadians say any such action would make a mockery of free trade. They say that because of the recession and the high degree of integration of the North American steel market, they cannot help but sell below cost in the United States.
The American complaint "amounts to taking advantage of people on the downside of an economic cycle," laments Roger Phillips, president if Ipsco Inc., a $500 million a year company that makes tubular steel in Regina, Saskatchewan, and Calgary, Alberta.
Backed by Ottawa, the Canadian companies have opened negotiations with their American counterparts on a potential peace formula -- a pact that would reflect the integrated nature of the steel market and prohibit antidumping measures if imports are either priced to meet the competition or do not have a substantial market share.
In beer, the United States has accused Canada of lacking good faith in removing trade barriers against American beer and has threatened to retaliate to recover $80 million of lost business. Washington has cited what it calls discriminatory practices by Ontario and Quebec. Particular anger has been voiced against an Ontario tax of 10 cents on all cans of beer sold in the province. Most of the American beer is sold in cans.
And Canada's apparel industry says it is fighting for its life in the Mexico-Canada-United States talks because of American demands for restrictive North American content rules. To placate the powerful American textile industry, Washington is insisting that clothing be cut and sewn in North America from fabric and yarn made on this continent before it can be traded duty-free among the three countries.
Yet virtually all the fabric in the Canadian dress and sportswear industry is imported from outside North America. "We search the world for great sources of supply, and we sell the niches; we're masters of nichemanship," says Jack Kivenko, vice president of Jack Spratt Manufacturing Inc. a jeans and workwear producer in Montreal and president of the Canadian Apparel Manufacturers Institute, a trade group.
If the American demand is accepted, he said, "it will mean that Canadian manufacturers will have to close down and locate manufacturing outside of Canada." The Canadian apparel industry employs about 125,000 people, 60 percent of whom work in the province of Quebec. The Politics Trade Issue Could Dominate
If the treaty does come up for ratification next year, the timing could not be worse for Mr. Mulroney, who may find free trade dominating the general elections. Although he has come up a little in the polls, a negative popular attitude toward the treaty is not what he needs. Only a few months ago his was the least popular administration since poll-taking started a half-century ago.
The Mulroney Government must call elections at least by the fall of 1993, and many expect the call next spring. But that is just when the North American agreement would be headed for final ratification by Congress and the two Parliaments.
Even if the Canadian Government tries to ignore the matter or play it down, the treaty's opponents do not plan to let that happen.
Lloyd Axworthy, a Liberal Member of Parliament from Winnipeg, Manitoba, and a leader of the opposition to free trade in 1988, said, "We will be much better prepared this time."
The Conservatives then won 169 of the 295 seats in the House of Commons, but they did so with less than half the votes cast -- 43 percent out of 13.1 million. Under Canada's plurality system, a candidate need poll only one vote more than the runner-up to win a seat, no matter how many votes the other candidates amass. The fact that the Liberal and New Democrat parties, both of which oppose free trade, were able to pick up 53 percent combined is cited by free-trade opponents as a justification for continuing their struggle.
Maude Barlow, an adviser on women's issues during the early 1980's Liberal leadership of Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau, heads the Ottawa-based Council of Canadians, the chief lobby against free trade. She said her group would begin a campaign this fall to abrogate the 1989 pact "with brochures, buttons, cross-country tours, town hall meetings, the works" and is "forming alliances with like-minded organizations in the United States and Mexico, to bring our experiences to bear."
The free-trade opponents include a powerful coalition of labor and farm interests and social activists, who cite not only high joblessness (the latest unemployment rate was 11.6 percent of the labor force) but also what they see as greater American economic leverage over Canada and a resulting diminution of sovereignty.
Government officials insist that free trade is getting a bum rap.
"It's time to blow the whistle on the free- trade blame game," said Michael Wilson, Canada's International Trade Minister. "Despite the problems generated by a tough global recession, a spate of difficult disputes with the United States and a deep slide in public support for the free trade agreement in Canada, there is now clear evidence that the free trade agreement is working."
In addition to the University of Toronto, the O.E.C.D. and the International Monetary Fund studies, the Government points to a recent survey by a consulting firm, DRI Canada, that found 97 Canadian manufacturing industries gained or maintained their American market share in the last three years, while only 11 lost market share.
Also underscoring the gains from the pact, the Government statistics that show manufacturing output per person rising four-tenths of 1 percent in 1991 represent an exceptional gain for a recession year, economists say.
Every $1 billion of new Canadian exports translates into roughly 15,000 new jobs. Canada's exports rose to $103.4 billion in 1991, a 5 percent increase over 1989, according to Statistics Canada, still another sign that the pact may be working in Canada's favor.
Over the same period, Canada's trade surplus with the United States increased from $10.6 billion to $17.2 billion, which is about a third the level of Japan's.
In Mexico, Canada sees openings chiefly for exports of financial services and high-technology electronics and telecommunications. Some 200 Canadian companies showed up at a trade fair earlier this year at Monterrey, Mexico, and, according to the Canadian Trade Ministry, are filling their order books.
These companies represent the new competitive edge that Canada is getting in international trade. They have become so aggressive, said Mr. Wilson, the trade minister, that "they are not even waiting for the trade agreement."

Economic Scene; What's Different About This Slump

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]27 Dec 1991: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/428301155?accountid=11752

Abstract: Martin Feldstein, president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, says in his introduction to "The Risk of Economic Crisis," a book based on a conference of leading American economists: "Although the United States has been fortunate enough not to experience the kind of massive economic collapse that occurred from time to time until the worldwide depression of the 1930's, there is no doubt that the possibility of another such financial and economic crisis cannot be dismissed." Could it happen now? Like Mr. Feldstein, Mr. [Hyman P. Minsky] says it could. Through nearly all of the postwar period, the United States had "fiscal autonomy" -- the power to take policy actions without much concern about adverse foreign reactions to the widening deficits that sustained domestic profits. "The situation may be different now," he warns. "The United States no longer is as autonomous or as powerful as in the past. Scenarios in which cooperation in maintaining global asset values and profit flows is necessary but not forthcoming can be sketched." Foreigners now have enormous holdings of American financial assets. The big deficits the United States ran in relatively prosperous times would mean the deficit it would have to run to abort a financial crisis might be enormous. The interventions next time, Mr. Minsky says, "may well be beyond the combined efforts of the Federal Reserve and the Treasury." Containing a future financial and economic crisis, he says, "may depend more on what Japan and Europe do than upon the Fed and the U.S. Treasury."

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+What%27s+Different+About+This+Slump&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1991-12-27&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: WHAT was at first regarded by the Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve as a mild and brief recession has become a long and painful one, possibly even what some economists are calling a "quiet depression."
David M. Jones, chief economist of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, says this slump is distinguished from its postwar predecessors by a clash between a dangerously overleveraged economy and unusually severe bank loan stringency. "The threat posed is an all-out private-sector credit contraction and asset price deflation, accompanied by mounting corporate bankruptcies and bank failures," he said. "The resulting decline in consumer wealth could curtail spending for a prolonged period."
Is 1992 shaping up as the analogue of 1932, the year when the recession of 1930-31 collapsed into depression? Or do we know enough economics to stop that from ever happening again?
Martin Feldstein, president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, says in his introduction to "The Risk of Economic Crisis," a book based on a conference of leading American economists: "Although the United States has been fortunate enough not to experience the kind of massive economic collapse that occurred from time to time until the worldwide depression of the 1930's, there is no doubt that the possibility of another such financial and economic crisis cannot be dismissed."
In that book, Hyman P. Minsky, professor of economics at Washington University, concludes that the reason a vicious downward spiral has not yet led to depression in postwar America is that apt intervention by the Government and the central bank can abort the process leading to depression at two points. One comes when endangered financial institutions are at the point of selling off assets; the institutions can be refinanced to prevent a wave of sales and a sharp and general fall of asset prices. Refinancing banks and crucial financial players, he says, is the basic central bank lender-of-last-resort operation.
The other intervention point comes when profits start falling, and the Government can act to avert collapse. In the model Mr. Minsky uses, total profits equal investment plus the Government deficit. To sustain profits during a period of falling investment, the Government can run a larger deficit.
Why did the United States Government not do that after the crash of 1929? Mr. Minsky's answer is that the Federal Government then made up only 3 percent of gross national product -- too small to offset the impact that falling investment between 1929 and 1933 had upon corporate profits.
Today's Government, constituting some 25 percent of G.N.P., is large enough to sustain profits by increasing the deficit through automatic stabilizers or fiscal policy. The combination of lender-of-last-resort interventions and increasing Federal deficits, he says, "explains why a serious, long-lasting and deep depression has not taken place up until now."
But could it happen now? Like Mr. Feldstein, Mr. Minsky says it could. Through nearly all of the postwar period, the United States had "fiscal autonomy" -- the power to take policy actions without much concern about adverse foreign reactions to the widening deficits that sustained domestic profits. "The situation may be different now," he warns. "The United States no longer is as autonomous or as powerful as in the past. Scenarios in which cooperation in maintaining global asset values and profit flows is necessary but not forthcoming can be sketched."
Foreigners now have enormous holdings of American financial assets. The big deficits the United States ran in relatively prosperous times would mean the deficit it would have to run to abort a financial crisis might be enormous. The interventions next time, Mr. Minsky says, "may well be beyond the combined efforts of the Federal Reserve and the Treasury." Containing a future financial and economic crisis, he says, "may depend more on what Japan and Europe do than upon the Fed and the U.S. Treasury."
But, just when cooperation among the United States, Japan and Europe is more critical than ever, tensions among them are rising. The Uruguay Round of trade talks is in jeopardy. Germany and the United States are moving in opposite directions on monetary policy, with Germany following a tight-money, anti-inflation policy.
The Fed, with the year nearly over, moved to cut the discount rate by a full percentage point. And the Administration, at last publicly acknowledging that the recession was continuing, intensified its search for fiscal stimuli.
Both the Fed and the White House were driven by news of plant closings by General Motors and others, layoffs, the troubles of financial institutions, weak Christmas sales and the approaching cold dawn of the 1992 election year.
Thus, the United States is moving to head off a not-so-quiet depression, despite the big deficit and foreign constraints, and 1992 will prove whether the anti-depression economic medicine can work in an economy that has gone global. With its year-end surge, the stock market was betting that it would.

Economic Scene; 2 Key Statistics Are Due to Shift

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]18 Oct 1991: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/428243008?accountid=11752

Abstract: The first is an updated version of the price index used to correct G.N.P. for inflation, shifting the base year of the index to 1987 from 1982. Periodic updates of the "G.N.P. deflator" are necessary as inflation or deflation affects different goods differently over the years, and the mix of goods that make up total national output changes. A price deflator based on outdated weights for different goods and services would distort the calculation. Using the new 1987-base G.N.P. deflator, the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis finds in a preliminary study that instead of falling at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, as measured in constant 1982 dollars, real G.N.P. rose by four-tenths of 1 percent, when measured in 1987 dollars. Thus, G.D.P. measures the value of goods and services produced within the United States, while G.N.P. includes the profits or other income received by Americans overseas. Production by, say, Toyota or Siemens in plants in the United States is included in America's G.D.P., but I.B.M.'s or General Motors' earnings brought back from Japan or Germany do not count in United States G.D.P. although they do count in G.N.P.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+2+Key+Statistics+Are+Due+to+Shift&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1991-10-18&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: IS the American economy in a recovery, a recession or a no man's land? The answer is not easy to come by because economic statistics lag behind current events and because data on past growth or contraction are complex, crude and continually being revised.
For instance, the first estimate by the Commerce Department of real gross national product -- total output adjusted for inflation -- for the second quarter had the economy growing at an annual rate of four-tenths of 1 percent. Hats went off to hail the recovery. The second estimate moved that figure down to one-tenth of 1 percent, and some economists, including Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, said the recession was over but the recovery had not yet begun.
Then department's third revision put the growth rate of real G.N.P. down further, to minus five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, provoking worries that the economy was still in recession.
But that is not the end of the changing picture. Two new sets of data, to be released in late November, will indicate that the recovery did begin in the second quarter after all.
The first is an updated version of the price index used to correct G.N.P. for inflation, shifting the base year of the index to 1987 from 1982. Periodic updates of the "G.N.P. deflator" are necessary as inflation or deflation affects different goods differently over the years, and the mix of goods that make up total national output changes. A price deflator based on outdated weights for different goods and services would distort the calculation.
Using the new 1987-base G.N.P. deflator, the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis finds in a preliminary study that instead of falling at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, as measured in constant 1982 dollars, real G.N.P. rose by four-tenths of 1 percent, when measured in 1987 dollars.
When the department releases its first estimate of the just-completed third quarter on Oct. 29, real G.N.P. will still be measured on the old 1982 price base. The new figures for real G.N.P. on the 1987 price base will not be released until Nov. 26.
In addition to shifting from 1982 to 1987 dollars, the department's second change will be to emphasize gross domestic product, rather than gross national product, as the primary measure of the national economy. G.D.P. is already used by almost all countries as the main indicator of growth.
G.D.P. covers the goods and services "produced by labor and property located in the United States," while G.N.P. measures the market value of goods and services produced by property and labor "supplied by United States residents," whether the production is here or abroad.
Thus, G.D.P. measures the value of goods and services produced within the United States, while G.N.P. includes the profits or other income received by Americans overseas. Production by, say, Toyota or Siemens in plants in the United States is included in America's G.D.P., but I.B.M.'s or General Motors' earnings brought back from Japan or Germany do not count in United States G.D.P. although they do count in G.N.P.
G.D.P. is considered by the Commerce Department the better measure of what is happening within the American economy, since income flows to businesses or residents of this country from abroad are influenced mainly by economic developments in the rest of the world. No measure gives all one wants to know; the Commerce Department will continue to report on both G.D.P. and G.N.P.
Though new official data for G.D.P. will not be introduced until late November, preliminary estimates by the Commerce Department show that real G.D.P., measured in constant 1982 dollars, rose at an annual rate of 1.4 percent in the second quarter of 1991, even more than the revised figures for G.N.P. in 1987 dollars now indicate.
The evidence is that the recovery is in motion, but slow motion. An Experimental Index of Coincident Indicators, developed by the leading mapper of the business cycle, the National Burerau of Economic Research, points to continuing but slowing economic growth. This slowdown in the rise of the so-called X.C.I., the bureau says, reflects the modest growth in industrial production and the net declines in real personal income and employee-hours of work during July and August. The figures released yesterday by the Government on industrial production, capacity use, trade and inflation confirm this picture of a weakening recovery.
The economy is shaping up as the key election issue. This week President Bush narrowly defeated Democrats' efforts to override his veto of the bill to extend unemployment benefits, but called a meeting of Republican leaders to discuss tax cuts and other measures to spur the economy.

Subject: UNITED STATES ECONOMY

People: SILK, LEONARD

Title: Economic Scene; 2 Key Statistics Are Due to Shift

Publication title: New York Times, Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y.

Pages: D.2

Publication year: 1991

Publication date: Oct 18, 1991

Section: D

U.S. Aid to Israel: $77 Billion Since '67

Author: Bradsher, Keith

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]23 Sep 1991: A.10.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/428188770?accountid=11752

Abstract: Nearly three-quarters of Israel's aid consists of grants, according to figures from the Bank of Israel. Israel reduced its annual interest on the remaining $13 billion in loans by $150 million several years ago by refinancing at a lower interest rate, a privilege also made available then to 37 other American allies with weak economies. No Need for U.S. to Pay Israel is seeking the $10 billion in loan guarantees now to help resettle up to a million Jewish emigres expected by 1995. With the loan guarantees, banks would lend to Israel at reduced interest rates with the assurance that the United States would be responsible for any principal or interest payments that Israel could not make. Israel's credit rating is fairly good, and its officials say there would be no need for the United States to pay any money. Economic and military aid programs to Israel, without adjustment for inflation, totaled $47.8 billion from 1967 through last year, according to the figures from the Bank of Israel. But Israeli officials themselves pointed out that it would be more accurate to adjust for inflation. Using the consumer price index in the United States, the aid to Israel would be to $77 billion in 1991 dollars. Some Hard to Estimate

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=U.S.+Aid+to+Israel%3A+%2477+Billion+Since+%2767&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1991-09-23&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Bradsher%2C+Keith&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Special to The New York Times
The controversy over Israel's request for $10 billion in United States loan guarantees has focused wide attention on a large-scale but little-understood American aid effort that since 1967 has totaled at least $77 billion -- $16,500 for each Israeli citizen -- when adjusted for inflation.
American aid to Israel may actually be larger than that, since it consists not only of the well-known grants and loans that prop up the Israeli economy and bolster its military, but also seldom-noticed indirect assistance. This includes such items as huge transfers of surplus military equipment, subsidies for Israel's foreign aid program and assistance to refugees arriving from the Soviet Union, State Department and Congressional officials say.
Moreover, Israel alone among recipients of American aid receives its money at the beginning of each fiscal year, instead of in payments over the course of the year, allowing it to invest in United States Treasury securities and collect interest on the money until it is actually spent.
Nearly three-quarters of Israel's aid consists of grants, according to figures from the Bank of Israel. Israel reduced its annual interest on the remaining $13 billion in loans by $150 million several years ago by refinancing at a lower interest rate, a privilege also made available then to 37 other American allies with weak economies. No Need for U.S. to Pay
Israel is seeking the $10 billion in loan guarantees now to help resettle up to a million Jewish emigres expected by 1995. With the loan guarantees, banks would lend to Israel at reduced interest rates with the assurance that the United States would be responsible for any principal or interest payments that Israel could not make. Israel's credit rating is fairly good, and its officials say there would be no need for the United States to pay any money.
Israeli officials contend that without the guarantees their country would be unable to provide the housing and jobs needed to use fully the many skills of immigrants from the Soviet Union. The Israeli economy and imports from the United States would suffer, they contend.
But President Bush has insisted that granting the aid now would needlessly upset the Middle East peace process, and he has asked Congress to put off debate on the matter for four months.
The current political uproar has strengthened Congress's interest in examining the financial burden of the American relationship with Israel, which has not been well understood because Israel has tapped many sources outside the main foreign aid programs. List From State Department
Representative Lee H. Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who heads the House Subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East, said he had recently received a list of readily measured aid from the State Department totaling $4 billion for the fiscal year ending this month. The list separately included several programs with costs that are hard to estimate, partly because not all of the money in them had been spent, he said.
"So far as I know it's a comprehensive list, but things keep popping out," Mr. Hamilton said.
An Administration official who insisted on anonymity said "it's really an aid industry," in which no one keeps a full tally of the aid provided.
Mr. Hamilton, Congressional aides and Israeli officials stressed that the United States received much in return for its assistance. Israel has been the nation's main military partner for decades in a region both vital to United States interests and highly unstable.
The $300 million for the stockpiling of American military equipment in Israel, for example, could not be labeled solely as aid to that country, since it is very advantageous to the United States to be able to store its gear there, Mr. Hamilton said.
Economic and military aid programs to Israel, without adjustment for inflation, totaled $47.8 billion from 1967 through last year, according to the figures from the Bank of Israel. But Israeli officials themselves pointed out that it would be more accurate to adjust for inflation. Using the consumer price index in the United States, the aid to Israel would be to $77 billion in 1991 dollars. Some Hard to Estimate
The programs that are hard to estimate include up to $700 million in surplus military equipment, most of it from American forces being withdrawn from Europe, that is to be turned over to Israel; $400 million in loan guarantees; $150 million in annual interest savings from the refinancing of United States military loans five years ago; $300 million for eventual stockpiles of American equipment in Israel; $60 million in price reductions for military equipment sales and $42 million for a joint air defense development program.
Israel's request for $10 billion in loan guarantees would not involve any immediate outlay for the United States. But under a new law that takes effect on Oct. 1, Congress would have to set aside some money to reflect the risk of potential defaults.
Congress's current budget rules also impose a cap on international spending, including foreign aid. Depending on how different types of aid are categorized, this means that Congress could be confronted with a difficult choice this year on how to divide up limited money among Israel, the Soviet Union and other candidates for American assistance.
The proposed $10 billion in loan guarantees for the resettlement of Soviet Jews in Israel would be much more generous than Mr. Bush's $1.5 billion agricultural loan guarantee program to feed the Soviet Union. The food loan program only guarantees 98 percent of the principal and the first 4.5 percentage points of interest. Banks Are Reluctant
Commercial banks have been reluctant to take part in this program for fear of losing the unguaranteed part of any loans.
By contrast, Israeli officials want their guarantees to cover all of the loans' principal and all of the interest. Because existing American loan guarantee programs do not have such generous terms, a new program would probably have to be created for Israel, Congressional aides said.
American loan guarantees could save Israel as much as $200 million a year in interest payments, said John F. H. Purcell, the director of the sovereign research group at Salomon Brothers Inc. This is because Israel has a BBB credit rating, forcing it to borrow at an interest rate that is 2 percentage points higher than the rate for United States Government-guaranteed debt, he said.
Such a calculation assumes that Israel would be able to borrow the money at all without the guarantees and without lowering its credit rating, which would result in higher interest rates. "Anybody but the very large countries would have trouble borrowing $10 billion," Mr. Purcell agreed.
Israeli officials estimate that with the guarantees they could borrow as much as $2 billion a year for five years, while without them they would be limited to $500 million a year.
Graph "Aid to Israel" shows U.S. Government cash and loans to Israel from '67 to '90 (Source: Bank of Israel)

Economic Scene; U.S. Will Press Plan for Growth In London Talks

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]05 July 1991: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/428146058?accountid=11752

Abstract: In describing his overall strategy, Mr. [Nicholas F. Brady] said, "When I first raised it last April, I was cast as a Johnny one-note." The "one note" heard by his critics in the United States and abroad was his call for lower interest rates. Foreign governments and publications said the United States had shown itself to be, as The Economist put it, "incapable of wise leaderhip." Many blamed Mr. Brady for trying to force monetary expansion at the risk of reigniting inflation. "The banking system is less strong," he said. "Are certain banks in trouble? Of course. Bigger banks? Yes!" But the mistakes of the 1980's, he said, should not deter us from moving ahead, "so that we're creating jobs, increasing investment." Affirming that "a strategy of hope is important," Mr. Brady drew a comparison with what he is proposing for the world economy and with the policy taken vis-a-vis Mexico, which, he said, is moving ahead economically "by marrying the Brady Plan for reducing Mexico's foreign debt with President Salinas's progress in opening up markets."

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+U.S.+Will+Press+Plan+for+Growth+In+London+Talks&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1991-07-05&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: IN an interview on Wednesday, the Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, said that at the London economic summit conference of the seven major industrial countries later this month, the United States would press for a "three-pronged strategy" to lift the world economy out of stagnation and help rescue the economies of the fledgling democracies of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
At the end of the meeting of the rich industrial countries, Mikhail S. Gorbachev will arrive for talks on reconstruction, trade and aid, first with President Bush and then with the other Western leaders.
These are three elements in the United States strategy for the meeting that Mr. Brady described:
* A more dynamic monetary policy aimed at bringing down real interest rates -- what money really costs borrowers after allowing for inflation -- to stimulate economic growth and yield more employment, income and a higher rate of capital formation for a world desperately short of capital.
* An international trade policy focused on the successful completion of the current round of negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The talks are aimed at opening markets in all countries and breaking down regional barriers to the flow of goods, including agricultural products and textiles, as well as services and intellectual property.
* The elimination of structural rigidities hampering job creation and productivity growth within countries, whether capitalist, socialist or still struggling in the transition from Communism to a market economy.
In describing his overall strategy, Mr. Brady said, "When I first raised it last April, I was cast as a Johnny one-note." The "one note" heard by his critics in the United States and abroad was his call for lower interest rates. Foreign governments and publications said the United States had shown itself to be, as The Economist put it, "incapable of wise leaderhip." Many blamed Mr. Brady for trying to force monetary expansion at the risk of reigniting inflation.
Now Mr. Brady is seeking to put his quest for lower interest rates in a broader context and to reply to the charge that he is soft on inflation. "The economists always insist that we must have non-inflationary growth," he said, while he prefers to talk in terms of low-inflationary growth.
Mr. Brady is doubtful, as was the late Prof. Sumner Slichter of Harvard in the early post-World War II period, that zero inflation and vigorous growth are compatible. Like Professor Slichter's position, Mr. Brady's is regarded by many conservatives as not just heretical but, far worse, undeliverable and unstable. The acceptance of even low inflation is likely to lead to a much higher rate of inflation, the critics say.
In the 1950's and early 1960's, however, low inflation -- by Professor Slichter's definition, 2 percent a year -- did prove consistent with strong economic growth in the United States. In the 15 years from 1950 through 1964, real economic growth in the United States averaged 4 percent a year. With the escalation of the Vietnam War in the mid-1960's and the failure of the Johnson Administration to cut domestic spending or raise taxes to pay for the war and the Great Society, the compatibility of low inflation with high growth was shattered.
Mr. Brady believes that the world's economic leaders need greater confidence and should concentrate on positive goals, like growth and open world trade, rather than being hamstrung by negatives like fear of inflation and unemployment.
He did not try to defend all the policies that had produced economic growth and financial boom in the 1980's. On the contrary, he was highly critical of the wave of leveraged buyouts of corporations in the United States and excessive debt creation.
"The banking system is less strong," he said. "Are certain banks in trouble? Of course. Bigger banks? Yes!" But the mistakes of the 1980's, he said, should not deter us from moving ahead, "so that we're creating jobs, increasing investment."
Affirming that "a strategy of hope is important," Mr. Brady drew a comparison with what he is proposing for the world economy and with the policy taken vis-a-vis Mexico, which, he said, is moving ahead economically "by marrying the Brady Plan for reducing Mexico's foreign debt with President Salinas's progress in opening up markets."
He said that in convincing Mexicans, including expatriates as well as foreigners, that Mexico meant business and that debt reduction would work, what critics regarded as the missing element in the formulation of the plan -- money -- was flowing into the country. Mr. Brady said the inflow to Mexico of expatriate capital would rise this year to $14 billion from $4 billion last year.
Mr. Brady said he believed other governments were "getting the message" that he has been trying to deliver for a comprehensive growth-oriented strategy, including reductions in interest rates. He called attention to the Bank of Japan's half-point cut in its discount rate, its benchmark rate of interest, to 5.5 percent on Monday. Japan had been holding interest rates high to wring inflation out of the economy.
Mr. Brady said he also saw evidence that Britain, Italy, Spain and Denmark were moving to lower-rate policies. He was more equivocal about Germany, where Karl-Otto Pohl has resigned as head of the Bundesbank to be replaced by another monetary hard-liner, Helmut Schlesinger. Timothy Deal, a member of the National Security Council who is helping to prepare the United States position for the London summit meeting, said he thought the Germans were still adamant about their rate policies.
Mr. Brady's line on the urgency of growth appears to be gaining international support. This week, the United Nations World Economic Survey for 1991 predicted that global economic growth this year would be zero and would rise in 1992 to only 2 percent -- barely enough to keep pace with population growth. And the U.N. declared: "In various industrialized countries, the monetary authorities feel that output growth over 2 or 3 percent a year would be inflationary and must be restrained. As long as this view prevails, these nations cannot serve their historic role as an engine of world economic growth."
The survey concluded that the present mix of monetary and fiscal policy seems to express political priorities in which unemployment is an acceptable price for containing inflation, "and high real interest rates are welcomed even at the expense of growth, at least in the short term." If such policies continue, the report said, "the more dynamic international economic environment needed for a shorter adjustment in the developing countries and a less costly transition in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union will not materialize."
This will be not only the United Nations' but the United States' line at the summit meeting in London. Mr. Brady said that as he saw it, a strategy for regenerating growth is the most important item on the summit's agenda.
Photograph Part of the United States strategy at the London economic summit meeting will be to call for lower interest rates, according to the Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

Economic Scene; Trade Bloc War? Concern Grows

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]26 Apr 1991: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/428053700?accountid=11752

Abstract: Mr. [Jacques Delors] seeks to blame the United States for this. He said he had told President Bush that if the United States continued its "negative" approach, in an attempt to paint the European Community as "the bad guy of the world," the talks would fail. "Bush understands that," Mr. Delors said. "We cannot negotiate under these circumstances." The Bush Administration regards this as evasion. It denies that it has taken an antagonistic line toward Europe on trade. The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, "has said nothing mean," said her spokesman, Timothy O'Leary. He said Mr. Delors was "trying to divert attention from the real issue -- outrageously high European agricultural subsidies." "It will depend on the mood," he said.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+Trade+Bloc+War%3F+Concern+Grows&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1991-04-26&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: IS the world economy headed for a split into three warring trade blocs -- Europe, North America and East Asia?
"Not if we succeed in the Uruguay Round," said Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, during a discussion in New York this week. Named for the country where the current trade negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade began in 1986, the Uruguay Round broke down in December over Europe's refusal to yield to American demands for drastic cuts in farm subsidies.
Efforts to get the trade talks back on track are going on. But the most formidable obstacle to their success -- European resistance to lower subsidies -- has not been removed.
Mr. Delors seeks to blame the United States for this. He said he had told President Bush that if the United States continued its "negative" approach, in an attempt to paint the European Community as "the bad guy of the world," the talks would fail. "Bush understands that," Mr. Delors said. "We cannot negotiate under these circumstances."
The Bush Administration regards this as evasion. It denies that it has taken an antagonistic line toward Europe on trade. The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, "has said nothing mean," said her spokesman, Timothy O'Leary. He said Mr. Delors was "trying to divert attention from the real issue -- outrageously high European agricultural subsidies."
Do the American negotiators see any sign that the Europeans are willing to change their position? "There's nothing yet," Mr. O'Leary said. And what about the future? "It will depend on the mood," he said.
But Mr. Delors said he thought there was "a better mood" ahead for discussing agriculture. "I share the fears of many economists and politicians about a world divided into many blocs," he said.
This view represents a growing awareness that the United States is moving to establish its own regional trade bloc and is prepared to take unilateral action against countries that it deems to be discriminating against American exports.
Following the free-trade agreement with Canada, the Bush Administration is moving aggressively to negotiate a wide-ranging free-trade agreement with Mexico. The Administration faces opposition from labor and environmental groups but is being strongly supported by a coalition of business interests favoring the pact and supporting the Administration's request for "fast track" negotiating authority, which requires that trade agreements be voted up or down by Congress without amendment.
Two motions are now before Congress to end that fast-track authority. But President Bush intends to submit a plan to Congress within the next week to protect workers' rights and the environment to safeguard the Mexican agreement and fast-track bargaining authority. The Administration thinks it has too much at stake to let the Mexican agreement fail.
It believes that the deal is the key to stronger economic growth on both sides of the border. And if the Mexican deal goes through, the Administration means to negotiate a similar free-trade arrangement with Chile and later with other Latin American countries.
Skeptics wonder whether the effort to build an American regional bloc makes sense. Prof. Jagdish Bhagwati of Columbia University calls American regionalism "an empty threat" to the European Community.
In a forthcoming article in Foreign Affairs, he declares: "It is not credible that the United States would shoot itself in the foot, and indeed higher up, by sidetracking her energies and her trade to a region whose fragile democracies, inflations, debts and slow growth rates offer a far less attractive market than the burgeoning Far East and the European Community, both of which are even now more substantial markets for American exports. If the United States turns foolishly away from the world to her own backyard, the European Community's likely reaction would be: fine, get buried in it."
That may be an overstatement. There is full awareness, both here and abroad, how vital to the economic growth of every country expanding world trade has been, and what a threat to future growth would be posed by a splitting off of the United States, Europe and East Asia into hostile regional trading blocs.
If the Uruguay Round fails, the largest German bank, the Deutsche Bank, states in its Bulletin, "the current trend toward inward-looking trading blocs will probably accelerate, and trade conflicts will multiply."
No country wants that outcome, knowing that it could breed recession or depression. Regionalism, based on internal free-trade principles, can contribute to the welfare of the Americas, Europe and East Asia, but only if each region is open to other regions and nations.

Subject: INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; CROP CONTROLS AND SUBSIDIES; AGRICULTURE; URUGUAY ROUND (TRADE TALKS)

FUTURES/OPTIONS; Oil-Related Inflation Fears Push Gold Prices Up Again

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]26 Oct 1990: D.17.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427832083?accountid=11752

Abstract: Gold futures settled $2.30 to $2.40 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for spot delivery at $375.80 a troy ounce, up from $373.50 on Wednesday. "The war drums were beating today," said William O'Neill, a precious metals expert with Merrill Lynch. Speculation about possible Soviet purchases of United States corn cooled amid reports from Moscow indicating the Soviets might not make any more purchases to fulfill a one-million-ton corn agreement by the end of the year without United States credit.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=FUTURES%2FOPTIONS%3B+Oil-Related+Inflation+Fears+Push+Gold+Prices+Up+Again&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1990-10-26&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.17&amp;au=The+Associated+Press&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Gold prices continued to climb yesterday as the resurgent oil market fanned inflation fears.
But platinum prices dropped sharply, reflecting declining Japanese investor interest and worldwide economic jitters.
Gold futures settled $2.30 to $2.40 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for spot delivery at $375.80 a troy ounce, up from $373.50 on Wednesday.
The increase marked gold's sixth daily advance in the last seven sessions, following a plunge to a three-month low of $360 on Oct. 16.
Silver futures settled 1.9 cents to 2 cents lower, with the spot price at $4.204 a troy ounce in lackluster trading on the Commodity Exchange.
Platinum was $6.60 to $8 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with the spot price at $415.80 a troy ounce.
Analysts said demand for gold had increased as a result of lower prices for the metal and higher prices this week for crude oil, which has bounced back sharply amid intensifying Middle East war rhetoric.
"The war drums were beating today," said William O'Neill, a precious metals expert with Merrill Lynch.
Higher oil prices could portend higher inflation, which typically spurs investor demand for gold.
Higher oil prices also could tip industrialized nations into recession and reduce industrial demand for platinum, which is widely used in automobile pollution-control systems.
James Steel, an oil and metals analyst with Refco Inc., a commodities brokerage, said platinum was also under pressure from lower Japanese stock prices. The Japanese value platinum as an investment and jewelry metal.
In petroleum trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light, sweet crude oil settled $2 to $3.17 higher, with December at $34.25 a barrel.
Grain and soybean futures prices fell modestly in light trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting slack export demand and harvest pressure.
Speculation about possible Soviet purchases of United States corn cooled amid reports from Moscow indicating the Soviets might not make any more purchases to fulfill a one-million-ton corn agreement by the end of the year without United States credit.

Let's Get Serious About Pentagon Cuts

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]16 Feb 1990: A.34.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427542486?accountid=11752

Abstract: I am puzzled by Irving Kristol's arithmetic in ''There Is No Military Free Lunch'' (Op-Ed, Feb. 2). He states that fixing the United States military budget at its current level would mean that, in 10 years, its buying power would be about 33 percent less than now - a fair projection, given the rate of inflation. Mr. Kristol states that the United States military establishment will then ''probably be slightly superior to Japan's, though perhaps not quite a match for Syria's tanks and air power.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Let%27s+Get+Serious+About+Pentagon+Cuts%3A+%5BLetter%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1990-02-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.34&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: To the Editor:
To the Editor:
I am puzzled by Irving Kristol's arithmetic in ''There Is No Military Free Lunch'' (Op-Ed, Feb. 2). He states that fixing the United States military budget at its current level would mean that, in 10 years, its buying power would be about 33 percent less than now - a fair projection, given the rate of inflation.
But Mr. Kristol states that the United States military establishment will then ''probably be slightly superior to Japan's, though perhaps not quite a match for Syria's tanks and air power.''
Now Japan spends about 1 percent of gross national product on defense, the United States more than 6 percent. Our G.N.P. is almost double Japan's; hence, we must be spending 10 to 12 times as much. Even if United States expenditures decline one-third in constant dollars, as Mr. Kristol projects, they would be seven to eight times current Japanese expenditures. Slightly superior? Is the real problem how much the United States spends on the military or how efficiently it uses the funds?
The comparison with Syria is even more ludicrous. The Syrian military is inferior to that of Israel, a country whose gross national product is a tiny fraction of the American and which must also contend with the Palestinian uprising and with threats on its Lebanese border.
Such scare projections, designed to protect the military budget at the expense of other needed programs, deflect from a reasoned consideration of just how much defense spending can be cut in the new international situation.
>SEYMOUR MAXWELL FINGER

New York, Feb. 2, 1990

The writer is senior fellow, Ralph Bunche Institute, CUNY Graduate School and University Center.
