Full text: LEAD: The consumer price index jumped 0.5 percentage points in October, indicating a 5.9 percent annual rate of inflation. The Federal Reserve Board has said it wants to keep inflation low. But with a weakening economy, its ability to stem inflation is limited. Four economists assess inflation and the Federal Reserve's next move.
The consumer price index jumped 0.5 percentage points in October, indicating a 5.9 percent annual rate of inflation. The Federal Reserve Board has said it wants to keep inflation low. But with a weakening economy, its ability to stem inflation is limited. Four economists assess inflation and the Federal Reserve's next move. Francis Schott Chief economist, Equitable Life Assurance Society.
The underlying inflation pressure - because of wage and cost problems - is still upward. Nevertheless, the 1990 inflation rate will be 4.5 percent, the same as in 1989.
The Fed would like to assist the economy, which is slowing, yet it has to continue fighting inflation, which at 4.5 percent is still too high. The solution to the dilemma is a very gradual easing of interest rates which will continue to 1990.
The Fed funds rate will come down another quarter percentage point to 8.25 by year-end. The prime rate will be down to at least 10 percent by year-end. During the first half of next year, the Fed funds will be 7.5 and the prime will be 9.5 or even lower. Pat Choate Economist and vice president, policy analysis, TRW Inc.
The ability of the Fed to make dramatic cuts in interest rates is severely constrained. The Federal budget deficit swirls along and there is no prospect of shrinking it before 1991. This continues to give the economy a very massive Keynesian stimulus. In addition, the continuing demand for imports is bidding up import prices and the dramatic availability of credit won't help keep inflation low.
I think the Fed will stand pat on interest rates. The Fed wants to cut inflation to zero. They will keep rates where they are, and I think that's the right thing to do. Inflation is still very troubling for the economy. Leif Olsen President, Leif Olsen Associates, an economics consulting firm.
The pickup in inflation in October's numbers isn't that significant. I fully expect that the next consumer price index will show a substantially slower rate of inflation. If you average the numbers, you can't conclude that inflation is accelerating. However, October retail sales are down 1.5 percentage points, the sharpest decline in two years, and personal consumption expenditures will be down for October as well. Throughout the year it has been difficult to achieve sales gains in durable and non-durable goods without price discounting. This indicates less inflation and slower growth.
The Fed will ease the funds rate one-fourth percent between now and early December depending on how slow the employment gains are. If we get surprisingly slow employment gains, we could also get a discount rate reduction as well. The prime rate will move when the Fed moves. Lacy Hunt Chief economist, Carroll, McEntee & McGinley Inc.
The inflation rate appears to be heading above 5 percent, perhaps up to 5.5 percent for the next year. First of all, wages are accelerating and will be given a boost by the minimum wage law. Productivity growth remains poor, meaning that the wage increases will be passed on in higher prices. Unleashing 450 million consumers behind the Iron Curtain suggests that there will be upward pressure on food prices. One of the big offsets to inflation has been oil prices, but now it appears that oil prices are headed upward. Reinforcing this is the fact that gold has risen above $400 an ounce - a 10-month high - and other commodities are going up as well.
If there is going to be a further easing in interest rates by the Fed, it has to be now. The economy will be stronger in the first part of the year. This quarter's gross national product grew by 1.4 percent. But this quarter absorbed two major natural disasters and two long strikes. Long-term interest rates will be down by one percentage point next year while growth will be at a 3 percent or better rate.

BUSINESS FORUM: FORECASTING INFLATION; 'P-Star' Can Spot Inflationary Trends

Author: Lee, L Douglas; L. Douglas Lee is vice president and chief economist of County NatWest/Washington Analysis Corporation, part of the NatWest Banking Group.

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]22 Oct 1989: A.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427389650?accountid=11752

Abstract: LEAD: Recent work at the Federal Reserve board, christened P-Star analysis, has stimulated a renewed debate about the relationship between the money supply and inflation. This new work is based on the earlier work of Irving Fisher, which he conducted evidence, and concluded that the P-Star concept is helpful in understanding inflation. If a concept is really helpful in understanding the workings of a capitalist economy, then it should be helpful when applied to any particular capitalist economy. To ascertain whether P-Star is equally useful outside of the United states, my colleagues and I examined the concept as a predictive tool in a number of different countries. We applied P-Star analysis to the United States, Britain, Japan and Australia. For each country, we found that the P-Star concept is useful in understanding the relationship between the money supply and inflation. It is our conclusion that P-Star is not foolproof. But neither is any other tool of economic analysis. Its results are sensitive to assumptions about economic growth, money velocity, and money growth, and it is most useful in judging the long-run forces influencing inflation. Having said that it is not perfect, however, it is also worth saying that the P-Star analysis is a useful addition to the tools that help us better understand the workings of the economy. In short, P-Star travels well.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=BUSINESS+FORUM%3A+FORECASTING+INFLATION%3B+%27P-Star%27+Can+Spot+Inflationary+Trends&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1989-10-22&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;au=Lee%2C+L+Douglas%3BL.+Douglas+Lee+is+vice+president+and+chief+economist+of+County+NatWest%2FWashington+Analysis+Corporation%2C+part+of+the+NatWest+Banking+Group.&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: Recent work at the Federal Reserve board, christened P-Star analysis, has stimulated a renewed debate about the relationship between the money supply and inflation. This new work is based on the earlier work of Irving Fisher, which he conducted evidence, and concluded that the P-Star concept is helpful in understanding inflation.
Recent work at the Federal Reserve board, christened P-Star analysis, has stimulated a renewed debate about the relationship between the money supply and inflation. This new work is based on the earlier work of Irving Fisher, which he conducted evidence, and concluded that the P-Star concept is helpful in understanding inflation.
Members of the Federal Reserve and its staff have been very careful in describing the usefulness of the P-Star concept. This is not a short-term forecasting tool that will predict next month's consumer price index. Nor will it provide simple answers to the policy choices central bankers must make.
What P-Star will do is provide a reasonably useful guide to whether inflation should be expected to speed up or slow down over the next 6 to 12 months. It can serve as an indicator of inflation over this period of time, provided there are no shocks to the system, like a major oil price change, and provided the current trends continue with respect to growth and the velocity of money - the number of times each unit of money is used to purchase the nation's output of goods and services each year.
After reviewing the Federal Reserve's analysis and agreeing that it provides a useful approach to understanding the relationship between the money supply and inflation, one is left wondering how well P-Star will travel. Can it be applied to other countries?
If a concept is really helpful in understanding the workings of a capitalist economy, then it should be helpful when applied to any particular capitalist economy. To ascertain whether P-Star is equally useful outside of the United states, my colleagues and I examined the concept as a predictive tool in a number of different countries. We applied P-Star analysis to the United States, Britain, Japan and Australia. For each country, we found that the P-Star concept is useful in understanding the relationship between the money supply and inflation.
Applying empirical tests to any economic theory is always a tricky proposition, but this is even more true when the theory is tested for different countries.
Capitalism is the common denominator, but each economy has its own characteristics. Definitions of commonly used terms, like money supply, vary. Measurements are made differently and data are aggregated differently. In some cases, financial instruments in one country do not have an exact counterpart in another.
With this standard in mind, we have reached conclusions about the outlook for inflation in each of the countries we examined. What makes these conclusions so interesting is that in each case P-Star analysis confirms the results of our inflation analysis based on traditional methods using real growth, wage trends, capital costs, resource costs, and so on.
In the case of Japan, our economists have concluded that the P-Star analysis is useful, provided transitory shocks like the oil crisis and the recently imposed 3 percent consumption tax are excluded. This work suggests that inflation in Japan has probably peaked as these special factors boosting inflation work through the system.
For Britain, there appears to be an unusually long time lag between changes in the actual rate of inflation and changes in the expected rate of inflation. Our analysis suggests that the current policy that has resulted in 14 percent interest rates and a sharp slowdown in the growth of the money supply is not excessive. However, it will have to be maintained for some time before the inflation outlook improves.
In Australia, the leveling out in the growth of the money supply since the end of 1988 points to the likelihood that there will be a lower inflation rate for 1990 and 1991.
No matter which country is used for the P-Star analysis, however, a healthy dose of caution is appropriate. It is quite possible that the stock of money outstanding in the world is large enough to maintain inflation's current momentum. In other words, there is still a substantial amount of liquidity in the global economy that was accumulated during 1987 and 1988 and that could cause inflation problems. Central bankers must continue to be alert to this possibility as they develop their policies.
It is our conclusion that P-Star is not foolproof. But neither is any other tool of economic analysis. Its results are sensitive to assumptions about economic growth, money velocity, and money growth, and it is most useful in judging the long-run forces influencing inflation. Having said that it is not perfect, however, it is also worth saying that the P-Star analysis is a useful addition to the tools that help us better understand the workings of the economy. In short, P-Star travels well.

People: Fisher, Irving LEE, L DOUGLAS

Company: FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM

Economic Scene; Dollar Anxiety At White House

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]06 Oct 1989: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427408449?accountid=11752

Abstract: Similarly, the Bush Administration started out by passively watching the dollar climb from 123 to 145 Japanese yen and from 1.7 to 1.95 against the German mark - until shortly before last week's Group of Seven meeting. Does that constitute a ''Plaza II'' commitment, in the phrase of C. Fred Bergsten of the Institute of International Economics? Or is it only a temporary convenience? The markets don't believe this is Plaza II. Shafiqul Islam, the senior fellow for international finance on the Council on Foreign Relations, said, ''The markets are confused - they see the United States only half-committed to stabilizing exchange rates, acting in a sense of crisis, but unsure what the real problem is.'' The European and Japanese governments also continue to doubt that the United States is yet prepared to take the hard, fundamental steps needed to restore strength to the dollar. Mr. Islam says, ''They are asking, 'If the United States doesn't fix its own policy, why should others support the U.S.?' '' Thus, the chronic United States budget deficits, low savings rates, and high costs of capital are forces that underlie what Budget Director Richard G. Darman calls ''now-now-ism,'' the fevered search of Americans for deals with immediate payoffs. Dollar depreciation may be the unavoidable consequence of fiscal deficits, payments deficits, high interest rates and a loss of national competitiveness, but cannot provide a lasting cure for those ills, as the poor experiences of other debt-ridden countries have amply demonstrated.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+Dollar+Anxiety+At+White+House&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1989-10-06&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: THE Bush Administration, concerned about the rising dollar, appears to have ended its ''benign neglect'' for the time being and is working with other governments to push the currency down.
THE Bush Administration, concerned about the rising dollar, appears to have ended its ''benign neglect'' for the time being and is working with other governments to push the currency down.
Yesterday, help came from abroad when the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, raised its key discount and Lombard rates a full percentage point and sold a lot of dollars. Other European central banks followed and the dollar fell - but briefly, and then went up again. The foreign-exchange markets had expected the move and had already factored it in. The markets remain uncertain, however, over how committed the United States and its partners in the Group of Seven, most importantly West Germany and Japan, are to pushing the dollar down, and holding it down, against market forces that have been pushing it up.
The Bush Administration lacks credibility on its dollar policy. From the time it took office until just before last week's meetings in Washington of the International Monetary Fund and the Group of Seven, the Bush Administration had reverted to the benign neglect of the dollar followed by President Reagan's first Treasury Secretary, Donald T. Regan. In the second Reagan term, James A. Baker 3d moved to the Treasury and set the dollar on a downward course, fearful at last that the soaring dollar, once hailed as a mark of strength, was ruining the nation's trade position.
Similarly, the Bush Administration started out by passively watching the dollar climb from 123 to 145 Japanese yen and from 1.7 to 1.95 against the German mark - until shortly before last week's Group of Seven meeting. Does that constitute a ''Plaza II'' commitment, in the phrase of C. Fred Bergsten of the Institute of International Economics? Or is it only a temporary convenience?
If market forces - and psychology - continued to drive the dollar up, it could again undermine American exports, suck in a rising tide of imports, aggravate protectionist pressures and drag the United States into recession.
The White House, apart from its dollar anxieties, also wanted lower interest rates for domestic reasons, to ward off recession and spur economic growth, and had been leaning on the Fed to deliver lower rates. The Germans, for their part, were worried that a rising dollar - and falling mark -would intensify inflationary pressures in their country and throughout Europe. But the Japanese are not yet ready to go along.
And the markets don't believe this is Plaza II. Shafiqul Islam, the senior fellow for international finance on the Council on Foreign Relations, said, ''The markets are confused - they see the United States only half-committed to stabilizing exchange rates, acting in a sense of crisis, but unsure what the real problem is.'' The European and Japanese governments also continue to doubt that the United States is yet prepared to take the hard, fundamental steps needed to restore strength to the dollar. Mr. Islam says, ''They are asking, 'If the United States doesn't fix its own policy, why should others support the U.S.?' ''
More important than rhetoric to talk the dollar down, central bank intervention or even coordinated manipulation of rates is whether the United States is prepared to deal with the budget deficit. It lies at the root of the trade deficit, the savings shortage, the dependence on foreign capital and the high interest rates that push the dollar up.
As Ronald McKinnon of Stanford University observes, in a highly open economy only fiscal policy, which operates directly on the balance between savings and investment, can reduce a deficit in trade and the balance of payments. In the 1980's, he says, the American fiscal deficit created a savings deficiency, which has not been repaired.
The now-widening United States budget deficit, partly disguised by putting the savings and loan bailout and other items ''off budget'' while putting the Social Security trust-fund surplus on budget, threatens to keep the American trade position weak and increases the ultimate risk of future dollar devaluation.
With that risk of devaluation - and the fear that it will result in higher inflation - investors demand higher yields on dollar assets than on those denominated in yen or marks. The high-risk premiums built into United States interest rates shorten the time horizons of American business.
Thus, the chronic United States budget deficits, low savings rates, and high costs of capital are forces that underlie what Budget Director Richard G. Darman calls ''now-now-ism,'' the fevered search of Americans for deals with immediate payoffs. Dollar depreciation may be the unavoidable consequence of fiscal deficits, payments deficits, high interest rates and a loss of national competitiveness, but cannot provide a lasting cure for those ills, as the poor experiences of other debt-ridden countries have amply demonstrated.

BUSINESS FOURM: GETTING TOUGH ON TRADE; Give Japan a Target and Say 'Import!'

Author: Dornbusch, Rudiger; Rudiger Dornbusch is a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]24 Sep 1989: A.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427353140?accountid=11752

Abstract: LEAD: Japanese tariff rates are only 6.4 percent, even lower than those of the United States, Canada or the European Community. But even so,, gaining market access in Japan is an experience not unlike attaining justice in Franz Kafka's novel ''The Trial.'' Japanese tariff rates are only 6.4 percent, even lower than those of the United States, Canada or the European Community. But even so,, gaining market access in Japan is an experience not unlike attaining justice in Franz Kafka's novel ''The Trial.'' Japanese companies might also locate in the United States to produce ''Japanese'' goods for sale in Japan and thus meet the import test. There is no problem with Japanese investment in the United States; we are interested in ''good jobs at good wages'' and American-located production. Whether the employer is an American or Japanese company is almost irrelevant. Of course, trade growth targets have to be based on exports of products with substantial American content.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=BUSINESS+FOURM%3A+GETTING+TOUGH+ON+TRADE%3B+Give+Japan+a+Target+and+Say+%27Import%21%27&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1989-09-24&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;au=Dornbusch%2C+Rudiger%3BRudiger+Dornbusch+is+a+professor+of+economics+at+the+Massachusetts+Institute+of+Technology&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: Japanese tariff rates are only 6.4 percent, even lower than those of the United States, Canada or the European Community. But even so,, gaining market access in Japan is an experience not unlike attaining justice in Franz Kafka's novel ''The Trial.''
Japanese tariff rates are only 6.4 percent, even lower than those of the United States, Canada or the European Community. But even so,, gaining market access in Japan is an experience not unlike attaining justice in Franz Kafka's novel ''The Trial.''
To the charge of a closed market, Japanese officials use one of two responses. Either they assert that Japan is not closed at all - but that Japanese consumers are special. Or they argue that perhaps there were difficulties in the past, but all that has changed and Japan is opening up vigorously.
Neither is true. Industrialized countries, without exception, show major increases in import penetration over time. But in Japan the ratio of manufactured imports to gross national product has stayed at about 2 percent over the last 20 years.
Japanese officials are quick to claim that Japan has been making strides in market opening. They make much of the fact that manufactured goods already account for more than half of imports, far above the share in the 1970's. But the rising share of manufactured goods is only the mirror image of the fall in oil and commodity prices in the 1980's and not the result of a sharp rise in manufactured imports. Growth of two-way trade in manufactures - common elsewhere because consumers like variety - has not happened in Japan.
It does not really matter for our purposes what causes Japan's imports to be low. There is no question that import discrimination exists. But the resulting cost of protection on Japanese consumers is their own problem, not ours. Even so, their discrimination hurts our export companies and that is unacceptable in an open trading system.
A new American trade policy toward Japan is now required. Where negotiations at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and diplomacy have failed, the Super 301 provision of the 1988 trade law offers a means to force recognition of American trade interests in the world market.
The Super 301 route should be used to increase American market penetration in Japan. A target should be set based on the growth rate of Japanese imports of American manufactured goods. Japan should be required to increase its imports of manufactured goods from the United States at an average rate of at least 15 percent per year, with adjustments for inflation in each country. Assuming a 5 percent growth rate in Japan, the import share of American manufactured goods in the Japanese market would thus rise from 0.7 percent to 1.7 percent over a 10-year period.
There ought to be an effective sanction mechanism, automatic and forceful enough to initiate a timely and complete Japanese understanding that adjustment is now required or else access to the American market will be blocked. A suitable mechanism is an automatic tariff surcharge on Japanese exports to the United States. The surcharge would be triggered automatically in proportion to any shortfall of the Japanese import growth target. Early fulfillment of the target would halt the process.
Such a policy raises a number of issues. Japan might simply shift demand from European to American goods. If so what would be the European response? And what if Europe made the same demands of Japan as the United States? One would hope that Europe would do just that and, in exchange, forgo the growing tendency to discriminate against Japanese goods. Japan would face a multilateral challenge to open its markets that, if met, would lead to freer trade.
Japanese companies might also locate in the United States to produce ''Japanese'' goods for sale in Japan and thus meet the import test. There is no problem with Japanese investment in the United States; we are interested in ''good jobs at good wages'' and American-located production. Whether the employer is an American or Japanese company is almost irrelevant. Of course, trade growth targets have to be based on exports of products with substantial American content.
Japan might consider this American posture unacceptable. The trade problem could then widen to become a national security concern and confrontation would be unavoidable. Japan has grown up and is looking to define a role commensurate with its economic strength. In that search, Japan must choose whether it is willing to be part of an open trading system or is seeking another role.
We are ambivalent about Japan, fearful of Japan bashing and uncertain about triggering trade conflict. Japan is conscious of our lack of resolve and exploits it to the fullest. Where we go wrong is in assuming that the showdown can be avoided. If we do not open up Japan's market, the next recession will inevitably lead to import restrictions here - a much worse outcome for the entire liberal trading system.

A Shaky Lid on an Inflation Threat

Author: UCHITELLE, LOUIS

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]12 Mar 1989: A.4.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427106836?accountid=11752

Abstract: Mr. [Robert Dryden] said Caterpillar had been able ''to insulate itself from the effect of the weaker dollar'' by constantly switching suppliers. The steel castings for cutting edges had been made by a Nebraska company, but the business went to a French concern, which, despite the strong franc, was willing to accept a price 20 percent lower than the Nebraska company's, Mr. Dryden said. ''There are Japanese and American competitors out there to discipline us,'' said Donald Paris, the company's chief economist. ''People haven't realized the determination of companies to hold on to customers. That's one of the reasons for the mistake about inflation.'' A price index covering the Dow Chemical Company's various products rose by 14 percent last year - an increase that plastics manufacturers that use Dow's chemicals could not always pass along to their customers. Paul Oreffice, Dow's chairman, said the increase simply restored Dow's price index to its early 1980's level.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=A+Shaky+Lid+on+an+Inflation+Threat&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1989-03-12&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=UCHITELLE%2C+LOUIS&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: As the dollar has plunged in the last four years, economists and policy makers have worried that the steep devaluation would eventually fuel inflation in the United States.
As the dollar has plunged in the last four years, economists and policy makers have worried that the steep devaluation would eventually fuel inflation in the United States.
This would happen, they reasoned, because foreign businesses would eventually be forced to raise the dollar prices of the products they sell in this country. Only by collecting more dollars could foreign companies maintain their revenues and profits in yen or marks.
They have indeed raised prices - not as much as economists had predicted but by enough to have a potentially big impact on inflation in the United States. Since the dollar began its decline in March 1985, the producer or wholesale prices that foreign businesses charge their American customers for thousands of products - including cameras, cars, steel, clothing, wine, machinery and medical equipment - have risen by an average of 26.2 percent. Most of this large increase has occurred in the last two years, according to Government data.
But a puzzling fact is that many of those price increases have not yet been passed on to the final consumer. The contribution of these increases to the 4.4 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index last year was less - perhaps much less - than five-tenths of one percentage point, estimates Catherine L. Mann, an economist at the World Bank who has studied the exchange rate-inflation relationship. Many economists had expected the contribution to be at least five-tenths of a percentage point.
The Government does not calculate the impact of rising import prices on the C.P.I. But anecdotal evidence supports the contention that the impact has been mild.
''The pass-through is not minimal but has been less than historical trends would have suggested,'' said Nigel Gault, a senior economist at Data Resources Inc.
Whether the pass-through will continue to be modest, however, is anyone's guess. Some economists and business executives see signs that price increases for imported goods are beginning to accelerate, a development more likely to take root if the dollar falls more. If that happens, and if the economy remains strong, more of the price increases will be passed on to the final consumer, some economists and business executives warn.
But others believe that growing competition from such newly industrialized nations as South Korea and Thailand will constrain the ability of Japanese and European companies - and also American companies - to raise prices in the United States .
Increasing the likelihood that import prices will remain a relatively small factor in inflation is the fact that American companies have changed the way they buy materials, components and machinery from abroad. They are increasingly trying to persuade suppliers to hold down prices - by promising them long-term relationships, for example, or by pitting one supplier against another.
The hold-down in prices is not uniform, of course. Rising import prices are passed along quickly to consumers when the product involved is in great demand and nothing quite like it is made in the United States. The Japanese, for example, are virtually the only manufacturers of 35-millimeter cameras, and such cameras today cost 50 to 60 percent more in retail stores in the United States than they did in 1985.
The wholesale prices of European wines have risen by more than 25 percent since 1985. Zachy's, a big liquor store in Scarsdale, N.Y., for one, did not increase its prices for French wine substantially until last year, when it raised them by 15 to 20 percent. From 1985 through 1987, Zachy's had not raised them by more than 5 percent annually.
''We had inventories to sell from, and we wanted to be competitive with domestic wines,'' said Garnett Eisner, Zachy's manager. But he said that wholesale prices finally rose so much that he had no choice but to pass them through.
The more common experience, however, is that of Caterpillar Inc. Like so many American manufacturers, Caterpillar, based in Peoria, Ill., is a big buyer of parts, machinery and materials from abroad. These purchases constitute a huge portion of the country's total imports.
In Caterpillar's case, 20 percent of all the items that the company uses to manufacture earth movers, tractors and other heavy equipment are purchased from overseas suppliers. These include steel from Brazil, automated welders from Sweden, machine tools from West Germany and Japan, and French-made steel castings that are honed into cutting edges for the plows that go on Caterpillar's tractors and earth movers.
Some of the computer-controlled, multimillion-dollar machine tools brought from Europe and Japan for Caterpillar's Peoria factory simply are not available in the United States. Their prices have risen more than 30 percent since 1985, including a 10 percent increase in the last 18 months, said Robert Dryden, a purchasing vice president at Caterpillar.
But Mr. Dryden said Caterpillar had been able ''to insulate itself from the effect of the weaker dollar'' by constantly switching suppliers. The steel castings for cutting edges had been made by a Nebraska company, but the business went to a French concern, which, despite the strong franc, was willing to accept a price 20 percent lower than the Nebraska company's, Mr. Dryden said.
On the other hand, 70 percent of the starting motors for the big diesel engines in Caterpillar equipment had been German-made until recently. That business now goes to a supplier in the United States: the Delco Products unit of the General Motors Corporation. ''We are constantly looking for these opportunities,'' Mr. Dryden said.
Using this approach, Caterpillar was able to keep overall price increases for its foreign supplies last year to 10 percent, the same rate of increase for the supplies it purchased in the United States. The prices Caterpillar charges for its heavy equipment went up only 5 percent last year and barely at all in 1986 and 1987.
''There are Japanese and American competitors out there to discipline us,'' said Donald Paris, the company's chief economist. ''People haven't realized the determination of companies to hold on to customers. That's one of the reasons for the mistake about inflation.''
Executives at other manufacturers tell similar stories. Steven Roberts, a purchasing executive at the Ford Motor Company, said that besides shopping around, Ford also holds down costs by developing long-term relationships with suppliers and ''working with them on pricing.''
Such actions help to explain why import prices have not climbed nearly as much as foreign currencies have against the dollar.
A weighted basket of the currencies of the nations from which the United States receives most of its imports has appreciated nearly 50 percent against the dollar since March 1985. Many economists had expected that appreciation to cause import prices to jump by 35 to 40 percent - or about 10 percentage points more than they have.
Ms. Mann of the World Bank says much more work needs to be done to understand the relationships among currency fluctuations, import prices and inflation rates. ''No one has tried to show just how changes in import product prices ultimately show up in the inflation rate,'' she said.
The research suggested by Ms. Mann would have to deal with the wealth of anecdotal evidence not accounted for in economic theory.
Dollar devaluation, for example, has served as a ''shield'' that has protected price increases by American manufacturers of basic materials, such as chemicals.
A price index covering the Dow Chemical Company's various products rose by 14 percent last year - an increase that plastics manufacturers that use Dow's chemicals could not always pass along to their customers. Paul Oreffice, Dow's chairman, said the increase simply restored Dow's price index to its early 1980's level.
That may be, but the increase became possible because the weak dollar helped make Dow a low-cost producer worldwide. This, in turn, opened up export markets and prevented foreign manufacturers from underpricing Dow at home.
The auto industry operates behind a different sort of shield, one that is not as inflationary. The prices of American-made and imported cars have risen in lock step since 1985, as if one kept a leash on the other. The Commerce Department keeps track of actual show-room selling prices, adjusted for discounts, rebates and taxes, but excluding financing costs and trade-in allowances.
The data show that the average price of an imported car was $15,316 last year, up 24 percent over the last four years. Although American car makers could have held the line on prices and tried to grab sales from the imports, they raised prices, too. The price of American-made cars rose an average of 25 percent during the same period, to $14,010 in 1988. ''One could argue that the devaluation and the increases in foreign car prices gave the domestic people a chance to raise their prices,'' said Clinton McCully, a Commerce Department economist.
The impact of devaluation on prices is sometimes hard to distinguish from other factors. The price of American- and foreign-made sheet steel used in cars and appliances, for example, is now about $600 a ton in the United States, up more than 20 percent since 1985, with most of the increase occurring in the last two years. Voluntary restraint agreements limiting steel imports played a role by cutting foreign competition in the United States. Dollar devaluation also helped, by bringing American steel more into line with overseas costs.
But in the view of Harutame Umezawa, executive vice president of Nippon Steel U.S.A., the biggest factor in the price increase has been strong worldwide demand for steel, with barely enough factory capacity to fill all the orders. Nippon Steel ships one million tons of steel to the United States a year, and if import limits were lifted, Nippon might not be able to increase this amount by very much because of short supplies in Japan, Mr. Umezawa said.
For the past year, another sort of import barrier has had a very clear effect on the price of metal ball-bearings, used in thousands of products with moving parts. An anti-dumping action last year by the Federal Government helped to push up the price of foreign-made ball-bearings.
Behind this shield, American manufacturers have raised pricesby 11 percent in the past year, squeezing companies like Monarch Machine Tool in Sidney, Ohio, which makes factory lathes.
''Our margins are way, way down,'' said Robert J. Siewert, the company's chief executive. Because of stiff competition from foreign machinery manufacturers, Monarch has managed to increase the prices of its lathes by a total of only 5 percent over the past two years.
But Mr. Siewert sees the tide turning. His overseas competitors, he says, are finally pushing up the prices of their lathes, attempting to recover more of their currency-related losses. That, in turn, will allow Monarch to raise the amount it charges for its machines, although no increases are planned yet, Mr. Siewert said.

BUSINESS FORUM: UNCONVENTIONAL WISDOM; Slay Inflation With Rapid Growth

Author: London, Paul A; Paul A. London is an economic consultant in Washington.

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]25 Dec 1988: A.3.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427001591?accountid=11752

Abstract: LEAD: Interest rates and the supposed trade-off between faster growth and higher inflation will be a problem for President Bush in 1989. His ''flexible freeze'' program to reduce the budget deficit requires lower interest rates - which reduce the cost of the existing deficit - and faster growth, which increases revenue. Interest rates and the supposed trade-off between faster growth and higher inflation will be a problem for President Bush in 1989. His ''flexible freeze'' program to reduce the budget deficit requires lower interest rates - which reduce the cost of the existing deficit - and faster growth, which increases revenue. But the decision makers at the Federal Reserve Board fear that faster growth will cause inflation. As a result, the Fed has pushed up short-term interest rates more than two percentage points since March in an effort to slow the economy. What does this tell us about the inflationary bottlenecks in the American economy? It suggests that the place to look for the causes of inflation is in the pricing policies of key manufacturing industries. It is wrong to say that oil prices ''caused'' the inflation in this country in 1979 and 1980 since they had no comparable effect in Japan. Rather, the problem is in the reaction of American manufacturing industries, where productivity gains, which have largely offset higher raw materials prices, have not been passed through to domestic and foreign consumers.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=BUSINESS+FORUM%3A+UNCONVENTIONAL+WISDOM%3B+Slay+Inflation+With+Rapid+Growth&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1988-12-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=London%2C+Paul+A%3BPaul+A.+London+is+an+economic+consultant+in+Washington.&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: Interest rates and the supposed trade-off between faster growth and higher inflation will be a problem for President Bush in 1989. His ''flexible freeze'' program to reduce the budget deficit requires lower interest rates - which reduce the cost of the existing deficit - and faster growth, which increases revenue.
Interest rates and the supposed trade-off between faster growth and higher inflation will be a problem for President Bush in 1989. His ''flexible freeze'' program to reduce the budget deficit requires lower interest rates - which reduce the cost of the existing deficit - and faster growth, which increases revenue. But the decision makers at the Federal Reserve Board fear that faster growth will cause inflation. As a result, the Fed has pushed up short-term interest rates more than two percentage points since March in an effort to slow the economy.
If the economy is to grow fast enough to reduce the budget deficit and provide resources for many other pressing needs, the new administration will have to seek lower interest rates and find other ways to fight inflation. Since 1969, the tight-money, slow-growth policies to control inflation have impeded the modernization of American manufacturing.
The contrast between Japanese and American economic policy is stark. The Japanese understand that faster growth means more investment in modern plants. This investment leads to lower production costs, increased competitiveness, higher living standards and - yes - less inflation. New plants are more efficient than old ones, therefore slowing growth inevitably means an economy that is less competitive.
Unfortunately, there is no sign that the United States is reconsidering its slow-growth economic course. This year, Japan is expected to grow 50 percent faster than America - the continuation of an 11-year trend. And gross fixed business investment, which is needed to provide for this growth, is 21 percent of gross national product in Japan, but only about 1.3 percent of G.N.P. in the United States. Slowing America's growth once more to fight inflation means that capital plants in this country will continue to fall behind those in Japan.
This is not to say that it is wrong to be concerned about inflation. With the current rate running at 4 to 5 percent, inflation is still a serious problem.
But high interest rates and slow growth reduce inflation in the way that chemotherapy works on cancer. It kills the good along with the bad cells and makes the patient dreadfully sick. Physicians, to their credit, are trying to find therapies that will kill cancer cells without killing the patient. But America's economic policy makers have not made the same intellectual leap.
America's domestic prices rose faster than Japanese prices from 1982 through 1986, when the opposite might have been expected. During that period, American prices were being held down first by recession and then by cheaper imports resulting from the strong dollar. Japanese domestic prices in the early 1980's should have surged. They were being pulled up by, among other things, a falling yen. But Japanese prices did not rise, and the reason for this gives a clue to what American anti-inflation policy should be.
Data suggest that the place to look for an explanation for Japan's success in controlling inflation is in the way its manufacturing industries control costs and price their products. Japan's producer price index rose 25 percent from 1976 to 1981. And the prices of important categories of manufactured goods like vehicles, electrical equipment and precision instruments, rose little or not at all. Those manufacturing industries avoided higher domestic and export prices when the rising cost of imported energy and raw materials might easily have pushed them up. They also avoided rising prices in the early 1980's when the rising dollar, with its impact on commodities, might also have pulled prices up. Japanese industrial prices have stayed down since 1985, although the rising yen has eaten into export price margins.
To keep prices stable, Japanese manufacturers are using productivity gains, which accrue when manufacturing industries invest, to expand and modernize.
In sharp contrast, since 1975, key American industries which compete with Japan have seen their own prices increase far faster than the producer price index. For example, Japanese wholesale auto prices are hardly higher now than in 1976. By contrast, American auto prices at the producer level, are up 12 percent since 1982 and 56 percent since 1978. And American steel prices surged 15 to 30 percent in the past two years, while Japan's prices remained stable.
The data show that falling industrial prices have kept Japan's overall inflation rate down, allowing for faster growth without inflation. Japanese manufacturers have raised productivity sharply by continuously modernizing their plants and consistently passing the gains on to domestic and foreign consumers. American manufacturing has had sharp productivity gains too, but key sectors have raised - not lowered - prices. As a result, American productivity increases have not meant greater market share, lower imports, higher employment, or faster growth.
What does this tell us about the inflationary bottlenecks in the American economy? It suggests that the place to look for the causes of inflation is in the pricing policies of key manufacturing industries. It is wrong to say that oil prices ''caused'' the inflation in this country in 1979 and 1980 since they had no comparable effect in Japan. Rather, the problem is in the reaction of American manufacturing industries, where productivity gains, which have largely offset higher raw materials prices, have not been passed through to domestic and foreign consumers.
In 1989, President Bush can have faster growth without inflation. But to have it he must use the Presidency to encourage American manufacturers to keep prices down to gain market share as the Japanese do. His administration needs to question damaging price increases publicly in the most important sectors of the economy. To do this will require a significant change in policy. There will be shouts of protest. But most American consumers will approve, and the data suggest that doing this is crucial.
If American manufacturing industries price their products less for quick profits and more to gain market share, the United States can beat inflation without slowing growth. Instead of letting the Federal Reserve fight inflation with the painful chemotherapy of tight money, the new administration ought to encourage anti-inflation pricing by industry. That is what our most successful competitor does.

FUTURES/OPTIONS; Precious Metals Prices Fall As Inflation Worries Ease

Full text: LEAD: The futures prices of precious metals ended lower yesterday after a report on the nation's unemployment reduced fears of inflation.
The futures prices of precious metals ended lower yesterday after a report on the nation's unemployment reduced fears of inflation.
The Labor Department reported yesterday morning that the nation's unemployment rate had risen to 5.5 percent in August, from 5.4 percent in July. The report indicated that the economy would not grow as quickly as previously anticipated, reducing the worries over inflation and higher interest rates.
Metal futures initially plunged on the unemployment news, with platinum down nearly $19 an ounce at midday. But prices recovered late in the session to close only modestly lower.
Precious metals, commonly seen as an investment hedge against inflation, tend to rise and fall with inflationary expectations. A sharp drop in crude oil prices added to the bearish tone in the metals markets, analysts said.
Peter Cardillo, commodities trading adviser with Josephthal & Company in New York, said the metals markets remained technically weak despite the comeback.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, platinum settled $7.90 to $8.20 lower, with October at $523.50 an ounce. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold settled 90 cents to $2.70 lower, with October at $431.80 an ounce; silver was 5.6 cents to 8 cents lower, with September at $6.518 an ounce.
Grain and soybean futures finished mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade in a late surge stimulated by technical factors in the absence of new supply-and-demand developments.
After the close, the Agriculture Department announced that the Soviet Union had bought an additional 800,000 metric tons of United States corn for delivery during the 1988-89 marketing year. The sale of 100,000 tons of corn was announced on Thursday, also for delivery in 1988-89.
Rumors of a large corn sale to the Soviets had lifted corn futures prices earlier in the week.
The Soviet Union bought 9.05 million tons of wheat and 5.17 million tons of corn for delivery in the fifth year of its grain-supply agreement with the United States. It also bought 830,000 tons of soybeans and 1.3 million tons of soybean meal. The agreement is scheduled to expire on Sept. 30.
Cattle futures posted strong gains in a late surge of pre-weekend position squaring on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures retreated on fears of slackening demand.

BUSINESS FORUM: REMAKING A NATION; What Mexico's Next President Must Do

Author: Feinberg, Richard E; Richard E. Feinberg is vice president of the Overseas Development Council.

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]03 July 1988: A.3.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426889678?accountid=11752

Abstract: * The ''national self'' cannot be the central geopolitical or economic option. Technology, markets and power do not lie primarily in debt-depressed, politically unstable Latin America but in the Pacific basin and North America. Third, on the contentious issues of drugs and migration, the United States could abandon unilateral measures in return for a greater Mexican willingness to recognize that their ''domestic'' policies affect American interests and are legitimate topics for negotiations. One possible deal: For the next several years, the United States could agree to accept a larger number of Mexican migrants if Mexico would place greater emphasis on job creation. Such initiatives would not be charity: They are bargains based on reciprocity. Most important, they are rooted in the conviction that it is in America's interest for Mexico's globalists to prosper. A successful Mexican perestroika could provide the United States with a more affluent, democratic, less distant neighbor.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=BUSINESS+FORUM%3A+REMAKING+A+NATION%3B+What+Mexico%27s+Next+President+Must+Do&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1988-07-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=Feinberg%2C+Richard+E%3BRichard+E.+Feinberg+is+vice+president+of+the+Overseas+Development+Council.&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: MEXICO will choose a new President on Wednesday. The near certain election of Carlos Salinas de Gotari will accelerate an intellectual revolution that is driving Mexico beyond its defensive, inward-looking past and toward a more receptive, internationalist future. This shift toward globalism offers a tremendous opportunity for improving Mexican
MEXICO will choose a new President on Wednesday. The near certain election of Carlos Salinas de Gotari will accelerate an intellectual revolution that is driving Mexico beyond its defensive, inward-looking past and toward a more receptive, internationalist future. This shift toward globalism offers a tremendous opportunity for improving Mexican-American relations.
Mexicans are re-examining their place in the world. Mexico turned inward after its 1910 revolution, formulating a foreign policy designed to keep it safe from the designs of an encroaching northern neighbor. A powerful state apparatus directed the nation's energies toward developing local industry and the middle-class consumer market. The state also protected the economy from external competition and its upper and middle classes from a restless peasantry and growing urban proletariat.
This safe society enjoyed solid growth with low inflation during the 1950's and 60's. In the last 15 years, however, the luster of the ancien regime has been badly tarnished by spiraling stagflation, capital flight, and widening gaps between rich and poor. A growing number of Mexicans believe that the paternalistic state can no longer guarantee economic development or social peace.
Now, Mexico is turning toward an alternative, globalist perspective based on these tenets:
* The old policies of protecting do mestic producers from imports have run their course. Mexican industry must now confront global competition.
* Economic national security can no longer be guaranteed by a rigid state that itself tries to provide jobs, investment and new technology. Closing the doors to internal investment and foreign technologies, and frustrating the drive for integration into the global trading and financial markets would not preserve Mexican sovereignty but only increase its vulnerability.
* The ''national self'' cannot be the central geopolitical or economic option. Technology, markets and power do not lie primarily in debt-depressed, politically unstable Latin America but in the Pacific basin and North America.
The Mexican Government has begun to act on these realizations. To force industry to become more efficient and competitive, Mexico has slashed tariffs and joined the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. A competitively valued peso is also focusing the attention of Mexico's entrepreneurs on foreign markets.
The globalists count among their numbers the Harvard-trained social scientist Carlos Salinas and his team of like-minded, often Americantrained technocrats. Nevertheless, the predominance of the globalist approach is far from assured. It still faces formidible opposition from some traditional politicians, government bureaucrats, smaller businessmen and many intellectuals.
Moreover, several roadblocks stand in the way. To begin with there is stagflation. Unless the three-digit inflation that plagued Mexico in 1987 can be tamed, globalism will become identified with price instability and falling real incomes.
Next is the problem of foreign debt. Mexicans unanimously want to reduce interest payments that are draining the country of investment capital and fueling inflation. However, the globalists eschew unilateral actions that might frighten the very foreign capitalists they wish to attract.
Then there is the problem of low investment. Without a return of business confidence, private investors will not create new, world-class industries. Business managers need steadier macroeconomic policies, price stability and expanding markets at home and abroad.
Social inequity is also a perennial problem for Mexico. Globalists have cleverly attributed Mexico's glaring inequalities to ancien regime policies that guaranteed companies monopoly profits and that subsidized the upper-middle class. However, the strength of political opposition on the left and right indicate that the globalists are vulnerable to the charge that their modernization campaign has lowered real wages and threatens many smaller, less competitive firms.
Finally, there is continued political disruption. Globalist economics could provide a structural foundation for a flowering of democracy in Mexico. By reducing the power of the fused ruling party-Federal bureaucracy, globalism offers an opening for competing interests. The strategic tasks facing the Salinas administration will be to smoothly manage the transition from a one-party state to a more pluralistic system.
THESE are serious challenges. The responsibility for overcoming them is Mexico's, but American policy makes a difference:
First, the net resource transfer from Mexico to international financial markets should be reduced by half. The United States can create a regulatory and political environment that encourages commercial banks to extend new loans or grant relief on old debts. Increased flows from multilateral agencies and capital-surplus countries like Japan can also spur investment and support globalist economic reforms.
Second, in both bilateral and multi- lateral forums, the United States and Mexico can reciprocally reduce trade barriers and avoid building new ones.
Third, on the contentious issues of drugs and migration, the United States could abandon unilateral measures in return for a greater Mexican willingness to recognize that their ''domestic'' policies affect American interests and are legitimate topics for negotiations. One possible deal: For the next several years, the United States could agree to accept a larger number of Mexican migrants if Mexico would place greater emphasis on job creation.
Fourth, the United States can adopt a diplomatic posture that neither undermines the Mexican Government through public scorn nor smothers it in an ostentacious embrace. Matter-of-fact recognition of progress when deserved, and careful and precise criticism when warranted, will most likely stimulate positive responses.
Such initiatives would not be charity: They are bargains based on reciprocity. Most important, they are rooted in the conviction that it is in America's interest for Mexico's globalists to prosper. A successful Mexican perestroika could provide the United States with a more affluent, democratic, less distant neighbor.

O.E.C.D. Growth Outlook Brightens

Author: STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]10 June 1988: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426859578?accountid=11752

Abstract: In its semiannual economic outlook report, the O.E.C.D., a group of 24 industrial democracies formed to promote cooperation and noninflationary growth, said that while the near-term risk of recession had receded substantially since October's stock market plunge, ''an inflation risk is beginning to reappear in several countries.'' The View on U.S. Inflation Increasing private savings and reducing the budget deficit would reduce inflationary pressures, the group said. Full text: LEAD: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned today of inflationary pressures in the United States but said the overall economic outlook for the industrial world appeared stronger than it seemed six months ago.
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned today of inflationary pressures in the United States but said the overall economic outlook for the industrial world appeared stronger than it seemed six months ago.
The organization's officials said that because their fears of the depressing effect of the stock market fall had not been borne out, they had revised their outlook. They now expect economic growth in the industrialized world to be 3 percent this year, compared with the 2.25 percent they projected in December. They also project growth to be 2.5 percent next year, compared with last December's forecast of 1.75 percent.
In its semiannual economic outlook report, the O.E.C.D., a group of 24 industrial democracies formed to promote cooperation and noninflationary growth, said that while the near-term risk of recession had receded substantially since October's stock market plunge, ''an inflation risk is beginning to reappear in several countries.'' The View on U.S. Inflation
The report is based on data accumulated through early May. In a news briefing today, David Henderson, the organization's chief economist, said that at least for now, inflation in the United States remained under control. Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said the same thing last month at an O.E.C.D. meeting in Paris.
The organization also expressed concern that the pace of reducing the American trade deficit might be so slow that it could jeopardize the stability of the currency exchange markets. The group said that reduction of the trade deficit could be slowed by continued strong growth in the American economy, especially in domestic demand. Such strong growth would ''also pose a risk of accelerating inflation, since margins of unused capacity and unemployed labor have become very thin in some sectors and regions,'' it said.
Increasing private savings and reducing the budget deficit would reduce inflationary pressures, the group said. In the absence of progress on these fronts, the report stated, ''the orientation of monetary policy would need to be tighter over the next year or so to contain inflation.'' It added, ''Interest rates may need to move higher in the period immediately ahead in view of emerging price pressures.'' The Inflation Threat
In its outlook the O.E.C.D. projects that inflation in the United States will be at an annualized rate of 3.75 percent for the second half of this year and 4 percent next year. But Mr. Henderson said, ''A further significant fall in the dollar or stronger growth and lower unemployment than we project could cause greater-than-expected inflation.''
The organization did not criticize West Germany as much as it had in previous reports for not doing more to spur economic growth. O.E.C.D. economists said Bonn's leeway to stimulate the German economy was constrained by a deficit expected to equal 2.6 percent of the nation's budget.
''West Germany is growing faster than we and others had projected it would,'' Mr. Henderson said. He said this was not so much because of policy measures as because of stronger-than-expected export growth.
The O.E.C.D. projects that West Germany, which has the biggest economy in Europe, will grow by 2.25 percent this year and 1.75 percent next year. Six months ago it estimated that Germany's economy would grow by just 1.5 percent this year and 1.25 percent next year.
The report praised Japan for stimulating its domestic demand and economic growth. It praised Britain's fast growth, but said that nation has to worry about a trade deficit and inflation. France was praised for low inflation but warned about a trade deficit, while Italy was scolded about its huge budget deficit.

WHEN THE WORLD LACKS A LEADER

Author: UCHITELLE, LOUIS

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]31 Jan 1988: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426702938?accountid=11752

Abstract: Superpower status has always required a sense of mission that the Japanese lack, says Prof. Edwin O. Reischauer, a Japan scholar at Harvard and the American Ambassador to Tokyo in the 1960's. ''We speak of making the world safe for democracy and we apply our ideas to everyone,'' he said. ''The Japanese have none of this sense of empire. They have trouble even joining a United Nations peacekeeping force.'' That is the solution sought by Mr. [Noboru Takeshita]. ''The Japanese are pushing hegemony away,'' Mr. Reischauer said. ''They want to move toward a system of greater interdependence.''
