ECONOMY'S PULSE FEELS A BIT FAINTER

Author: Cowan, Edward

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]21 July 1985: A.3.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425459327?accountid=11752

Abstract: Both Mr. [Paul A. Volcker] and his institution have been accused of being preoccupied with inflation at the cost of jobs. In a rare dig at the Fed, and maybe at himself, Mr. Volcker said that Fed policy makers as a body expected almost 4 percent inflation this year and some slight speed-up in 1986. But ''I personally think,'' he said, ''we will do better than that.'' The policy-making committee ''in its majesty has overestimated inflation in each of the last four years,'' he said. The Fed rebased the money supply in 1983 as well. Last week's action predictably drew criticism from monetarist economists, who prescribe a constant annual rate of money growth rather than a discretionary rate. ''The fact that the inflation rate is very low at the moment is reminiscent of the 1960's and 1970's,'' said Allan Meltzer of Carnegie Mellon Institute. The most likely outcome, he said, was that the Fed would ''wait too long'' to slow money growth, producing a resurgence of inflation, ''and then will slow down too much.'' Mr. Volcker, arguing that the link between money and the economy is not constant, asserted a ''need for a considerable degree of judgment rather than precise rules.'' For example, he said the Fed could drive down the dollar faster to shrink the trade deficit, but won't lest it run excessive risks of inflation. Even so, the Fed, a frequent target of criticism by the White House and Congress, won praise. ''We're pleased with it,'' Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said. And it escaped censure from House Democrats. They seemed to agree with the Fed that the budget deficit is the central problem.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=ECONOMY%27S+PULSE+FEELS+A+BIT+FAINTER&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1985-07-21&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=Cowan%2C+Edward&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: With its report that economic growth this spring was disappointing, its warning from Federal Reserve chief Paul A. Volcker not to count on the central bank to push interest rates much lower, and its continuing impasse on House and Senate negotiations to shrink the Federal budget deficit, last week did little to ease the creeping sense of uncertainty about the economic outlook.
The latest Government reports showed continued weakness in June in manufacturing and mining. The economy as a whole, the Commerce Department said in its report on the gross national product in the second quarter, expanded at an annual rate of 1.7 percent. That is much less than the initial 3.1 percent estimate but more than the negligible first-quarter gain of 0.3 percent. The growth rate for the first half of the year was a negligible 1 percent, only a whisker away from stagnation. This raised questions about the staying power of the expansion, almost three years old.
Still, the Administration stuck to its forecast of a stronger second half after learning that last month business investment surged, consumer outlays held firm and personal income advanced. Imports, which soared last winter because the strong dollar has made them cheap, showed only a slight spring rise. But exports continued to slide. ''The trend in exports is now decidedly weak,'' with the slack having spread from farm to factory, said Aubrey H. Zaffuto, economist at J. Henry Schroder Bank.
The financial markets seemed to take divergent views. The New York Stock Exchange, evidently optimistic about the outlook for profits, punched out three new highs, with the Dow Jones industrial average ending the week at a record 1359. Bonds prices retreated after Mr. Volcker's testimony, which gave no encouragement to those who seek another cut in the Fed's discount rate.
Mr. Volcker's warning of the limits on how much the Fed can help came in his semi-annual report to Congress on monetary policy and the economy. He was uncommonly optimistic about keeping inflation down below 4 percent. But he cautioned that the economy was marred by ''gross imbalances that can neither be sustained indefinitely nor dealt with successfully by monetary policy alone.'' The United States, Mr. Volcker said, was consuming too much, saving and investing too little, and borrowing and buying too much abroad. That borrowing, he said, included a ''disquieting'' rise in corporate debt to finance takeovers and mergers.
As if to validate the last imbalance he cited - ''too many borrowers at home and abroad remain under strain or overextended'' - the Bank of America reported a $338 million second-quarter loss, caused by the bank's doubling its cushion for bad loans. The action came under pressure from a crack team of Federal bank examiners, dispatched from New York to get tough with the country's second biggest bank. A more encouraging report about financial institutions came from the savings and loan industry, which after several lean years forecast record 1985 profits, except for that 10 percent of the thrifts which continue to lose money.
'Accommodative' Policy

Unlike the economy as a whole, the thrifts have been helped by the large decline in interest rates in recent months. But the economy as a whole may yet respond. In the guarded language of central bankers, Mr. Volcker told a House Banking subcommittee that though there were limits to what the Federal Reserve could achieve, it was trying to stick to an ''accommodative'' monetary policy. He was more worried about the economy, he said, than about recent growth of the basic money supply at a rapid pace that he said was not necessarily inflationary. The Fed, he reported, was raising the benchmark from which it would calculate second-half growth of the basic money supply (currency plus checking accounts).
Both Mr. Volcker and his institution have been accused of being preoccupied with inflation at the cost of jobs. In a rare dig at the Fed, and maybe at himself, Mr. Volcker said that Fed policy makers as a body expected almost 4 percent inflation this year and some slight speed-up in 1986. But ''I personally think,'' he said, ''we will do better than that.'' The policy-making committee ''in its majesty has overestimated inflation in each of the last four years,'' he said.
Yet Mr. Volcker worried that if the Fed creates too much money and the dollar falls too much, the extra liquidity and the higher cost of imports could trigger faster inflation. The dollar has fallen 15 percent or so this year, though it rebounded late last week.
The Fed rebased the money supply in 1983 as well. Last week's action predictably drew criticism from monetarist economists, who prescribe a constant annual rate of money growth rather than a discretionary rate. ''The fact that the inflation rate is very low at the moment is reminiscent of the 1960's and 1970's,'' said Allan Meltzer of Carnegie Mellon Institute. The most likely outcome, he said, was that the Fed would ''wait too long'' to slow money growth, producing a resurgence of inflation, ''and then will slow down too much.''
Mr. Volcker, arguing that the link between money and the economy is not constant, asserted a ''need for a considerable degree of judgment rather than precise rules.'' For example, he said the Fed could drive down the dollar faster to shrink the trade deficit, but won't lest it run excessive risks of inflation. Even so, the Fed, a frequent target of criticism by the White House and Congress, won praise. ''We're pleased with it,'' Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said. And it escaped censure from House Democrats. They seemed to agree with the Fed that the budget deficit is the central problem.

Economic Scene; The Flight To the Dollar

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]27 Feb 1985: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425310474?accountid=11752

Abstract: Many economists who, a year ago, were warning of an imminent collapse of the dollar have now begun to say it may stay up for years to come. The new Morgan Economic Letter, released this week by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, sees ''a growing perception on the part of foreigners that the United States is a highly attractive place to lodge funds.'' Among the reasons for this: higher interest rates here than elsewhere, the more dynamic American economy and ''the safe-haven appeal of a country that offers political stability.'' ''Neither the unusual funds-gathering role of American banks nor the foreign investment in the United States can be counted on indefinitely,'' the Morgan economists say. ''But there is also little reason to expect either an imminent decline in large capital flows to this country or a major weakening in the dollar.'' ''While in some cases the fears of investors may have been exaggerated,'' he said, ''the perception that the United States is a safe and secure place for funds is not.'' He contended that, relative to any other country in the world, ''the United States continues to have an advantage.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+The+Flight+To+the+Dollar&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1985-02-27&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: AFTER soaring to record heights this week, the dollar fell back yesterday. But the soaring dollar still promises to reach new altitudes this year. Before falling and later recovering a bit in New York yesterday, it rose abroad to 3.47 against the West German mark, and some traders and analysts think it could climb to 3.6 marks or perhaps all the way up to 4 marks. And the British pound fell as low as $1.04 before rising to $1.06; a buck for a pound seems inconceivable to those who can remember when the pound was worth nearly $5.
How long can the high-flying dollar stay aloft? R.T. McNamar, the former Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, suggests that, thanks to the strong inflow of foreign capital to the United States, the dollar will stay permanently strong. In a recent speech to the National Foreign Trade Council in New York, Mr. McNamar suggested that the dollar's strength, despite the record United States trade deficit, was due to the preference of investors all over the world to put their money here more than in any other country.
This preference, the result of a search for maximum, safe, after-tax returns, he asserts, stems basically from the resurgence of United States economic growth. The American economy grew by 6.8 percent last year, compared with the average growth rate of 2.3 percent for the four largest European economies and the 5.5 percent growth rate of Japan. The United States growth rate has sextupled from its rate of slightly above 1 percent in 1979-80, while the other countries have been essentially flat. The persistently low European growth rates and the higher Japanese rates, according to Mr. McNamar's theory, explain why the European currencies have fallen so far against the dollar, and why the Japanese yen has declined much less.
At his news conference last week, President Reagan embraced the economic growth theory for the dollar's rise and indicated a reluctance to intervene in currency markets in any effort to drive the dollar down. Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, indicated his own reluctance to intervene in the exchange markets, and speculators took this as a cue to bid the dollar higher. Yesterday, Mr. Volcker said that intervention perhaps had not been forceful enough, and traders took this to mean that action might be more forceful in the future. Without United States cooperation, it is unlikely that foreign governments can intervene on a large enough scale to force the dollar down.
Mr. McNamar contends that the steep decline in the rate of United States inflation, relative to other countries, has also helped to strengthen the dollar. The strong dollar is itself a source of disinflationary pressure. Within the United States, it curbs exports and spurs imports, giving Americans more goods to consume than they produce. Internationally, the dollar's strength is depressing commodity futures, which this week fell to a 23-month low. Gold dropped $12.30, to $282 an ounce on Monday, a five-and-a-half-year low, before rising yesterday.
Many economists who, a year ago, were warning of an imminent collapse of the dollar have now begun to say it may stay up for years to come. The new Morgan Economic Letter, released this week by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, sees ''a growing perception on the part of foreigners that the United States is a highly attractive place to lodge funds.'' Among the reasons for this: higher interest rates here than elsewhere, the more dynamic American economy and ''the safe-haven appeal of a country that offers political stability.''
''Neither the unusual funds-gathering role of American banks nor the foreign investment in the United States can be counted on indefinitely,'' the Morgan economists say. ''But there is also little reason to expect either an imminent decline in large capital flows to this country or a major weakening in the dollar.''
Many foreigners and Americans are asking these days, ''Where else would you put your money?'' Indeed Mr. McNamar puts heavy stress on this country's safe-haven role for capital. Investor concerns, he says, have ranged from the impact of East European debt problems on German banks to political instability and turmoil in the Middle East and the debt situation in Latin America, which in recent weeks has flared up again.
''While in some cases the fears of investors may have been exaggerated,'' he said, ''the perception that the United States is a safe and secure place for funds is not.'' He contended that, relative to any other country in the world, ''the United States continues to have an advantage.''
But is all this new-era talk? The flight to the dollar, driving up its price, is certainly not an unmixed blessing. It is intensifying the problems of American farmers and other exporters. It is exacerbating protectionist pressures, as producers try to offset the damages resulting from an overvalued dollar. And Mr. Volcker said yesterday that the dollar's rise was inhibiting the conduct of monetary policy, seemingly implying that the Fed might be supplying more money to the economy than it would prefer, thereby eventually contributing to upward pressure on prices.
By forcing other countries to raise interest rates as a means of preventing further declines of their currency, the soaring dollar is threatening to make a sick world economy even sicker. Yet a precipitate fall in the dollar would also destabilize the United States and other countries. We shall consider these problems, and what to do about them, in another column.

CURRENCY MARKETS Gold Lowest Since '82; Dollar Up Despite Rates

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]27 Nov 1984: D.26.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425235015?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''People are concerned that we are going to see another round of oil-price cuts,'' said David Nelson, director of metals futures research at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Traders still view inflation-adjusted rates of interest in the United States as attractively high, said David Arbesman, first vice president at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ''They are looking at the differential on real rates of return between the United States and the rest of the world and are finding that, while the differential is smaller, it still favors the United States,'' he added. In London, fears of falling oil prices were cited for pushing the pound below $1.20 for the first time since mid-October. ''The pound is friendless and its decline could become self- perpetuating,'' said a brokering accountant, Paul Neild. He said the British Government was showing no sign of interest in propping up sterling.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=CURRENCY+MARKETS+Gold+Lowest+Since+%2782%3B+Dollar+Up+Despite+Rates&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1984-11-27&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.26&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Gold tumbled yesterday to its lowest level since the middle of 1982 on prospects for continued low inflation. The dollar, meanwhile, surged despite falling interest rates.
The decline in gold prices accelerated as the day progressed. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted the late bid for gold at $331.75 a troy ounce as of 4 P.M., down from $340 an ounce on Friday.
''People are concerned that we are going to see another round of oil-price cuts,'' said David Nelson, director of metals futures research at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
Falling oil prices, he added, tend to depress the prices of precious metals for two principal reasons. One is that a decline in oil prices would reduce inflationary pressures in the short run, Mr. Nelson said. He noted that many investors buy gold as a hedge against inflation.
Less Revenue for Producers
The other reason, he added, was that an oil-price decline could mean lower revenue for Middle East oil producers that have been heavy buyers of gold.
Gold opened lower in Asia, falling to $340.82 a troy ounce in Hong Kong from Saturday's close of $341.25. Later, in Europe, gold closed at $337 an ounce in London, down $4.25 from Friday. In Zurich, gold also closed at $337 an ounce, down $5 from Friday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery tumbled $8.80, to $331.20 an ounce. That was the lowest close for gold since it finished at $322.60 an ounce on July 8, 1982, according to the Comex statistics bureau.
In the currency markets, the dollar advanced despite recent declines in American interest rates.
In the latest demonstration of the interest-rate trend, several major United States banks yesterday cut their prime lending rates, or the benchmark against which they measure rates on short-term business loans, by a quarter percentage point, to 11 1/2 percent.
Still Attractively High
But traders still view inflation-adjusted rates of interest in the United States as attractively high, said David Arbesman, first vice president at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ''They are looking at the differential on real rates of return between the United States and the rest of the world and are finding that, while the differential is smaller, it still favors the United States,'' he added.
As the trading day began, the dollar rose to 245.60 Japanese yen from 243.45 yen last Thursday in advance of a three-day holiday weekend. In United States trading, the dollar slipped to 245.85 yen, from 245.875 yen on Friday.
In London, fears of falling oil prices were cited for pushing the pound below $1.20 for the first time since mid-October. ''The pound is friendless and its decline could become self- perpetuating,'' said a brokering accountant, Paul Neild. He said the British Government was showing no sign of interest in propping up sterling.
The pound fell to close at $1.1978 in London, from $1.2170 Friday. In the United States, the pound slipped to $1.2036, from $1.21225 on Friday.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 3.0640 West German marks, up from 3.0215; 2.5228 Swiss francs, up from 2.4985; 9.3820 French francs, up from 9.2650; 3.4545 Dutch guilders, up from 3.4160; 1,896.12 Italian lire, up from 1,874.50, and 1.3190 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3180.
Dollar rates in New York, as of 4:30 P.M., compared with late rates Friday, included: 3.05925 West German marks, up from 3.03625; 2.5265 Swiss francs, up from 2.5070; 9.3715 French francs, up from 9.32125, and 1.32005 Canadian dollars, up from 1.31815.

ECONOMIC SCENE; FOREIGN FUNDS HELP ON DEFICIT

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]14 Sep 1984: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425187797?accountid=11752

Abstract: Some of the upsurge in foreign investment in the United States is due to high real interest rates here and the big spread between rates here and abroad. As the Morgan Bank's new Economic Quarterly observes, ''Rising real interest rates and the uptrend in the dollar's value caused borrowers to look outside American markets for cheaper funds and attracted investors' capital inflows.'' Higher United States interest rates are not the whole of the story. Foreigners have become extremely bullish on the American economy. In interviews and discussions with American journalists and bankers, they are declaring their belief that the United States economy has regained its dynamism, that prospects for profits are stronger here and that the United States is a safer haven for their capital than anywhere else in the world. ''Where else would you put your money?'' one Argentine businessman asked this correspondent. A group of leading business executives, the Committee for Economic Development, says in a forthcoming policy statement: ''Getting the deficit down will challenge our nation's ability to rise above partisan and special interest and to act in the long-term interest of our economy and society. What we do now and during the next year will be a signal to the American people and to the rest of the world as to whether or not we are willing to take responsible, decisive and comprehensive actions to restore control over our economic destiny.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=ECONOMIC+SCENE%3B+FOREIGN+FUNDS+HELP+ON+DEFICIT&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1984-09-14&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: DESPITE the record trade deficit, which this year is likely to exceed $130 billion, the United States dollar continues to climb, as foreign capital floods into this country.
Net foreign investment in the United States soared to an annual rate of $77.7 billion in the first quarter of 1984 and to $80.6 billion in the second quarter, compared with $33.9 billion for all of 1983.
Some of the upsurge in foreign investment in the United States is due to high real interest rates here and the big spread between rates here and abroad. As the Morgan Bank's new Economic Quarterly observes, ''Rising real interest rates and the uptrend in the dollar's value caused borrowers to look outside American markets for cheaper funds and attracted investors' capital inflows.''
But higher United States interest rates are not the whole of the story. Foreigners have become extremely bullish on the American economy. In interviews and discussions with American journalists and bankers, they are declaring their belief that the United States economy has regained its dynamism, that prospects for profits are stronger here and that the United States is a safer haven for their capital than anywhere else in the world. ''Where else would you put your money?'' one Argentine businessman asked this correspondent.
This rising confidence in the United States economy is reflected in the change in the way foreign capital is coming to this country. Earlier, the inflows were coming through American banks, which increasingly borrowed from abroad because of the interest-rate differential.
Recently, however, money from abroad has increasingly been flowing into United States securities markets. Changed Treasury regulations allowing American corporations to issue Eurobonds - as well as the Treasury's own moves to tap that market - are strengthening the trend. The repeal of the 30 percent American withholding tax on interest paid to foreigners has further whetted the appetite for American securities.
The heavy inflow of foreign funds has made the huge Federal budget deficit tolerable, as foreign savings nearly cover the shortfall of domestic savings to finance the deficit and thus prevent a soaring of interest rates that would devastate the securities markets and stifle business capital spending, housing and durable goods purchases.
In the first quarter of 1984, the Federal deficit was running at an annual rate of $161 billion, while state and local governments were running a surplus of $54 billion, for a net Government borrowing requirement of $107 billion. However, the net inflow of foreign investment ran at an annual rate of $78 billion, covering more than three-quarters of the net Federal, state and local deficit. So the actual drain of the total government deficit has been relatively small,
But how long can this go on? Some economists believe that, if the huge net inflow of savings from abroad were to stop, chaos would follow. The Federal Reserve would be confronted with the dilemma of whether to finance the huge deficits and risk inflation, or refuse to finance them and risk depression. It would be a no-win choice.
The debate over the importance and urgency of reducing the Federal budget deficit, which forms the heart of the economic issue in the 1984 election campaign, needs to face the question of how long foreigners will be willing to go on financing America's budget and trade deficits.
Stephen Marris, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics, recently said in Congressional testimony that nobody knows how long this can go on - at least with any certainty. America, the richest and most powerful country in the world, he said, ''could continue to attract savings from abroad for quite some time.''
But he and many other economists think it is imprudent to count on this. He concludes that the limits of the ability of foreigners to finance the deficits will be reached by the end of next year.
Is it prudent to depend on foreigners to finance the American deficit indefinitely? Or should Americans put their own fiscal house in order?
A group of leading business executives, the Committee for Economic Development, says in a forthcoming policy statement: ''Getting the deficit down will challenge our nation's ability to rise above partisan and special interest and to act in the long-term interest of our economy and society. What we do now and during the next year will be a signal to the American people and to the rest of the world as to whether or not we are willing to take responsible, decisive and comprehensive actions to restore control over our economic destiny.''
Their anxiety contrasts sharply with the euphoria about the American economy so evident not only abroad but also in the American stock market yesterday - a soaring of spirits that is improving even more the odds on Mr. Reagan's re-election.

Title: ECONOMIC SCENE; FOREIGN FUNDS HELP ON DEFICIT

CONVENTION IN DALLAS: THE REPUBLICANS; REAGAN HAS ACHIEVED MANY GOALS, BUT SOME STIR OPPOSITION

Author: Pear, Robert

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]20 Aug 1984: A.18.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425158730?accountid=11752

Abstract: Another line from Mr. [Reagan]'s inaugural address recalls a goal that remains unfulfilled. ''For decades,'' he said, ''we have piled deficit upon deficit, mortgaging our future . . . for the temporary convenience of the present.'' Far from reducing the deficit, Mr. Reagan's policies, especially a three-stage tax cut, contributed to an increase. The deficit hit a record of $195 billion in the fiscal year 1983, up from $59.6 billion in 1980. Mr. Reagan's term has been marked by continuing controversy over Central America. He contends that the Soviet Union, Cuba and the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua are trying to ''install Communism by force throughout the hemisphere.'' Accordingly, he has sought to increase United States aid to the Government of El Salvador, which is fighting rebel guerrillas, and to the rebel groups trying to topple the Nicaraguan Government, whom he describes as ''freedom fighters'' against the Government of Nicaragua.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=CONVENTION+IN+DALLAS%3A+THE+REPUBLICANS%3B+REAGAN+HAS+ACHIEVED+MANY+GOALS%2C+BUT+SOME+STIR+OPPOSITION&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1984-08-20&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.18&amp;au=Pear%2C+Robert&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: In three years, President Reagan has achieved much of what he promised: curbing inflation, stimulating economic growth, reducing the role of the Government, limiting access to social welfare programs.
In his inaugural address, Mr. Reagan promised to end what he called ''an economic affliction of great proportions.'' The economy is now growing faster, with less inflation, than at any time since the early 1960's. Its vigor has surprised forecasters.
But the improvements have left many individuals untouched. For some, the importance of macroeconomic gains are outweighed by dissatisfaction with specific aspects of Mr. Reagan's domestic policies. He has challenged a bipartisan consensus on civil rights developed over 20 years. He tried to shift the emphasis of environmental policy from the protection to the development of natural resources. His Administration, acting under a Congressional mandate to review the Social Security disability rolls, has cut off benefits for thousands who were later found to be disabled and qualified.
Far Short of Balanced Budget
Another line from Mr. Reagan's inaugural address recalls a goal that remains unfulfilled. ''For decades,'' he said, ''we have piled deficit upon deficit, mortgaging our future . . . for the temporary convenience of the present.'' Far from reducing the deficit, Mr. Reagan's policies, especially a three-stage tax cut, contributed to an increase. The deficit hit a record of $195 billion in the fiscal year 1983, up from $59.6 billion in 1980.
However, Republicans say the economy is in better shape than it was four years ago.
Inflation is down. The Consumer Price Index, which rose 12.4 percent in the last year of the Carter Administration, rose just 3.8 percent last year, and it rose at an annual rate of 4.1 percent in the first half of this year.
In the process, the nation went through a deep 16-month recession. The unemployment rate reached a 40- year high, 10.6 percent, in the final months of 1982, when nearly 12 million people were out of work, but it has now declined to 7.4 percent, about the same level as when Mr. Reagan took office.
Median family income rose slightly last year, even after adjustment to account for inflation. But the purchasing power of such income was 3 percent less than the purchasing power of the median family income in 1975 or 1980. And in 1983 the national poverty rate reached its highest level in 18 years.
What follows is a summary of Mr. Reagan's record in key areas.
Budget
Mr. Reagan has reduced the rate of growth in social spending and sharply increased military spending. He has, moreover, altered the terms of public debate. The usual question now is not whether to cut back social programs but how much.
Mr. Reagan's last budget said there had been a ''dramatic halt in domestic spending growth.'' While this is true, both Administration officials and their opponents tend to overstate the changes. Mr. Reagan wants to magnify his success in gaining control of the budget, while his critics want to persuade voters that the changes have caused suffering.
The effects might have been more dramatic if Congress had approved all of Mr. Reagan's proposals. Administration officials say they got slightly more than half the budget reductions they sought.
Actual Spending Cuts
Mr. Reagan has repeatedly said that he reduced only the rate of growth in social spending, not the actual level. For some programs, including Medicaid and Social Security, this is true. But it is not true with respect to housing or job training; in these programs and others, actual spending authority was reduced.
Mr. Reagan attributes the vibrancy of the economy, in part, to the 1981 tax cut, a cornerstone of his program. Less than half the revenue lost as a result of the tax cut has been made up through savings in social programs. Over the last three years the increase in interest payments on the Federal debt exceeds all the savings Mr. Reagan has achieved in health, education, welfare and social service programs.
With the increase in interest costs and military outlays, the Federal budget has grown in relation to the economy. Total Federal outlays represented 24.7 percent of the gross national product in the fiscal year 1983, up from 22.4 percent in 1980, according to the Office of Management and Budget.
Defense
From the fiscal year 1977 to 1981, military spending grew at an annual rate of 2.6 percent, after increases to make up for inflation. Under Mr. Reagan, from 1981 to 1983, it rose 7.3 percent a year.
Mr. Reagan has emphasized big strategic weapon programs such as the MX intercontinental missile and the B-1 bomber more than conventional weapons.
The military accounted for 24 percent of the budget in the fiscal year 1981 and took up 26.4 percent in 1983. In his 1985 budget, Mr. Reagan proposed to spend $272 billion on the military, 29 percent of the Federal budget. Military spending will be about 50 percent greater this year than in 1981, and 25 percent greater in real terms after accounting for inflation.
Experts say the military services are bigger, more heavily armed and better staffed as a result of the additional spending. But Congressional investigators say the United States could not sustain a war with conventional weapons against the Soviet Union, and there has been growing debate about readiness.
While generally supporting the buildup, Congress has insisted on a somewhat slower pace than the President proposed.
Foreign AffairsThe Reagan Administration asserts that it has ''set a new direction'' in foreign policy, ''eliminating a decade's accumulation of doubts about U.S. staying power, constancy and readiness to support our friends.''
At his first news conference, in January 1981, Mr. Reagan said the Russians could not be trusted because ''they reserve unto themselves the right to commit any crime, to lie, to cheat'' in order to achieve world domination. The tone of his oratory has softened recently, and this summer the Administration expressed a willingness to explore the Soviet Union's offer to begin talks on limiting antisatellite weapons.
But there have been no major agreements with the Russians on arms control or other issues, and Mr. Reagan is the first President in more than 40 years not to have had a summit meeting with a Soviet leader.
Mr. Reagan's term has been marked by continuing controversy over Central America. He contends that the Soviet Union, Cuba and the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua are trying to ''install Communism by force throughout the hemisphere.'' Accordingly, he has sought to increase United States aid to the Government of El Salvador, which is fighting rebel guerrillas, and to the rebel groups trying to topple the Nicaraguan Government, whom he describes as ''freedom fighters'' against the Government of Nicaragua.
Invasion of Grenada
The United States invaded the Caribbean island of Grenada last October. The Administration said its purpose was to protect Americans on the island, to help restore democratic institutions, to forestall a ''Cuban occupation'' and to remove ''a brutal group of leftist thugs.'' But some critics said the evidence of a major Communist threat in Grenada was not as clear as Mr. Reagan argued.
His critics say that in Central America and elsewhere, Mr. Reagan has been far too willing to use military power rather than diplomacy to achieve his goals. Just as he has moderated his public pronouncements on the Russians this year, he has in recent months begun quiet talks with the Nicaraguans and tried to play down military aspects of the struggle in Central America.
In the Middle East, Mr. Reagan contends that he has restored good relations with Israel and that he has solid ties with Egypt and Saudi Arabia, two major pro-Western governments. But the Administration's hopes of achieving major diplomatic progress in the region, along the lines set forth in Mr. Reagan's speech of Sept. 1, 1982, have been disappointed. The construction of Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank has continued, despite Mr. Reagan's criticism of the policy. Efforts by Secretary of State George P. Shultz to bring about complete withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon collapsed after Syria refused to go along and forced the Lebanese to abrogate an agreement that Mr. Shultz had worked out between Lebanon and Israel in May 1983.
A truck-bombing killed 241 Americans at the Marine compound in Beirut last October, and Mr. Reagan ended the United States role in the multinational force there five months later. American standing in the region now seems to be on the rise, with Arab countries relying on the United States for help against Iran and for assistance in finding mines laid in the Red Sea.
Social Security
The President's proposals to trim Social Security, in 1981, caused such an uproar that he was forced to retreat and appoint a bipartisan commission to study the program's problems. Within three months of receiving the panel's report, Congress approved and Mr. Reagan signed a bill incorporating most of its proposals to guarantee the system's solvency.
Perhaps the biggest change was a six-month delay in the payment of annual cost-of-living adjustments, starting in 1983. The new law also increased Social Security payroll taxes, authorized taxation of benefits, called for a gradual increase in the standard retirement age and required coverage of new Federal workers and employees of nonprofit organizations.
Government actuaries said these changes would insure the solvency of the system well into the next century. But in recent months Mr. Reagan and Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan have suggested that the program might need to be re-examined before the end of the decade.
No Federal program has caused more trouble for the Administration than Social Security disability insurance. In reviewing the eligibility of those on the rolls, as required by a 1980 law, the Administration halted benefits for many people with serious mental or physical handicaps.
Social Security officials, reacting to what they described as ''horror stories,'' temporarily suspended the effort to cut off disability benefits.
Health
Medicare pays doctor and hospital bills for more than 26 million elderly and 3 million disabled people. The Reagan Administration proposed, and Congress in 1983 approved, the biggest change in the program since its creation. Hospitals that had been reimbursed for almost all ''reasonable'' costs are now paid a flat amount, fixed in advance, for treating any Medicare patient with a particular ailment. The new system, though not explicitly designed to save money, has made hospitals and doctors more cost-conscious.
Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of the Health and Human Services, says the Administration has ''broken the back of the health-care inflation monster.'' Critics say her statement is premature since medical costs continue to rise faster than other prices.
Laws passed with the support of the Reagan Administration require higher deductibles and premiums for Medicare coverage. Congress has rejected an Administration proposal to make people pay substantially more for the first weeks of hospital care in return for better protection against the cost of catastrophic illness.
The Administration has also slowed the growth of Medicaid, the Federal- state health program for the poor.
Poverty Programs
The Reagan Administration has made a basic change in the philosophy of social welfare programs while virtually halting their growth. Mr. Reagan has tried to limit benefits to what he calls the ''truly needy,'' and he defines the term more narrowly than any other President has since the 1960's.
The Congressional Budget Office estimated that spending had been reduced by these amounts, as opposed to what it would have been under laws existing in January 1981: Aid to Families with Dependent Children, reduced 13 percent; food stamps, 13 percent; child nutrition, 28 percent; general employment and training programs, 35 percent.
The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1981 eliminated cash welfare assistance for many of the working poor. In the past, welfare was intended to supplement the earnings of such people. But the Administration insists that benefits should be paid only to those who, because of age or disability, cannot work.
About one million people became ineligible for food stamps as a result of the 1981 law. Most had incomes exceeding 130 percent of the official poverty level. The law also reduced food stamp benefits for many, including some of the poor.
Rise in Poverty Rate
Hunger re-emerged as an issue in 1983. Mr. Reagan appointed a commission to study the problem. It concluded that reports of widespread hunger ''can neither be positively refuted nor definitively proved.'' But it recommended a slight increase in food assistance.
According to the Census Bureau, the poverty rate rose to 15.2 percent in 1983 from 13 percent in 1980 as the number of poor people rose by 6 million, to 35.3 million. The 1983 poverty rate was the highest since 1965. (A family of four was classified as poor if it had cash income of less than $10,178 last year.)
Mr. Reagan has curtailed spending for the construction of subsidized housing. He has redirected Federal aid into vouchers, or certificates, that low-income families can use to pay housing expenses. The Administration and its critics agree that the program represents a profound change after four decades of attempting to stimulate the production of low-income housing.
Civil Rights
Mr. Reagan has succeeded in restricting the range of remedies available for ending discrimination.
He says he disagrees with his predecessors and civil rights groups on just a few issues: he opposes busing as a means of school desegregation and quotas as a remedy for discrimination in employment and education.
But the disagreements have been more fundamental. Mr. Reagan has opposed amending the Constitution to guarantee equal rights for women. He tried to reverse a policy denying tax- exempt status to private schools that discriminate on the basis of race. (The Supreme Court rejected the Administration's position by a vote of 8 to 1.)
Voting Rights Act
The Administration initially resisted efforts to strengthen the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Mr. Reagan ultimately signed a bill passed with bipartisan support.
The Administration has tried to impose a stricter standard requiring people alleging discrimination to prove that it was intentional. Scorning broad-based affirmative action, the Administration has tried to limit relief to those who can show that they personally suffered discrimination.
After a string of losses, the Administration has won several civil rights cases in the Supreme Court. The Court adopted the Administration's narrow reading of a law that prohibits sex discrimination by schools and colleges receiving Federal aid. In a major victory for the Administration, the Court ruled that judges may not alter the rules of a valid seniority system to prevent the layoff of recently hired blacks.
Ralph G. Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, a coalition of national groups, speaks for the critics when he says that the Reagan team has ''the worst civil rights record of any Administration in more than half a century.'' Mr. Reagan says his critics have misrepresented his record.
Education
Mr. Reagan initially tried to abolish the Department of Education, as he promised in the 1980 campaign. In his budget for the fiscal year 1983, he said the Federal role in education ''should return to more traditional minimal levels.'' Accordingly, he proposed ''significant reductions in funding'' for almost all education programs.
Congress has consistently provided more money for education than Mr. Reagan wanted. In early 1982 he envisioned outlays declining steadily from $15.4 billion to $8.3 billion in 1987. In fact, there was a 5 percent reduction in education spending as outlays declined from $15.1 billion in 1981 to $14.3 billion in 1982. The President's budget for 1985 sought $15.5 billion.
A Presidential commission warned last year that ''a rising tide of mediocrity'' threatened American education. Mr. Reagan toured the country lamenting the state of education. He summoned schools ''back to basics,'' proposed merit pay for teachers and urged principals to crack down on discipline problems. But he did not propose any substantial increase in Federal aid.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates that three years of cutbacks have reduced spending on aid for the education of disadvantaged children by 17 percent, guaranteed student loans by 27 percent and other financial aid for college students by 13 percent, as opposed to previously anticipated outlays.
Congress has not approved Mr. Reagan's proposal to allow parents a tax credit for tuition at private or parochial schools.
Nor has Congress approved his proposal for a constitutional amendment permitting organized prayer in public schools. But it has approved a bill allowing students to hold religious meetings in schools before or after regular class hours, provided the meetings are not sponsored by the school or its teachers.
Environment
When Mr. Reagan signed a report of the Council on Environmental Quality last month, he said the nation ''has a God-given responsibility to preserve and protect'' its natural resources. He did not say that the council's budget had been reduced to $700,000 a year from $3.1 billion in the fiscal year 1980.
Mr. Reagan's top two environmental appointees were forced to resign. Anne McGill Burford stepped down as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency in March 1983 amid charges that agency officials had been lax in enforcing hazardous waste laws, had made ''sweetheart deals'' with polluters and had manipulated toxic cleanup grants for political purposes. The allegations were not tested in court. But Rita M. Lavelle, who was in charge of the agency's toxic waste program, was found guilty of perjury and obstructing a Congressional investigation.
Interior Secretary James G. Watt resigned seven months later. His policies had angered environmental groups and their allies in Congress, but the immediate occasion was an off-the-cuff remark in praising a Federal commission on coal leasing, on which, he said, ''I have a black, I have a woman, two Jews and a cripple - and we have talent.''
Emphasis on Development
Under Mr. Reagan, the Interior Department has shifted its emphasis from the protection of public lands toward the development of natural resources. Oil and mining companies, ranchers, loggers and developers welcomed the change, as did conservatives committed to a free-market economy. But Congress imposed moratoriums on oil and coal leasing.
Agriculture
Despite Mr. Reagan's desire to curtail Government intervention in the economy, farm subsidies and price supports became more costly than ever last year. Commodity price supports and related programs cost $18.9 billion in the fiscal year 1983, up from $4 billion in 1981. Those figures do not include $9 billion worth of surplus commodities used to pay farmers under an Administration program to discourage planting excess crops.
The program, begun by Mr. Reagan in 1983, represented an extraordinary change in his farm policy, which had stressed production and little Government intervention. But depressed export markets and two years of bumper crops had created massive surpluses.
Administration officials say the program achieved its purpose, reducing stockpiles of corn, rice and cotton. But multimillion-dollar payments to some farmers drew harsh criticism.
Meanwhile, Congress approved legislation that paid farmers not to produce milk. Mr. Reagan signed the bill although he had reservations about its cost and its departure from free-market principles.
Antitrust Policy
The Reagan Administration has made fundamental changes in antitrust policy.
William F. Baxter, who presided over the antitrust division of the Justice Department for the first three years of the Reagan Administration, insisted that antitrust laws must not be used to penalize efficiency. He overhauled the department's merger guidelines.
The Administration achieved the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company through settlement of a lawsuit brought in 1974. It also dropped a 13-year-old antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation. The Federal Trade Commission, which shares responsibility for enforcing antitrust laws, has approved mergers and joint ventures involving such big businesses as Texaco and Getty Oil. However, it has applied the laws in novel ways to city governments, challenging, for example, local taxi regulations.
Trade
The foreign trade deficit reached a record of $69.4 billion last year. If the trend of the first five months continues, the deficit for 1984 will be $122 billion, 76 percent greater than last year.
The expanding economy and the strength of the dollar have driven demand for imports. In addition, high interest rates in this country have forced up the international value of the dollar, making it relatively cheap for the United States to import foreign goods and expensive for other countries to buy American products. Some economists contend the high interest rates result, in part, from huge Federal budget deficits. Democrats say that Administration policies contributed to the budget deficit, so Mr. Reagan must bear some responsibility for the trade deficit.
The President says he is committed to free-trade principles, but he has granted import relief to the specialty steel and motorcycle industries, tightened restrictions on textile imports and encouraged Japan to extend ''voluntary'' limits on auto sales to the United States.
Decentralization
Mr. Reagan has reduced Federal regulations and given states more authority to decide how Federal grants should be spent.
In 1981, 70 special-purpose Federal programs were merged into nine general-purpose grants. Federal officials attached few strings to the block grants, so hundreds of pages of regulations were eliminated. The grants cover broad areas like social services, preventive health and maternal and child health.
State officials have generally welcomed this aspect of Mr. Reagan's ''new federalism'' but objected to the simultaneous reduction in aid. The Federal Government spends 20 to 25 percent less for block grants than it spent for the same programs before they were consolidated. As a result, many local agencies have had to reduce services.
Congress never showed much interest in Mr. Reagan's proposal for a ''swap'' under which the Federal Government would assume all Medicaid costs while the states took responsibility for welfare and food stamps.
The Administration has found support for many of its efforts to reduce economic regulation of business, industry, prices and markets. But it has met opposition to many of its efforts to roll back health, safety and environmental rules.

REAGAN ATTACKS CONGRESS'S ROLE ON MANY FRONTS

Author: FRANCIS X. CLINES , Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]05 Apr 1984: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424942983?accountid=11752

Abstract: Mr. [Reagan] described in a clearly complaining tone the Congressional debate on the topic, '' 'Oh, bring our men home, take them away,' '' and declared: ''All this can do is stimulate the terrorists and urge them on to further attacks.'' Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=REAGAN+ATTACKS+CONGRESS%27S+ROLE+ON+MANY+FRONTS&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1984-04-05&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=FRANCIS+X.+CLINES+%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: President Reagan, entering the third month of his re-election campaign, challenged Congress tonight on a broad array of foreign and domestic issues.
Mr. Reagan, in a nationally televised news conference, repeatedly criticized Congress for its role on such issues as Lebanon, El Salvador aid, restrictions of the War Powers act, public school prayer, his fairness toward the poor and the ''sleaze factor'' charges being lodged against his appointees by Congressional Democrats.
The President, less than a week after withdrawing forces from the coast of Lebanon, said flatly that Congress ''must take a responsibility'' for events in Lebanon. More than 260 Marines died during the President's controversial commitment of American troops to a multinational peackeeping force in Beirut.
A Complaining Tone
Mr. Reagan described in a clearly complaining tone the Congressional debate on the topic, '' 'Oh, bring our men home, take them away,' '' and declared: ''All this can do is stimulate the terrorists and urge them on to further attacks.''
After such a commitment of troops, the President contended, ''You have rendered them ineffective when you conduct that kind of a debate in public.''
The President was noticeably more combative toward Congress, too, in denouncing as ''not helpful in what we're trying to do'' a proposal approved in the Senate that would limit his request for El Salvador aid.
He complained that such questions as the President's freedom in international diplomacy should be made subject under the War Powers Act to ''a committee of 535 individuals, no matter how well intentioned.''
His remarks this evening amounted to his strongest criticism yet of Congress's attempts to differ with or modify his policy initiatives. Response From Democrats
Congressional Democrats, equally alert to the volatility of election-year issues, quickly responded to the President, repeating their charges that his tax cut and budget policies had benefited the affluent at the expense of the poor, and that this had now been documented by the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office.
''On the issue of fairness,'' House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. declared, ''Everyone believes the Congressional Budget Office. No one believes Reagan.''
During his news conference, the President challenged the Democrats' attempt to raise the ''fairness'' issue, decalring: ''It's probably the most glaring example of political demagoguery that our friends have been engaging in.'' He stressed that lower inflation and the tax cut have both, in his opinion, helped the poor. The Congressional Budget Office study found that families with annual incomes of less than $10,000 lost $400 in in earning power while those with incomes above $80,000 had gained $8,000.
The President made a point of noting that his budget program ''wasn't an executive order, it was passed by Congress.''
The President's performance in the half-hour session clearly pointed toward the election-year tradition of American politics by which an incumbent President often finds himself running against Congress as the chief focus in defending his stewardship. Meese Controversy
In discussing the embattled situation of Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential Counselor and Attorney General nominee who is now the focus of a special prosecutor's inquiry, the President defended the integrity of all his appointees. He rejected ''the use of the word sleaze'' now being bandied about in Democratic broadsides, and he accused opponents of attempting ''guilt by accusation.''
''I believe the halls of government are as sacred as the temples of worship,'' he declared at his news conferene, stressing that service in his Administration demanded ''nothing but the highest integrity.''
The President defended Mr. Meese, his long-time friend and political advisor, and said he was ''not going to take any action for political expediency.''
He denied accusations that there is a steady pattern of officials leaving his Administration under charges of malfeasance, saying that they left to spare the Administration political pressure and that ''many have been cleared.''
''Its' strange that their names keep popping up again,'' he said, referring to the Democratic attempt to make a re- election year issue of the so-called ''sleaze factor.'' A Defense on School Prayer
Mr. Reagan's s tendency toward greater criticism of Congress also was clear as he defended his recent campaign to enact a Constitutional amendment to restore officially condoned public school prayer. The President said that most of the Senate had misconstrued his proposal as mandating prayer. ''We were asking nothing of the kind,'' he said.
Actually, the Reagan Administration helped defeat a compromise proposal allowing for set periods of voluntary silent prayer in public schools in order to press for its own proposal for vocal prayer periods in which unwilling students would have had to excuse themselves.
In the course of answering a question about Colorado Governor Richard D. Lamm's recent remarks on the need to permit terminally ill old people to die, the President indicated some criticism of the news media. He declined to answer the question specifically saying news accounts have not been accurate and he himself had been ''interpreted incorrectly myself some times.'' Timing Considered Important
The timing of the news conference, a day after the New York Democratic primary won by Walter F. Mondale, was considered important by the President's political advisors for the opportunity afforded the President to remind voters of his incumbency during a period when he is not campaigning heavily. It was the 23d prime-time TV news conference of his 38 months in office, and the second since he announced his candidacy for re-election.
The Meese controversy, now the focus of a court-appointed special prosecutor, had been dismissed by the President in earlier comments as a case of misperception fostered by his political opponents. The President has said that, far from engaging in job favoritism in exchange for financial favors, the members of his Administration have suffered considerable financial sacrifices in volunteering to leave the private sector for lower paying Government jobs.
The Democrats have been attempting to make Mr. Meese the symbol of a 1984 campaign issue that, in partisan attacks, has been termed the ''sleaze factor,'' an alleged pattern of misbehavior and poor judgement critics attribute to more than two score Reagan appointees in the past three years. Republicans have dismissed this as a desperate tactic resorted to by the Democrats in part because the general economic recovery has made the President's own performance in office so difficult to challenge.
Mr. Meese has denounced the controversy as baseless election-year politics and as the work of unnamed individuals who were ''peddling distortions'' to harm himself and the President. He is to remain in his job as Counselor to the President while the special prosecutor's inquiry goes forward into the 1984 election year. This will take several months, at a minimum, and White House officials concede it presents a lingering political problem, at least until the inquiry is resolved one way or the other. Mr. Meese himself requested the inquiry after pressure began mounting in the Senate.
Among the questions that might be pursued by the special prosecutor is whether there is a connection between the job appointments of a half dozen Reagan Administration officials and the fact that they had helped Mr. Meese with various aspects of his personal financial problems. A related topic involves his faliure to properly disclose to the Government a $15,000 loan he received from on of those apppointees. In addition, there is the question of how involved Mr. Meese might have been with some 1980 Jimmy Carter campaign papers found in the Reagan campaign files.

Subject: UNITED STATES POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; SPEECHES AND STATEMENTS; PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF 1984; ELECTION ISSUES; APPOINTMENTS AND EXECUTIVE CHANGES; ETHICS; FOREIGN AID; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE; WAR POWERS ACT OF 1973; EDUCATION AND SCHOOLS; PRAYERS AND PRAYER BOOKS; UNITED STATES ECONOMY; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PRESS CONFERENCES
