REAGAN AT MIDTERM; News Analysis

Author: HEDRICK SMITH, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]29 Dec 1982: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424515567?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''If the President doesn't like the word 'compromise,' '' he said, ''well then, let's say he's got to make some adjustments in the original course. There's a problem with people who think there's so much mileage in being right all the time, I don't care who it is, even the President of the United States.'' ''There's more resistance in the political system now to more of the President's desire for change,'' David Gergen, the White House communications director, conceded. ''It's too early to judge how this Presidency will go down. If the next two years are as productive as the first two, he'll go down as the first successful Presidency in 20 years. But there are a lot more obstacles. We're in a difficult period now. It's going to be tougher with Congress. But at least he's got the foundation laid.'' ''He's more cautious, more reflective,'' said one close associate. ''He's not a man given to saying 'I'm worried' or 'I'm concerned,' but you do occasionally hear him say things like that now in a general sense. He's not yet translated that into specific things like saying, 'I wonder if we're doing the right thing on the economy,' or 'I wonder if we're going for too much on defense.' It's more general than that: worrying aloud about Congress or being concerned about the economy.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=REAGAN+AT+MIDTERM%3B+News+Analysis%3A+%5Banalysis%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-12-29&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=HEDRICK+SMITH%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: At midterm, the once-dazzling political momentum of what conservatives enthusiastically called the Reagan Revolution has stalled. In the year ahead, President Reagan faces what his allies and advisers see as the most critical tests of his Presidency both at home and abroad.
''Historically, the third year is the one that makes or breaks a Presidency, and Ronald Reagan's third year is more critical for him than any President since World War II,'' said Richard Wirthlin, the President's longtime poll-taker and a fellow California Republican conservative.
''It's the year when people will judge the President not only by the goals he articulated in the campaign or the legislation he has passed, but how his program has affected their lives,'' Mr. Wirthlin said. ''It's also a year in which foreign policy will be given a more severe test.''
On a string of tough issues - the budget, Social Security, military spending, the MX missile, arms control talks with the Russians, Middle East diplomacy - the choice that politicians of both parties see Mr. Reagan confronting is between his ideology and political pragmatism, between the tactics of confrontation and compromise, between sticking with a course that suits the Republican right or shifting more toward the political center. Voicing Private Anxieties
On the major issues, some of the President's White House aides and Cabinet associates see similar forks in the political road. They prefer not to be identified in speaking. But privately, some acknowledge their concern that his presidency faces serious difficulties.
Their brimming optimism of 1981 has been tempered by recession and losses in the November elections as well as by stunning defeats on the MX missile and other issues in the recent special session of Congress. They concede not only the strain of recession but broad Congressional disillusion with the economic program, a perceptible shift in power from the White House toward Congress since November, and open splits and uneasiness among Republicans, especially while there is uncertainty whether Mr. Reagan intends to run in 1984. On Capitol Hill, Republicans grumble that the White House is not being well run but is hobbled by factional tensions.
''I'm usually the Dr. Norman Vincent Peale type, upbeat and trying to smile as often as I can,'' said Robert H. Michel, the Illinois conservative who is House Republican leader, ''but I'm really apprehensive and fearful of where we're going next year unless the economy comes back in the spring.'' 'Some Adjustments' in Course
''If the President doesn't like the word 'compromise,' '' he said, ''well then, let's say he's got to make some adjustments in the original course. There's a problem with people who think there's so much mileage in being right all the time, I don't care who it is, even the President of the United States.''
''You can't govern this country when it's polarized,'' said Senator William Cohen, a Republican moderate from Maine. ''I think the President has got to compromise on most issues until the unemployment rate comes down.''
''There's more resistance in the political system now to more of the President's desire for change,'' David Gergen, the White House communications director, conceded. ''It's too early to judge how this Presidency will go down. If the next two years are as productive as the first two, he'll go down as the first successful Presidency in 20 years. But there are a lot more obstacles. We're in a difficult period now. It's going to be tougher with Congress. But at least he's got the foundation laid.''
In public appearances, President Reagan projects undiminished the jaunty confidence of his 1980 campaign or his stunningly successful 1981 legislative year. He reminds visitors that in his first two years, inflation fell from 13.1 to 4.8 percent, interest rates dropped from 21 percent to 11.5 percent, and the pace of growth in Federal spending has been slowed while the growth of military spending has been accelerated.
But in place of his earlier calls for a balanced Federal budget in 1983 or 1984 and economic recovery that would deal with both inflation and unemployment, Mr. Reagan now talks of ''structural deficits'' of well over $100 billion and ''structural unemployment'' of 6 to 6.5 percent. 'Horrendous Deficits' Coming
In year-end interviews, he tacitly acknowledges that a long, draining effort lies ahead. ''We're going to be faced with horrendous deficits for several years,'' he told editors of the Hearst newspapers. ''You cannot cut the budget enough to balance it. You cannot raise taxes enough to balance it.''
And when his close associates are promised anonymity, some say that even though the President generally voices his faith in his program, they have lately detected a subtle change in private moments.
''He's more cautious, more reflective,'' said one close associate. ''He's not a man given to saying 'I'm worried' or 'I'm concerned,' but you do occasionally hear him say things like that now in a general sense. He's not yet translated that into specific things like saying, 'I wonder if we're doing the right thing on the economy,' or 'I wonder if we're going for too much on defense.' It's more general than that: worrying aloud about Congress or being concerned about the economy.''
Nonetheless, senior White House officials discourage expectation that President Reagan will readily bend in his dealings with the new Congress.
''The Reagan you saw on MX was a confrontational Reagan,'' one senior Presidential aide said. ''He went for the production funds that he wanted. When he got beaten, he compromised.'' 'He'll Go for 75 Percent'
''Next year, you're going to see a Reagan who's not going to be quick to compromise on principle,'' this official continued. ''But if he can get 75 percent of what he wants, he'll go for 75 percent and not insist on 100 percent if he can't get that. Of course, we know it's going to be tougher for us to get what he wants in the future.''
Political realities have changed dramatically since 1981. The loss of 26 Republican seats in the House has buried the Reagan coalition that passed his big budget and tax cuts of 1981 and has given Democrats control of the House.
Beyond that, White House strategists acknowledge that the elections showed an erosion of public support; many minority, blue collar and elderly voters who supported Mr. Reagan in 1980 went back to the Democratic Party.
They also concede that the election mood will affect the legislative debate in 1983. As Mr. Gergen observed, ''to be even talking now about cuts in entitlement programs brands you as antiblack, antipoor and insensitive.'' Some of the 19 Republican senators up for re-election in 1984 are acutely sensitive to avoiding these labels as they approach the new Congressional session. Not the Feared Figure He Was
In sum, the President's political impact has diminished. He is not the feared figure of 18 months ago. Moreover, the unity of the Republican Senate majority was seriously wounded by the conservative filibuster against increasing the Federal gasoline tax that was led by Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican.
''People up here will be looking to see whether the White House draws a line against Helms in the new year,'' said an aide to Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader. ''The President will have to choose pretty early between the right and the center.''
The President's willingness to compromise next year will ''depend on the issue,'' his aides say. On Social Security revisions, he is described as wanting to develop a bipartisan solution, even starting with some possible bargaining in the bipartisan commission. On taxes, they say he is adamant about keeping in place the 10 percent cut in the tax rate scheduled for July.
Some Congressional Republicans believe that Mr. Reagan must give a signal of new political realism in his State of the Union Address in the form of proposals dealing with unemployment and the hard-hit ''smokestack industries'' of the Northeast and Middle West. But a more prevalent view is that the key indicator will be his stand on military spending: Will he go for high growth or moderate his past trend? Some See His Goals as Too High
In preliminary Administration discussions, President Reagan has given the impression he wants cuts of $20 billion in domestic programs and a real increase of 10 to 12 percent in military spending. Republican leaders regard that as unrealistic.
''The President has just got to recognize he's going to have to make some adjustments there,'' said Mr. Michel. ''He's going to want to hang tough. But when you have members of the Armed Services Committee, some pretty hard-neck guys, saying there's something wrong with his levels, then the President just can't blindly ignore it.''
The White House thinking is that the President knows privately he will have to compromise eventually but will want to stake out a tough early bargaining position. But Democrats and even some Republicans warn that tactic is risky. ''If the President comes in and plays the old budget game and his budget is rejected by both parties, it could just deal him out of the budget negotiations,'' Representative James R. Jones, chairman of the House Budget Committee, said. Foreign Policy Is the Reverse
Curiously, as the President seems to have lost political initiative with Congress, the reverse has happened in foreign policy. Once fairly aloof and disengaged, he has now become more involved and taken some new initiatives. Some of his advisers are hopeful that foreign affairs will provide important breakthroughs in 1983, though they acknowledge the pitfalls.
Problems with Western Europe have eased somewhat, thanks largely to the quiet diplomacy of Secretary of State George P. Shultz. But protectionist sentiment remains a politically explosive force in Congress as well as in Europe and Japan. While 1982 left a standoff both with China and the Soviet Union, the President and his advisers now sense an opportunity in the Middle East.
As the year ends, the Administration has had to concede failure in its effort to arrange the withdrawal of troops of Israel, Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization from Lebanon, one key to progress. But lately, direct talks between Lebanon and Israel have engendered hope.
On a parallel track, President Reagan has pushed hard to draw King Hussein of Jordan into talks with Egypt and Israel on Palestinian self-rule. After two rounds of talks with Hussein, Mr. Reagan voiced the hope that this target was now ''within our reach.'' Assurances to King Reported
Building on his initiative of Sept. 1, which gave the outline for a broad Palestinian agreement linking the West Bank loosely with Jordan, the President was reported to have given the King some assurances of American backing for the Arab position that Israel should relinquish sovereignty over most of the West Bank.
This is Mr. Reagan's most ambitious and risky venture in personal diplomacy. It runs the perils of intricate and inconclusive maneuvering by King Hussein and the Palestinian leadership and sharp confrontation with Israel with repercussions in the Unitd States, should Hussein declare that he will enter the negotiations if Israel will halt its settlement program on the West Bank.
With Moscow, Mr. Reagan has only just begun serious political exchanges with the new Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov. But Administration policy-makers expect the pace of arms negotiations and the accompanying propaganda maneuvering to intensify next spring and summer.
Although American interest has traditionally been on strategic arms talks, there is little sign of much active bargaining. Far more acute and active diplomacy involves the Administration's effort to get Moscow to dismantle its force of 333 SS-20 medium range missiles with the threat to deploy 572 American missiles in Europe, starting late in 1983, or accepting a complete ban on both sets of missiles. Some Expect Both to Moderate
Washington's quick rejection of Mr. Andropov's offer to take the Soviet inventory down to 162 missiles, to match the British and French forces, merely sets the stage for further moves. Although the President and his spokesman firmly insist on the Reagan ''zero option,'' calling for each side to scrap its medium range missiles, there are hints that some officials expect both Moscow and Washington to moderate their stances.
But officials concede these are delicate negotiations that will test not only American ingenuity but the strength and support of West European governments who have sought the American missiles but whose publics are tempted by arms control proposals. Some officials believe President Reagan will be hard-pressed to avoid being thrown on the political defensive unless he shows flexibility.
It is almost inevitable that the sense of pressure on all fronts raises the question of changes in the Reagan Cabinet or White House staff, often traditional in a third year. Cabinet Changes Expected
The President himself, talking to the Hearst editors on Dec. 13, hinted at coming changes. Speaking of his Cabinet, he said, ''A number are going to have to return to their own activities, and I am going to hate to lose them.''
He mentioned no names, but there has already been talk about the possible departure in spring or summer of Raymond H. Donovan, the Labor Secretary; Samuel R. Pierce Jr., Secretary of Housing and Urban Development; and David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget.
Although White House officials contend that James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, and Ed Meese 3d, the President's counselor, have restored reasonable working relations after some earlier frictions, prominent Congressional Republicans complain of tensions and lack of coordination between them. Moreover, Michael K. Deaver, the President's close aide and deputy White House chief of staff, has talked persistently of leaving for private business in spring or early summer and his departure could precipitate a major White House shake-up.
But ultimately, Mr. Reagan's political fate, and probably even his decision on running for a second term, rides on the economy, where the outlook is poor. As the recession has stretched on, professional economists have lowered their projections for economic growth in 1983 from 3 or 4 percent to 1.5 to 2 percent, and unemployment has pushed up to 10.8 percent.
More and more Republicans say that the President's program, which Senator Baker termed ''a riverboat gamble,'' is not paying off. Anemic Recovery No Help
Presidential advisers assert that recovery will come but worry that it will be so anemic that it will leave Republicans running for reelection with unemployment close to 10 percent late in 1984. In the budget debate, they are privately at odds over over whether the President should make his target roughly 3 percent or 5 percent growth over the next two years, risking continued high unemployment with fairly tight money on the one hand or inviting a looser monetary policy and rekindling inflation on the other.
''We all believe recovery is coming in 1983, but the significant question is how long and how strong will it be,'' said one Presidential aide. ''Everybody agrees we can't just leave the economy on automatic pilot and we've got to do more. But there's no agreement now on what that means we should do.''

WORLD ECONOMIC ISSUE; Economic Analysis

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]13 Dec 1982: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424502541?accountid=11752

Abstract: Many economists still believe in that basic Keynesian solution. But most believe it too simplistic and too inflation-prone. Many ''post-Keynesian'' economists, such as Prof. Sidney Weintraub of the University of Pennsylvania, have as a major theme the supplementing of general economic policies with an ''incomes policy'' to provide tax incentives or penalties to induce labor and management to make wage decisions that do not add to inflation. Different Focus Suggested M. Louise Curley, a vice president and economist at Scudder, Stevens & Clark, the investment counseling concern, warns that there is still ''no consensus on monetary policy.'' But she, too, says, ''Only a global approach will work,'' and she calls for ''prudent shifts in monetary and fiscal policy, which will have to vary from country to country.'' She says there may have to be target zones for exchange rates of major countries. ''[John Maynard Keynes] may be right now, given the massive unemployed resources in the world,'' he says. ''The biggest risks are on the downside.'' He says interest rates need to be driven down further, declaring, ''[Paul A. Volcker] should be aware of the risks all over the world. This is not just a domestic issue.'' Since Death of Brezhnev

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=WORLD+ECONOMIC+ISSUE%3B+Economic+Analysis%3A+%5Bseries%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-12-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Last of six articles that have appeared periodically on current world economic problems
After three decades of the greatest growth in history, the world economy has been caught for the last three years in what a committee of international economists assembled by the United
Nations calls ''a vicious spiral of contraction.'' The key economic issue facing all nations today is how to break that spiral and get back on a path of steady growth. But there are sharp disagreements among governments on how to proceed.
High unemployment in the industrial world, the most severe since the Depression of the 1930's, is increasing pressure on governments to pursue ''beggar my neighbor'' policies, excluding foreign goods or devaluing currencies to save jobs at home, whatever the consequences for other nations. Suffering and Instability
Disputes between industrialized countries and developing countries have grown worse as the developing nations see the prices of their commodities fall and the incomes of many of their people depressed to - or below -the subsistence level.
''Present trends in the world economy,'' warns the Committee for Development Planning of the United Nations, ''point to the danger of further contraction and stagnation, entailing extensive human suffering in many of the poorest developing countries, as well as risks of widespread political instability.''
The decades of expanding world trade that followed World War II have bound the fate of all nations together. Economic Interdependence
The United States, Japan and Europe are linked by vast flows of money, and every advanced industrial country sells from one-third to one-half of its manufactured exports to the developing countries.
And the Communist countries of Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union and China are increasingly linked to the developed market economies of East Asia, Western Europe and North America as well as to the developing countries.
This economic interdependence accelerated expansion during the prosperous years through growing trade, higher output and greater production efficiency resulting from the international division of labor. Competition for Markets
But this same interdependence is now aggravating the shrinkage of the world economy, as foreign markets contract and nations seek to protect their own economies.
Until the beginning of the 1980's, the leading countries of the industrial world shared a common perspective on economic policy, giving priority to fighting inflation, with the major stress on monetary restraint.
The second ''oil shock'' of 1979 jolted the world into higher inflation and initially strengthened the consensus on tightening the flow of money. In the United States the change was signaled by President Jimmy Carter's replacement of G. William Miller as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board with Paul A. Volcker, for the stated purpose of bringing down double-digit inflation and bolstering the failing dollar through a tough monetary policy.
One result of this widespread assault on inflation was a steep rise in unemployment to the highest levels since the Depression. And it is climbing unemployment that has broken the anti-inflation consensus within and among nations. Choices Facing the U.S.
The Reagan Administration appears split: Should it pursue stimulative fiscal policies - such as relaxation of monetary curbs - despite huge looming budget deficits? Or should it take a more austere approach, raising taxes, cutting spending - including military outlays - and thus narrowing the budget deficit, while keeping monetary policy relatively restrictive in order to bring down inflation and interest rates?
Other countries are on courses dictated by their leaders' ideologies and the interests of their major constituencies. The Conservative Margaret Thatcher, strengthened politically by Britain's victory over Argentina in the Falkland Islands war, seems determined to hold to her hard-boiled free-market and monetarist course, although, with unemployment above 14 percent, there are signs that the British are loosening the monetary reins.
But France, under its Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, has put through a program of nationalization of selected industries and banks. This has provoked a flight of capital to other countries, weakening the franc and jeopardizing the drive to stimulate growth and bring down unemployment. Earlier U.S. Effort Noted
The Mitterrand attempt to go for growth on its own mirrored the earlier effort of the Carter Administration, during its first three years in office, to spur expansion and reduce unemployment - an effort that was aborted by worsened inflation and a weakened dollar.
The nations have become so interdependent that a program for growth apparently needs to be based on a coordinated international policy. Yet it is clear that any program for world recovery will depend, first and foremost, on policies to regenerate continuing expansion in the United States, still the most important economy in the world and a crucial market for both rich and poor countries.
But there is not yet any agreement, in the United States or the other leading industrial countries, on what policy for lasting recovery should be. A struggle is still going on over whether to give the highest priority to ending unemployment or to stopping inflation.
Sir Geoffrey Howe, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer and a strong monetarist, has argued that stable growth will resume only when the back of inflation has been decisively broken. To push for expansion prematurely, he contends, would be to lose the hard, costly struggle against inflation just when it can be won. More Arguments Heard
But monetarism - its most famous advocate is Prof. Milton Friedman, a winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science - is being assailed these days not only by liberals but also by conservatives such as Friedrich A. von Hayek, another Nobel laureate, who maintains that moderate monetary restraint is simply prolonging the agony of both unemployment and inflation.
Professor von Hayek said recently that, if inflation was to be stopped and growth restored, ''you have to do it rapidly and drastically.'' In an interview a decade ago, he said it would be a lot easier to get the people of a democratic country to endure 30 percent unemployment for six months than to endure 10 percent unemployment for three years.
No government in the West appears prepared to risk such shock treatment. On the contrary, pressures are building within all countries for a shift toward policies of fiscal and monetary stimulus, to stave off the threat of depression and induce early recovery. The New Game: Fighting Depression
Some economists believe the world is already in a depression. Prof. George Stigler of the University of Chicago, this year's Nobel laureate in economics, made the term ''depression'' respectable when he used it to describe the current slump after emerging from a meeting with President Reagan.
Whether the world is in a recession or depression is, as he said, a semantic question. Whatever the semantics, this is not yet nearly so catastrophic a depression as that of the 1930's. But many economists and international groups have warned that it could degenerate into a state comparable to the collapse that brought Adolf Hitler to power in Germany and led inexorably to World War II.
How to prevent another deep depression is an issue most economists thought they would never have to face again. A consensus among economists emerged in the late 1930's and 40's - a consensus that the basic answer to depression had been discovered by the British economist John Maynard Keynes and his followers. Prescribing a Mixture
That answer was a call for national governments, when output fell to levels too low to sustain high employment, to increase the total level of money demand for goods and services to create more jobs.
This could be done by the right mixture of fiscal and monetary measures - by cutting taxes or raising government expenditures, even if this meant incurring large budget deficits, and by supplying more money to the economy and reducing interest rates to encourage consumer spending and business investment.
Many economists still believe in that basic Keynesian solution. But most believe it too simplistic and too inflation-prone. Many ''post-Keynesian'' economists, such as Prof. Sidney Weintraub of the University of Pennsylvania, have as a major theme the supplementing of general economic policies with an ''incomes policy'' to provide tax incentives or penalties to induce labor and management to make wage decisions that do not add to inflation. Different Focus Suggested
Also emerging is a group that might be called post-monetarists - economists who hold that the monetarists believe in too simple and rigid a link between a measurable supply of money and the level of prices.
Some critics of monetarism, such as Prof. Benjamin Friedman of Harvard and Henry Kaufman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, believe that the monetary authorities should focus more on the total credit needs of the economy and on interest rates.
Others coming from a monetarist background, such as Prof. Ronald McKinnon of Stanford University, believe the Federal Reserve's monetary policy has been technically mismanaged because the central bank has focused on national rather than world money in an era of international financial interdependence. Professor McKinnon maintains that the money supply of the industrial countries is a better determinant of United States economic activity than the domestic money supply.
He contends that when the Federal Reserve failed to accommodate the surging international demand for the dollar that started in late 1980, the value of the dollar rose to unrealistic levels, damaging America's trade position, while strong demand for the dollar and unduly tight monetary reins produced higher interest rates and a much steeper recession than Washington had expected. Emergence of a New Consensus
Although it is too early to be certain, a new post-Keynesian and post-monetarist consensus appears to be emerging. This consensus would take as its point of departure the current world slump, with its grave deflationary dangers, reminiscent of the problems that the world confronted half a century ago. Deflationary pressures are particularly hurting the developing countries, which are so dependent on the prices they get for their commodity exports, and are even jeopardizing the existence of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
Although the drop in oil prices may eventually ease the problems of international deficits suffered by the oil-importing nations, it could in the interim intensify world financial problems by drying up international flows of capital that had been generated by the members of OPEC. Their surpluses, now sliding into deficits, have been recycled by American and other Western banks, which have been able to make use of the funds on deposit.
The strains on the financial system have grown intense as the enormous accumulations of debt have run into hundreds of billions of dollars. Recent international meetings, such as last week's Frankfurt gathering of the United States, West Germany, France, Britain and Japan, have been efforts to devise a plan for preventing the collapse of that mountain of debt. The Aftereffects of Wars
As painful as world inflation has been, world deflation could be even worse, accelerating the spiral into a deep depression. Historically, deep depressions have, sooner or later, followed major wars.
Edward M. Bernstein, the first research director of the International Monetary Fund, contended more than two decades ago that the critical historical link between war and economic depression had been the relation between gold reserves and the quantity of money, together with the rigidity and mismanagement of currency rates.
Wars exhausted the money-creating powers of the gold-standard countries. After wars ended, the limitations of holding gold reserves forced deflation upon them.
After World War I, for instance, all the major countries adopted highly restrictive monetary policies, which, by the end of the 1920's, had choked off economic growth. World deflation was aggravated by protectionist trade policies. In the United States the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 hurt other countries' exports, provoking retaliation, and led those hurt to engage in severe deflation to maintain their currencies' exchange rates. Bretton Woods and GATT
After World War II, the United States, Britain and other major nations were determined to end the cycle of wartime booms and postwar busts.
They pledged themselves to avoid protectionism through the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. And, at the 1944 monetary conference held at Bretton Woods, N.H., they created a monetary system intended to be more flexible and expansive than the old gold standard, although at its center was the fixed relationship between the dollar and gold, which was pegged at $35 an ounce.
But the United States, by running deficits and supplying dollars and gold to the rest of the world and by accepting others' currency devaluations, made it possible for both world economic growth - and inflation - to continue far longer than it had after World War I.
This could not last forever. As early as 1959, Prof. Robert Triffin of Yale pointed out the dilemma: The monetary system depended on United States deficits and the supply of dollars (which greatly exceeded gold production) to create additional foreign reserves. But it was also steadily weakening the dollar as an asset that nations would be willing to hold. Introduction of 'Paper Gold'
The creation of special drawing rights (''paper gold'') was supposed to solve that problem. In fact, however, it was not S.D.R.'s but the emergence of the Eurodollar market and, after 1973, the ending of the fixed exchange rate between the dollar and gold and the subsequent floating of all currencies that permitted the game of growth-and-inflation to continue.
But that phase generated excessive inflation, weakened the dollar further and unsettled the monetary system to the point of instability, and it petered out in the late 1970's.
The long-deferred post-World War II deflation could not be avoided any longer. And monetarism - curbs on the growth of the money supply - played the role that the gold standard had played after World War I in bringing growth and inflation to a halt. Monetarism was advocated by its champions as a means of correcting inflation without causing depression, since the money supply would still be allowed to grow, but at a more moderate, noninflationary pace. Offering a Bundle of Solutions
The reality has been much harsher than anticipated in terms of unemployment, slumping production and trade. Economists are searching once again for a way out of the dangerous bind - a path that will lead to economic recovery without sidetracking back to the inflation that compelled the United States and other countries to take the painful deflationary steps that have led to the current problems.
They recognize that stimulative policies will need strong international cooperation, at least among the major countries, led by the United States, Japan and West Germany.
They also see a need for reform of the international monetary system, to find a way between the instability of floating exchange rates and the rigidity of fixed exchange rates. Comments From Economists
Prof. Peter Kenen of Princeton University, a leading international economist, criticizes the ''sense of paralysis'' of government officials and central bankers in failing to move more decisively to repair the world monetary system.
M. Louise Curley, a vice president and economist at Scudder, Stevens & Clark, the investment counseling concern, warns that there is still ''no consensus on monetary policy.'' But she, too, says, ''Only a global approach will work,'' and she calls for ''prudent shifts in monetary and fiscal policy, which will have to vary from country to country.'' She says there may have to be target zones for exchange rates of major countries.
Robert Hormats, a former Assistant Secretary of State under President Reagan, believes that, ''little by little, understanding is emerging.'' While urging stronger international mesures to prevent beggar-my-neighborism through trade barriers or competitive devaluations, Mr. Hormats recognizes that this will be hard unless recovery begins.
''Keynes may be right now, given the massive unemployed resources in the world,'' he says. ''The biggest risks are on the downside.'' He says interest rates need to be driven down further, declaring, ''Paul Volcker should be aware of the risks all over the world. This is not just a domestic issue.'' Since Death of Brezhnev
James D. Wolfensohn, president of the international investment company that bears his name, sees an urgent need for American ''economic and social leadership.'' He says that, with the death of the Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, there is an opportunity to ''refocus'' military policy, and that this would contribute to bringing down budget deficits from the $200 billion range.
He hopes President Reagan ''is more pragmatic than some of the things he has said.'' Until domestic and international debt problems are addressed effctively, Mr. Wolfensohn says, the outlook will remain bleak.
The economists agree there is no one big solution. Many elements will be involved: changes in monetary and fiscal policy to promote recovery, measures to shore up the monetary system and rescue banks threatened with collapse, actions to combat rising protectionism, special help for the debt-ridden countries of the third world and, perhaps most important of all, stronger leadership and a political commitment to rescue the world economy from unemployment and stagnation.
If the slump lasts too long, many fear it could end in the breakdown so long avoided. There is widespread apprehension that the world is again facing the inevitable ''appointment in Samarra'' with the collapse that follows the postwar boom.
The greatest hope that a replay of history can be prevented comes from the widespread recognition of the threat and the slowly emerging consensus on all that needs to be done to prevent it.

JOBS VS. PRICES: A DIFFICULT VOTER ASSESSMENT; News Analysis

Author: Clymer, Adam

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]15 Oct 1982: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424454649?accountid=11752

Abstract: Charles T. Manatt, the Democratic national chairman, offered one caustic analysis of why reduced inflation rates were not helping the Republicans more. ''Inflation is the heaviest burden on the elderly,'' he said, ''and instead of gaining any credit from them, the Republicans have just scared and scared and re-scared them about Social Security.'' They sound more frustrated than despondent. ''Slowly, very slowly, we're getting a little more credit,'' said Mr. [Robert M. Teeter], who argued that there was a deep, underlying ''fear and specter of inflation'' still to be tapped. Mr. [Edward J. Rollins] said he would be satisfied if Mr. [Reagan] advanced from getting ''very little'' credit to getting ''some credit.'' Then, he said, his party might move up from getting ''none'' to ''a little.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=JOBS+VS.+PRICES%3A+A+DIFFICULT+VOTER+ASSESSMENT%3B+News+Analysis%3A+%5BAnalysis%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-10-15&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Clymer%2C+Adam&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Republicans appear to be receiving more blame than credit from the electorate for the performance of the economy. They seem to be losing more support because of rising unemployment than they are gaining from lessened inflation, lower interest rates and a cut in income taxes.
Part of their problem is that much of the public does not believe that inflation has been checked. But perhaps even more significant, in the view of such Republicans as Richard B. Wirthlin, President Reagan's poll-taker, is that when unemployment is as severe as it is, it muffles other, more pleasant economic notes.
In the long run, Republicans may get the credit they say they deserve. But they would prefer it from voters now, rather than from economic historians later, and the short run lasts only 18 more days, until Election Day. Thrust of Reagan's Address
President Reagan's television speech Wednesday night, saying the progress being made on inflation would soon help check unemployment, was the biggest Republican salvo in a political barrage that seeks to alter the balance between blame and credit by Nov. 2.
The 23-minute speech was officially described as nonpartisan. But all Mr. Reagan did to change from his partisan mode was to omit the castigations of Democrats. His positive arguments were the same as before. He closed with an appeal for ''staying the course'' that duplicates the message of the 30-second television commercials that House Republicans are broadcasting.
Mr. Wirthlin said in an interview yesterday that his polling showed some slow progress for Mr. Reagan himself in receiving credit for lessened inflation and lower interest rates.
But in general, the Republican campaign has not succeeded in changing a situation that Edward J. Rollins, Mr. Reagan's chief political aide, describes this way:
''The President is getting a little credit for his accomplishments, but I think very little. The party is getting none whatsoever. The reason is simple. Most Americans don't feel economically better off.''
Although some Republicans argue that an underlying fear of inflation is an important political asset for them, it is plain that that issue has receded in public consciousness.
When Mr. Reagan took office, for example, 37 percent of the public considered inflation the nation's most important problem while 10 percent cited unemployment, according to the New York Times/CBS News Poll. Last month, asked the same question, 24 percent said unemployment and 4 percent said inflation. Worries about the economy in general as the most important problem more than doubled in the same period, to 44 percent from 19 percent. Fears of New Depression
For more than a decade, Republicans have argued that the politics of the economy have changed, and that postwar fears of a return to the Great Depression have ebbed. Consequently, they have contended, inflation that affected everyone constituted a bigger element in politics than did the unemployment of 5 or 6 or 7 percent of the labor force, a group that did not vote much anyway.
Whether that idea was ever correct, it appears wrong today. The National unemployment rate has reached 10.1 percent. It includes millions accustomed to steady work, for whom voting has been as much a badge of middle-class status as mortgage payments and new cars. The Americans who have told this year's Times/CBS News Polls that there has been adult unemployment in their families do not appear significantly less likely to vote than the rest of the public.
Nor is it just those who have been laid off who are affected politically. Most politicians feel that it is the fear of unemployment among those who have seen their co-workers lose their jobs that affects votes. Problem of Credibility
Republican candidates try to make the case that Mr. Reagan made on television. But though effects vary a bit from place to place, they often have a hard time selling it. Webb Franklin, a Congressional candidate, said in Cleveland, Miss., on Monday that the 10.1 percent rate ''is definitely a burden.''
But Republicans have another problem. Much of the public does not believe that inflation has abated, even though Mr. Reagan was correct in saying that an increase of 12.4 percent in the Consumer Price Index in 1980 slowed to a rate of 5.1 percent so far this year.
''It's disturbing that not too many believe it,'' said Representative Guy Vander Jagt, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee. The Times/CBS News Poll found both in May and September that the public was divided into three almost equal groups: those who believe prices are rising faster than a year earlier, those who think they are rising more slowly or those who believe they are rising at about the same rate. 'The Heaviest Burden'
Charles T. Manatt, the Democratic national chairman, offered one caustic analysis of why reduced inflation rates were not helping the Republicans more. ''Inflation is the heaviest burden on the elderly,'' he said, ''and instead of gaining any credit from them, the Republicans have just scared and scared and re-scared them about Social Security.''
Two other recent elements of the Administration's reports of success seem to have had even less impact. Mr. Reagan spoke proudly of both declining interest rates and the surge in stock market prices as evidence of the success of his economic program.
Robert M. Teeter, another leading Republican poll-taker, said those developments had political value, as ammunition ''to prove that the economy is really getting better and that unemployment will follow.''
Mr. Wirthlin said he felt that interest rates were coming to be viewed by the public as ''a standard barometer of how other things are doing.'' Factor of Interest Rates
But he said that since rates on consumer loans, automobile loans and home mortgages still remained very high, the political value of well-publicized reductions in the prime rate was limited. ''I don't think the average American has seen the effect of the drop in interest rates yet,'' he observed.
The political meaning of the stock market boom is also disputed, even among Democrats. Patrick H. Caddell, a leading poll-taker, scoffed at it, saying, ''The American people view the stock market the way they view sorcery.''
But Matt Reese, a longtime Democratic consultant, said he sometimes found that a Wall Street boom translated into hope in the country. And Mr. Vander Jagt contended that such a belief was actually ''deeply ingrained in the American psychology.''
Leading Republicans hope that a renewed burst of advertising, and perhaps more appearances by Mr. Reagan, can alter the perceptions they know they face just enough to take advantage of local issues, money, and other campaign advantages in particular races.
They sound more frustrated than despondent. ''Slowly, very slowly, we're getting a little more credit,'' said Mr. Teeter, who argued that there was a deep, underlying ''fear and specter of inflation'' still to be tapped.
Mr. Rollins said he would be satisfied if Mr. Reagan advanced from getting ''very little'' credit to getting ''some credit.'' Then, he said, his party might move up from getting ''none'' to ''a little.''

FIGHTING INFLATION IS UPHILL ALL THE WAY

Author: Cowan, Edward

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]12 Sep 1982: A.4.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424425500?accountid=11752

Abstract: * Finally, labor-cost ''pressures have been moderating,'' as employers pare wage and benefit increases. The rebound in productivity normally associated with recoveries would also help hold down costs. So will labor's caution. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the stresses of import competition and recession have been such that nearly three-fifths of the 1.9 million workers covered by major collective bargaining settlements reached so far this year ''will receive no specific wage increase'' except what may come from cost-of-living formulas. More than 90 percent of these workers are in hard-hit autos and trucking. ''The problem was not inflation but the wasting of the economy, getting the economy running again.'' Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=FIGHTING+INFLATION+IS+UPHILL+ALL+THE+WAY&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-09-12&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=Cowan%2C+Edward&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Embarrassed by ballooning budget deficits and record postwar unemployment, the Administration has one solid economic achievement - successfully squeezing inflation - and no doubt will make the most of it on behalf of Republican candidates this fall.
Inflation has come down faster than seemed possible when Ronald Reagan was sworn in 20 months ago, but at a price - a crunching recession with heavy losses of jobs and corporate profits and consequently Federal revenues. Some critics, and not all of them Democratic politicians or labor leaders, suggest the battle against inflation was carried to an extreme.
''We've been fighting the wrong dragon since the beginning of the year,'' Edward Jefferson, chairman of the DuPont Company, says. ''The problem was not inflation but the wasting of the economy, getting the economy running again.'' With interest rates still high despite some cautious Federal Reserve action to ease them, the prognosis for recovery is guarded. The latest figures, Data Resources Inc. said last week, pointed to ''a long bottoming-out process.'' The absence of clear signs of recovery was underscored last week by the Commerce Department's report that despite the inducements of last year's Reagan tax cut business has again scaled down planned capital investment.
On inflation, however, progress has been dramatic. The improvement was reflected in Friday's report of a moderate August rise of sixtenths of one percent in the producer price index for finished goods and slight declines for raw materials and semi-finished goods. The finished goods index, a clue to retail price trends, stood 4 percent higher than a year ago, half the rate of gain recorded a year ago.
Early in 1981, the basic inflation rate was 9 percent to 10 percent, with the Consumer Price Index charging along at an even faster clip. There had been some slowdown since early 1980, when a temporary burst of the C.P.I., approaching a 20 percent annual rate, had forced President Carter to tear up his budget and impose credit controls. But double-digit inflation was still a worrisome reality, a threat to the well-being of the jobless and the employed, pensioners and investors. Since January 1981, the basic inflation rate (and the C.P.I.) has come down to roughly 6 to 7 percent. Some analysts are optimistic that further progress can be made even if the overdue rebound from the 1981-82 recession is starting.
Still, progress will be slow. In 1983, according to a tabulation of 43 forecasts, consumer price inflation will slip to 5.9 percent, from 6.2 percent this year. By 1984, some forecasters say, there could be some resurgence, if sustained recovery occurs. ''We have the potential for reducing the inflation rate by about a point a year without any significant real costs,'' said William A. Niskanen, acting chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.
The Reasons for Moderation
Mr. Niskanen estimated that squeezing one percentage point a year out of the inflation rate was compatible with 3 percent average economic growth, with ''an upside of 4 or 5 percent for a year or two.'' The Administration takes the monetarist view, which emphasizes excessive money supply growth as the cause of inflation. The more conventional approach sees the money supply as one of several causes. Taking a pluralistic tack, Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates lists the following reasons for expecting ''moderate inflation.''
* An absence ''well into 1984'' of shortages of labor and production capacity. Factories now have more than 30 percent of their facilities idle.
* Abundant wheat and corn harvests, and large carryover stocks, will keep grain prices low. Citibank calculates corn prices are down 27 percent from 1981, wheat down 8 percent.
* With oil supplies tending to outstrip consumption and more production being developed, energy prices will be moderate ''at least until 1984,'' says Wharton. Oil prices are likely to rise less than inflation for several years, Mr. Niskanen adds, though ''we can have a shock at any time,'' such as a shutdown of production in Iraq or Iran.
* Finally, labor-cost ''pressures have been moderating,'' as employers pare wage and benefit increases. The rebound in productivity normally associated with recoveries would also help hold down costs. So will labor's caution. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the stresses of import competition and recession have been such that nearly three-fifths of the 1.9 million workers covered by major collective bargaining settlements reached so far this year ''will receive no specific wage increase'' except what may come from cost-of-living formulas. More than 90 percent of these workers are in hard-hit autos and trucking. (The United Auto Workers, negotiating with Chrysler this weekend against a Tuesday midnight contract expiration, signed new contracts with the other car companies earlier this year.)
The wage slowdown has occurred also among nonunion workers, who are 80 percent of the labor force. The Labor Department's employment cost index for private nonfarm workers showed a 1.3 percent rise in the spring, down from 1.9 percent in 1981.
Not least, mortgage interest rates have started to decline. That may not mean much to families outside the housing market, but it helps to hold down the Consumer Price Index, at least until rents are substituted for home purchase costs in January. Lower interest rates also mean cost relief for business.
Ten years ago this autumn, the Nixon Administration, having invoked mandatory price and wage controls, was striving to haul the inflation rate below 3 percent. Not even the determinedly bullish Reagan Administration economic forecast of July held out the prospect of 3 percent inflation in the foreseeable future. Its best hope was 5.4 percent in 1987.

IT WILL COME BACK TO HAUNT US

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]25 July 1982: A.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424377162?accountid=11752

Abstract: The bill currently has 218 sponsors in the house (enough for passage), 17 sponsors in the Senate and action on the legislation is expected within a few weeks. Not surprisingly, the United States domestic auto makers, which are using more foreign parts themselves but cannot afford to alienate the U.A.W., have declined to take sides. By [Malcolm Baldrige] SEVERAL versions of a ''local content'' bill, which would require ana uto manufacturer to produce a certain percentage of each vehicle in t he United States before it could be sold here, are pending in C ongress. I believe the evidence is overwhelming that these bills, a ttractive as they may seem, would greatly harm the American e conomy, the consumer, and the flow of world trade without helping t he American auto industry in any substantial way. Local content requirements would clearly violate the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Such a violation would expose our exports in nonautomotive areas to retaliation in such forms as quotas, higher duties or local content requirements. Our studies show that our most vulnerable exports include aircraft, office equipment, electrical components, corn, wheat and soybeans. In just the first round of what could easily become a trade war, some $15 billion of exports could be affected. For every $1 billion so excluded, 25,000 American jobs would be lost. On the domestic front, the arguments are just as strong. An interagency task force on local content has done a study showing that if auto sales in the United States approached the previous alltime high by 1985 (the year local content requirements would become fully effective), local content would result in no more than 200,000 additional jobs in the auto sector. But the study also shows that the employment gains would be offset by job losses at United States assembly plants of foreign manufacturers, at foreign car dealerships and at port facilities.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=IT+WILL+COME+BACK+TO+HAUNT+US&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-07-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Should Congress Put a 'Made in U.S.A.' Stamp on Imported Cars? Malcolm Baldrige and Douglas A. Fraser have often locked horns over issues of trade and industry. Again, the Commerce Secretary and president of the United Auto Workers union are at odds, this time over proposed legislation that would, in effect, require major foreign-car companies such as Toyota, Nissan and Volkswagen, to make most of the vehicles for the American market in this country.
Proponents bill the legislation as a way to get the domestic auto industry moving again and stop the loss of jobs in the auto sector. The Reagan Administration has raised the red flag of trade wars plus increased inflation if the local-content legislation is passed.
Specifically, the Fair Practices in Automotive Products Act would require that for auto makers selling more than 500,000 cars a year in the United States, 90 percent of parts and labor be domestic; for those selling 200,000 to 500,000, 75 percent, and for those selling 100,000 to 150,000, 25 percent.
The bill currently has 218 sponsors in the house (enough for passage), 17 sponsors in the Senate and action on the legislation is expected within a few weeks. Not surprisingly, the United States domestic auto makers, which are using more foreign parts themselves but cannot afford to alienate the U.A.W., have declined to take sides. By MALCOLM BALDRIGE SEVERAL versions of a ''local content'' bill, which would require ana uto manufacturer to produce a certain percentage of each vehicle in t he United States before it could be sold here, are pending in C ongress. I believe the evidence is overwhelming that these bills, a ttractive as they may seem, would greatly harm the American e conomy, the consumer, and the flow of world trade without helping t he American auto industry in any substantial way.
The issues raised by local content requirements are far-reaching. They go well beyond the short-term implications of the specific bills being conconsidered by Congress. They cross over industry lines and would seriously undermine the United States position in the world trading community.
Specifically, the bills would be inflationary: Car prices would go up, the auto industry's ability to seek low-cost sources of supply would be restricted, new regulatory burdens would be placed on the industry, it would be more difficult for the industry to become internationally competitive and, perhaps most important, the bills would violate international trade agreements.
In times of difficult worldwide economic conditions, shortsighted pressures to adopt protectionist-type legislation are intense. Each country finds a growing number of individuals advocating actions to protect its industries and its domestic jobs regardless of the longterm consequences.
The United States has long been recognized as the world leader in assuring a free and open trading system worldwide. Every administration since World War II has defended this principle. If local content legislation is adopted, we will indicate to our trading partners that we are abandoning that position. Our efforts to open other countries' markets would lose credibility immediately. With one of every seven manufacturing jobs and one of every three farmland acres in the country dependent on exports, key sectors of our economy would be dealt a severe blow.
Local content requirements would clearly violate the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Such a violation would expose our exports in nonautomotive areas to retaliation in such forms as quotas, higher duties or local content requirements. Our studies show that our most vulnerable exports include aircraft, office equipment, electrical components, corn, wheat and soybeans. In just the first round of what could easily become a trade war, some $15 billion of exports could be affected. For every $1 billion so excluded, 25,000 American jobs would be lost.
The legislation would also damage the Reagan Administration's efforts to obtain reciprocal trade liberalization. We have been making good progress in this area, but content legislation would be viewed as an irreversible renunciation of our position.
On the domestic front, the arguments are just as strong. An interagency task force on local content has done a study showing that if auto sales in the United States approached the previous alltime high by 1985 (the year local content requirements would become fully effective), local content would result in no more than 200,000 additional jobs in the auto sector. But the study also shows that the employment gains would be offset by job losses at United States assembly plants of foreign manufacturers, at foreign car dealerships and at port facilities.
Substantial additional losses would occur over time as our trading partners took retaliatory measures. The way to shore up our auto industry is through competition. American cars and trucks must become competitive in the world marketplace appropriately, not through legislation that artificially helps auto employment at the cost of the consumer and other industries.
Local content legislation would add to the cost of a car to the consumer. Our studies show that car prices would increase about 10 percent if local content requirements were adopted. That alone would push up the Consumer Price Index by about three-tenths of one percentage point. After the dramatic progress we have made in getting inflation down to the 5 percent to 6 percent range, we do not need laws that would push it back up.
Local content also would handcuff American auto manufacturers who would be unable to seek the lowest-cost sources of supply, placing them at a further disadvantage with their international competitors and putting further upward pressure on prices. They would be forced to purchase supplies from sources that would allow them to meet required content percentages, and would not be free to find the best product at the best price.
The problems of the United States auto industry will not be solved by enacting trade barriers. Those problems would be solved by providing an economic climate in which the United States auto companies could become more productive and competitive.
The Reagan Administration recognizes the pressures that have resulted in strong Congressional support for local content bills. We agree that action needs to be taken. We disagree only on the methods to use. Government subsidies which are obviously protectionist are not the answer.
The Administration's programs of economic incentives, regulatory relief and voluntary trade liberalization are aimed at giving both the auto industry specifically and the American industries generally the sound footing they need to do the job.
Illustration photo of Malcolm Baldrige

LOOKING FOR A WAY TO SUBDUE CURRENCY AND INTEREST DISCORD; News Analysis

Author: LEONARD SILK, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]05 June 1982: 2.30.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424369491?accountid=11752

Abstract: President Reagan is seeking to defuse both issues. On the first, he is prepared to join in a study of the effectiveness of intervention in determining long-run exchange rates. The Secretary of the Treasury, Donald T. Regan, has said here that he is confident the study proposed by the United States will bear out the position of the Reagan Administration that intervention should take place only in times of extreme upheaval. But if the study finds otherwise, he adds, the United States would ''reconsider'' its policy. Appointment of Gold Panel Otmar Emminger, former president of West Germany's central bank, for instance, contends that intervention in the foreign-exchange markets for the purpose of smoothing short-run rate fluctuations is unnecessary and that speculation ordinarily does a constructive job. But Dr. Emminger, like many other Europeans, does make a case for actions by governments to keep currency rates in appropriate balance - that is, close to each currency's real market value - over the medium term and the long term. He would make a partial exception for the United States, since the world is on what can be called a ''dollar standard.'' Neglecting a Strong Dollar Virtually all the Europeans here agree that it has been a mistake for the United States to return to the policy of ''benign neglect'' of the dollar, a policy they say the Carter Administration followed at first - until the dollar plunged in 1977.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=LOOKING+FOR+A+WAY+TO+SUBDUE+CURRENCY+AND+INTEREST+DISCORD%3B+News+Analysis%3A+%5Banalysis%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-06-05&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=2.30&amp;au=LEONARD+SILK%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The United States is trying hard, at this eighth summit conference, to convey the message that it will go a long way to meet European criticism of its foreign-exchange and domestic economics.
The Europeans believe that, without greater United States cooperation on these issues, the world economy may be facing extreme currency instability, high interest rates, painfully slow growth and high unemployment for years to come.
The United States is not in fundamental disagreement with the objectives of its allies. But the American approach is far more noninterventionist, far more free-market oriented than the Europeans would prefer, and the sounds of sweet harmony that might emerge from this conference on goals cannot be taken at face value.
However, there is a serious likelihood that a plan will emerge from this meeting to deal with the two problems of greatest concern to the Europeans. Grappling With Two Problems
One of the problems is the great volatility of currency rates in recent months and the unwillingness of the United States until now to intervene in the foreign-exchange markets to end this volatility and keep the value of the dollar in more stable relationship with other currencies. Such stability would improve trade conditions.
The other problem is the high level of United States interest rates, which the Europeans attribute to the clash between a stimulative fiscal policy and a restrictive monetary policy in the United States. The Europeans hold high American interest rates responsible for their own high rates and underemployed economies. The high cost of financing, they maintain, has stifled investment and consumer buying.
President Reagan is seeking to defuse both issues. On the first, he is prepared to join in a study of the effectiveness of intervention in determining long-run exchange rates. The Secretary of the Treasury, Donald T. Regan, has said here that he is confident the study proposed by the United States will bear out the position of the Reagan Administration that intervention should take place only in times of extreme upheaval. But if the study finds otherwise, he adds, the United States would ''reconsider'' its policy. Appointment of Gold Panel
The Administration appears to be employing the same tactics it used successfully at home when it called for a study of returning to the gold standard in response to strong pressure from domestic advocates of gold. The appointment of the Gold Commission, with a majority of its members opposed to a revived gold standard, put an end to the gold advocates' pressure.
The issue of foreign-exchange policy, like the gold issue, is complex. There is little unity among government officials or economists in different countries on how currency stability can be achieved.
Otmar Emminger, former president of West Germany's central bank, for instance, contends that intervention in the foreign-exchange markets for the purpose of smoothing short-run rate fluctuations is unnecessary and that speculation ordinarily does a constructive job. But Dr. Emminger, like many other Europeans, does make a case for actions by governments to keep currency rates in appropriate balance - that is, close to each currency's real market value - over the medium term and the long term. He would make a partial exception for the United States, since the world is on what can be called a ''dollar standard.'' Neglecting a Strong Dollar
Virtually all the Europeans here agree that it has been a mistake for the United States to return to the policy of ''benign neglect'' of the dollar, a policy they say the Carter Administration followed at first - until the dollar plunged in 1977.
They have concluded that the Reagan Administration, like earlier Administrations in Washington, will act to stabilize the dollar if it begins to fall again.
The real motive of the Europeans in pressing the United States so hard to help stabilize the values of world currencies is that they believe a highly volatile system is disruptive of foreign trade and damaging to their economies.
While the United States is dependent on foreign trade for only about 9 percent of its gross national product, West Germany depends on foreign trade for 22 percent of its G.N.P. With smaller European countries, trade accounts for as much as 40 to 50 percent of their G.N.P.
These countries feel that a currency out of alignment with the dollar is a serious menace to their economic development in a world that operates essentially on a dollar standard.
It is for this reason that the Europeans have created the European Monetary System, a regional currency system with fixed but adjustable parities between currencies. They believe the E.M.S. has worked well - or at least well enough to hold their economies together and to avoid undue harm to any single country. Domestic Emphasis for U.S.
That the United States would come into an expanded monetary arrangement similar to the European system seems improbable. Although the European countries participating in monetary system have much in common economically, the Reagan Administration wishes to keep a free hand, since it considers the success of its domestic economic policy far more important than what happens in the foreign-exchange market or even to America's foreign trade.
Furthermore, the Reagan Administration still appears dominated by a monetarist economic theory. This theory implies that it is unnecessary to worry about foreign economic relationships, provided that one maintains a slow and steady growth of the money supply, thus keeping inflation under control. To the Europeans, this seems like a counsel of perfection that has not worked.
Yet the spirit of agreement that President Reagan and his colleagues are showing here should not be dismissed as insignificant. For it appears to represent a serious effort to promote greater international monetary cooperation and stability. The United States has many reasons of its own to get the world economy into better order. Confidence that the United States is indeed moving in this direction must await further developments at Versailles - and afterward.
