U.S. AND ALLIES FACE DIFFICULT ECONOMIC TALKS

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]30 May 1982: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424343883?accountid=11752

Abstract: Technology transfer among countries may receive more attention than at previous summit talks. But other issues once considered paramount - inflation, energy and ''North-South'' relations, between the developing and industrial nations - will be far down on the agenda. ''North-South relations will be treated lightly because no one has much to offer on that front,'' said C. Fred Bergsten, a former United States Treasury official. ''We don't expect programs to emerge from Versailles,'' said Manfred Lahnstein, West Germany's Finance Minister, ''but our performance can have a real effect on investor confidence.'' FIRST ADD AGENDA FOR SUNDAY MAIN Significantly, this official talked about the need to promote ''economic stability'' and ''economic convergence'' among the industrial nations at the summit meeting. The hope is that if France and the other nations agree to closer consultation on economic policies, the Reagan Administration will do more to stabilize the dollar.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=U.S.+AND+ALLIES+FACE+DIFFICULT+ECONOMIC+TALKS&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-05-30&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The United States and France have reportedly agreed on how to begin rebuilding the international monetary system. Page 4. By SANDRA SALMANS
The concern of the United States with fighting inflation and the Western European concern with stimulating employment are expected to clash when leaders of the seven major industrialized democracies meet this week for an economic summit conference.
West Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada, faced with economic stagnation and rising unemployment, plan to press President Reagan to reduce his projected budget deficit and allow interest rates to fall.
Japan may join the call. ''We would like to have American interest rates down to reasonable levels,'' said Ikusaburo Kashima, deputy division director at Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry.
Even Britain, which shares the restrictive monetary policies of the United States, will suggest ''in restrained tones'' that interest rates might be allowed to fall, one senior British official said. The Other Issues
Other issues at the annual gathering of the leaders, which begins Friday in Versailles, France, will include barriers to free trade, economic relations between the richer and poorer nations and technology transfers from industrialized to nonindustrialized societies.
Despite the stated opposition to its methods for fighting inflation, the Administration hopes to find support. ''We should all be anti-inflationary together,'' Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said in a briefing last week, at which he called for ''closer coordination'' of various economic policies.
The United States is expected to relent in one area of monetary and economic policy: intervention by central banks in foreignexchange trading. The Reagan Administration will make ''some accommodation on exchange stability,'' Frederick Schultz, former of the Federal Reserve Board, predicted last week.
The United States has traditionally opposed such intervention, which involves the buying and selling of currencies by the central banks to keep exchange rates at levels that the governments might deem appropriate or useful in carrying out broader monetary and trade policies.
Apart from interest rates, world trade issues appear to dominate most agendas. President Reagan is expected to push for curbs on trade credits to the Communist bloc, but will be opposed by France and Germany, officials said.
There may be more unanimity on the issue of Japanese exports, which narrowly escaped attack at the previous summit conference, a year ago in Ottawa. But Japan's new package of market-opening measures, announced last week, may forestall greater restrictions by the West. The Versailles talks will be an occasion to ''sell the package,'' one Japanese official said.
Technology transfer among countries may receive more attention than at previous summit talks. But other issues once considered paramount - inflation, energy and ''North-South'' relations, between the developing and industrial nations - will be far down on the agenda. ''North-South relations will be treated lightly because no one has much to offer on that front,'' said C. Fred Bergsten, a former United States Treasury official.
The three-day meeting is the eighth such conference of the major Western allies and Japan. It will take place in a climate clouded by the war in the Falkland Islands, for which Britain has been paying a heavy price not only in lives but also in its relationship with the other members of the European Economic Community. List of the Participants
Many of the participants - Mr. Reagan, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, President Francois Mitterrand of France, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of Germany, Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini of Italy, Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada, as well as the president of the European Economic Community, Gaston Thorn - were newcomers last year, and the Ottawa meeting thus emphasized communication rather than consensus on specific issues.
As at any high-level international conference, many of the policies that will ultimately be announced have already been formulated by the diplomats from the seven nations. Although the governments are now better established, no one expects much substantive progress this weekend.
''We don't expect programs to emerge from Versailles,'' said Manfred Lahnstein, West Germany's Finance Minister, ''but our performance can have a real effect on investor confidence.'' FIRST ADD AGENDA FOR SUNDAY MAIN
Following are summaries of the agendas that the major participants will take to Versailles: United States
On the thorny issue of interest rates, President Reagan is hoping only for understanding from his counterparts. But the Administration, which has consistently opposed intervention in currency markets, will propose the formation of a group to study various policies.
''We want to see the evidence,'' Treasury Secretary Regan said, adding that he would like the group to be composed of himself and the finance ministers of France, Britain, Japan and Germany.
The United States has a number of trade issues at the top of its agenda. On East-West relations, it would like the group to endorse curbs on trade credits to the Soviet Union, although President Reagan will not insist that this issue be included in a communique, officials said.
If he cannot get satisfaction on the general issue of credits, Administration officials say, the President is prepared to use all legal means to block the construction of the pipeline that the Soviet Union wants to build to bring natural gas from Siberia to Western Europe. European nations generally support the pipeline.
The President also intends to raise the issue of growing trade barriers among industrial nations, including European subsidies for farm and steel exports. A detailed discussion of protectionist measures may be deferred until the world trade talks scheduled for November, but the Administration wants a commitment to the principle of free trade.
In addition, the United States will seek endorsement of regulations governing the flow of capital across borders, to prevent nations such as Canada from restricting activity by foreign investors. Other particpants are said to be uninterested in such rules. Japan
''The handling of trade conflict is the issue of greatest concern for Japan,'' said Kasumasa Kusaka, deputy director of the general coordination division of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry.
In recent months, the perennial tension between Japan and the Western nations over persistent trade imbalances has intensified, with Tokyo coming under increasing pressure for concessions. Now Japanese officials are hoping that the package of measures to stimulate imports announced last week will deter the United States, Europe and Canada from taking new measures to restrict imports of Japanese goods.
Japan also has a stake in joining Europe and Canada, albeit discreetly, in attacking high interest rates in the United States. For one thing, the high rates keep the yen relatively weak, making exported Japanese goods cheaper and trade surpluses larger. Furthermore, Japan, partly in fear that it could become the target of wrath, would welcome anything that would distract the others from trade issues.
Japan will also join France in promoting the notion of technological cooperation as a key element in revitalizing the international economy, according to Shohei Naito, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. No specific proposals are likely to emerge, but it is expected that a group will be formed to study such areas as robotics and bioengineering. West Germany
Chancellor Schmidt has been among the most outspoken European critics of United States interest rates and projected budget deficits, but he is resigned to the prospect that the meeting will not produce a consensus on economic policy, according to German officials.
''Schmidt has agreed not to be didactic, not to seek confrontation,'' said Horst Schulmann, the Finance Ministry official who has prepared Bonn's contribution to the conference, despite fears that continued recession in the United States will worsen Europe's economic troubles.
On the issue of foreign exchange intervention, however, Bonn hopes to win a consensus that the severe fluctuations in the markets should be eased.
Buoyed by its exports, Germany has bucked the recessionary trend better than most of its neighbors, holding down both inflation and unemployment. Accordingly, Mr. Schmidt, who has consistently denounced the growing movement toward protectionism, may join President Reagan in seeking a commitment to free trade.
In another respect, however, Germany will be on the defensive: Officials fear that its ailing neighbors will urge it to stimulate its own economy as a means of stimulating theirs. ''If the request surfaces, we will politely say no,'' Finance Minister Lahnstein said. France
As the host at Versailles, President Mitterrand has made it clear that he wants a successful and harmonious summit meeting, and France is accordingly expected to be one of the more complaisant participants.
Nevertheless, according to a high-level French official, the Government has put United States interest rates at the top of its agenda. France's 13.8 percent inflation rate is higher than that of any other nation attending the summit meeting, but France has enjoyed relatively good economic growth, and the Government is concerned that its boomlet could end unless interest rates fall and investment revives.
At the same time, the official said, France recognizes that America's high interest rates reflect a national political debate over the budget, and sympathizes with the Reagan Administration's plight.
Significantly, this official talked about the need to promote ''economic stability'' and ''economic convergence'' among the industrial nations at the summit meeting. The hope is that if France and the other nations agree to closer consultation on economic policies, the Reagan Administration will do more to stabilize the dollar.
More than most of the other participants, France wants the meeting to help expedite international cooperation in telecommunications and high technology. According to the official, France is also acutely interested in North-South issues, and thus will seek to extend the concept of economic stabilization to commodity prices. On both issues, however, France may be thwarted by the United States and others. Britain
Whatever role the Conservative Government might initially have planned to play at the summit meeting, Britain's ability to operate in diplomatic circles has been significantly reduced by the Falkland Islands war. Having sought -and for the most part received - economic sanctions against Argentina and other help from all of the countries that will be represented at Versailles, a senior official noted, Britain will be loath to take a hard line against the other participants.
But ''we shall be looking for some sort of reaffirmation of counterinflation policies,'' a senior British official said; that is ''fairly high on our agenda.''
Of the seven, only Britain will rally to Washington's side in supporting restrictive monetary and fiscal policies. At the same time, however, the British will join the others in asserting that the projected United States budget deficit is too high. The Government will express the ''hope that you would get interest rates down,'' the official said.
The British are also likelier than their European neighbors to support the United States view on East-West trade. Until recently, Britain had been among the most vocal countries on the issue of Japanese trade, arguing that Japan should loosen its fiscal purse strings and abandon its own protectionist measures if it wanted continued access to British markets. But London will press the issue only if others go along, the official said. Italy
Regarded by some as the poor cousin of the industrial nations meeting at Versailles, Italy has in fact fared better recently than some of the others. Its 10 percent inflation rate is lower than that of Canada, France or Britain, unemployment is a tolerable 9 percent, and there is slight economic growth.
But Italy is also troubled by tight monetary policy and high interest rates in the United States. Rome expresses particular concern about the recent strength of the dollar and would like to see the Reagan Administration intervene in currency markets. The growing trend toward protectionism, Italian officials say, is due partly to the dollar's strength.
Relations at Versailles between Italy and Britain may be complicated by the war in the Falkland Islands. Of the Common Market members to attend the summit meeting, only Italy has refused to impose sanctions against Argentina in retaliation for its invasion of the islands. About 40 percent of the Argentine population is of Italian descent. (Ireland, a member of the Common Market but not a summit participant, also declined to go along with the sanctions.)
North-South issues in general may be raised by Italy. ''We cannot have sustained economic growth without improving the purchasing power and well-being of the South,'' said Antonio Badini of the Prime Minister's office, who helped prepare Italy's agenda. Canada
For Canada ''to have any chance of quick recovery,'' Allan MacEachan, the Finance Minister, declared recently in the House of Commons, ''the first essential is a drop in U.S. interest rates.'' Thus, like the other leaders, Prime Minister Trudeau will present his complaint about United States policies, and may be the most outspoken.
Canada's recession has been exceptionally deep. Its unemployment rate reached 9.6 percent last month, the highest in 40 years. And unlike the United States, it cannot point to lower inflation as compensation. If an election were held tomorrow, all polls show that Mr. Trudeau's Liberals would be defeated.
On North-South issues, Canada is expected to join France in pushing for endorsement of ''global negotiations'' concerning aid to developing countries. While the Reagan Administration agreed in theory to such talks at Ottawa last year, it wants the emphasis on private investment, and discussions may become stalemated.

LOW RATES NO CURE-ALL, REGAN WARNS O.E.C.D.

Author: PAUL LEWIS, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]11 May 1982: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424349473?accountid=11752

Abstract: Mr. [Donald T. Regan] said at a news conference afterward that ''speaker after speaker'' had complained that high United States interest rates were blocking economic recovery in the world and threatening to throw six million more people out of work in the O.E.C.D.'s 24 industrial countries, bringing their total unemployment up to 30 million by the end of the year. A Glimpse of the Future The only way for the rest of the world to bring down the cost of borrowing, encourage industrial investment and reduce unemployment, according to Mr. Regan, is to pursue ''sound economic policies'' and show ''seriousness'' in the fight against inflation. ''The process of economic revitalization must start with a credible commitment to noninflationary policy,'' Mr. Regan said in his prepared speech. The first is the fact that, although inflation in the United States has dropped sharply in the last three months to an annual rate of just 3 percent, the banks' prime rate remains near 16 percent. ''Inflation and the real rate of interest are moving in opposite directions, and that is serious,'' complained Sir Geoffrey Howe, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=LOW+RATES+NO+CURE-ALL%2C+REGAN+WARNS+O.E.C.D.&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-05-11&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=PAUL+LEWIS%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, taking the offensive in the growing international dispute over American economic policy, warned Western finance ministers today that the lower interest rates they want in the United States ''will not be a panacea for the world's economic problems.''
Speaking on the first day of the annual ministerial meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, Secretary Regan said a reduction in rates in America would not necessarily reduce borrowing costs in all other Western countries or weaken the dollar in relation to the rest of the world's currencies.
Mr. Regan said at a news conference afterward that ''speaker after speaker'' had complained that high United States interest rates were blocking economic recovery in the world and threatening to throw six million more people out of work in the O.E.C.D.'s 24 industrial countries, bringing their total unemployment up to 30 million by the end of the year. A Glimpse of the Future
But he argued that countries with continuing high inflation and large budget deficits would find their currencies staying weak against the dollar even after American interest rates come down. Thus these countries would still be forced to maintain relatively high rates, he said.
Since last August, he said, the average interest rate on United States Treasury bills has fallen more than three percentage points, while the dollar has actually strengthened, on a trade-weighted basis, by half a percentage point against the currencies of the O.E.C.D.'s other member nations.
The only way for the rest of the world to bring down the cost of borrowing, encourage industrial investment and reduce unemployment, according to Mr. Regan, is to pursue ''sound economic policies'' and show ''seriousness'' in the fight against inflation. ''The process of economic revitalization must start with a credible commitment to noninflationary policy,'' Mr. Regan said in his prepared speech.
The Treasury Secretary gave his warning at a meeting that is widely seen as a dress rehearsal for the seven-nation Western economic conference to take place next month at Versailles, outside Paris. The conference will bring together governmental heads of the United States, Britain, Canada, France, West Germany, Italy and Japan. The O.E.C.D. scheduled its ministerial meeting this year so that smaller Western nations that will not be represented at Versailles could make their concerns known in advance. Spread of Anxiety Noted
Treasury Secretary Regan said he is aware of the anxiety that high American interest rates are causing throughout the world, remarking that the Reagan Administration also wants to get them lower. The United States, with 10 million unemployed workers, now accounts for more than one-third of total O.E.C.D. unemployment, he said, while many key American industries - including auto makers, construction companies and thrift institutions - are ''in serious difficulty'' as a result of the high cost of credit.
The way to lower United States interest rates is to reduce the United States budget deficit, he said, adding that this has become ''an international necessity'' as well as a domestic one.
Concern about the depressive effect of high United States interest rates on the world economy has been sharpened in recent weeks by two separate developments, several ministers said in their speeches today.
The first is the fact that, although inflation in the United States has dropped sharply in the last three months to an annual rate of just 3 percent, the banks' prime rate remains near 16 percent. ''Inflation and the real rate of interest are moving in opposite directions, and that is serious,'' complained Sir Geoffrey Howe, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer.
The second is a downward revision in the growth forecast issued by the O.E.C.D., which has narrowed its earlier prediction of a 1.5 percent rate of Western economic expansion this year to a mere three-tenths of 1 percent. Even the slight upturn predicted for 1983 is described by the organization's secretariat as ''technical,'' reflecting more stable oil prices and an end to the shrinking of business inventories. Inflation as Primary Target
Despite this grim outlook, Emile van Lennep, Secretary General of the O.E.C.D., said at today's news conference that he expects all of its members to stick to inflation-fighting as their top priority, a policy adopted some years ago.
But officials said the O.E.C.D. secretariat wants Germany and Japan, which have low inflation and a strong trade surplus, to abandon plans to reduce their federal budget deficits, since this would slow imports and weaken demand throughout the world.
The secretariat's recommendations are contained in new proposals for a ''differentiated'' recovery strategy that seeks to detail the contribution each O.E.C.D. member country could best make to world recovery on an individual basis.
However, both the German and Japanese ministers said today that their governments were eager to reduce public spending to make room for more private investment.

Economic Scene; Military Costs Vs. Inflation

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]07 May 1982: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424352763?accountid=11752

Abstract: Recalling his service as a member of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers during the Vietnam buildup, Mr. [Otto Eckstein] said, ''We were blamed for not raising taxes and thereby causing inflation, but the Reagan Administration expects praise for cutting taxes by 25 to 30 percent during a military buildup.'' He called this ''a really big mistake, the biggest mistake since 1932 or 1937.'' It would not be enough, he said, for the Administration to contain inflation by ''rolling back civilian nondiscretionary programs all the way to 1939, as they are proposing to do.'' The Federal Reserve's efforts to hold down the rate of growth of the money supply and thereby curb inflation in the face of big tax cuts and budget deficits, he concluded, would lead to slower real growth and persistently high unemployment by ''crowding out'' private investment. To the arguments of advocates of a rapid military buildup that the economy is slack, industry is operating at a low level of capacity, unemployment is high and there have been to date no serious shortages of critical raw materials, he responded: ''All this is, of course, true, but it fails to recognize sufficiently the highly specialized nature of most military procurement and the shortages of highly skilled labor and and specialized components required by defense industry.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+Military+Costs+Vs.+Inflation&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-05-07&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: IS the military buildup planned by the Reagan Administration likely to rekindle inflation? Or, with so much slack in the economy, is there a ''window of opportunity'' for rapid military expansion?
The Reagan budget calls for military outlays to increase from $187.5 billion in the fiscal year 1982 to $221.1 billion in 1983 and to go on rising to $292 billion in 1985 and $364 billion in 1987. Economic analysts estimate that those numbers imply a real rate of increase of 9 to 10 percent in spending and an inflation rate for military goods of 10 percent.
This week, at a conference on military spending held in New York by the Center for Defense Information, Elmer B. Staats, former Comptroller General of the United States, said the relevant question was not whether the United States could afford that military buildup but whether the military program had the right priorities and whether the nation was willing to pay for it. The problem, he said, was more political than economic.
On that basis, Otto Eckstein, professor of economics at Harvard and president of Data Resources, questioned the Administration's policies for accommodating the big military buildup without imposing taxes to pay for it.
Recalling his service as a member of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers during the Vietnam buildup, Mr. Eckstein said, ''We were blamed for not raising taxes and thereby causing inflation, but the Reagan Administration expects praise for cutting taxes by 25 to 30 percent during a military buildup.'' He called this ''a really big mistake, the biggest mistake since 1932 or 1937.'' It would not be enough, he said, for the Administration to contain inflation by ''rolling back civilian nondiscretionary programs all the way to 1939, as they are proposing to do.''
The Federal Reserve's efforts to hold down the rate of growth of the money supply and thereby curb inflation in the face of big tax cuts and budget deficits, he concluded, would lead to slower real growth and persistently high unemployment by ''crowding out'' private investment.
But that is not an immediate problem. With manufacturing industry operating at 71 percent of capacity and unemployment at 9 percent, such Administration spokesmen as Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, have stressed the contribution rising military spending will make to the business recovery.
The pressure on resources is likely to be mitigated by the slow rate at which spending on weapons procurement flows out. Data presented by Stanley S. Fine, a retired rear admiral, to the military-spending conference indicated that outlays for ships would be only 2.4 percent of the appropriation for ships, 10.4 percent for aircraft, 14 percent for missiles and 6.3 percent for tanks.
However, with military appropriations scheduled to climb from $218.9 billion in 1982 to $291 billion in 1984 and $408.4 billion in 1987, pressures will keep climbing through the rest of this decade.
The planned military buildup in the next four years, estimates cited by Mr. Staats say, will absorb 30 percent of ''goods producing'' gross national product, up from 6 percent in the fiscal year 1981.
To the arguments of advocates of a rapid military buildup that the economy is slack, industry is operating at a low level of capacity, unemployment is high and there have been to date no serious shortages of critical raw materials, he responded: ''All this is, of course, true, but it fails to recognize sufficiently the highly specialized nature of most military procurement and the shortages of highly skilled labor and and specialized components required by defense industry.''
And he concluded that there would be even greater increases in overall prices for military procurement than in the past. Higher procurement costs of major weapons systems than budgeted could force reductions in items crucial to military readiness.
The impact of the military buildup on inflation is, however, a macroeconomic, not a microeconomic, question, depending on how the nation chooses to pay for the buildup. But to the extent that growing military outlays swell the projected budget deficits, they are likely to be inflationary and call forth tight-money policies, which are likely to curb real economic growth.
The ''window of opportunity'' for military buildup looks open right now but will close if the economy recovers. The alternative ways of paying for the military buildup, thereafter, would be higher taxes, slower growth or inflation.

U.S. INTEREST-RATE FEVER ADDS TO EUROPE'S ACHES

Author: Rattner, Steven

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]14 Mar 1982: A.4.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424301378?accountid=11752

Abstract: Britain and its allies, the Chancellor said as he sipped a gin and tonic, have ''a legitimate interest in the success of the United States Administration in reconciling its spending obligations with its own responsible pursuit of monetary discipline.'' Lack of success, he suggested, would mean ''a risk of continuing high interest rates, which would be damaging to recovery.'' ''Even optimists should not have, over all, any illusions that the interest level in the United States could go down quickly, fundamentally and permanently,'' said Count Otto Lambsdorff, the West German economics minister after returning from Washington. ''For it seems to me that in U.S. economic policy, there is a fundamental conflict between monetary and finance policy.'' Worry in Europe about American economic policy is genuine. Interest-rate gyrations in the United States wreak havoc with European plans. Most fundamentally, foreign exchange rates have become increasingly sensitive to differences in interest rates. This has forced other countries to match increases in American rates or face the unpleasant consequences of seeing their currency depreciate. For ''open'' European economies, heavily dependent on trade, the principal consequence is more inflation as the price of imports rises. Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve chairman, ''is dictating the pace of events around the world, not only as regards economic activity but also as regards inflation,'' said Paul Neild, chief economist at Phillips & Drew, a London stock brokerage. ''Many countries would be pursuing more stimulative policies if left free to do so.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=U.S.+INTEREST-RATE+FEVER+ADDS+TO+EUROPE%27S+ACHES&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-03-14&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=Rattner%2C+Steven&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: When Sir Geoffrey Howe, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, unveiled the new budget in the House of Commons last week, Britons listened carefully for news of taxes and spending. But while he had their attention, Sir Geoffrey couldn't resist tossing in a mention of the consequences of high interest rates and large budget deficits in the United States.
Britain and its allies, the Chancellor said as he sipped a gin and tonic, have ''a legitimate interest in the success of the United States Administration in reconciling its spending obligations with its own responsible pursuit of monetary discipline.'' Lack of success, he suggested, would mean ''a risk of continuing high interest rates, which would be damaging to recovery.''
By such thinly veiled warnings, senior economic officials here and on the Continent have been stating their concern over United States policy. Since President Reagan announced his new budget last month, European criticism of high rates has broadened, persisting even while American rates drifted downward during the past two weeks.
''Even optimists should not have, over all, any illusions that the interest level in the United States could go down quickly, fundamentally and permanently,'' said Count Otto Lambsdorff, the West German economics minister after returning from Washington. ''For it seems to me that in U.S. economic policy, there is a fundamental conflict between monetary and finance policy.''
Worry in Europe about American economic policy is genuine. Interest-rate gyrations in the United States wreak havoc with European plans. Most fundamentally, foreign exchange rates have become increasingly sensitive to differences in interest rates. This has forced other countries to match increases in American rates or face the unpleasant consequences of seeing their currency depreciate. For ''open'' European economies, heavily dependent on trade, the principal consequence is more inflation as the price of imports rises. Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve chairman, ''is dictating the pace of events around the world, not only as regards economic activity but also as regards inflation,'' said Paul Neild, chief economist at Phillips & Drew, a London stock brokerage. ''Many countries would be pursuing more stimulative policies if left free to do so.''
Underpinning these views are serious economic difficulties. In most of Europe, including West Germany, unemployment has risen far more sharply than in the United States, to record levels. Ten days ago, the Common Market predicted that unemployment among its 10 members would rise to 12 million by the end of the year, from slightly above 10 million now.
The economic troubles have had substantial political repercussions. Last year, they helped elect Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, as President of France. They are a prime factor in British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's low approval ratings in opinion polls and in West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's growing difficulty in holding his coalition Government together. For Europeans, almost certainly facing tough economic problems in any event, American interest rates are a convenient whipping boy. Two weeks ago, Mr. Mitterrand said after meeting in Paris with Mr. Schmidt that tough action against American interest rates was planned. Last week, Mr. Mitterrand carried the message directly to Washington and President Reagan. But it was already clear that the threat - widely assumed to be foreign exchange controls - was unlikely to be carried out.
In recent days, concern has ebbed slightly. Europeans are mainly concerned about rates and at the moment, interest rates in the United States and the value of the dollar both seem to be declining. The fall in world oil prices has also reduced the pressure, holding out the promise of added economic growth in Europe without the necessity of stimulative policies. But officials preparing for the June economic meeting of President Reagan and six other leaders of industrial countries have been unable to agree on recommendations because of divisions over how to respond to American policy.
European governments appear increasingly prepared to go their own way, despite the American rates. Several weeks ago, West Germany, the Netherlands and Britain began cutting interest rates, even though disappointing money supply numbers in the United States had just sent American rates climbing again. Similarly, Sir Geoffrey, in last week's budget, unveiled a new monetary policy that was widely perceived to be less rigorous than the old one. The pound immediately went down in value.
In addition to economic effects, displeasure over American rates has accentuated other differences between the United States, with its conservative President, and most of Europe, with the notable exception of Britain. On big issues with economic dimensions, such as defense spending, the contractionary effects of American economic policy have made it more difficult for Europeans to cooperate. On the proposal to build a natural gas pipeline from the Soviet Union to Western Europe and for other restrictions on East-West trade, French and West German willingness to heed American pleas has been diminished because both countries export substantially more to Eastern Europe than the United States does. Common Market ministers last week decided to reduce the sanctions against Moscow they had discussed after the crackdown in Poland.
Similarly, with budget deficits swollen by recession, European nations have had difficulty meeting the commitment to increase defense spending by 3 percent in real terms, above inflation; only Britain has come close to succeeding. Sir Geoffrey proposed an 11.6 percent rise in defense spending next year, with inflation projected at 9 percent.
To be sure, the European attitude sometimes defies logic. When Jimmy Carter was President, European leaders led by Mr. Schmidt regularly lectured the United States on the need to tighten its monetary policy. Now, it is precisely this tightening that is upsetting them.

GOLD COIN FAVORED BY U.S. BOARD

Author: AP

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]09 Mar 1982: D.16.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424320014?accountid=11752

Abstract: The United States Gold Commission today completed all but the final details of its recommendations to Congress. The recommendations reject a gold standard for the United States, while favoring the minting of a new gold ''coin'' that would be sold at the market value of its gold content but would not be used as currency. Mr. [Henry S. Reuss] said today that the gold coin ''was what the gold lobby really wanted all the time.'' Creation of the commission led to considerable public discussion about the possibility of the United States returning to some form of a gold standard, such as requiring that a percentage of all paper money be backed with gold. Some of the President's advisers have favored a gold standard as a means of controlling inflation.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=GOLD+COIN+FAVORED+BY+U.S.+BOARD&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-03-09&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.16&amp;au=AP&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The United States Gold Commission today completed all but the final details of its recommendations to Congress. The recommendations reject a gold standard for the United States, while favoring the minting of a new gold ''coin'' that would be sold at the market value of its gold content but would not be used as currency.
The session today will be the last for the 17-member commission unless significant new arguments arise in the final drafting of its report, which is due on Capitol Hill March 31. The Presidential commission last year began to study the controversial issue of tying the value of the dollar to the value of gold and to submit its recommendations to Congress.
In votes taken last month, the commission rejected, 15 to 2, a resolution that would have permitted the conversion of paper currency to gold, something that has not been possible in the United States since 1933. Sold for Gold Content
By a 12-to-3 vote, the commission had recommended the minting of a new gold coin that would be sold by the Treasury for its gold content, probably in half-ounce and one-ounce sizes. The coin, called the American Eagle, would be sold as an alternative to gold coins offered as investments by Mexico, Canada, South Africa and other countries.
The investment in American Eagles would keep dollars invested in gold from leaving the country. The coin would be similar to the gold medallion that the Government has had trouble selling since it was created in 1980, although the coin - unlike the medallion - would be exempt from capital gains and sales taxes.
One commisssion member, Representative Henry S. Reuss, a Wisconsin Democrat, made several unsuccessful attempts today to have the group retract or water down the gold-coin recommendation.
Mr. Reuss noted that 30 members of the House Banking Committee, a solid majority, had signed a letter opposing the coin proposal. Opposition Rejected
But a commission member, Ron Paul, a Texas Republican who, like Mr. Reuss, is also a member of the Banking Committee, said, ''I think we should totally ignore the recommendation of Congress to the commission'' on what commission members should recommend to the Congress.
Congress voted in 1980 to create the commission, and President Reagan appointed seven senators and representatives, three of his own advisers, three Federal Reserve governors and four private citizens as members last June.
Mr. Reuss said today that the gold coin ''was what the gold lobby really wanted all the time.'' Creation of the commission led to considerable public discussion about the possibility of the United States returning to some form of a gold standard, such as requiring that a percentage of all paper money be backed with gold. Some of the President's advisers have favored a gold standard as a means of controlling inflation.

Economic Scene; Looser Money, Less Inflation?

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]13 Jan 1982: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424280869?accountid=11752

Abstract: In the latest issue of the Quarterly Review of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, Thomas J. Sargent and Neil Wallace, the bank's leading monetary economists, offer what they call ''Some Unpleasant Monetarist Arithmetic'' to demonstrate that, although tight money in the face of a loose fiscal policy may work temporarily to reduce inflation, it eventually leads to higher inflation. Using a quantitative model, Mr. Sargent and Mr. Wallace reach the spectacular conclusion that, given the Government deficit that needs to be financed, looser money will produce less inflation than tight money.The reason is that tight money will put the economy into deeper recession and choke back longer-term growth, swelling the budget deficits and necessitating greater issuance of Government bonds and greater money creation, and hence causing greater inflation. This striking result depends on two crucial assumptions. The first is that the real rate of interest (the nominal level of interest rates minus the rate of inflation) exceeds the growth rate of the economy. At present, that assumption applies. The second crucial assumption is that the path of fiscal policy does not depend on present or futu re monetary policies. With the Administration setting its own budge t and tax course undeterred by the Fed's planned path of monetary g rowth, that assumption also appears to hold.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+Looser+Money%2C+Less+Inflation%3F&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-01-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: THE prospects for the American economy in 1982 are growing increasingly dismal. The securities markets have weakened, reflecting anxieties over rising interest rates. The Administration's policy makers have insisted that interest rates would come down with inflation, but the markets do not believe it. They foresee pressures on rates intensifying as the Government plans for growing budget deficits three years ahead - deficits that were supposed not to happen, as faster growth threw off enough additional revenue to pay for the big tax cuts.
At the same time, unemployment is climbing faster than expected. The jobless rate, which was 7.4 percent when Ronald Reagan took office, reached 8.9 percent in December, and could hit 10 percent in the months ahead.
Is the Reagan Administration's effort to combine monetarism - tight control of the money supply - with so-called supply-side tax cuts and climbing military spending proving a failure? Or is the weak performance of the economy simply the price for bringing inflation down and establishing conditions for steady growth?
The monetarists within the Administration and at the Federal Reserve Board, headed by Paul A. Volcker, are clinging to the hope that tight money will beat inflation and inflationary expectations out of the system. But some economists within the Federal Reserve System have begun to voice sharply dissenting views about the wisdom of trying to use tight money to stop inflation in the face of the huge looming Federal budget deficits.
In the latest issue of the Quarterly Review of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, Thomas J. Sargent and Neil Wallace, the bank's leading monetary economists, offer what they call ''Some Unpleasant Monetarist Arithmetic'' to demonstrate that, although tight money in the face of a loose fiscal policy may work temporarily to reduce inflation, it eventually leads to higher inflation.
In fact, they say, if individuals and corporations expect future inflation because of coming big budget deficits and base their monetary demands and actions on those expectations, tighter money will do little to check inflation even temporarily.
To be sure, if money is held tightly enough to dump the economy into recession, as it now has, the slump may cause a temporary decline in inflation. But the economists beli eve that sooner or laterthe necessity of financing huge deficits is l ikely to breed greater inflation.
The critical issue, they contend, is whether fiscal policy dominates monetary policy or vice versa. At present, they see the fiscal policy of the Reagan Administration dominating the Fed's monetary policy.By independently laying down its budget and deficit plans, the Administration determines how much money will have to be raised through the public sale of interest-bearing Government bonds and through seigniorage -revenue raised by money creation.
Using a quantitative model, Mr. Sargent and Mr. Wallace reach the spectacular conclusion that, given the Government deficit that needs to be financed, looser money will produce less inflation than tight money.The reason is that tight money will put the economy into deeper recession and choke back longer-term growth, swelling the budget deficits and necessitating greater issuance of Government bonds and greater money creation, and hence causing greater inflation.
This striking result depends on two crucial assumptions. The first is that the real rate of interest (the nominal level of interest rates minus the rate of inflation) exceeds the growth rate of the economy. At present, that assumption applies. The second crucial assumption is that the path of fiscal policy does not depend on present or futu re monetary policies. With the Administration setting its own budge t and tax course undeterred by the Fed's planned path of monetary g rowth, that assumption also appears to hold.
The Sargent-Wallace study does not deny the possibility that monetary policy could permanently affect the inflation rate under a monetary regime that effectively disciplined the fiscal authority, but such a regime does not exist in the United States now.
The faltering growth of the American economy, rising unemployment and persistently high interest rates, especially on long-term securities, disclose stubborn inflationary expectations and raise grave doubts about whether monetarism, combined with big budget deficits, will work any better in Ronald Reagan's America than it has in Margaret Thatcher's Britain.

CAN WE INDEX OUR WAY OUT OF INFLATION?

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]16 Nov 1981: A.22.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424223552?accountid=11752

Abstract: First, given a current inflation rate of about 10 percent, it is inconceivable that nominal rates of interest can fall to 3 to 6 percent today as they claim, even if inflation risk disappears from the lenders' point of view. The best that can be hoped for is that lenders will not charge a premium over and above the anticipated rate of inflation for the inflation risk they would bear with non-indexed contracts.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=CAN+WE+INDEX+OUR+WAY+OUT+OF+INFLATION%3F%3A+%5BLETTER%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-11-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.22&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: T o the Editor: Professors Robert Heilbroner and Adolph Lowe do not seem to have taken account of the full implications of their proposal to index loan contracts to an appropriate price index (letter Nov. 4).
First, given a current inflation rate of about 10 percent, it is inconceivable that nominal rates of interest can fall to 3 to 6 percent today as they claim, even if inflation risk disappears from the lenders' point of view. The best that can be hoped for is that lenders will not charge a premium over and above the anticipated rate of inflation for the inflation risk they would bear with non-indexed contracts.
Second, indexation simply shifts the inflation risk from the lender to the borrower. For instance, the issue of such indexed instruments in the housing market in prior years would have prevented the financial crisis many savings and loan associations face today, but by the same token would have increased the number of bankruptcies of households unable to meet rapidly escalating mortgage obligations.
It may be argued that the social cost of insuring against the failure of the financial institutions (the lenders) through the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is lower than that associated with the obvious disruptions caused by a large number of personal bankruptcies. The experience in Britain where quasi-index-linked contracts have been prevalent in the housing market for several years has not been as positive as Professors Heilbroner and Lowe suggest. In the face of the borrowers' inability to pay higher interest costs, lenders were simply forced to reschedule the payments due them.
Finally, the ability of business borrowers to pass on their increased costs to their customers varies from industry to industry, so that revenues do not necessarily keep pace with inflated costs. Since movements in the prices of various goods do not closely mirror the changes in the aggregate price index, it is risky for an individual firm to write such indexed contracts. The reluctance of business firms in most countries to issue index-linked contracts in the past is indirect evidence of their unwillingness to bear the risk of inflation.
Index-linked loan contracts are certainly a valuable addition to the available range of financial instruments, since they permit a different allocation of inflation risk between borrowers and lenders than is currently feasible. However, to recommend them as a panacea to cure all the ills of inflation is certainly overstating the case in their favor. MARTI G. SUBRAHMANYAM Chairman, Finance Graduate School of Business New York University New York, Nov. 6, 1981

____________________________________________________________

Arms Impact On Inflation

Author: AP

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]08 Oct 1981: D.13.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424219540?accountid=11752

Abstract: While the Administration's military program is a major one, Mr. [Murray L. Weidenbaum] added, ''it is a long-term expansion and can be foreseen and planned for in the private sector.'' He said, ''Thus, I believe the dangers on this score have been overstated.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Arms+Impact+On+Inflation&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-10-08&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.13&amp;au=AP&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The Reagan Administration's military buildup could contribute to inflation ''in the very short run,'' but it was not expected to have a major effect on consumer prices, Murray L. Weidenbaum, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today.
Defense spending can contribute to inflationary pressures ''when prices in the economy are slow to adjust to a relative shift in the economy's pattern of demand away from civilian products and toward defense production,'' Mr. Weidenbaum told a Congressional joint economic subcommittee.
That happens primarily when ''overly rapid and unforeseen growth in defense requirements creates bottlenecks in the supplying industries,'' he said.
But while the Administration's military program is a major one, Mr. Weidenbaum added, ''it is a long-term expansion and can be foreseen and planned for in the private sector.'' He said, ''Thus, I believe the dangers on this score have been overstated.''
Mr. Weidenbaum said that despite the military buildup, outlays by the Defense Department were projected to rise only from 5.5 percent of the gross national product in the fiscal year 1981, to 7 percent in the fiscal year 1986.
By contrast, he said, military spending accounted for 8.6 percent of the G.N.P. in 1962 and 9 percent in 1968, the peak year of American involvement in the Vietnam War.

Forum; GETTING THE COAL ON THE ROAD

Author: Owen, Henry

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]20 Sep 1981: A.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424180443?accountid=11752

Abstract: Nor is the obstacle any lag in demand: Conversion of oil-burning facilities to coal and creation of new coal burning facilities is proceeding so rapidly in Western Europe and Japan that demand for coal imports by these regions is expected to increase fourfold from 1979 to 1990. Despite present softness of the coal spot market in Europe, a very substantial long-term increase in demand remains likely. THE obstacl e to increased coal trade lies in artificial restraints in the coal e xporting nations: Unstable conditions in Poland, which have reduced its coal output; fear of interracial strife in the future and an equivocal government policy in the past, which have made importer s reluctant to rely unduly on South Africa; periodic labor difficu lties in Australia, reflected in last year's strike, andinadequate po rt facilities in the United States, which have provoked bitter compla ints from our trading partners. The problems in Poland, South Africa, and A ustralia are not susceptible to rapid resolution. So the Unite d States will remain a key residual supplier - the more so since mos t coal importers are anxious to diversify their sources of supply in order to reduce theirvulnerability to untoward events in other cou ntries. The United States role is so large as to make it unlikel y that world coal trade will be doubled unless restraints on that rol e created by inadequate ports are overcome. * There is the longer-term problem of channel depths. Even if the improvements in coal loading and storage facilities described above are achieved, United States coal ports will remain inadequate, because European and Japanese coal importers want to shift some of their coal commerce from the present Panamax 60,000-ton ships to larger ships (100,000 tons and over), which can transport coal more economically. Present water depths in most world coal ports are too shallow to take these ships. Steps are being taken to remedy this condition in some European, Australian, and South African ports, but not in the United States.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Forum%3B+GETTING+THE+COAL+ON+THE+ROAD&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-09-20&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;au=Owen%2C+Henry&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: I F the dredging of channels in a few United States ports is not begun in the next several years, American efforts to beat stagflation will be significantly hampered. To say that this connection is not widely appreciated would be a vast understatement. But the connection is there, and unless we take account of it, we will suffer.
The 1970's showed that sharply rising oil prices meant more inflation and less economic growth in the industrial countries. Oil prices are no longer rising steeply, in part because these countries have reacted to higher prices by reducing their oil consumption and increasing their use of alternative energy sources.
The most important of these alternatives is coal. When the leaders of the seven main industrial countries met at the 1980 economic summit conference in Venice, they pledged their countries to double coal trade in the coming decade. Whether this pledge is fulfilled will do much to determine whether the present relative stability of oil prices continues, or fades away as the current recession wanes and unforeseen interruptions in oil supply occur.
The obstacle to doubling coal trade is not lack of supply in the main exporting countries: The United States, Australia, Poland, and South Africa have sufficient reserves to increase enormously their production of coal for sale abroad.
Nor is the obstacle any lag in demand: Conversion of oil-burning facilities to coal and creation of new coal burning facilities is proceeding so rapidly in Western Europe and Japan that demand for coal imports by these regions is expected to increase fourfold from 1979 to 1990. Despite present softness of the coal spot market in Europe, a very substantial long-term increase in demand remains likely. THE obstacl e to increased coal trade lies in artificial restraints in the coal e xporting nations: Unstable conditions in Poland, which have reduced its coal output; fear of interracial strife in the future and an equivocal government policy in the past, which have made importer s reluctant to rely unduly on South Africa; periodic labor difficu lties in Australia, reflected in last year's strike, andinadequate po rt facilities in the United States, which have provoked bitter compla ints from our trading partners. The problems in Poland, South Africa, and A ustralia are not susceptible to rapid resolution. So the Unite d States will remain a key residual supplier - the more so since mos t coal importers are anxious to diversify their sources of supply in order to reduce theirvulnerability to untoward events in other cou ntries. The United States role is so large as to make it unlikel y that world coal trade will be doubled unless restraints on that rol e created by inadequate ports are overcome.
There is a good deal of misunderstanding about these restraints. Three separate problems need to be distinguished from each other:
* There are the short-term problems of adjustment that caused large numbers of European ships to wait long periods to load coal at United States East Coast ports last spring. These problems have been eased not only by the end of the Australian strike but also by innovative procedures that have made it possible to schedule waiting ships at our East Coast ports more efficiently and by increased coal exports from our Gulf Coast ports.
* There is the medium-term problem of structural change: United States coal loading and storage port facilities were designed for lesser amounts than must now be moved, and were designed primarily for metallurgical coal, rather than the steam coal that is now in growing demand abroad. So these facilities must be expanded and modernized. The private companies that own the piers and the relevant port authorities are taking effective steps to these ends.
* There is the longer-term problem of channel depths. Even if the improvements in coal loading and storage facilities described above are achieved, United States coal ports will remain inadequate, because European and Japanese coal importers want to shift some of their coal commerce from the present Panamax 60,000-ton ships to larger ships (100,000 tons and over), which can transport coal more economically. Present water depths in most world coal ports are too shallow to take these ships. Steps are being taken to remedy this condition in some European, Australian, and South African ports, but not in the United States.
This United States lag is due to a legislative problem: The Administration has concluded that dredging should not and cannot, in present budgetary circumstances, be financed by the Federal Government. This means that a bill will have to be passed by the Congress defining how this function is to be transferred to the states and local authorities. And it has proved damnably difficult to get Congressional agreement on such a bill. Many coastal states are involved, and their immediate interests and financial capabilities differ.
Until it is clear that a few United States coal ports will be dredged, some European and Japanese coal importers will be reluctant to sign long-term contracts to buy greatly increased amounts of American coal. In the absence of such contracts, some American companies will be reluctant to make the long-term investments needed to fulfill United States coal export potential. This will not only limit world coal trade but also hurt those Americans who make their living producing and transporting coal.
The Administration is cutting red tape on dredging. Legislative action in the next 12 months is also needed, and is feasible. But this will require that two things occur:
* That the Administration take the lead in seeking legislative consensus.
* That public demand for port dredging be felt, making it easier for the members of Congress principally concerned to compromise. Failing this, the great United States export coal boom that people talk about for the 1980's will turn out like the great United States domestic coal boom that people used to talk about for the 1970's - a dazzling vision that is only partially reflected in expanded sales of the hard black stuff that substitutes for oil.
Without a United States coal export boom, the link between oil consumption and economic growth in the industrial world will not be broken - a link that condemns us to recurring inflation and low growth, whenever the balance between oil demand and supply tilts, as it may periodically, against the oil importing nations.
There is an excellent chance of solving our coal port problem. But only if a lot more public attention is paid to it than is now the case. --------------------------------------------------------------------- Henry Owen, w ho was in charge of the White House coordination for President Car ter at the London, Bonn, Tokyo and Venice economic summit meetin gs, is with the Consultants International Group in Washington.
Illustration photo of loading coal on ship in Newport News

NOW IT'S DEFENSE VS. THE DEFICIT President Reagan in March and September 1981 (p.24)

Author: Halloran, Richard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]13 Sep 1981: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424182483?accountid=11752

Abstract: Thus, [David A. Stockman] is on a collision course with Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, who held Stockman's job under former President Nixon and earned the sobriquet ''Cap the Knife.'' Today, charged with the task of meeting [Ronald Reagan]'s military objectives, he has become ''Cap the Warrior.'' Important as the shift strikes the government, investors as yet seem unimpressed. ''What Wall Street is looking for is a credible anti-inflation policy on the part of the Reagan administration,'' Gary Wenglowski, economist for Goldman, Sachs & Company, said. ''This is a Republican administation, yet the deficits are larger than the [Jimmy Carter] deficits - $60 billion to $65 billion this year and about the same next year. And investors fear that it will be too politically unpopular for Reagan to say 'no' to inflation.'' Representatives of defense contractors in Washington have been noticeably silent during the Administration's struggle with the military budget. ''We're hunkered down waiting to see what's going to happen,'' one said. ''We honestly don't know what's going to be cut, or even if anything is going to be cut.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=NOW+IT%27S+DEFENSE+VS.+THE+DEFICIT+President+Reagan+in+March+and+September+1981+%28p.24%29&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-09-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Halloran%2C+Richard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: At first, it seemed that the moment of truth for President Reagan was at hand. He had pushed his huge budget and tax cuts through the Congress in early August and gone off to vacation in California. But the latent conflict over the rapidly growing defense budget reared up behind him.
The financial community and the president's own economic advisers, led by David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, told him he couldn't do both. Stockman said that another $75 billion at least would have to come out of the budget in 1983 and 1984 to reach the 1984 balanced budget, and he urged that much of it come from defense - the only part of the budget that had been singled out for substantial increases.
The signals from investors could not be clearer. Both bond and stock prices have been plunging, and the euphoria of the budget and tax cut victories has been lost in uneasiness over the economy. Essentially, Wall Street wants an indication that the Reagan administration is serious about dealing with inflation by restraining government borrowing and thus the ever rising budget deficits.
Thus, Stockman is on a collision course with Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, who held Stockman's job under former President Nixon and earned the sobriquet ''Cap the Knife.'' Today, charged with the task of meeting Reagan's military objectives, he has become ''Cap the Warrior.''
Aligned behind Stockman are two other White House colleagues, the chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, and the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Murray L. Weidenbaum.
On Weinberger's side stands Deputy Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci, who has the best command of the military budget in the Pentagon - and Secretary of State Alexander M . Haig Jr., although whatever help Haig has given the defense secr etary, with whom he has had repeated differences, has been largely be hind the scenes.
Edwin Meese 3d, the influential presidential counselor, has kept his own counsel in this case. The wrangling has now gone public. After the president got back to the White House for a series of meetings on the budget last week, he faced some complicated choices: Slow the increase in military spending, cut deeper into the social welfare and domestic programs, accept a continuing deficit. As the smok e and dust of the squabbling began to clear by the end of the week, the president appeared to be moving toward a compromise.It would invo lve a hold-down of $5 billion to $30 billion in the 1983 and 1984 defense budget increases; what one official called ''a massive savin g'' of up to $45 billion in the nondefense budgets; a small deficit of around $10 billion in the 1984 Federal budget, and $3 billion in new revenues from user taxes.
The rhetoric of the debate on defense has been misleading. Headlines speak of ''cuts,'' but there would be no actual cuts - just reductions in the president's projected increases. Such reductions still represent a painful shift for the Reagan administration. In January, Weinberger and other senior officials said that military needs, not the budget, would drive military spending. However, more recently, Henry E. Catto, the Pentagon's chief spokesman, told reporters, ''The original projections are now being revised. I think it fair to say that this is a look in the light of new realities.''
Important as the shift strikes the government, investors as yet seem unimpressed. ''What Wall Street is looking for is a credible anti-inflation policy on the part of the Reagan administration,'' Gary Wenglowski, economist for Goldman, Sachs & Company, said. ''This is a Republican administation, yet the deficits are larger than the Carter deficits - $60 billion to $65 billion this year and about the same next year. And investors fear that it will be too politically unpopular for Reagan to say 'no' to inflation.''
Wenglowski added that Wall Street will be looking primarily at the deficit in fiscal year 1982. ''Reagan has to show a break in the deficit trend, starting in 1982,'' he said. ''Projections of 1984 do not mean anything.''
Alan Benasuli, aerospace analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert, the New York brokerage house, said he thought the president would probably reduce the 1982 military budget to $205 billion to $210 billion with 4 to 5 percent real annual growth, from the current projected level of $222 billion with 7 percent growth. ''That will come to about $20 billion to $30 billion in cuts, which is 40 percent of the necessary cuts,'' Benasuli said. ''He's not going to have any problem getting those through Congress. He will just have to persuade his conservative backers.''
At this point, it is unclear just where the military budget cuts will be made. There are several ways of looking at the complicated budget, one of which is by category of appropriation. The $222 billion budget for 1982, for example, includes $43.8 billion for personnel and another $15.4 billion for retired service people; $64.1 billion to operate, train and maintain the forces; $68.5 billion to procure weapons and equipment; $21.7 billion for research and development of new weapons and equipment, and $8.1 billion for construction of military facilities and housing.
Put another way, the same budget can be broken down into $89.5 billion for general purpose, or conventional forces; $41 billion for training, medical and other personnel activities; $20.1 billion for central supply and maintenance; $18.5 billion for research and development; $17.4 billion for strategic, or nuclear forces; $14.5 billion for intelligence and communications; $11.3 billion for national guard and reserve forces; $4.4 billion for air and sea lift; $4.2 billion for administration, and $1.3 billion to support other nations.
Adminstration officials said the president had exempted cuts in strategic nuclear weapons and hardware, which would involve companies such as Martin Marietta in its work on the MX missile, Rockwell International and other makers of strategic bombers. But the budget issue has again set back basic decisions on how to improve the nuclear deterrent, so that those companies have little assurance of what may be coming their way. Manufacturers of conventional weapons are even more uncertain.
The immediate future depends not only on how much Reagan decides to trim out of the projected military budget but also on the military priorities set by him and Weinberger. Holding down the expansion of the Navy, for instance, could affect shipbuilders such as Newport News, Litton, Bath Iron Works, Todd Shipyards and Electric Boat, plus makers of naval aircraft such as Grumman.
If the decision were to delay an expansion of ground forces, then Chrysler, Hughes, Sikorsky and Raytheon might not get expected orders. Scrapping Air Force expansion plans could chew into General Dynamics or McDonnell Douglas. Cutting down on operations and tra ining might mean less buying of petroleum products from Motor Oil Hellas, Exxon, Standard of California and Tex aco.
Wall Street analysts seem to agree that the cuts would come primarily in the conventional force weapons, in the form or reducing orders for such systems as General Dynamics's F-16 fighter plane and the M-1 tank, for which the Chrysler Corp. is the prime contractor.
''Fairchild Industries' A-10 attack plane is a good example,'' said Benasuli of Drexel Burnham. ' 'Under the Carter budget, it would have ended in April 1983. Reagan reinstated the program with orders for 60 planes . If we go back to no planes at all, then Fairchild has a problem.''
Analysts also see few cuts coming on the personnel side. ''Funding for hardware is scheduled to rise 93.8 percent over two years,'' said Wolfgang Demisch, aerospace analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company. ''It's going to be a lot easier to cut there then to cut back on personnel, which is politically sensitive.''
Representatives of defense contractors in Washington have been noticeably silent during the Administration's struggle with the military budget. ''We're hunkered down waiting to see what's going to happen,'' one said. ''We honestly don't know what's going to be cut, or even if anything is going to be cut.''
One area the White House will not cut seems to be the promised pay increase. Officials have said that the administration would continue to seek the 14.3 percent raise, effective Oct. 1. That would have considerable positive effect on the economies of communities around military bases. But the officials said that planned increases in the size of the force and in civilian employees were not at all guaranteed.
A long-time analyst chuckled about what had happened. ''Jimmy Carter fed us all that baloney in 1976 about how he was going to cut $5 billion to $7 billion from the defense budget, but when he got here, he was confronted with military reality,'' he said, referring to the Soviet buildup and invasion of Afghanistan and the long crisis over the American hostages in Iran. ''Then Ronald Reagan fed us all that baloney in 1980 about how he would go full steam ahead to rearm America. When he got into office, he came face-to-face with economic reality.''
Weinberger himself is a study in contrasts. Although he is softspoken, congenial and humorous, a careful reading of his words suggests that he is the toughest in Reagan's flight of hawks.
While the numbers in the argument between Stockman and Weinberger sound enormous, the contention is actually over about 5 percent of the military budget. Part of the 5 percent reduction had already been built in and was there waiting to be taken if needed. As the 1983 budget was being drawn up during the summer, the OMB directed the Pentagon to identify a series of 5 percent cuts that could be made if needed to help balance the budget.
Those cuts were primarily in the procurement of weapons and other hardware. With that as a starting point, the Pentagon was instructed to identify other possible cuts in costs of manpower, operations, training, maintenance and research and development.
The main point of attack, once Reagan decides where the cuts are to be made, will be the 1982 appropriations bills that have barely started their way through Congress. Small savings in fiscal 1982, which starts Oct. 1, are possible, according to Administration officials, but the real slowdown would come in 1983 and 1984, when actual outlays would be made. The administration then intends to reinforce that by holding down the growth of military budgets that are authorized for 1983 and 1984, they said. Some officials suggested that $3 billion would be saved in 1982, $11 billion in 1983, and $16 billion in 1984 to arrive at the $30 billion target.
While much of the comment recently has emphasized the battle between the OMB and the Defense Department, they haven't been all that far apart. OMB supported the small increase in the additions the Reagan administration made to Carter's 1981 military budget and the $25.8 billion amendment to the 1982 budget to bring it up to $222 billion. It also approved projections announced last March that would have the Congress authorize $1.46 trillion in military budgets through 1986, with another $412 billion in 1987.
At the same time, Weinberger and Carlucci reorganized the Pentagon's strategic planning and budget programming process, seeking to reduce the adversarial nature of the dealings within the department and between the department and the OMB. Stockman's associate director for national security, William Schneider, was given a seat at the table and a vote in the deliberations of the Defense Review Board. It has become the Pentagon's executive committee and is headed by Carlucci.
The OMB and the Pentagon have adopted what one official called ''a no-surprises policy.'' All issues are fought out at the Review Board. Pentagon officials have forsaken end-runs to the President, and the OMB has promised not to seek previously unmentioned cuts when the budget comes across the Potomac River to its offices in the old Executive Office Building.
While neither civilian officials nor military officers are happy over the prospect of not getting all they thought they would, no one has suggested that the Republic would fall if the trims are
