MILITARY IS TOLD TO PREPARE CUTS IN 1983 BUDGET

Author: RICHARD HALLORAN, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]03 Aug 1981: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424187136?accountid=11752

Abstract: Some of the service program managers have tried to pad their programs with ''gold watches,'' or items inserted so that they could be cut with little pain, the officials said. But they said there had been less of that than expected and most of it would be trimmed out before the program was approved. Budget officials have contended that inflation in the Defense Department's budget has risen at about the same rate as that in the rest of the Federal budget, except for fuel costs and personnel compensation, which run on their own tracks. Pentagon officials have argued that the inflation rate has been unrealistically low and thus they have had to cut the numbers of weapons they could buy. Thus, if a well-managed program had experienced only 2 percent growth in costs because of inflation, its new budget would have a 2 percent inflation factor. A program in which inflation had run to 10 percent might be assigned that inflation factor but would also be closely scrutinized for possible poor management, the officials said. Cutting Cost of Tactics

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=MILITARY+IS+TOLD+TO+PREPARE+CUTS+IN+1983+BUDGET&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-08-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=RICHARD+HALLORAN%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The Reagan Administration has instructed the military services to identify in their 1983 budget proposals a series of 5 percent cuts that might be made if needed to keep the Federal Government headed toward balancing the budget in 1984.
Senior Administration officials said that the 7 percent annual growth rate in military spending set by President Reagan and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger remained policy for now, but was not sacred and could be cut if the Administration's economic assumptions proved mistaken.
The officials also disclosed a new approach to the perennial problem of assigning an inflation factor to military budgets. Instead of applying it across the board, they said, more realistic rates would be applied to each large program.
Guidance Given by White House
Further, the officials said they were looking for ways to hold down the military budget by seeking less costly military tactics and operations and by finding more efficient ways to recruit, train and retain manpower.
The budget for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, 1982, will be the first budget on which the Administration can make its own full imprint, since the changes in the budgets for the fiscal years 1981 and 1982 were only revisions of the Carter Administration's final budgets.
The Administration has given its basic guidance to the military services, and they have been preparing responses on the weapons, equipment, supplies and other programs they consider necessary to execute the Administration's policy. Programs Facing Review
Those programs, the officials said, must stay within the fiscal guideline set by the Administration, which is basically a 7 percent growth after accounting for inflation. Those programs are scheduled for review in the Pentagon in August and in the White House in September and October before being folded into the Federal budget to be presented to Congress in January.
The 5 percent reductions in the military budgets amount to a safety net for balancing the budget in 1984, and they could also be invoked, officials said, if inflation failed to come down to targets set by the Administration.
Each of the military services, the officials said, has been instructed to identify low-priority programs now so that there will be no surprises later if the cuts have to be imposed. Padding of Some Programs
The officials also said that the cuts would be made in entire segments of programs, not by stretching out purchases of hardware, as was the case in earlier budget cutting. To reduce the number of tanks bought in a year, for instance, would increase the unit cost and thus dilute an effort that Mr. Weinberger has emphasized.
Some of the service program managers have tried to pad their programs with ''gold watches,'' or items inserted so that they could be cut with little pain, the officials said. But they said there had been less of that than expected and most of it would be trimmed out before the program was approved.
The rate of inflation to be assigned to the military budget has long been a source of contention between the Defense Department and the White House's Office of Management and Budget, which sets the rate for the entire executive branch of the Government. Inflation at Comparative Rate
Budget officials have contended that inflation in the Defense Department's budget has risen at about the same rate as that in the rest of the Federal budget, except for fuel costs and personnel compensation, which run on their own tracks. Pentagon officials have argued that the inflation rate has been unrealistically low and thus they have had to cut the numbers of weapons they could buy.
Administration officials said that an effort would be made to reconcile that dispute by applying different rates of inflation to each program. Those rates would be based, they said, on experience with inflation in the recent past.
Thus, if a well-managed program had experienced only 2 percent growth in costs because of inflation, its new budget would have a 2 percent inflation factor. A program in which inflation had run to 10 percent might be assigned that inflation factor but would also be closely scrutinized for possible poor management, the officials said. Cutting Cost of Tactics
The Administration officials said that most efforts to reduce military spending in the past had been directed at the cost of hardware. They said that they intended to take a new look at tactics, to see whether military operations might not be just as effective but less expensive.
They said, for instance, that the American tendency was to mass tactical aircraft for heavy aerial strikes while allied air forces depended more on deception, low-level flying and less costly munitions.
On manpower, the officials said that long-term enlistments were under study in an effort to cut recruiting and training costs and to increase productivity by keeping experienced people in the services longer.
They also said they were studying the expansion of munitions plants as a possibly cheaper way of preparing for a long war without having to manufacture ammunition and store it now.

BONN BUDGET PLAN FOR THE MILITARY CUT IN REAL TERMS

Author: JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]31 July 1981: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424130068?accountid=11752

Abstract: Mr. [Helmut Schmidt] said Government spending was being reduced because ''in the foreseeable future, for months, and well into 1982'' no decline in international interest rates could be expected because of the high rates in the United States. Minister Asked 10% Increase He said it was unlikely that any alliance member, except the United States, would meet the pledge next year. ''We cannot compete with that,'' he added, ''We're suffering from high American interest rates. We didn't invent this high interest rate policy.'' To compete with American banks for investor capital, Western Europe's credit institutions have had to raise their lending rates, causing a falloff in business investment that is prolonging the recession. In the absence of lower United States rates, Mr. Schmidt said last week in Ottawa, West Germany's only recourse is to relieve pressure on capital markets by reducing Government borrowing through spending cuts.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=BONN+BUDGET+PLAN+FOR+THE+MILITARY+CUT+IN+REAL+TERMS&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-07-31&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=JOHN+TAGLIABUE%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The West German Cabinet today approved a rough outline for the 1982 budget that foresees a possible drop in military spending after inflation is accounted for. Chancellor Helmut Schmidt attributed the decline to the impact of high interest rates in the United States.
The Chancellor, announcing the budget figures at a news conference after an all-day Cabinet session, said the Defense Ministry budget would increase by 4.2 percent, roughly equal to the overall budget rise. If 5 to 6 percent inflation is subtracted, the real change in military spending could be a cut by as much as 1.8 percent.
Mr. Schmidt said Government spending was being reduced because ''in the foreseeable future, for months, and well into 1982'' no decline in international interest rates could be expected because of the high rates in the United States. Minister Asked 10% Increase
The 1981 military budget was $16.2 billion. Defense Minister Hans Apel originally asked for an increase of $1.6 billion, but only $696 million was approved.
The decision on military spending was one of the few firm elements to emerge from the Cabinet meeting, which was originally intended to produce an full-fledged austerity program aimed at reducing Government borrowing and relieving pressure on capital markets.
Mr. Schmidt, who seemed relaxed and good-humored despite the strains of two days of difficult talks, said total spending would increase by 4.3 percent, to $98.7 billion, reducing borrowing to $10.8 billion from $14.7 billion this year.
He said circumstances had changed since West Germany pledged, in 1978, together with its partners in the Atlantic alliance, to make efforts to increase military spending by 3 percent annually through 1986.
He said it was unlikely that any alliance member, except the United States, would meet the pledge next year. ''We cannot compete with that,'' he added, ''We're suffering from high American interest rates. We didn't invent this high interest rate policy.''
To compete with American banks for investor capital, Western Europe's credit institutions have had to raise their lending rates, causing a falloff in business investment that is prolonging the recession. In the absence of lower United States rates, Mr. Schmidt said last week in Ottawa, West Germany's only recourse is to relieve pressure on capital markets by reducing Government borrowing through spending cuts.
The budget announcement represented at best an incomplete victory for Mr. Schmidt on the fiscal front. He had hoped for a clear-cut program to be announced today, but is caught between forces in his own Social Democratic Party that favor increased taxes and Government pump-priming to relieve the economy, and the Free Democrats, the junior partner in his coalition, who favor cuts in social security spending to foster business investment. Legislation Must Be Drafted
Much of the saving announced today depends on the passage of enabling legislation, still to be approved by the coalition partners and the Cabinet.
The left wing of Mr. Schmidt's party favors a plan for an income and withholding surtax to finance an economic program. A decision on the surtax, which is opposed by the Free Democrats, has been put off until September.
Business leaders expressed disappointment with the budget. The disappointment seemed reflected in the Frankfurt currency market, where the dollar reached a level of 2.4683 marks, the highest level since September 1976.
Military officials have played down the possible effects of the spending cuts, contending that the measure in dollars alone does not accurately reflect military preparedness. ---- No Comment From Pentagon Special to the New York Times
WASHINGTON, July 30 - A spokesman for the Department of Defense said that senior officials were aware of the proposed military budget in West Germany but would have no comment on it at this time.

7 LEADERS END ECONOMIC MEETING; AGREE ON GOAL BUT NOT THE MEANS

Author: HENRY GINIGER, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]22 July 1981: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424138391?accountid=11752

Abstract: Mr. [Reagan] said: ''We leave with a true sense of common understanding and common purpose.'' He expressed gratitude to the others ''for the understanding and support for the economic policies we have embarked upon in the United States.'' 'Pessimists Were Not Justified' It carefully avoided short-range predictions or promises and represented a compromise between countries like France, worried mostly about unemployment, and those like the United States that are aiming mainly at reduc- ing inflation. ''We see low and stable monetary growth as essential to reducing inflation,'' the statement said. ''Interest rates have to play their part in achieving this and are likely to remain high where fears of inflation remain strong.'' During their news conference some of the participants returned to this double theme of military balance with the Soviet Union and arms control. There was no specific reference to Poland in the political statement. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. explained this, saying the leaders had felt ''a definite sense of relief'' that the recent congress of the Polish Communist Party was able to proceed without incident. ''It looks like a continuation of the moderating trend,'' he said.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=7+LEADERS+END+ECONOMIC+MEETING%3B+AGREE+ON+GOAL+BUT+NOT+THE+MEANS&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-07-22&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=HENRY+GINIGER%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The United States and six other industrial democracies concluded their seventh annual economic conference today with a pledge to revitalize their economies, but with no precise agreement on how to accomplish this in the immediate future.
Led by President Reagan, the leaders of Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan and West Germany expressed Text of communique, page D18. satisfaction with the outcome of the meeting, and they agreed to meet again next year in France.
The leaders spoke to reporters from the stage of the opera house in the National Arts Center and, for the most part, were careful to emit only sounds of harmony. But some of the basic grievances against the United States, notably over its high interest rates, persisted. After two days of what one official called ''sometimes brutal discussions'' the United States made no concessions on economic policies.
Mr. Reagan said: ''We leave with a true sense of common understanding and common purpose.'' He expressed gratitude to the others ''for the understanding and support for the economic policies we have embarked upon in the United States.'' 'Pessimists Were Not Justified'
Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the host, who had predicted a difficult meeting, said that ''the pessimists were not justified.'' He added that the talks had bolstered ''mutual trust and confidence in facing the crises that challenge us.''
The long and carefully balanced final statement smoothed out basic disagreements in promising a twin effort to defeat inflation and unemployment, to avoid economic protectionist policies and to help the poor nations.
It carefully avoided short-range predictions or promises and represented a compromise between countries like France, worried mostly about unemployment, and those like the United States that are aiming mainly at reduc- ing inflation. ''We see low and stable monetary growth as essential to reducing inflation,'' the statement said. ''Interest rates have to play their part in achieving this and are likely to remain high where fears of inflation remain strong.''
Having reflected American monetary policy, the statement went on: ''We are fully aware that levels and movements of interest rates in one country can make stabilization policies more difficult in other countries by influencing their exchange rates and their economies.''
The demands of the French, the West Germans, the Italians and the Canadians were thus met. Absent from the document was any commitment by the United States to bring down interest rates soon, although Mr. Reagan and his officials held out hope that this might happen before the end of the year.
President Francois Mitterrand of France, who pointedly suggested in his closing statements that there was no agreed conclusion on some points, bluntly told the Americans during the talks that any extension of high rates beyond the end of the year would be ''intolerable.'' Balanced Policies
The leaders agreed that a balanced range of policies would be needed to reduce inflation and to achieve higher investment and sustainable growth. The various peoples, their statement said, had to appreciate the need for a change in expectations about growth and earnings, about management and labor practices and relations and change in the direction, scale and pattern of industrial investment. It was agreed, also, that most countries needed ''urgently to reduce public borrowing and increase support for productive investment and innovation.''
But the Europeans, particuarly the French, were vexed about the damping effect of American interest rates on investment at home and the fact that the increase in the value of the dollar had raised their energy import costs and deflected funds from investment.
Mr. Reagan, while expressing his understanding of European difficulties and protesting that high rates were not an American policy but the result of the domestic economic situation, showed little disposition to make immediate changes.
Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, one of the sharpest critics along with President Mitterrand, noted at the final news conference that the United States had expressed its intention to do its best to bring down interest rates. But he warned that his country would have to take ''certain decisions,'' which he did not specify.
Secretary of Treasury Donald T. Regan reported an exchange with Gaston Thorn in which the Common Market leader urged him to bring down interest rates, saying: ''Hurry it up, will you? We can't wait too long.'' Accord on Talks
Making no concession on monetary policy, the United States did give some satisfaction to the Canadians, the French and the West Germans on the world's north-south economic disparities, expressing willingness ''to participate in preparations for a mutually acceptable process of global negotiations in circumstances offering the prospect of meaningful progress.''
The Canadians, in particular, greeted this as a major concession by the Reagan Administration after it had expressed little interest in and some puzzlement about global negotiations.
But Richard V. Allen, Mr. Reagan's national security adviser, told reporters that the United States still wanted to know what was involved in such negotiations before making any specific commitment.
The seven leaders, along with Mr. Thorn, head of the Common Market's Commission, held most of their discussions in the seclusion of Chateau Montebello, a lodge 40 miles from Ottawa.
This morning, they flew by helicopter to Ottawa, where they had lunch with the Governor General, Edward R. Schreyer, then held a last meeting in the Parliament complex in the middle of the city. They were guarded by hundreds of policemen, whose main task was to keep back the thousands of ordinary people who sought their first chance to see the leaders in person as their heavily armored cars moved through flag-lined streets. Soviet Trade an Issue
In their final formal statement, and in their meeting with reporters, the leaders placed heavy emphasis on political problems, notably their relations with the Soviet bloc. It was the most marked departure from previous summit meetings. But as Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher explained: ''Political and economic matters cannot be isolated from one another and treated separately.''
As in the case of monetary policy, there was no consensus on how to carry on commercial relations with the Soviet Union. The leaders agreed to consult and coordinate action to insure that ''our economic policies continue to be compatible with our political and security objectives.''
A high-level meeting is to be held this fall to review what the United States would like to be a tightening up of trade so that it does not help to increase the strength of the Soviet bloc. But the French and West Germans made clear their wariness of any policy that might cut their trade relations with Eastern Europe. French Note Wheat Sales
A French spokesman indicated that if the United States sought to reduce the transfer of technology to the Soviet Union, France would raise questions about American grain sales, during a meeting in which the West would ''have to put all its cards on the table.''
There was more agreement on the need for strong defense to offset the buildup of Soviet military power. This goal was laid out last night in a special political statement, which added that the West also sought ''balanced and verifiable arms control and disarmament agreements.''
During their news conference some of the participants returned to this double theme of military balance with the Soviet Union and arms control. There was no specific reference to Poland in the political statement. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. explained this, saying the leaders had felt ''a definite sense of relief'' that the recent congress of the Polish Communist Party was able to proceed without incident. ''It looks like a continuation of the moderating trend,'' he said.
President Reagan flew to Washington tonight and one by one the other leaders also took off for their capitals. They left with the same lack of fanfare and ceremony with which they arrived here Sunday for what was considered one of the most informal such conferences ever held, though one of the most intensive.
The meeting was part of a series begun in France in 1975 and since then carried on in each of the member countries.

BONN OFFICIAL BACKS U.S. MONETARY POLICY

Author: AP

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]18 June 1981: D.11.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424120390?accountid=11752

Abstract: Addressing a ministerial meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, he said that ''it would be entirely wrong not to afford the United States fundamental support for its anti-inflation policy.'' Mr. [Richard McNamar] also said that the Reagan Administration did not envisage a change in policy ''in response to temporary interest rate or exchange rate swings.'' France, Italy Lead Critics France's Finance Minister, Jacques Delors, today reiterated his attack over the American anti-inflation policies, which, he said, were ''traumatizing'' many countries. But he expressed the hope that the United States course would meet with rapid success.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=BONN+OFFICIAL+BACKS+U.S.+MONETARY+POLICY&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-06-18&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.11&amp;au=AP&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The United States found powerful support for its much-criticized monetary policy today from West Germany's Economics Minister, Count Otto Lambsdorff.
Addressing a ministerial meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, he said that ''it would be entirely wrong not to afford the United States fundamental support for its anti-inflation policy.''
At the same session a top United States official today also defended the policy by insisting that high interest rates, ''however painful domestically and internationally,'' are a result of and not the cause of inflation.
Richard McNamar, Deputy Treasury Secretary, followed a line similar to that taken by Myer Rashish, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, who, defending the policy yesterday, accused its critics of flagging in the battle against inflation.
Mr. McNamar also said that the Reagan Administration did not envisage a change in policy ''in response to temporary interest rate or exchange rate swings.'' France, Italy Lead Critics
''We have a monetary policy which temporarily is producing high rates,'' he said, not an interest rate policy.
France and Italy led the sharp European criticism of the American policy on the opening day of the meeting yesterday, with France comparing the rates to a ''third oil crisis.''
The reason for the European opposition is that high American interest rates have attracted funds from abroad, thereby depressing foreign currencies. The Europeans have raised their own interest rates defensively, even though it has had a slowing effect on already-depressed economies.
France's Finance Minister, Jacques Delors, today reiterated his attack over the American anti-inflation policies, which, he said, were ''traumatizing'' many countries. But he expressed the hope that the United States course would meet with rapid success.
Mr. Delors told reporters that he had warned O.E.C.D. ministers of the risks of social and political destabilization arising from current United States interest rates, remarking that certain European regions were already affected by de-industrialization, structural unemployment and despair that could be transformed into revolt.
Mr. Delors listed the top financial priorities of the new Socialist Government as defense of the franc, moderate support of the economy, limiting the budget deficit, continuing a strict monetary policy and curbing inflation.

Economic Scene; Why Reagan Is in a Hurry

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]01 May 1981: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424107605?accountid=11752

Abstract: The ghost of the ''guns-and-butter'' economic policy that unleashed inflation in the wake of the Kennedy-Johnson tax cut of 1964 (which the contemporary supply-siders hail as the very model for their own proposed cut) has hung around to haunt the Reagan Administration. The President's aides have sallied forth to quiet those critics who are saying that the Administration's plan to run budget deficits for the next three years will aggravate inflation. In his address to Congress Tuesday night, Mr. [REAGAN] sought to allay anxieties about inflation by presenting his program as a safe cure for the economy's ''sickness.'' While his own health was much improved, the President could not say the same for the economy. Six months since he was elected, he said, inflation was still at a double-digit level, mortgage interest rates hung at 15 percent, eight million workers were still unemployed, the average worker's hourly wage was lower and 6,000 businesses had failed. The current environment of inflation, unemployment and excess capacity, Mr. Reagan suggested, would not be quickly dispelled by his own complex mixture of tax cuts and civilian spending cuts, defense increases, regulatory reforms and monetary restraints. ''Because of the extent of our economy's sickness,'' he said, ''we know that the cure will not come quickly and that, even with our package, progress will come in inches and feet, not in miles.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+Why+Reagan+Is+in+a+Hurry&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-05-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: PRESIDENT REAGAN has completed his first 100 days riding the crest of a wave of personal popularity and rising public optimism about the economic outlook. The latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll finds that 67 percent of the respondents approve of Mr. Reagan's handling of his job, a little higher than President Carter rated four years ago.
The rising confidence in Mr. Reagan appears to be translated by a growing number of people into better prospects for their personal fortunes. The poll found that 36 percent of the public now expect to be better off financially a year from now, while 18 percent expect to be worse off. Last December the optimists and pessimists were evenly split, 25 percent to 25 percent.
Paradoxically, Mr. Reagan and his economic advisers are trying to restrain rising optimism about the economy, which has been further buoyed by the leading indicators and the remarkably strong performance of the gross national product in the first quarter.
The Administration is concerned that, as an old Russian proverb has it, ''the bride is too beautiful'' -too beautiful to support the Administration's case for big three-year tax cuts, rapidly rising defense expenditures and projected budget deficits in the presence of inflation. The rise in the prime rate and other interest rates this week dealt a blow to the equity and bond markets, still troubled by worries about chronic inflation.
The ghost of the ''guns-and-butter'' economic policy that unleashed inflation in the wake of the Kennedy-Johnson tax cut of 1964 (which the contemporary supply-siders hail as the very model for their own proposed cut) has hung around to haunt the Reagan Administration. The President's aides have sallied forth to quiet those critics who are saying that the Administration's plan to run budget deficits for the next three years will aggravate inflation.
The President's men heap scorn not so much on the old-fashioned conservatives who have always traced inflation to budget deficits but on the liberals whom they accuse of deserting their former tolerance and sophistication about deficits for the purpose of attacking the President's priorities, social philosophy and defense buildup.
In his address to Congress Tuesday night, Mr. Reagan sought to allay anxieties about inflation by presenting his program as a safe cure for the economy's ''sickness.'' While his own health was much improved, the President could not say the same for the economy. Six months since he was elected, he said, inflation was still at a double-digit level, mortgage interest rates hung at 15 percent, eight million workers were still unemployed, the average worker's hourly wage was lower and 6,000 businesses had failed.
Some other President might have used the recent data suggesting a slowdown in the rate of inflation, revival of production and heightened public optimism as a means of spurring the economic recovery. But that was not Mr. Reagan's concern Tuesday night. Instead, in the presence of a warm and affectionate response from Congressmen on both sides of the aisle, he recited a litany of sad economic statistics as evidence of the economy's persistent sickness, which he had inherited from President Carter, and the urgency of action to cure it.
At the same time, by stressing the economy's suffering from the disease economists call stagflation (which includes a high level of unemployment and idle capacity as well as inflation) Mr. Reagan was implicitly denying that the general economic condition of the United States today is comparable to the overstrained environment that confronted the Johnson Administration during the Vietnam buildup, when the guns-and-butter blunder was committed.
The current environment of inflation, unemployment and excess capacity, Mr. Reagan suggested, would not be quickly dispelled by his own complex mixture of tax cuts and civilian spending cuts, defense increases, regulatory reforms and monetary restraints. ''Because of the extent of our economy's sickness,'' he said, ''we know that the cure will not come quickly and that, even with our package, progress will come in inches and feet, not in miles.''
Then why all the hurry to push the big, complex program through Congress? Because, Mr. Reagan said, ''to fail to act will delay even longer - and more painfully - the cure which must come.''
Whatever the analytical uncertainties about the current economic environment or the impact that the President's program will have upon inflation or stagnation, however, there can be no doubt about the present favorable political environment in the nation and in Congress for passage of Mr. Reagan's economic package.
Mr. Reagan means to seize that tide of public confidence, now that he has it. No politician can ever assume that people will love him in November as they did in May.
Illustration drawing

TEXT OF STATEMENT ON ECONOMIC MATTERS ADOPTED BY HOUSE DEMOCRATIC CAUCUS

Author: Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]09 Apr 1981: B.12.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424076541?accountid=11752

Abstract: The Democratic Party has seen our American government not as an enemy, not as ''the problem,'' as President Reagan said it was in his Inaugural Address, but as a necessary instrument for achieving vital public goals. Government provides for the common defense, for the education of the young, for the exploration of space and assured production of food. Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=TEXT+OF+STATEMENT+ON+ECONOMIC+MATTERS+ADOPTED+BY+HOUSE+DEMOCRATIC+CAUCUS%3A+%5BTEXT%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-04-09&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.12&amp;au=Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Following is the text of the statement of Democratic Economic Principles adopted today by the House Democratic Caucus:
For half a century, the Democratic Party has been an engine of equity and progress in America. It has stimulated upward mobility and achieved a better life for millions of Americans. It has been the voice of working men and women, winning for them the right to decent wages and working conditions. It has protected racial and religious minorities from injustice and discrimination. It has promoted quality education for all of America's young and has secured, for older citizens, a living income and adequate medical care. Democratic programs have been the catalyst for vibrant economic growth in the private sector of the economy.
The Democratic Party has seen our American government not as an enemy, not as ''the problem,'' as President Reagan said it was in his Inaugural Address, but as a necessary instrument for achieving vital public goals. Government provides for the common defense, for the education of the young, for the exploration of space and assured production of food. No Administration, no matter what its ideology or commitments, can dispense with these and other critical functions of government if it expects to serve the American people.
Government can become the problem if it fails to respond in a timely and effective fashion to an urgent public need. Controlling rampant inflation is such a need today. It is a profound threat to achieving our goal of sustained economic growth and high employment, to concord between citizens and to our future domestic security. Numerous Causes of Inflation
The causes of high inflation are numerous, most of them experienced by nations throughout the world. Its cures are just as many. There is no single act of government, or of business or labor or of foreign oil-producing states, that can stop inflation in its tracks.
Its momentum, built into certain wage agreements and pricing policies, spurred by rising energy costs, abetted by lagging productivity growth rates, encouraged by expectations of more inflation to come and worsened by high interest rates and high government deficits, is too strong to be reversed by any one policy. It is foolhardy to try to combat inflation with a massive acrossthe-board tax cut whose immediate effect would be to make it much worse.
Inflation can be controlled by the efforts of Congress, the Administration, business and labor. As the majority party in the House of Representatives, Democrats are determined to do their part in bringing the Federal budget into balance. Reducing spending, while it is only one element of anti-inflation policy, is a vital one. Reducing the Federal deficit is important to bringing down interest rates.
A national consensus has developed behind slowing the growth rate of Federal spending, reducing the size of government, including its maze of regulations, and providing tax relief to those whose taxes have grown because inflation has forced them into higher tax brackets.
Democrats will support each of these goals, and will work with the new Administration to achieve them. We will continue the efforts begun by a Democratic Congress to increase competition by eliminating costly and unnecessary government regulation, and to make regulations more cost-effective and simpler where they serve an important natonal purpose, such as insuring health and safety or protecting the environment. Spending Cuts Must Be Equitable
Democrats will not, however, join in any program of fiscal control that puts the main burden of fighting inflation on the backs of the middle-and low-income workers while providing unprecedented benefits for the privileged few. Nor will we support the false economies which will result in more spending and higher deficits in future years. Spending cuts are essential, but they must be cost effective and equitable.
In controlling Federal spending, we intend to abide by the following guidelines:
- We will seek out and eliminate fraud, waste and abuse. We will provide the resources to prosecute those taking advantage of government benefits to which they are not entitled, whether wealthy tax evaders, illegal monopolies or participants in welfare fraud.
- We will promote the work ethic by encouraging recipients of government assistance to work and by resisting cuts that would throw people out of work and onto welfare.
- We will help those who cannot work, particularly the disabled, the sick and the elderly. A society cannot remain healthy and selfrespecting while ignoring those who are poor and helpless through no fault of their own.
- We will strengthen our defense force, in cooperation with our allies, to insure world peace. We will increase military capability and readiness, eliminate Pentagon waste and renew the search for mutual arms control agreements.
- We will promote cooperation rather than conflict among the levels of government. We must recognize local strengths, local initiative and regional differences in the country as we decide the structure and number of Federal programs. We will not purposelessly add unnecessary tax and regulatory burdens to state and local governments.
- We will examine indirect spending through the tax code with the same critical eye we focus on direct spending. Wasteful and unfair tax loopholes will be closed.
- We will upgrade our efforts in the area of law enforcement to intercept the flow of illegal drugs across our borders, stem the tide of illegal immigration, introduce efficiencies into our criminal justice system and work in partnership with state and local governments to combat crime.
In sum, we pledge to develop a lean Federal budget, which puts us on the path to balancing the budget and provides for the human needs of our people. Reagan Tax Cuts Criticized
The Administration has proposed a tax reduction that gives the most substantial relief to the very rich rather than to the middle class, and gives too little attention to the most urgent areas of need, which include the stimulation of investment and savings. In addition, the Administration plan is inflationary because it will stimulate demand before supply, creating enormous deficits in the process.
This program is based on the untested faith that more spendable income will, in time, lead to greater investment and savings without causing an unacceptable rise in inflation in the interim. We believe that this faith is the fiscal equivalent of faith in a free lunch. For these reasons, we firmly reject the Administration's Kemp-Roth plan, as we believe most Americans do.
In reducing taxes, we intend to abide by the following guidelies:
- Tax cuts should be coordinated with spending cuts so as not to increase the deficit.
- Individual tax reductions should be equitably distributed in accordance with the philosophy of a fair, progressive income tax system, with emphasis on helping middle-class Americans overcome the adverse effects of inflation and increased payroll taxes.
- Rather than relying entirely on the untargeted Kemp-Roth plan to increase personal savings, we must offer specific incentives to increase savings of all kinds.
- Tax laws must directly address the specific problems of American business, especially small and medium-sized businesses, through liberalized depreciation and specific incentives for research and technological innovation that will enable us to rejuvenate America's industrial base and make American products more competitive in world markets.
- Tax equity must be sought not only through general tax reduction but in correcting specific inequities, such as the marriage penalty. While controlling Federal spending, cutting taxes in a focused way and reducing the burden of Federal regulations will help, they will not, by themselves, achieve our ultimate goal of reducing inflation and maintaining steady economic growth and high employment. They will not correct inflation's underlying causes. Need for Cooperation Cited
Those underlying causes - our dependence on foreign energy, lagging technology in American industry, the adversarial relationship between business and labor, the escalating wage-price spiral and the failure to develop fully our human capital - must be addressed. We intend to do just that.
As a first step, we need to develop a new attitude of cooperation, among business, labor and government. Neither business nor labor nor government alone can solve the fundamental economic problems of the 1980's. Together we can get the job done.
We must not allow the rhetoric of the moment to create a new myth about government. We have learned that government does not have all the answers. Now we are being told that any government involvement is always a problem, and that the market will always allocate resources fairly and efficiently. That, too, is a myth. Private enterprise has been strengthened, rather than hindered, by government-aided research and development, development of basic transportation facilities and aid to small business, urban areas and farmers.
Virtually every other industrialized nation marshals its scarce economic resources by fostering a continuing dialogue among business, labor and government. It is time we, in America, unite to tackle the most difficult challenges of our future.
As part of building this partnership, we Democrats intend to work to shape a constructive role for government, working in concert with business and labor, in the following areas:
Energy. We must continue to focus on our energy problem. Simply, turning our energy future over to the major energy companies will not solve our energy problem. Rather, we must pursue a balanced policy, emphasizing production and conservation and the development of alternative fuels. And we must develop a modern transportation infrastructure to take full advantage of our energy resources, particularly that of coal. This will help strengthen the country's economy and will make an important contribution toward reducing world dependence on oil. Also, we must continue to develop water resources, especially for adequate and usable supplies of water. In the short term, we must be prepared to deal with the energy emergencies that may result from supply interruptions. Over time, we must work toward ending our dependence on foreign energy.
Technological Innovation. We must reverse the decline in the productivity growth rate. Technological innovation, generated by expenditures for research and development, is the most powerful force for increasing productivity. In recent years American businesses, often with eyes fixed on quarterly balance statements, have not invested in research to bring about the technological advancement necessary to keep our products competitive on world markets. We must increase our investment in research and development. Government must help by funding and encouraging research, just as it has done for decades in agriculture, where America is more productive than any other nation.
Labor-Management Relations. It is time to enter a new era of cooperation between labor and management. Both labor and management must understand that when American industry is not competitive they both suffer, and their suffering can only be reduced if they work together to increase our competitiveness. Government, too, must be involved. It must support managers who take risks to bring about technological change and explore new management techniques like worker democracy. And it must help workers adjust to technological progress so that they will benefit from and welcome technological change.
Incomes Policy. Our nation needs an incomes policy, a flexible set of methods for combating inflationary wage and price trends. The question of how to design and implement such a policy is highly controversial. That will involve the cooperation of government, labor and business. Built-in wage and price incrases affect today's inflation rate, and ameliorating the costs that they impose on the economy will help the nation gain control of price inflation. Those who suffer most from inflation are wage-earners and their families.
Investment in Human Capital. A productive, technologically advanced economy will not run by itself. It needs a healthy, well educated work force. America's greatest wealth is her people, and it is a renewable resource. Through effective education, job training and health and nutrition programs, we must insure that all Americans have the opportunity to become productive members of the work force. Business, labor and government, together, must invest in our precious human capital.
Interest Rates. Falling back on a policy of tight money and high interest rates to contain inflation will be unsuccessful. High interest rates increase the cost of borrowing and promote the wageprice spiral.
Strengthening the Economy. Reducing inflation without abandoning cirizens in need or neglecting those basic underpinnings of economic growth that government alone is capable of financing is not only critical to our domestic well-being, but is essential, too, if America is to continue to play a stabilizing role in the world. Improving our defense forces, in the face of a relentless Soviet buildup of its capabilities, is only one necessary step in assuring the defense of freedom. An American economy with steady, noninflationary growth is also necessary if higher defense expenditures are to be sustained and America's key role in world trade is to continue.
The Democratic Party has faced and surmounted a variety of challenges in the past 50 years. Depression, threats from abroad, inequities in our own country, all have required and received Democratic leadership and Democratic answers. The current challenge to the nation can be met as well. We are dedicated to meeting it in the same confident spirit that our leaders in the past met the tests of their day.
Illustration Photo of Rep. Thomas P. O'Neill

Economic Scene; Reagan Facing Car-Trade Issue

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]06 Mar 1981: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424070292?accountid=11752

Abstract: In a speech yesterday to the Conference Board, Kenneth W. Dam, provost of the University of Chicago, called for wider recognition that the United States could no longer be envisioned as a ''closed economy'' but had to be seen as an ''open economy'' in the making of all economic policies. He was calling for a fundamental shift of perspective as the basis for revising United States policies in areas ranging from fiscal and monetary policy to antitrust. Antitrust policy, with the avowed purpose of increasing competition domestically, could in fact weaken the competitiveness of United States industry in the world market. Since the 1940's and 1950's, he contended, American antitrust policy has been obsessed with concerns over concentration ratios and barriers to entry. Meanwhile, foreign companies are growing, and taking over shares of the market of even the largest American companies.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+Reagan+Facing+Car-Trade+Issue&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-03-06&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: ONE of the hottest issues facing the Reagan Administration is whether to impose import restraints against small, fuel-efficient Japanese cars. The major United States auto producers and the United Automobile Workers union, with the backing of Michigan political leaders, are pressing the Administration for such protection. But the Reagan Cabinet is split on the issue, and the President is still holding his cards close to his vest.
The auto import issue, so important in its own right, is even more crucial as the key to the entire Reagan effort to revitalize the American economy and strengthen its position in the world.
The concern of many economists is that, if the Reagan Administration takes the protectionist route in autos, it will open the door to similar demands by other industries losing ground in the domestic and world market.
In a speech yesterday to the Conference Board, Kenneth W. Dam, provost of the University of Chicago, called for wider recognition that the United States could no longer be envisioned as a ''closed economy'' but had to be seen as an ''open economy'' in the making of all economic policies. He was calling for a fundamental shift of perspective as the basis for revising United States policies in areas ranging from fiscal and monetary policy to antitrust.
Fiscal and monetary actions to stimulate demand, he suggested, had to take account of the international value of the dollar. A depreciating dollar resulting from excessive stimulation would aggravate inflation and set up a vicious cycle.
Antitrust policy, with the avowed purpose of increasing competition domestically, could in fact weaken the competitiveness of United States industry in the world market. Since the 1940's and 1950's, he contended, American antitrust policy has been obsessed with concerns over concentration ratios and barriers to entry. Meanwhile, foreign companies are growing, and taking over shares of the market of even the largest American companies.
The relevant market for many major industries, Mr. Dam said, is the world. General Motors, for example, had 28 percent of the world market for autos in 1978, and Ford had 19 percent, but their shares have been slipping as such companies as Volkswagen, Toyota, Nissan, Renault and Peugeot-Citroen have advanced. Chrysler was fifth in the world auto market in 1959 but had slipped to 15th place in 1978.
In chemicals, Du Pont dropped from first place in 1959 to fourth in 1979, and Union Carbide fell from second to seventh in the world market. In 1959, the United States accounted for seven of the top 10 chemical companies and in 1979 for only three.
Six of the top eight electronics and appliances companies in the world were American in 1959, but only three were in 1979. In steel, the United States accounted for nine of the ten top companies in 1959 but only two in 1979.
The explanations are complex, involving changes in productivity, exchange rates and comparative advantage. The United States, Mr. Dam said, still has a comparative advantage in agriculture, services and such specialized products as wide-bodied aircraft and computers, though he fears, he added, that its advantage is slipping. Antitrust, he maintained, does not recognize the new global environment in which United States companies must compete. Rather, it imposes impediments that make it difficult for them to manage their affairs in a way that reduces costs and increases productivity.
For openers, he would have the antitrust division of the Justice Department throw out its merger guidelines and start afresh with a merger policy based on the assumption that the relevant market is the world. The main effects of such a perspective, he asserted, would lie not in the area of horizontal mergers, which involve direct competitors, but in conglomerate and vertical mergers, where the merged companies are in different stages of production and therefore are not directly competitive. He argues that prohibitions against vertical mergers cannot be defended on economic grounds at all.
If companies cannot merge vertically to compete effectively in the world, he warned, the United States will either have to resort to protectionism in an effort to shore up less competitive American companies or accept a drop in the world market shares of American companies to the point where they will wind up being acquired by more powerful foreign competitors. He opposes import restraints because, he argued, they would only slow down the rationalization of United States companies.
Like Mr. Dam, the liberal traders in Mr. Reagan's camp are afraid that protectionism will ultimately not help but only hurt the effort to strengthen American industry in the world economy.
President Reagan cannot avoid the decision much longer as to whether he is going to be a free-trader or an old-style Republican protectionist. The supply-siders like to stress that President Hoover's major blunder was signing the Smoot-Hawley Tariff of 1929, which helped wreck the world and American economies.
If the Reagan choice is made in favor of protectionism, it will doubtless be billed as temporary and articulated in liberal-trade language. But this may not be enough to avoid exacerbating the danger to United States inflation, declining industrial efficiency and the threat of damage to the world trading mechanism.

PRIMARY FOREIGN AID SURVIVES IN BUDGET

Author: JUAN de ONIS, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]22 Feb 1981: A.9.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424048788?accountid=11752

Abstract: An A.I.D. statement on the new budget figures said that in the future, United States contributions to international institutions, such as the World Bank and regional development banks in Latin America, Africa and Asia, ''will depend on how efficiently United States funds are used and how well the institutions serve the interests of the United States and international economic community.'' The reduction from the Carter Administration request in the revised budget and the loss of purchasing power through inflation will require a review of direct aid programs in many developing countries, officials said. These programs in over 90 countries also depend on decisions in Congress on Mr. [Reagan]'s already trimmed foreign aid request.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=PRIMARY+FOREIGN+AID+SURVIVES+IN+BUDGET&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-02-22&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.9&amp;au=JUAN+de+ONIS%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The State Department has salvaged the essential parts of the United States foreign economic aid program from proposals by the White House Office of Management and Budget to cut the spending planned by the Carter Administration, but the program still faces an uphill fight in Congress, Government officials said today.
Officials of the United States Agency for International Development said that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., with the support of the Treasury Department, had obtained a level of direct economic aid higher than in the last year of the Carter Administration and a White House decision to honor all international commitments to international aid institutions negotiated by the former Administration.
For example, President Reagan's revised budget figures, sent to Congress this week with major cuts in many domestic programs, maintained a $3.2 billion pledge for the International Development Association, which is a World Bank affiliate that lends to the poorest developing countries.
David A. Stockman, the director of the budget and the architect of the Reagan Administration's cuts in spending, had proposed that United States halve its I.D.A. commitment, which was negotiated with other major donor countries as part of a $12 billion replenishment of funds for the agency. Contribution Spread Over 3 Years
The State Department and the Treasury joined forces to oppose this cut, which they regarded as a breach of an international commitment, and the full figure was kept but was spread over three years: $560 million this year, $850 million next year and $1.85 billion the next. American aid officials said the deferral of contributions would not significantly impair the agency's lending ability, although some discussions with other donors would be necessary.
An A.I.D. statement on the new budget figures said that in the future, United States contributions to international institutions, such as the World Bank and regional development banks in Latin America, Africa and Asia, ''will depend on how efficiently United States funds are used and how well the institutions serve the interests of the United States and international economic community.''
The revised budget authorization request for fiscal 1982, which begins Oct. 1, calls for $1.9 billion in direct American aid, which is less than the $2.3 billion requested in the Carter Administration's budget but higher than the $1.7 billion authorized by Congress for the current fiscal year.
The figures for direct assistance do not include economic support funds, which are part of the United States security program. They go mainly to Israel, Egypt, Morocco and other countries where United States military and political interests are involved. The revised figures for these programs have not been announced, but Israel has been told there will be no cuts, officials said.
The reduction from the Carter Administration request in the revised budget and the loss of purchasing power through inflation will require a review of direct aid programs in many developing countries, officials said. These programs in over 90 countries also depend on decisions in Congress on Mr. Reagan's already trimmed foreign aid request.
Budget cutting is now a dominant concern in Congress, and when programs close to home are being reduced, foreign aid is more vulnerable than it is in a time of expanding budgets.

Economic Scene; Reagan's Cuts Stir Skepticism

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]06 Feb 1981: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424065205?accountid=11752

Abstract: RONALD REAGAN has begun to use the Presidency as what he calls a ''bully pulpit,'' quoting Theodore Roosevelt. But Mr. Reagan faces a congregation full of skeptics and agnostics about his ability to stop inflation, cut Government spending, balance the budget and revitalize the economy. This would be a grave blow to the President and his supply-siders, who have based their program for revitalizing the economy, and eventually balancing the budget and stopping inflation, on the big tax-cut program. However, a majority of economists, including the ''mainstream'' conservatives in Mr. Reagan's camp, are nervous about worsening inflation by putting through Kemp-Roth on schedule and in its original dimensions. Under such an approach, Mr. [Robert V. Roosa] says, actual cash payments into the Treasury would not be reduced for taxpayers above the established minimum. They would instead become forced savers of the equivalent of the 10 percent cut, although he proposes that anyone could sell the notes in the marketplace. That way, there would still be no net cash drain on the Treasury, which would not have to repay or refinance the notes until long after the sequence of 10 percent cuts had been completed. By that time, if all goes well, Mr. Roosa says, ''the economy should have been stimulated to new heights, tax receipts should be booming and the burden of the tax cut would have been shifted forward to a more propitious time.'' The notes could also be made redeemable at a discount, like World War II savings bonds, before their date of maturity.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+Reagan%27s+Cuts+Stir+Skepticism&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-02-06&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: RONALD REAGAN has begun to use the Presidency as what he calls a ''bully pulpit,'' quoting Theodore Roosevelt. But Mr. Reagan faces a congregation full of skeptics and agnostics about his ability to stop inflation, cut Government spending, balance the budget and revitalize the economy.
The Economic Forum, a group of 11 leading economists regularly assembled by the Conference Board, a business research group, has just released its forecast that the gross national product will rise by 10.7 percent this year but that nearly the whole rise will result from inflation. Nearly half the members of the forum said they did not expect a balanced Federal budget, even by the fiscal year 1984, a year after Mr. Reagan's present target.
Doubts that the President can cut the budget much this year are widespread. James R. Capra, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, warns against the ''misconception'' that Federal spending can be cut or at least slowed soon. In an article in the just published winter edition of Quarterly Review of the New York Fed, he says that if the primary focus of the debate over the control of spending is the current fiscal year, the prospects for meaningful reductions in the fiscal years 1982 or 1983 are likely to be jeopardized, with near-term savings achieved through delays or traded for future program expansions.
Congress and the Administration may have to settle for a longerrange goal of offsetting the revenue losses from a tax cut by 1983, Mr. Capra says. He urges that the process of reconsidering basic legislation begin right away, no matter whether enough changes can be enacted to bring down Federal spending significantly in the current term. Otherwise, he fears, ''the chances for any spending cuts for 1982 may slip away and the opportunities for reducing spending growth in 1983 and beyond could be severely circumscribed.''
But it may be no easy matter for the Reagan Administration to swallow its earlier rhetoric about making prompt and deep cuts in Federal spending to offset proposed tax cuts. The conservative Republicans in Congress, after years of harassing the Democrats over past increases in the debt ceiling, are now threatening to refuse to support President Reagan's proposed $50 billion increase in the debt limit to $985 billion, which was passed by the House yesterday. The thumping of desks in Congress over the debt ceiling looks as much like a charade as ever, because the spending programs and tax bills that produce deficits have long been voted, but it keeps the heat on the Administration to try to shrink the deficit.
Mr. Reagan and his advisers are clearly loath to abandon their drive for enactment of the Kemp-Roth bill, introduced by Representative Jack Kemp of upstate New York and Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, calling for annual reductions of 10 percent in personal income taxes in the fiscal years 1981, 1982 and 1983, with individual income tax rates thereafter to be indexed to the rate of inflation. Nevertheless, if the Administration seriously intends to link spending cuts to tax cuts, as Mr. Reagan suggests, the tax bill may have to be long delayed and scaled down.
This would be a grave blow to the President and his supply-siders, who have based their program for revitalizing the economy, and eventually balancing the budget and stopping inflation, on the big tax-cut program. However, a majority of economists, including the ''mainstream'' conservatives in Mr. Reagan's camp, are nervous about worsening inflation by putting through Kemp-Roth on schedule and in its original dimensions.
Robert V. Roosa, a senior partner of Brown Brothers Harriman, who served as Under Secretary of the Treasury in the Kennedy Administration, has suggested a way of fulfilling President Reagan's promise of 10 percent tax cuts for each of the next three years without adding to the immediate cash deficit in the budget. He proposes that every taxpayer above a certain minimum income, such as $20,000, be required to receive his or her tax cut in the form of marketable Treasury notes bearing a market rate of interest and maturing in five to eight years.
Under such an approach, Mr. Roosa says, actual cash payments into the Treasury would not be reduced for taxpayers above the established minimum. They would instead become forced savers of the equivalent of the 10 percent cut, although he proposes that anyone could sell the notes in the marketplace. That way, there would still be no net cash drain on the Treasury, which would not have to repay or refinance the notes until long after the sequence of 10 percent cuts had been completed. By that time, if all goes well, Mr. Roosa says, ''the economy should have been stimulated to new heights, tax receipts should be booming and the burden of the tax cut would have been shifted forward to a more propitious time.'' The notes could also be made redeemable at a discount, like World War II savings bonds, before their date of maturity.
The supply-siders might or might not like this idea; it would drastically alter their desire to put more money in individual earners' pockets for saving or spending at the taxpayers' discretion. However, the plan to provide Treasury notes to taxpayers might increase incentives as much as cash payments, increase national savings, defer consumption, raise investment and militate against the inflationary effect of excessive tax cutting.

No I'm not concerned that there would be sabotage. I've met with Mr. [Paul Volcker], and not with the intention of trying to dictate; because it is an independent agency and I respect that. But I think that we have to face the fact that interest rates are not in themselves a cause of inflation - they're a consequence. And when you have, as we have had, double-digit inflation back-to-back for two solid years now - the last time that happened was in World War I. And when you have double-digit inflation there that way, there is no question that interest rates are going to have to go up and follow that inflation rate. And so the answer to the interest rates is going to be our program of reducing Government spending, tied to the reduction of the tax rates that we've spoken of, to bring down inflation; and you'll find that interest rates come down. The reason that we've got to tie taxes and we have to cut - tie spending together, is we, for all these decades, we've talked and we've talked about solving these problems and we've acted as if the two were separate. So one year we fight inflation, and then unemployment goes up. And then the next year we fight unemployment, and inflation goes up. It's time to keep the two together where they belong - and that's what we're going to do. Conservative Unhappiness
