Full text: Alan Riding is The New York Times's Mexico City bureau chief. By Alan Riding
On the southern edge of Mexico City -where the capital's grimy air is purified by nearby pine forests and, on most days, the distant, snow-capped Popocatepetl volcano is actually visible - a stunning glass and cement creation opened last October. Hundreds of thousands of Mexicans have since flocked to see it, to explore its passages, to gawk at its exhibits, even to contribute generously to its upkeep. For the Perisur, as it is called, is that most appropriate monument to the changes that sudden oil wealth has brought to Mexico: a shopping center.
Covering 52 acres, with four department stores, 154 shops, plus restaurants and banks and a parking area that is already too small, Perisur is, in fact, the largest shopping center in Latin America. Its counters are stocked with expensive imported products - from Japanese motorcycles to Polish glassware - that until recently few Mexicans could afford. ''It's amazing,'' said one shopper, the wife of a senior Government official, a few days after the grand opening. ''Soon people won't have to go to Houston for their shopping.''
Meanwhile, Antonio Juarez Soriano, a 29-year-old security guard, stood on the balcony of Perisur's elegant internal mall and watched the crowds below struggling with large packages in arms and children in tow. ''People are spending in a minute what I earn in a month,'' he said, with no apparent bitterness in his voice. ''But they're people with education. I only did two years at school.'' His own wage of $300 a month is being rapidly eroded by inflation - the rate hit 30 percent last year. ''We hear a lot about the oil on television,'' he said, ''but I can't afford new clothes or shoes for the family. You know, six of us live in one room. I must look for a better-paid job.''
Mexico has always been a nation of contrasts and contradictions, but never more than today. Within five years, the country's oil income has rocketed from $3 billion to $14 billion. Those oil dollars are being poured into industrial expansion, and the economy is growing an unprecedented 8 percent annually. Yet the nature of the boom, against a background of explosive population growth, is creating worrisome social and political tensions at home, while Mexico's new oil wealth has inspired a dramatic change in the nation's posture toward the world in general and the United States in particular.
Once an introspective and reluctant satellite of its neighbor to the north, Mexico has been transformed by oil into a burgeoning regional power, anxious to raise its voice on international affairs, quick to cross swords with Washington. The change was evident last month when Mexico unilaterally terminated fishing agreements with the United States. It was recognized by Ronald Reagan with his decision to hold preinauguration talks with President Jose Lopez Portillo. Indeed, Mexico's businessmen and officials are courted today wherever they go, and the nation's economic growth is the envy of a world struggling with recession.
Yet the self-confident Mexico seen strutting across the hemispheric stage contrasts sharply with the country's somber mood at home. Fortunes are being made, but hardship is spreading. Even business executives and senior Government officials - reveling in the fruits of record company profits, exorbitant salaries and endemic corruption - are beginning to get nervous. Having just joined the exclusive and influential club of major oil exporters, Mexico is already displaying some of the ill effects of sudden wealth and chaotic growth.
On Sept. 16, Independence Day, Miguel Jesus Solis traveled from nearby Toluca to the capital's main plaza to sell Mexican flags. ''What has happened to all the oil?'' the 29-year-old street vendor asked as he watched soldiers parade by in new uniforms. ''All I know is that prices go up and up. A liter of Coca-Cola costs six times as much as a liter of gasoline. At this rate, we'll finish up drinking gasoline.''
President Lopez Portillo, two-thirds of the way through his sixyear term, is sensitive to the paradox. ''It is universally recognized that the country's future is assured,'' he noted recently, ''yet it is here, within our country, that we are full of doubts about our future.'' The ''great opportunity'' offered by oil, he said grimly, is being threatened by ''destructive confrontation, disorder, inefficiency, lack of understanding, egotism and corruption.''
So far, the widespread social malaise has found no political expression beyond cynical resignation. But an influential politician has warned: ''We're living in one of the most dangerous periods of our history. We're growing wildly, but we don't seem to know where we are going.'' When Lopez Portillo took office in December 1976, he inherited the worst economic crisis in four decades. The peso was sinking fast, inflation was out of control, unemployment was rising, investment was at a standstill and the private sector was deeply disenchanted with the antibusiness rhetoric and populist reforms of his predecessor, President Luis Echeverria Alvarez. The only card Lopez Portillo had was oil, yet even that stirred little public confidence. There was widespread skepticism that Mexico indeed had such large stores of oil as Lopez Portillo believed, and the oil card would have to be played by Pemex, a state-owned monopoly with a widespread reputation for inefficiency and corruption. Lopez Portillo nevertheless held down wages, credit, imports and Government spending while pouring all available resources into the company. And Pemex did the job.
Specifically, Jorge Diaz Serrano did the job. It was in December 1976 that Diaz Serrano, an urbane 59-year-old engineer who had made a fortune as an oil contractor, took his first post in Government - as director general of Pemex. Unlike the company's previous management, he fervently believed that Mexico possessed vast oil reserves. And, within three weeks of taking office, he was able to announce an increase in Mexico's proven hydrocarbon reserves - Mexico combines crude oil and natural gas in its estimates - from 6.3 billion to 11.1 billion barrels. He also announced a $15 billion investment program intended almost to triple Mexico's production by 1982, to 2.24 million barrels a day.
Today, those figures look laughably conservative. Production has already reached the 2.4 million barrel mark; oil exports during 1980 earned Pemex about $10 billion. Proven reserves, some two-thirds of which are oil, now stand at 60.1 billion barrels, with total ''potential'' reserves of 250 billion barrels. If confirmed, these would place Mexico in the same category as Saudi Arabia.
When the dimension of Mexico's oil bonanza was recognized, officials began looking around the oil-exporting world for a model to guide their country's own development. But they saw only what they wanted to avoid. Venezuela, for example, woke up in the 1970's to find it had spent 50 years of oil earnings on imported food and luxury items and had built up all too little industry. Saudi Arabia spent huge sums on sophisticated armaments and foreign technology but was never able to become independent of the major multinational oil companies and Western technicians. And, most worrisome, Iran tried to modernize its socioeconomic structure so quickly that its rigid political system fell victim to cultural and religious rebellion.
Yet Lopez Portillo and his aides found cause for optimism in the fact that Mexico was different. It had already undergone a major social revolution,between 1910 and 1917, that had broken the entrenched power of the Roman Catholic Church and the rural aristocracy, and had installed a broad-based political system committed to improving the lot of the poor. As early as 1938, it had nationalized its oil industry and therefore had no need to invite in the oil majors. Further, its economy had grown rapidly since World War II, creating a firm industrial base on which an oil-financed expansion could build, guided by thousands of skilled bankers, entrepreneurs, economists and engineers.
All of which helps explain why the administration has been taken aback by how quickly the economy has fallen victim to the ills of sudden oil wealth - ''la petrolizacion,'' as the Mexicans call it. Last year, two-thirds of all export earnings came from oil, while nonoil exports stagnated. Investment was channeled into massive industrial projects while agriculture languished, and in 1980 the nation was forced to spend an unprecedented $2 billion on grain imports. Foreign-made luxury goods flooded the market to please elite consumers while the inflation rate rose almost 60 percent in a year.
Meanwhile, Pemex has been accumulating economic and political power. So influential has the organization become that Diaz Serrano is considered a possible - albeit unlikely - successor to Lopez Portillo. ''Pemex has become a state within a state,'' one leftist politician said. ''No one can control it. It does exactly as it pleases. It has so much money that it can buy anyone.''
Nowhere is the oil fever higher than on the offshore platforms in Campeche Sound in the Gulf of Mexico, some 50 miles north of Ciudad del Carmen. It was only a hunch that the major onshore reserves in southeast Mexico might extend to the continental shelf, but Pemex began drilling in the area in 1977 and was immediately lucky: Well after well proved commercially viable. (Even the disastrous oil spill of the summer of 1979, when the Ixtoc offshore well poured millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico for nine months, before being capped, revealed a new field containing 800 million barrels of oil.) Since June 1979, when crude began to flow through a 36-inchwide pipe to the coast, offshore production has risen to a million barrels a day. To Luciano Flores Plauchu, Pemex's local superintendent, it all seems like a dream. ''At the moment, we don't have the equipment to carry out new explorations,'' he said. ''Rather, we're just trying to define the limits of the 13 fields that we have already found.'' It is a public secret, though, that the oil-bearing geological structures are believed to extend all the way around the Yucatan Peninsula.
The Campeche wells are averaging a remarkable 30,000 barrels a day, but Pemex plans an entirely different approach for the Chicontepec deposits in northern Veracruz, where some 16,000 low-output wells are to be drilled over the next 13 years. Exploration is also under way in other areas, and commercial quantities of gas have been found offshore in the Pacific opposite the western state of Nayarit, and of oil onshore in nearby Jalisco state. Huge dry gas deposits have been struck in the Sabinas Valley near the United States border.
But oil wealth imposes its own development model, gobbling up an ever larger share of the federal budget. Exploration leads to exploitation and natural gas requires treatment plants and pipelines, and crude oil demands an expanded tanker fleet, new ports, pipelines, refineries and petrochemical complexes. In five years, Pemex's staff has jumped from 80,000 to 120,000, prompting the company to start construction of a 55-floor headquarters in Mexico City. And all of this expansion -Pemex's budget this year is more than $23 billion - has distorted economic growth.
Agriculture, probably the weakest sector of the economy, was the first area to go into crisis through neglect. The Government became alarmed, though, not when social conditions began to deteriorate because of the cutback in welfare spending, but when vast quantities of food had to be imported from the United States to supply urban areas. Facing the oil-for-food specter so common among oildeveloping countries, recognizing the absurdity of importing American food when Mexican farm laborers must go to the United States to find work, the Government has now pledged to make Mexico self-sufficient in basic grains by 1985.
Similarly, the transportion system, scarcely improved in decades, has come close to collapse under the pressure of food and machinery imports. The railroads, for example, are essentially those ridden by Pancho Villa and his rebel troops 65 years ago. The antiquated ports are the relic of a country that traditionally conducted two-thirds of its total foreign trade overland with the United States. Even the highways were built to bear perhaps one-fifth of today's traffic. Now the Government is trying to break through these bottlenecks with massive spending.
Primed by such expenditures, the economy has exploded into activity over the past three years, with the private sector rushing to catch up with demand - not only for consumer goods, but for machinery and raw materials as well. Imports soared from $5.8 billion in 1977 to around $20 billion last year. Just during 1980, total foreign investment, most of it American, rose by $1.4 billion dollars to $8.2 billion.
After the lean years for business under President Echeverria in the early 1970's, it is not surprising that Lopez Portillo's administration is applauded by the private sector. The Government has kept the lid on wages despite inflation. It has also provided business with generous fiscal incentives and increased subsidies for energy, raw materials and public utilities.
And big business has flourished as never before. Last year, the country's two largest private banks, Bancomer and Banamex, each with assets exceeding $10 billion, increased their profits by 66 percent and 71 percent, respectively. Many large corporations, such as the Alfa and Visa groups, have diversified their activities and grown into powerful, American-style conglomerates. Alfa's interests, for example, range from steelmaking to tourism; Visa's, from brewing to fishing.
Some economists, both inside and outside the Government, are worried that the advent of a business-oriented Administration in Washington under President Reagan will tighten the bonds between these Mexican groups and American-owned transnational corporations, thus weakening the state's control of the economy. ''The thought that Mexican big business, United States big business and Washington should have a commonality of interests is, to say the least, alarming,'' one left-leaning official said.
The real price of the boom, though, is a seriously overheated economy. To avoid ''financial indigestion,'' the Mexican Government has ordered a leveling-off of oil production when it reaches 2.7 million barrels a day sometime next year, but the surfeit of funds has already exacerbated inflation. The administration has nevertheless decided to live with inflation, arguing that the alternative - an economic slowdown - would be catastrophic for employment levels. In fact, officials argue that rapid growth and high Government spending should help create four million new jobs by 1982. And it believes that only by means of additional jobs - rather than welfare spending - will social conditions permanently improve for the poor. The Government is looking for a dramatic transformation of society, with an end to chronic unemployment, deep rural poverty and sprawling city slums by the year 2000. Most Mexicans, though, worry only about getting through today. The dimensions of Mexico's social crisis are intimidating. The country's population growth rate, though down from 3.5 percent in 1974 to 2.9 percent today, will raise the number of inhabitants from today's 70 million to at least 104 million by the year 2000. The distribution of the population is dangerously polarized between huge, unmanageable cities - Mexico City, soon to be the largest city in the world, already has 14 million residents - and some 95,000 remote communities. About 43 percent of all Mexicans are under the age of 14 years, placing enormous strains on educational and health services. In 1978, nine million Mexicans above the age of 15 had never attended school. Nationwide, 43 percent of all deaths involve children under the age of 5. Some 60 percent of the population is undernourished, with food intake per capita having fallen steadily over the past decade because of poor agricultural performances. Both urban and rural housing are sorely inadequate, with 69 percent of the population living in homes of just one or two rooms.
Last year, the Government began to channel some oil money toward Mexico's poorest 15 million people, at least half of them Indians living in remote areas. It created a special department to help those outside the money economy and beyond the normal reach of welfare agencies. By the end of 1982, it will have spent $4 billion on basic foods, drinking water and health services. Some 40 new rural medical clinics are already operating. ''It means the Indians now walk two or three hours instead of two or three days for treatment,'' explained Ignacio Leon Pacheco, who is in charge of assistance to the Tarahumaras Indians. ''I really think we're beginning to make progress.'' Dozens of Government grain warehouses have also been established, and they are beginning to break the power of unscrupulous middlemen who often charge the rural poor prices twice as high as in the cities.
The long-term answer to the peasant crisis, though, must lie in reducing the rural population. One ''escape valve,'' of course, is illegal emigration to the United States. Mexico estimates that between 450,000 and 1.4 million of its citizens work without proper documentation in the United States each year. But most peasants who leave the countryside prefer to move in with relatives already settled in Mexican cities. Even in the worst urban slums, with their open sewers and cardboard shacks, squatters can usually find temporary work, their children can attend school and, in emergencies, a doctor can be called. In the Santo Domingo slum of Mexico City, Mrs. Carmelita Gonzalez di Guevara said she preferred her two-room shack to village life in the state of Guanajuato. ''Things are difficult here, but they're worse in the pueblos,'' she said. ''My cousins have just arrived here because the drought spoiled their corn crop.''
In practice, half the labor force is under-employed - outright unemployment is only about 8 percent - and receives less than the legal minimum, either because workers are underpaid by employers or because they toil as carwashers and newspaper vendors or simply because they are kept busy only four months of the year, at harvest time. And even those Mexicans who are permanently employed have found their buying power shrinking. Jose Enrique Garcia, a 34-year-old office clerk who receives annual wage hikes and now earns $600 per month, complained that the rent on his two-bedroom apartment had just jumped by 70 percent. ''We feel the squeeze all the time,'' said this father of two. ''We don't eat out anymore. And forget about vacations: I work through mine to get paid extra.''
Against this background, the spending spree of the wealthy seems almost unreal. Statistics on income distribution can be deceptive, but the World Bank estimated that, in 1977, the top 20 percent of households received 57.7 percent of Mexico's income, while the bottom 20 percent received just 2.9 percent. The dramatic growth in demand for consumer goods -the Aurrera supermarket chain announced a 75 percent increase in profits during the third quarter of last year compared with the same period in 1979 - nevertheless suggests that new wealth is being accumulated, not only by top industrialists and bankers, but also by professionals, civil servants and skilled, unionized workers.
All over Mexico City, apartment and office buildings are going up and are often sold before the first earth is moved. In the affluent Bosques de las Lomas neighborhood, some 60 permits are issued each month for new homes costing an average $400,000 each - in cash, because mortgages, at 26 percent annual interest, are available only for cheaper houses. The demand for new cars is strong, even though locally made gas-guzzling Ford LTD's sell for almost $30,000 apiece.
The son of one prominent politician has gone beyond Fords; he collects Rolls-Royces, even though discretion prevents him from riding around in them. Some industrialists have added homes in New York or California or Padre Island, Tex., to their mansions in Mexico City, their rural haciendas and their villas by the beach - and, of course, they've bought executive jets to fly between them. Others have purchased $100,000 racing horses to improve their stables, or prefer to invest in paintings. One leading banker recently estimated that there are more than 200 Mexicans worth at least $100 million dollars. Mexicans are proud of the stability they have enjoyed for the past 60 years. The country's political system is an unusual mixture of authoritarianism and democracy. The President enjoys almost mystical power, personifying the nation as did the Aztec Emperor and Spanish Viceroy; yet, according to the Constitution, he must step down after six years in office. The Institutional Revolutionary Party (P.R.I.) has been in power without interruption since 1929, although six small parties are also represented in Congress. The system has undergone numerous crises and survived.
But now it is facing a new challenge, a widespread discontent to which the system has been unable to respond adequately. Because neither the P.R.I. nor the opposition parties, which include the Communists, enjoy much credibility, the simmering anger of many Mexicans takes no visible form. Yet it undeniably exists, particularly among the urban poor, who are more politicized than their peasant cousins, and among the middle classes, who are irritated by the conspicuous consumption of the wealthy and by the belief that much of the Government is corrupt. (The most common practice is for officials to be partners in companies that receive huge contracts from the Government -above all, for construction work in Mexico City and the oil regions.) The resentful silence of the majority has therefore become a greater political worry than the angry shouts of a few leftists. Recalling that both the 1910 revolution and the massive anti-Government protest movement in 1968 came without apparent warning, one P.R.I. Congressman noted worriedly: ''Nothing ever happens in Mexico - until it happens.''
Over the last four years, the politicians have lost ground to the technocrats who now dominate the administration. In part, this is attributable to President Lopez Portillo, himself a former finance minister who came to power with no strong political organization of his own. In part, it is a function of an economy in which Government spending accounts for almost half the gross domestic product. But the net result is that power is exercised by bright young planners with doctorates in economics from Harvard or the Sorbonne. Their authority depends entirely on that of the President, while politicians who have climbed through the ranks and are in touch with grass-roots sentiment have little voice.
In the present mood of uncertainty, then, political attention is increasingly focused on who will succeed President Lopez Portillo. Following tradition, the outgoing President can pick the P.R.I.'s candidate for the July 1982 elections, which, like his nine predecessors, he will win. No one knows what criteria will guide Lopez Portillo's choice. Until the candidate's ''destapamiento'' - or ''unhooding'' - next fall, a busy ''phantom'' campaign will continue as different aspirants jockey for position, trying to influence the outcome by showing their best face to the President. Most Mexicans are hardly aware of this struggle, and even the contenders themselves must publicly deny any interest in the succession, though politicians are already thinking of little else.
More than usual is at stake in the upcoming succession, but no one can know what policies the chosen successor will adopt until he takes office. For the first time in his political career, he will not be trying to please his immediate superior and he can at last ''unmask'' his true self.
Gradually, though, a consensus is emerging that the next President must give politicians a louder voice in determining economic policy. After all, the argument is increasingly heard, Mexico has always needed a strong Government in order to remain stable. And, in the past, it has been the politicians who have known when to be flexible, when to be populist - even when to be repressive - to insure the system's survival. Further, the fear is occasionally voiced that, unless the politicians provide clear leadership, the army will do so. The military has been skillfully kept out of politics by successive civilian administrations over the past 35 years, but under President Lopez Portillo, the Minister of Defense, Gen. Felix Galvan Lopez, has been unusually vocal, not only calling for modernization of the still small and ill-equipped armed forces, but also freely offering his opinion on a wide range of political issues.
The dominating challenge for the next administration, though, will be the effects and opportunities of Mexico's oil bounty. ''The differences between the rich and poor are becoming more acute,'' Heberto Castillo, leader of the small Mexican Workers Party, wrote recently. ''The people know that the rich include Government officials. No one believes that a senior Government official can be poor, while 70 percent of Mexicans, some 50 million people, live in conditions that become more precarious by the day.'' One Mexican analyst noted cynically that Mexicans do not suffer from unfulfilled expectations ''because they never expected to see any of the oil wealth.'' But surely they never expected oil to make them poorer. On the international stage, oil has given Mexico the confidence to raise its voice. This year, the country took a seat on the United Nations Security Council for the first time since 1946, while next June it expects to play host to an unprecedented ''North-South'' summit to be attended by the leaders of some 25 industrialized and developing nations. Just last month, Mexico unilaterally renounced all remaining fishing agreements with the United States, arguing, in the words of one official, that ''there is no reason to allow the United States to fish in our waters if there is no reciprocity.'' The reciprocity he apparently had in mind was the allocation to Mexico of a quota for catching squid off the New England coast. Washington has refused to grant the quota.
In its own back yard of the Caribbean basin, Mexico has begun to compete with the United States and Cuba for political leadership, criticizing Washington's support for El Salvador's civilian-military junta, challenging Cuba's erstwhile monopoly over revolutionary causes. Some officials in Washington have been angered by Mexico's political support for the leftist opposition groups trying to oust the United States-backed regime in El Salvador. Others have been upset by Mexico's warm ties with Cuba, failing to see them as an assertion of Mexico's independence from Washington. Mexico has also moved to prevent economic crises from fomenting political unrest by joining with Venezuela in a scheme to provide cheap oil to nine small nations of the region. And it has already rejected the idea, promoted by Ronald Reagan during the election campaign, of a North American common market comprising Mexico, Canada and the United States. Mexico sees the notion as an American gambit to obtain greater supplies of its oil.
This new independence has led to a series of small crises in bilateral relations, with Mexico seemingly ready to escalate minor differences into tests of national honor. Disputes over such issues as the price of Mexican natural-gas exports and a drought blamed on United States hurricane-chaser aircraft have turned into fiestas of Mexican nationalism. After the Ixtoc offshore-oil blowout damaged Texas beaches in 1979, Mexico angrily rejected charges that it was responsible for the accident and refused to pay compensation. Last fall, when President Lopez Portillo angered Washington by blocking the late Shah of Iran's return to exile in Mexico, he argued curtly that Mexico should not become embroiled ''in a conflict which is not ours.''
But Mexico's bravado abroad also reflects a heightened sense of insecurity, a fear that United States policy toward Mexico is motivated essentially by the need to gain access to Mexican oil - up to and including a takeover, as a last resort, of the Mexican oil fields. Its principal foreign-policy objective is therefore to convince Washington that Mexico is not the answer to its energy problem.
Mexico has decided neither to send to any single country more than 50 percent of its exports nor to supply any country with more than 20 percent of its oil imports. This policy was adopted, Foreign Minister Jorge Castaneda explained, ''not so much because of the risk that an excessive share of sales to the United States would increase our dependence, but because of the greater danger that the United States would become excessively dependent on Mexican oil.''
Not surprisingly, Washington has been frustrated by Mexico's policy and irritated by its general uppishness. A few United States officials have even talked of ''teaching Mexico a lesson,'' perhaps linking food sales to increased availability of Mexican oil, but calmer heads have prevailed. During the recent United States Presidential campaign, both candidates pledged to continue working for closer relations with Mexico, recognizing perhaps that the prime United States interest in Mexico is the preservation of political stability. Nothwithstanding Mexico's need to score occasional nationalist points against Washington, Mexico remains dependent on the United States -as a source of food, tourism and credit, as a natural market for its manufactured and agricultural products as well as energy exports, and as an escape valve for undocumented migrants. Its relations with Washington have always ultimately been dictated by pragmatism. Thus, for example, though Mexico follows the pricing policies of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, it has never joined the cartel, in large measure because doing so would have involved the loss of certain trading benefits with the United States.
This pragmatism was evident in Mexico's response to Ronald Reagan's victory last November. At first, officials reacted nervously to the prospect of a conservative, probusiness Administration in Washington. But, within weeks, they concluded that bilateral relations might even improve, with a President Reagan less likely than a Democratic President to curb illegal migration under pressure from organized labor. It is only over policy toward Central America, where the Reagan Administration is perceived as more prone than President Carter's to intervene, that Mexicans fear a clash with Washington. But even there, Lopez Portillo is clearly hopeful of persuading Reagan that a ''hands-off'' policy would be more prudent.
The peril to the United States, then, lies not in any excess of Mexican nationalism or independence, but rather in a mishandling of its oil wealth that could tumble the country into political chaos. A tightening of United States borders to Mexican products, large-scale deportation of illegal aliens and greater pressure on Mexico to increase its oil exports could all prove counterproductive for the United States. ''We cannot in the present situation take into account interests other than our own,'' Jorge Castaneda told an American audience last June, ''but the results will be beneficial to you and to us.'' Four years ago, Mexico's oil finds seemed like a miracle, but they have still to be proved a blessing.

CASTRO SAYS REAGAN FOREIGN POLICY WILL POSE A THREAT TO WORLD PEACE

Author: Thomas, Jo

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]18 Dec 1980: A.5.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424026126?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''If you give us the olive branch, we won't reject it,'' he told 1,800 cheering guests and delegates from around the world at the Second Communist Party Congress. But he also warned, ''If you continue the hostility and make aggression we will respond energetically.'' ''Those who go to kill people in Central America will have to be ready to die,'' he said, adding that ''no one is threatening the United States,'' but no onewill accept ''the threats of the United States against our lives.'' Mr. [Fidel Castro] attributed Mr. [Ronald Reagan]'s victory at the polls to inflation and unemployment in the United States ''in particular among blacks and young people'' and a ''feeling of frustration and skepticism among the people.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=CASTRO+SAYS+REAGAN+FOREIGN+POLICY+WILL+POSE+A+THREAT+TO+WORLD+PEACE&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1980-12-18&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.5&amp;au=Thomas%2C+Jo&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Special to The New York Times
Fidel Castro, the Cuban President, said today that he was ready to accept ''the olive branch'' from the United States, but expressed deep concern that Ronald Reagan's foreign policy as President would be a threat to Latin America and world peace.
''If you give us the olive branch, we won't reject it,'' he told 1,800 cheering guests and delegates from around the world at the Second Communist Party Congress. But he also warned, ''If you continue the hostility and make aggression we will respond energetically.''
He said that any military intervention by the United States in Central America could lead to a ''defeat greater than Vietnam'' for the United States.
''Those who go to kill people in Central America will have to be ready to die,'' he said, adding that ''no one is threatening the United States,'' but no onewill accept ''the threats of the United States against our lives.''
In a speech that began at 10 in the morning and continued until 10:15 P.M. with breaks for lunch and dinner, Mr. Castro, for the first time, reviewed Mr. Reagan's campaign pronouncements about a Western Hemisphere fraught with uncertainty and danger.
He reaffirmed Cuba's commitment to Communism and said Cuba was ready to work toward a ''reasonable and constructive agreement'' on Cuban emigration to the United States.
Mr. Castro warned that Cuba would authorize visas for Cubans to leave the country any way they could if progress was not made toward resolving several issues, including the reunion of families, and if the United States continued to follow what he described as a policy of stimulating illegal immigration.
''Mariel is not resolved, Mariel is simply suspended,'' he said. ''The United States created this problem. It is up to them to solve it.''
Mr. Castro said that Cuba has been trying to figure out Mr. Reagan's views on world affairs by examining the Republican platform, Mr. Reagan's speeches and statements by his advisers, but the Cuban President concluded that nobody knows what Mr. Reagan's plans are.
He ridiculed Mr. Reagan's avowed interest in more armaments for the United States and a buildup of armed forces as ''simply absurd'' and said it was a policy that could not be justified in the nuclear age.
After warning against military intervention elsewhere in Central America, Mr. Castro recalled that Mr. Reagan had talked about the possibility of a new blocade against Cuba, or the possibility that Cuba might be blockaded in retaliation against the Soviet Union. He called this view ''repugnant.''
His lengthly speech, given in the auditorium of the Palace of the Convention, was greeted with tremendous enthusiasm. There were standing ovations in response to his warnings and statements directed at the United States.
Wearing a dress army uniform of olive green, tie and white shirt rather than his customary fatigues, Mr. Castro spoke on a stage hung with a red curtain where protraits of Lenin, Marx, and Jose Marti, the George Washington, of the Cuban Revolution, were displayed.
He said that during the early months of the Carter Administration it looked as if some normalization of relations between the two countries might be possible, but then relations deteriorated.
Mr. Castro attributed Mr. Reagan's victory at the polls to inflation and unemployment in the United States ''in particular among blacks and young people'' and a ''feeling of frustration and skepticism among the people.''

People: Castro, Fidel Reagan, Ronald Wilson

Economic Scene; Arms Budget's Heavy Impact

Author: Eichner, Alfred S

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]15 Oct 1980: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/423991294?accountid=11752

Abstract: The United States, preoccupied by the military rivalry with the Soviet Union, may well have ignored the more important economic rivalry with its O.E.C.D. allies. One step among the many required to put the United States on an equal competitive footing may well be to insist that equal shares of G.N.P. be devoted to national defense among the O.E.C.D. countries. --------------------------------------------------------------------- Leonard Silk is on vacation. This is the first of two articles by Alfred Eichner, professor of economics at Livingston College of Rutgers University and director of the Center for Economic and Anthropogenic Research. It is hardly surprising, therefore, that if one looks at the record of economic growth of the countries in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, including the United States, one observes a strong inverse relationship between the portion of gross national product devoted to national defense and the growth rate over time. As can be seen from the accompanying table, the United States, which devotes by far the highest portion of its G.N.P. to defense spending, has one of the lowest growth rates among the O.E.C.D. countries. Conversely, Japan, with by far the lowest portion of its G.N.P. devoted to national defense, has the highest growth rate.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+Arms+Budget%27s+Heavy+Impact&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1980-10-15&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Eichner%2C+Alfred+S&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: WHEN the Presidential candidates' positions on national defense are examined, the focus invariably is on the balance of military power between the United States and the Soviet Union. The effect on the American economy is usually ignored.
By conventional wisdom, defense spending is a boon to the economy. Increased outlays for the military, especially on hardware, represent an addition to aggregate demand and therefore stimulate the economy, leading to higher levels of output and employment.
Indeed, there are many, both on the left and on the right, who believe that the postwar prosperity of the United States has been undergirded by high levels of spending on national defense. There is historical evidence to support this view: The recovery from the 1949 recession was clearly aided by the outbreak of hostilities in Korea a year later and the higher growth rates of the 1960's were achieved only after President Kennedy succeeded in persuading Congress that, in light of the Berlin crisis, defense spending should be increased by 50 percent.
From this perspective, then, President Carter's plans to increase defense spending by 3 percent in real terms should be seen as a boon to the economy. The President's military budget would, in fact, help to speed the recovery from the recession that the Carter Administration has produced as a palliative for inflation. And Governor Reagan's proposal to increase defense spending by 5 percent in real terms would be an even greater boon.
But this is to look at only one side - the demand side - of the effect that defense spending has on the economy. There is also a supply-side effect.
On the supply side, defense spending represents a diversion of resources from other uses. The same is true, of course, of spending on consumption goods and of spending on investment goods (new plant and equipment). But spending on consumption goods at least adds to the material well-being of those who obtain the goods. And spending on investment goods at least serves to increase the economy's capacity to produce other goods.
Spending on national defense does neither. It simply represents a diversion of resources from consumption and, especially, if economic growth is a major concern, from the investment required to achieve higher rates of economic growth.
It is hardly surprising, therefore, that if one looks at the record of economic growth of the countries in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, including the United States, one observes a strong inverse relationship between the portion of gross national product devoted to national defense and the growth rate over time. As can be seen from the accompanying table, the United States, which devotes by far the highest portion of its G.N.P. to defense spending, has one of the lowest growth rates among the O.E.C.D. countries. Conversely, Japan, with by far the lowest portion of its G.N.P. devoted to national defense, has the highest growth rate.
This is not to argue that the share of G.N.P. devoted to national defense is the only factor that need be taken into account in explaining the growth of different economies. Other factors are important, too, among them the extent to which an economy experiences cyclical fluctuations. Still, because of the supply-side effect, the importance of the share of G.N.P. devoted to defense should not be overlooked. History is replete with examples of countries that squandered economic opportunities by devoting too great a share of their resources to military ends.
History is also replete with examples of countries that, being unwilling or unable to make adequate provisions for defense, have been swallowed up by neighboring states. Obviously, in a world without an overriding police authority to assure peaceful relations among countries, some portion of the G.N.P. devoted to defense spending is unavoidable.
Still, the disparities shown in the accompanying table are striking. It is not immediately clear why the United States, which among the O.E.C.D. countries faces the least danger of actual invasion should need to devote so much larger a share of its G.N.P. to national defense.
One can, of course, argue that a need exists for the United States to serve as the world's policeman, in enforcing a Pax Americana. But it is not clear how relevant this argument remains when most other countries would reject any such role for this country. The argument is particularly suspect in light of the recent success of other O.E.C.D. countries, especially West Germany, France and Japan, in nearly matching - if not actually overtaking - the United States in per capita income.
The United States, preoccupied by the military rivalry with the Soviet Union, may well have ignored the more important economic rivalry with its O.E.C.D. allies. One step among the many required to put the United States on an equal competitive footing may well be to insist that equal shares of G.N.P. be devoted to national defense among the O.E.C.D. countries. --------------------------------------------------------------------- Leonard Silk is on vacation. This is the first of two articles by Alfred Eichner, professor of economics at Livingston College of Rutgers University and director of the Center for Economic and Anthropogenic Research.

THE SEVEN: ENERGY, TRADE AND FEAR OF A GLOBAL SLUMP

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]22 June 1980: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/423941376?accountid=11752

Abstract: Moreover, the disappointments of the last few years, as inflation and unemployment continued to edge steadily higher, have destroyed the belief that the governments can control the world economy. As the Canadian Deputy Prime Minister, Allan Maceachen, said recently, ''We just don't have much room for maneuver any more.'' ''Its a political summit as much as an economic one this time,'' said a member of the committee from the seven governments that prepared for the summit talks. The American downturn would have come sooner if Americans had not fought it off by spending their savings, thus encouraging manufacturers to go on investing. But now Americans are building up their savings again, uncovering what European economists like to call the ''concealed recession.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=THE+SEVEN%3A+ENERGY%2C+TRADE+AND+FEAR+OF+A+GLOBAL+SLUMP&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1980-06-22&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Canada, France and Great Britain
By PAUL LEWIS VENICE THE annual economic summit meeting of the seven major industrial democracies has a different atmosphere about it this year. Disarray among the allies on political issues is overshadowing economic dialogue, and there is also a sense that common economic problems have become so intractable that decisions made here won't help much to solve them.
The participants - the United States, Britain, Canada, France, Italy, West Germany and Japan - have already committed themselves to policies of restraint and slowed growth to fight inflation, which leaves little scope for brave new initiatives. The governments and their electorates appear to understand more clearly than in the past that there seems to be no painless escape from the combination of recession and inflation that higher oil prices impose.
Moreover, the disappointments of the last few years, as inflation and unemployment continued to edge steadily higher, have destroyed the belief that the governments can control the world economy. As the Canadian Deputy Prime Minister, Allan Maceachen, said recently, ''We just don't have much room for maneuver any more.''
The summit meeting, which is scheduled to get under way today at the island monastery of San Giorgio Maggiore, is eclipsed by differences over the Soviet Union's invasion of Afghanistan, the American hostages in Iran and the Palestinian issue.
''Its a political summit as much as an economic one this time,'' said a member of the committee from the seven governments that prepared for the summit talks.
Energy, which dominated the agenda of the Tokyo summit meeting last year, is no less of a dilemma this year, even though the decline of the American economy has eased some of the pressure on oil prices. The price increases continue, however, threatening the West with a perpetual recession.
In addition, the sharp rises of oil prices in 1979 and the smaller increases so far this year pose still another headache for the world's developing countries, whose ability to absorb more debt is in some cases already exhausted. At a meeting here of European leaders last weekend, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany warned that third-world bankruptcies next year could drag down the industrial economies.
Protectionism is likely to be an issue, too. Protectionist sympathies in the United States are the strongest they have been in a generation, partly because of the immense success of Japanese and German automobiles in the American market.
Here's how the conference's principal themes show up in the context of the participating economies: RECESSION in the United States, coming faster than expected, may reinforce the downturn developing in Europe and Japan, sending the major economies marching off into a synchronized slump such as in 1975. The risk is heightened by the danger that governments will overdo their inflation-fighting.
But the leaders President Carter plans to meet in Venice fear premature stimulation of the United States economy brought on by election-year pressures more than a protracted recession. A surrender in America's fight against inflation would most likely bring a rush out of the dollar that could tear the European Monetary System apart and invite OPEC to raise oil prices again.
Pressures for a tax cut and other forms of economic stimulation have increased with the report last week that the United States gross national product, according to preliminary Government estimates, plunged at an annual rate of 8.5 percent in the second quarter. That drop would be second only to the 9.1 percent plunge in the first quarter of 1975. Unemployment last month was 7.8 percent of the labor force. Inflation has improved, however. The Consumer Price Index increased at an annual rate of slightly over 11 percent in April, compared with an 18 percent rate in the first quarter.
What also worries European and Japanese leaders is the likelihood that protectionist pressures will intensify as the recession in the United States deepens. Western leaders have done a better job than many expected in preserving free trade in recent years. But the clamor in the United States for action against foreign steel and other imports now threatens to undo the work, just when recessionary forces are increasing in Europe and America and the world can least afford a trade war.
The rejection by Congress of Mr. Carter's proposed oil import fee, which was designed to conserve oil, is expected to damage Mr. Carter's credibility as a leader on energy. Mr. Carter wants the meeting to accept a strong statement on saving oil and developing coal and other alternative energy sources.
The American downturn would have come sooner if Americans had not fought it off by spending their savings, thus encouraging manufacturers to go on investing. But now Americans are building up their savings again, uncovering what European economists like to call the ''concealed recession.''
A 4.8 percent April fall in the index of leading indictors followed by a 2.1 percent decline in industrial production in May show the downturn will be more brutal than the Administration had expected. How long will it last? With housing starts and retail sales collapsing at record rates and corporations starting to cut back investment plans, a sizable downturn could be under way by Election Day.
ECONOMIC growth in Japan promises to be stronger than almost anywhere else in the industrial world this year, reaching 4.8 percent, according to the Government's own forecasts, or twice Europe's likely average and not far below the 6 percent rate Japan achieved in 1978 and 1979.
Inflation is high at nearly 10 percent but not calamitously so with wages expected to rise 7 percent this year and likely to pay for themselves through a matching increase in productivity.
Japan has shed its traditional large surplus of exports over imports as a result of rising oil prices and lower currency values, and is likely to run a deficit of some $12 billion this year.
Other countries fear that Japan may get back on the export trail too soon for international comfort, reducing its own deficit but adding to those of weaker countries. Merrill Lynch Economics Inc., in an international review, says an export-led recovery may develop later this year, or next year as the United States begins to pull out of its recession. The rapid decline in interest rates in the United States, it says, has taken the pressure off the yen as well as Japanese interest rates. Despite its recent strength, the yen is still 8 percent below its peak of last year.
An export-led recovery would be bad news for Detroit, which sees the flood of Japanese cars to the United States as a cause of some of its problems. The United Automobile Workers has been clamoring for Government relief from the imports and has sought commitments from the Japanese to build their cars in plants in the United States.
Japan's political problems are paramount at the moment. The nation is in a political vacuum after the unexpected death June 12 of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira of a heart attack. Elections were being held today to elect the upper and lower houses of Parliament, and a new Prime Minister won't be named until later.
Japan is being represented at Venice by Foreign Minister Saburo Okita and the Ministers of Finance and International Trade and Industry. They are not expected to make any forceful decisions on Japan's part. WEST GERMANY in recent weeks has seen a scaling down in forecasts for the economy's performance this year. At first the Bundesbank hoped for 4 percent growth, not far off last year's 4.5 percent performance. Now it sees 3 percent growth and the Government 2.5 percent. The latest business survey was starkly pessimistic with most industrialists forecasting sharply lower orders and reduced investment.
But while the Wagnerian gloom builds up, the Government has surrendered its traditional payments surplus under the impact of rising oil prices and weak export demand. This year Germany is likely to run a deficit of more than $14 billion.
The worry is that Germany will continue to fight inflation - at 5.7 percent still one of the lowest rates in the world - with tightmoney policies and an appreciating mark. This means increased pressure on everyone else to keep interest rates high and lower growth all around. Germany holds the key to a synchronized deep downturn the central bankers worry about.
Another fear haunts many European policy makers. Lower growth could help Germany export its way back into surplus in a year or so, as it did after the first big oil price explosion. But as the German deficit shrinks, the deficits of the developing world would swell, bringing new risks of bankruptcies, loan defaults and financial panic.
Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has asked President Carter to meet with him personally during the Venice meeting, apparently to avoid a public rift that could be developing over Mr. Schmidt's plans to visit Moscow June 30.
AFTER topping Europe last year with growth of 5 percent, Italy may lead the continent again in growth this year with a 3.5 percent rate of economic expansion.
Italy is turning in another strong performance in defiance of all the laws of economic gravity. Inflation is over 20 percent; the balance of payments is in deficit; Government spending is out of control; the Prime Minister faces impeachment; the central bank governor is under indictment - and the lira has unaccountably become one of Europe's strongest currencies.
''Our success often seems a little unbelievable, even to ourselves,'' comments Bruno Brovedani, chief economist at the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro.
As a country without oil or coal of its own and one that enjoys good relations with the Arab world, Italian officials say Prime Minister Francesco Cossiga will press the leaders at Venice to follow Europe's example and make a determined effort to open negotiations with OPEC on oil pricing.
WITH an anticipated growth rate of 2.5 per cent this year, France is also weathering current economic storms quite well, although it has no oil or other raw materials of its own. Activity is expected to slow later this year, but as yet there is no sign of a real recession developing.
Much of the credit belongs to Prime Minister Raymond Barre, who ended price controls and took other economic liberalization measures that have enabled French companies to turn in exceptionally good profits last year, helping underpin an investment boom the authorities hope will keep the economy strong through 1981.
International confidence in Mr. Barre's policies also helps explain why the franc has remained strong, despite rising inflation, which is expected to top 12 percent this year, and an anticipated payments deficit of around $5 billion.
President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, who faces elections next year, is acutely aware that the the increase in oil prices has destroyed France's much publicized plans to reduce both unemployment and inflation this year.
The country already has the most advanced and ambitious nuclear power program in the West, as well as one of the toughest oil conservation programs.
At Venice, no Western leader will be a more eloquent proponent of the view that energy is the key to Western recovery than President Giscard d'Estaing. He is also one of the most vocal critics of America's failure to curb its oil consumption faster and reduce the upward pressure on prices.
BRITAIN, like the United States, is a major weak spot in the Western economic picture this year. Growth is expected to be negative, with the economy contracting by around 2.5 percent. Unemployment is climbing steadily, inflation is unlikely to fall below 16 percent on average and the balance of payments will be about $1 billion in the red. This dismal performance is made more lamentable by the fact that Britain is self-sufficent in energy, thanks to its North Sea oil and gas fields. Britain's weakened economy can make little contribution to Western recovery for some time to come.
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is probably the strongest proponent among the seven Western leaders of the current economic orthodoxy that holds that conquering inflation, learning to use less energy and preserving free trade are the overwhelming priorities for Western economic policy makers at the moment.
Mrs. Thatcher and the Foreign Secretary, Lord Carrington, have warned repeatedly in recent weeks that the major threat to Western economies at the moment is the political one posed by the explosive Middle East situation and the danger of an interruption in oil supplies. At Venice, Mrs. Thatcher can be expected to argue that a Middle East peace settlement is of fundamental importance for the health of Western economies.
THE defeat of the Quebec separatists in last month's referendum in Canada has removed a major political uncertainty that had been hanging over the Canadian economy.
But it will not prevent Canada from being dragged down into whatever kind of a recession develops in the United States, which still takes over 70 percent of its exports.
Despite his liberal credentials, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau is following his other summit colleagues in putting all the emphasis on inflation-fighting in his economic policy these days.
At Venice, officials expect him to press the economic case for doing more to sustain third-world development as a way of keeping growth alive in the West.

People: Schmidt, Helmut

WEST GERMAN STATISTICS ON INFLATION IN DISPUTE

Author: Tagliabue, John

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]09 June 1980: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/423946414?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''Price stability exists in Germany only in the figures statisticians keep,'' according to a story in the mass circulation magazine ''Quick.'' ''The published inflation rate of 5.8 percent is simply wrong. In reality prices are rising at a rate more like 12 percent.'' ''Germany's inflation rate is not 6 percent, but much higher,'' the newspaper began, aping its opponents. ''False claims like that turn up whenever Germany's inflation rate is compared with that of the United States.'' ''In the German case, you're talking about pure statistics, in our case about a perspective, a prognosis,'' an American economist in Bonn said. ''The problem is, when Germans compare their figures with the American rate, they too often take the compounded rate, without noticing the difference.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=WEST+GERMAN+STATISTICS+ON+INFLATION+IN+DISPUTE&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1980-06-09&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=Tagliabue%2C+John&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Inflation, like beauty, is in the eye of the beholder. That is the conclusion of some West German economists who say that Germany's remarkably low inflation rate, a startling comparison with that of the United States, is in part cosmetic.
Using the same yardstick as the United States, and juggling the basket of consumer goods on which the country's consumer price index is based, they say West Germany's rate of inflation, rather than hovering at the modest 5 to 6 percent reported officially, might actually be a volatile 12 or 13 percent.
On the other side of this skirmish, which is being waged in popular magazines, weighty financial-page articles and banking newsletters, are economists and state statisticians, who defend both their yardsticks and their numbers, and say the United States is grossly exaggerating its price growth.
Specious Arguments
''Price stability exists in Germany only in the figures statisticians keep,'' according to a story in the mass circulation magazine ''Quick.'' ''The published inflation rate of 5.8 percent is simply wrong. In reality prices are rising at a rate more like 12 percent.''
On the other side, the respected Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung recently did battle in an article with what it inferred were specious arguments of the same sort.
''Germany's inflation rate is not 6 percent, but much higher,'' the newspaper began, aping its opponents. ''False claims like that turn up whenever Germany's inflation rate is compared with that of the United States.''
Part of the problem is that the price increases West German homemakers and consumer advocates register at the supermarket do not seem adequately reflected in the official inflation rate.
75% Rise in French Cheese
A recent study done by the consumer magazine ''DM'' pointed out that a three-pound loaf of bread their buyers bought in January cost 15 percent more in March. A package of imported French cheese cost 75 percent more, and the price of a can of soup was up almost 60 percent.
Those price increases may not be entirely typical for West Germany, but they have some economists wondering whether official statistics are more psychology than economics.
The psychology of inflation is extremely delicate in West Germany, where the legendary inflation of 1923 made postage stamps cost millions of marks, and a loaf of bread was paid for with bushels of worthless paper money. After World War II, galloping inflation again destroyed people's savings and made paupers of millionaires overnight.
Much of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's international reputation rests on his country's moderate inflation rate. For years he successfully resisted the appeals of European leaders that Germany be the locomotive of the European economy, because he feared rampant inflation that Germans would not accept.
Methods for Figuring C.P.I.
Partly at issue are the methods used in West Germany and the United States to reach the figures that trace the growth of the consumer price index, the figure governments and economists use to represent the level of prices people pay for goods.
The inflation rate commonly quoted in West Germany and in most European countries represents the percentage by which consumer prices increase in any month of the current year from the same month of the year earlier.
Thus, Germany's reported 6.1 percent inflation in the month of May meant that the country's consumer prices, as measured by the Federal statistics office, were 6.1 percent higher this year than in May 1979.
But economists note that the figure Germans usually cite to measure inflation in the United States is an animal of another species. It represents the rise in consumer prices in any month, compared with the preceding month, and compounded - as interest on savings would be - monthly for an entire year.
Pure Statistics
To give an example of what a difference this can make, economists point out that when the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics said in February that America's annual rate of increase in consumer prices was 18 percent, the West Germans reported a comparatively low inflation rate of 5.6 percent. Using the American yardstick for that month, however, Germany's annual rate would have been 14 percent.
''In the German case, you're talking about pure statistics, in our case about a perspective, a prognosis,'' an American economist in Bonn said. ''The problem is, when Germans compare their figures with the American rate, they too often take the compounded rate, without noticing the difference.''
Though German economists admit their monetary officials use annual rates as well as year-to-year comparisons, they say the compounded rate grossly exaggerates short-term trends and does not allow for sporadic price movements that may not be repeated in the year.
Problems With Compounding
''The compounded figure is a hypothesis, and in 90 percent of the cases it's not going to be accurate,'' said Friedrich Marx, a statistician at the Federal Bureau of Statistics in Wiesbaden.
American economists admit that the Germans are partly right. ''At the start of the year, inflation in the United States was high, but if prices begin to level off, then the compounded rate will have distorted things,'' an American accountant in Frankfurt said.
Some critics say part of the inflation rate difference is due to differences in the basket of goods used to determine the consumer price index. Unlike the Germans, for example, the Americans included the cost of mortgage financing in the housing cost column.
''Since the middle of 1979 this has been a major inflationary factor in the United States, because high interest rates have dragged mortgage costs up. If the Americans used our basket, the results would be lower,'' Mr. Stalf said.
Illustration CHART OF WEST GERMAN INFLATION
